HEADLINE: HERE NOW;
Irish Hospitality With a Splash of Show Business

BYLINE: By HAROLD GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
IT'S just after 11 P.M. at Scratcher, an Irish bar that one month ago insinuated itself onto a quiet, tree-lined strip in the East Village. On this Wednesday night, the 1,000-square-foot space, at 209 East Fifth Street, is packed with assorted downtown denizens, many of whom were passionate patrons of Sin-e, the Irish cafe on St. Marks Place that changed ownership a few months ago. In one corner, a dozen Irish regulars, all musicians, play fiddles and flutes while a woman sings a plangent folk dirge about love and death.
Scratcher's success is due in large part to Karl Geary, its long-tressed and fashionably tattooed 23-year-old co-owner. Mr. Geary, Sin-e's former manager, has become a minor star of sorts. Two summers ago, he was featured in Madonna's "Sex" video. "It was like being in bed with the whole Coca-Cola corporation," he says. And he will appear as Renfield in "Nadja," the David Lynch-produced vampire movie to be released in August, starring Elina Lowensohn. But his current passion is Scratcher. "Scratcher's what they called us people on the dole in Dublin, kind of my roots," Mr. Geary says. 
 The place itself is simple, with walls glazed in soothing umber and burnt sienna. For sale behind the bar are Tatos -- odiferous Irish cheddar-and-onion potato chips -- cans of Batchelor's baked beans and bags of Irish coffee. As he stands behind the bar pouring Guinness the careful Irish way, two women at the bar talk about Mr. Geary.
"O.K.," one says. "Karl. Scale of one to ten."
"Nine. Umm. No. Eight. Too naive for nine."
This conversation makes Mr. Geary uncomfortable. "The place isn't about me," he says. "It's about the people who come here."
At a table near the bar, Carolyn Adelman, a production assistant for Michael Moore's "TV Nation," seems to agree. "I'm in my element here," she says. She and some editors from HarperCollins are playing a word game. They stare into their beers as if such concentration will reveal the definition of "adipose."
At the bar, Adam Roth, the leader singer with Psychic Penguin, amuses two women with an Elvis Presley imitation. "This is Ireland," Mr. Roth says later. "It's more like a Galway bar, wide open, than a Dublin bar, which is nook filled and pub-y. And Karl is this enigma, an old soul trapped in a young body."
Whatever the bar's attraction, Mr. Geary has enjoyed the fabled luck of the Irish. He sits down, eats a Milky Way bar, pops two Advil, lights a Marlboro and says: "Spike Lee and his crew liked the place so much, they switched the wrap party for 'Girl 6' from the Bowery Bar. What a party it was. Beautiful women dancing. I had to hold back one of the bartenders from joining in." HAROLD GOLDBERG

GRAPHIC: Photo: Karl Geary, center, working at Scratcher, his new Irish bar in the East Village. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: After Assurances on California Jobs, Clinton Is Expected to Approve Base-Closing List

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
After agonizing for more than a week, President Clinton is expected to approve the recommendations of an independent commission on military bases, now that the Pentagon has been assured that it has the authority to keep thousands of jobs at a California Air Force base, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Clinton had been considering rejecting the commission's recommendation to close McClellan Air Force Base near Sacramento because the loss of the installation's 11,000 military and civilian jobs would hurt the economy of a large state crucial to his 1996 campaign hopes. 
 That prompted complaints from Republicans and some commission members that the White House was meddling in a process set up to insulate decisions about base closings from political influence.
A final decision has not been made but could come as early as Monday. In an exchange of letters late Saturday, the commission's chairman, Alan J. Dixon, a former Democratic Senator from Illinois, assured Deputy Defense Secretary John P. White that the panel's recommendations could allow the Pentagon to turn over all but about 800 jobs at McClellan to local private contractors. Pentagon lawyers had demanded written assurances that this was what the panel intended.
That may assuage the White House and let Mr. Clinton claim victory for California, but it carries a political price. Some commission members said that the Administration had hurt the integrity of the base-closing process by having Mr. White, the secretaries of the Air Force and Navy, and other Pentagon political appointees call panel members in the previous 48 hours to express concerns over the specific intent of the commission's recommendation on McClellan.
"That's why we're getting a little angry," said Joe Robles Jr., a retired Army general and member of the commission who received calls from Mr. White and a senior Army official. "It looks like they're just trying to score Brownie points with California."
Senior Administration aides denied playing politics with a process that had remained largely apolitical through three earlier rounds of base closings. They said they were just trying to clarify what the eight-member commission really meant to say on McClellan, since this is the last scheduled round of closings.
"I wanted to understand what each was thinking, and we have an obligation to talk to them," Mr. White said in a telephone interview.
But in none of the earlier rounds has an Administration hemmed and hawed so openly, for political reasons, over a panel's findings. In 1988 and 1991 President George Bush quickly endorsed the commission's work and sent it to Congress, which speedily approved the findings. The same was true in 1993, under President Clinton.
"This dithering has hurt the President more than anything," said a commission member, who spoke on condition of anonymity. California politicians are also upset, because they say that the assurances do not guarantee that the jobs will stay in the area.
By law Mr. Clinton has until July 15 to approve the commission's list or send it back with specific objections. If the President were to send it back, the panel would have until Aug. 15 to make any changes. At that point, Mr. Clinton would have to accept or reject the list in its entirety.
Mr. Clinton met for 90 minutes on Saturday with Defense Secretary William J. Perry, Mr. White, Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser.
Much of the meeting focused on how to keep McClellan's jobs in private hands after the base closed, a concept called "privatization in place." Mr. Clinton asked Pentagon officials to provide in the next few days more details on how this would work.
Also at issue was whether the commission's recommendation on McClellan allowed the Pentagon to award local contractors those jobs. Lawyers for the commission said it did. Pentagon lawyers wanted more specific language.
This disagreement prompted the phone calls from Pentagon officials to individual commissioners.
"As far as I'm concerned this was drafted as an open process and should be an open process," said Wendi Louise Steele, a commissioner. "If I were in their position, I wouldn't make those calls."
But other commission members said they saw no harm. Benjamin F. Montoya, a retired rear admiral who said he received calls from Mr. White and Secretary of the Navy John Dalton, said: "Secretary Dalton called and wanted to know what procedure I'd find acceptable. I don't think it was lobbying. He just wanted my views on the language."
J. B. Davis, a retired Air Force general who said he spoke to Mr. White and Secretary of the Air Force Sheila Widnall, said: "It doesn't upset me at all. They're just trying to measure something before they put it on the table."
But General Davis said that the White House had overreacted to the concerns of California's two Democratic Senators, Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein, before receiving the commission's recommendations on July 1. "Almost anything they do now appears political," he said.
In response to a letter from Mr. White, Mr. Dixon repeated in writing on Saturday what he had said publicly for weeks: that the commission's recommendation authorizes the Pentagon to transfer all work at McClellan, except about 800 communications jobs, to any other Defense Department depot "or to any private sector commercial activity, local or otherwise, including privatization in place."
The panel directed that the communications jobs go to the Tobyhanna Army Depot in Pennsylvania.
Mr. White said Mr. Dixon's letter and his conversations with other commission members satisfied the Pentagon's legal questions.

HEADLINE: Media;
TELEVISION: Smelling blood, Fox is taking quick aim at NBC's beleaguered 'Saturday Night Live.'

BYLINE: By Bill Carter 

 BODY:
NBC's "Saturday Night Live" has been written off as dead numerous times in its 20-year run, but only this year has the speculation been taken seriously enough for its competitors to consider trying to rub out the show permanently.
While ABC and CBS have both been developing late-night shows for Saturdays, Fox has already announced its plans: starting in October the network will offer its own Saturday night sketch-comedy show, "Mad TV." 
 The program will be Fox's return to late-night TV after three failures, most recently with the "Chevy Chase Show" in 1993. Executives of Fox told their affiliated station managers recently that its ambition to grow into a full-fledged network required expansion into the late-night arena.
But the stations have resisted another late-night Fox show on weeknights because that is when the stations make big profits with syndicated programs. For Fox to get a new chance in that area, it may have to first prove that it can make late-night programming work on Saturdays.
"Mad TV" will be produced in association with Mad magazine, which is owned by Time Warner Inc. The show will be a mix of dark humor, social commentary and movie satire. (The pilot features a long sketch called "Gump Fiction" that transforms Forrest Gump into a "Pulp Fiction"-style hired gun.)
Like its rival on NBC, "Mad TV" will feature young, mostly unknown actors. Unlike "Saturday Night Live," it won't be live and won't be broadcast from New York. Rather, it will taped earlier in the week in Los Angeles.
"Mad TV" also won't be on at 11:30 P.M.; instead, the network will try to get a jump on NBC by starting the show at 11. This reflects a continuing strategy in Fox's guerrilla war against the more established networks: find every possible advantage to go after the big network properties. If Fox could succeed in wresting coverage of the National Football League from CBS, the thinking goes, then why not take a run at "Saturday Night Live"?
And Fox has another advantage: Unlike the other networks' trying to grab some of the estimated $20 million to $30 million a year that "Saturday Night Live" brings in for NBC, Fox already has access to an hour of late-night time on Saturdays. ABC and CBS must recapture time from affiliated stations, which now fill that period with their own programs.
Fox's affiliates, however, have been broadcasting repeats of a Fox show, "Tales from the Crypt," at 11 on Saturday nights.
That show has done "reasonably well for us," said John Matoian, president of the Fox Entertainment Group, which oversees the network's programming. "We just decided it was time to be more aggressive on Saturdays."
One reason, he said, is the perceived vulnerability of "Saturday Night Live," which has been assailed by critics in the last two years as creatively bankrupt and in bad taste. But, Mr. Matoian added: "I'm not one of the people ready to write 'Saturday Night Live' off. It's still a formidable franchise. Lorne Michaels has fixed that show before."
Mr. Michaels, the creator and executive producer of "Saturday Night Live," has been all over the country recently auditioning new comedians to revive the show. A nearly all-new cast is expected in the fall.
But that cast will now face a similar program. The only concession that Mr. Matoian will make to NBC's incumbent status is, "We won't premiere the same week in October that they do."
Despite the obvious appeal of "Mad TV" to the younger viewers that Fox has always attracted, Mr. Matoian, who is in his mid-40's, is the first Fox programmer whose style seems more suited to putting shows on CBS than Fox.
In fact, Mr. Matoian did put shows on CBS, mostly movies, as head of the network's movie division for three years until joining Fox in 1994. Those movies generally appealed to viewers older than 40, while the Fox audience often needs to have three viewers in the same room for their combined age to reach 40.
Mr. Matoian acknowledged that "I certainly wasn't a watcher of this network." He was put off, he said, by Fox's penchant for shows that featured "sex for sex's sake."
Of course, those shows helped put Fox on the network map. But Rupert Murdoch, chairman of Fox and its parent, the News Corporation, has now set the network on a course to compete across the board, which means fewer raucous shows strictly for teen-agers.
To make the job easier, Mr. Murdoch has backed Mr. Matoian with the biggest financial commitment Fox has ever made to programming.
In the past, Fox put almost every pilot it made onto the air and never held any shows in reserve as backup series. Last spring, Mr. Matoian was able to commission 26 pilots, by far the most Fox has ever made, to find the eight new series that he will put on the air this fall. He was even able to put seven other shows into production as backups.
"Rupert went out and spent billions of dollars on football and improving our station lineup," Mr. Matoian said. "He also understands that to add value to that, the entertainment schedule has to also be upgraded."
Although Mr. Matoian declined to cite the amount, he said: "I have a much bigger budget to work with. We're upping the ante all over. I didn't set a figure. I just said, 'I need more original movies; I need more original series.' "
But before "Mad TV" or any other new Fox program can get on the air, the network must suffer through what so far has been a disastrous summer of plunging ratings. A week ago, Fox had a minuscule prime-time rating of 4.4, its lowest since January 1989. (Each rating point represents 954,000 homes.)
"The economics of saving on paying for extra original shows in the summer start to make no sense if you lose all your audience," Mr. Matoian said.

HEADLINE: Stolen Cars Find a World Of Welcome

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The glittering green Toyota 4-Runner sat in a lot at a port terminal here, surrounded by a sea of cars waiting to be shipped overseas. But something looked wrong.
The trunk lock was sealed crudely with a jagged piece of metal and four screws, suggesting a break-in. Jose Valentin, a Newark police detective, and his partner, Douglass Farrell, a United States Customs Service agent, sniffed around the car for more clues, prying open its hood, crouching to look up at its belly, pointing to spots where identification stickers had been peeled off. 
 After deciphering a manufacturer's coded engraving to learn the Toyota's true identification number, they made a call to headquarters. Reported stolen in Coney Island, Brooklyn, the $31,000 Toyota, mixed in with legitimate exports, had been on its way to Tallin, Estonia.
The nations that have emerged from the Soviet Union are a common destination for the flourishing traffic in stolen luxury cars and sport utility vehicles. A growing number of stolen Lexuses, Mercedes-Benzes, Jeep Grand Cherokees and Nissan Pathfinders are being shipped overseas, to nations where they can be impossible to buy legally.
Demand from China, Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union has pushed the number of stolen cars shipped overseas to as many as 375,000 a year -- of 1.5 million cars stolen annually in the United States, according to the National Insurance Crime Bureau, an organization financed by insurance companies to fight vehicle theft and fraud. The number sent overseas in 1990 was 200,000, said Ernest R. Zwicke, an agent with the bureau. The demand then was fueled chiefly by the drug trade in Latin America, which remains a major destination for stolen cars, he said. Less than a decade ago, there was barely a market.
The cars have a familiar snob appeal for the entrepreneurial class that has flourished under the political and economic liberalization in formerly Communist countries. "Foreign cars are prestigious -- certainly more so than a Lada," said one Moscow driver, Yevgeny V. Yurchenko, comparing them with the typical Russian car.
The flow of cars has also been hastened by the breakup of police states where borders were rigidly controlled, said Dennis J. Benjamin, manager for outbound enforcement in the Customs Service's Washington headquarters.
The unusual thing about the Toyota in the Port of Newark was how easily it was spotted. Detective Valentin recognized the car as a 1995 model, not a 1990, as the paperwork said, and knew that smugglers often age cars on paper to deflect attention. But only a small fraction of stolen cars are recovered by the Customs Service, which has a limited force of inspectors. The number of cars recovered has climbed modestly since 1992, but their value has skyrocketed. In 1992, agents intercepted 1,700 cars worth $6.8 million, or $4,000 each; in 1994, they stopped 2,300 cars worth $30.1 million, or $13,100 each.
Rings of immigrants are operating in many port cities: The Hong Kong gangs known as triads steal cars in Los Angeles for the market in China; a Polish gang in Chicago specializes in Eastern Europe; Latin American rings work out of Miami, Federal officials say.
But nowhere is the trend more pronounced than in the New York region, even though overall car theft is down in New York City. The region is "the national leader in sheer number of cars stolen," said Lieut. Robert Martin of the New York Police Department's Auto Crime Squad. "It has access to ports in New York City and New Jersey and it has a concentration of immigrants," he said.
In the last three years, enforcement agencies have cracked down on rings smuggling cars to points including Latin America, China, Russia, Ukraine, Poland, Nigeria and Ghana, Lieutenant Martin said.
In February, with the arrests of two charismatic Bronx auto-shop owners, Fernando Pena and Juan Ovalles, the authorities got an unusually good look into the worldwide black market for cars. The two headed an organization that stole more than 100 cars a month and resold them in the Dominican Republic, according to court documents, the F.B.I. and New York police officials.
The police trailed ring members for 15 months and arrested 29 of them. Mr. Pena, 52, had been arrested and convicted several times since 1971 on charges related to car theft, but he resurrected his business each time, becoming something of a legend in the industry and earning the nickname the Godfather. Mr. Ovalles, 44, was less experienced, but his reputation was equally secure among associates who called him Juan Chapa -- "chapa" being Spanish slang for a counterfeit vehicle identification plate. Their trial is set for the fall.
Together, the two had 30 years in auto theft, said Arthur Grubert, assistant special agent in charge of the criminal division at the F.B.I.'s New York office. But it was not until around 1990 that they dipped into the new and highly lucrative export business. F.B.I. officials said the ringleaders bribed Dominican customs officials for the certificates of origin of cars that had been imported legally into the Dominican Republic. With the certificates in their hands, the ringleaders dispatched thieves to steal vehicles of matching make and model, usually Mitsubishi Monteros, Toyota Land Cruisers and other four-wheel-drive vehicles popular in Latin America. The cars were retagged with fake identification plates. Some were sold through dishonest dealerships in New Jersey, but most were stuffed into oceangoing containers and shipped out of Newark or Miami.
"Sometimes this happened as quick as two days," one F.B.I. agent said. "The car was on its way to the D.R. even before the owner realized it was stolen."
The cars found their way to the showrooms of two Santo Domingo dealerships, whose owners -- relatives or friends of the Bronx men -- have also been charged. Sometimes, however, the demand for Monteros or Land Cruisers was so heavy that the vehicles were shipped to Santo Domingo without any final destination. Word of a shipment spread quickly, and dealers gathered at the port to bid on the cars.
The economics of smuggling luxury cars are clear to anyone who wants to import -- legally -- a Lexus LS400 to China. Toyota does not sell Lexuses in China, a nation with tariffs that would put a price of between $120,000 and $125,000 on an LS400 that costs $52,000 here, said Carnie Colliver of Auto Pacific Group, a consulting firm in Santa Ana, Calif.
By contrast, a Lexus can be bought cheaply and quickly on the black market. A smuggler could pay several hundred dollars to the street-level thief, a few thousand to ship the Lexus to Hong Kong and maybe more to bribe customs officials to clear it into China. Even if the ring sold the car in China for as little as $60,000, it would pocket a profit of as much as $50,000. The popularity of the Lexus in China has kept gangs in the United States and Hong Kong busy and given rise to a booming black market in spare parts.
While China and Russia may not yet have an American-style middle-class of consumers, the emergence of a sizable monied class has produced strange car-buying habits: The Lexus and Mercedes have leapfrogged the Ford Taurus and Honda Accord.
The cars stolen in the United States increasingly reflect the demand overseas, said Kim Hazelbaker, senior vice president of the Highway Loss Data Institute. Of the top 10 cars with the highest risk of being stolen in 1994, four were sport utility vehicles and four were luxury cars. Just three years ago, the most popular were still sports cars taken on joy rides or older models stolen for parts.
The problem begins at the nation's ports, where enforcement lies primarily in the hands of the U.S. Customs Service, which has 6,500 inspectors nationwide but only about 230 assigned specifically to monitor exports.
Smugglers typically contact a shipping company that supplies steel containers, usually 40 feet long, 10 feet wide and 10 feet high. As many as three cars are stuffed inside, sometimes hidden behind trapdoors and surrounded by furniture and garbage. The smugglers report thecontents to the shipping company, omitting, of course, the cars. The company simply hands customs officials a manifest of the cargo.
"You'll go to East New York, Brooklyn," Mr. Farrell, the customs agent in Newark, said, "and on a deserted block, you'll see four ocean-going containers. Why?"
At the port, customs inspectors open a container only if they have received a tip, or if the destination and paperwork look suspicious, said James A. Sullivan, a customs officials who supervises the two-year-old Vehicle Enforcement Team in Newark. Random checks are seldom made of the 1.5 million containers a year leaving the nation's second-busiest port. "To search thoroughly one 40-foot container will take four or five guys eight hours," he said.
To detect smuggled cars, the Customs Service is testing a giant X-ray machine in a port near San Diego. For their part, auto makers, concerned that rising insurance rates will dissuade drivers from buying certain models, are making it harder to alter their identification markers. But law enforcement officials agree that to curb illegal exports, they must address the problem overseas. Agents from the National Insurance Crime Bureau are in Europe -- especially in Poland and the Baltics, which are transfer points -- to train local customs officials to identify stolen cars from the United States. Robert M. Perito, the director of the Office of International Criminal Justice in the State Department, said the United States and the Central American nations are close to signing treaties that will make it easier to return stolen cars.
Joe Pierron, the international director for the insurance crime bureau, said that even with the treaties, recovering a stolen car will be laborious and costly. But in the long run, enough recoveries might dampen the demand overseas.
"The buyers over there must face the risk of losing their stolen cars," he said. "Now they don't."

HEADLINE: TV News Crossing Old Lines On Jobs

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
It was Friday night, the start of the Fourth of July holiday weekend, when Jerry Nachman, vice president of news at WCBS-TV (Channel 2) in New York, got a phone call at home telling him three things: that Elizabeth Holtzman, the former New York City Comptroller, had been mugged at an automatic teller machine in Manhattan, that two city firefighters had helped to catch the culprit and that Channel 2 had no reporter available to cover the story.
Mr. Nachman, a newsman for 25 years, dashed downstairs to a news van at his front door, got to the scene, interviewed Ms. Holzman and the firefighters, and reported it all live on the 11 o'clock Channel 2 news. 
 Inadvertently, Mr. Nachman thus added his own peculiar hybrid to the growing ranks of what is known in the television business as "hyphenates." Mr. Nachman's hyphenated position that night was "vice president-reporter," which may be a first.
But further down in the ranks, more and more categories are being melded into new combinations in television newsrooms, creating such hyphenates as director-technical director or writer-producer, or even triple titles like cameraman-reporter-editor. And union lines are being crossed as never before.
"What's happening now would have been unthinkable some years ago," Mr. Nachman said, "because unions were so jurisdictional and companies were so stratified. But for reasons ranging from downsizing by companies to enlightened self-interest by unions, we're getting some new combinations."
In the last half-dozen years, television news organizations' desires to cut costs and their unions' desires to remain relevant have combined with the increasing sophistication of video technology to accelerate the trend toward combining jobs.
In the early days of television, not only were cameras hefty and awkward, but separate equipment was required for lighting and sound, the responsibility of separate technicians. Now, separate sound and lighting technicians are rarely used on spot-news assignments. And less technical expertise is needed to use equipment in the studio.
"Cameras alone cost $50,000 or $60,000 as recently as 5 or 10 years ago," said David Bartlett, president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association. "Now, you can buy these 8-millimeter cameras for $10,000 or less, and you or I can't tell the difference in picture quality. If they can put five cameras on the street intead of one, they can multiply the number of stories they can cover. And you don't need highly trained technicians to ride herd on that $50,000 camera, either."
Reporters have carried cameras and directors have doubled as writers and producers for a long time in smaller cities, and in nonunion organizations like New York 1 News, the all-news cable channel owned by Time Warner Inc., in New York City.
But at the networks and the big-city stations, such crossovers have been slower to occur, largely because of union rules. At ABC and NBC, most technicians are represented by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, known as NABET. At CBS, most belong to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, or I.B.E.W., which, several people in the industry say, has been the most flexible union in pioneering the boundary-crossing job categories.
The electrical workers began negotiating with CBS in the mid-1980's on how to reconcile management's desire for more flexibility with unions' desire to protect jobs. The compromise they eventually worked out -- its details have often been amended in recent contracts -- permits an individual to work across union lines so long as the individual is a dues-paying member of all the unions involved.
For example, one person can now do a job that used to need two people: a director (or associate director), which is a category from the Director's Guild of America union, and a technical director, a category from the I.B.E.W. or NABET.
"Instead of the director calling out 'take three' to the T.D., and the T.D. pushing the button for camera No. 3, one guy just pushes button 3 himself," said Tom Bradford, executive producer of "CBS Up To the Minute," the network's overnight news program.
Now three years old, the program has served as a laboratory for some of these cross-union experiments. "Our show had to be compact, in terms of manpower and budget, and the unions have been very cooperative," Mr. Bradford said. "Our producers write copy and physically cut and edit videotape. We can have late tape come in from a news agency, and we can assemble a news report fast, using a writer-producer-editor if need be."
He said some of the staff members had come from local stations elsewhere in the country and were accustomed to doing several jobs.
Conversely, Mr. Nachman said, "a lot of people from big stations in places like New York got so specialized they only knew the work that spanned their own two arms, and when they wanted to change their lives and move to some place like Portland or Albuquerque, they found they were unemployable."
The networks have generally been slower than local stations at melding job categories, with the exception of their foreign staffing.
"In Europe, if a five-person crew covers a story for five days, the cost for hotel rooms, air fare and baggage for all their equipment can add up to $25,000 or $30,000 for that assignment," said John Stack, foreign news editor for NBC News. "If you can send three people, it's that much less costly.
"And safety is a concern in war zones. In Bosnia, for example, we'll send a cameraman-editor, a correspondent and a producer. They can get around more quickly; they can split up if need be."
Mr. Stack said the "multi-skilled technician and editorial person is certainly the electronic journalist of the future."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Melding of job categories in television news means that some employees are members of two unions. Jack Rosen, associate director and technical supervisor at CBS, belongs to the Director's Guild and the I.B.E.W. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay;
Honoring Repression

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At a convocation this fall, Williams College in Massachusetts will confer full academic honors on its alumnus Goh Chok Tong, Prime Minister of Singapore.
In that dictatorship (where chewing gum gets you a $1,000 fine and sharing a marijuana cigarette invites the death penalty) students are prohibited from waving political banners. 
 "If you allow students to do so," Mr. Goh has said, "then workers will begin to do so over the slightest grievance, and if you have several such demonstrations, right away the impression is created the government is not in control of the situation -- that the place may become unstable, and that will have an impact on foreign investors."
Some Williams faculty, sensitive to what philosophy professor Sam Fleischacker calls "the irony of offering the leader of the world's foremost opponent of academic freedom an academic honor," protested to the college's president, Harry C. Payne.
Mr. Payne replied that Mr. Goh -- who seized a three-year-old invitation -- "embodies the mission and hope" of Singapore, adding lamely "the tendering of a degree is not intended to honor every aspect of a person, a government, or a set of ideas."
"The event will be used as a powerful symbolic tool in Singapore," responded Mr. Fleischacker, "to show that no matter how flagrantly Singapore's government violates basic political rights, its 'success' will still win it acceptance and indeed honor with the Western nations. Williams' action will help vindicate the International Herald Tribune's regular caving-in to Singapore's judicial blackmail. . . ."
Now there's a comment that tromps on journalism's tenderest corns. When an American academic, Christopher Lingle, dared to suggest in an I.H.T. article that "dynastic politics" played a part in governing some Asian nations, Singapore's dictator, Lee Kuan Yew, assumed that the shoe fit him. He brought a libel suit before his hand-picked judges to humiliate the American newspaper.
On the advice of local counsel all too cozy with the ruling party, The Trib apologized. This only whetted the appetite of the dictator and his front man, Mr. Goh, who is warming the prime minister's seat until Lee's son, the dauphin, can take over.
In a Singapore courtroom two weeks ago, Goh denied being "a stooge for Prime Minister Lee" but then let the cat out of the dynastic bag: Such press criticism, said Goh, "simply destroys what we have set out to do, and that is to have a smooth transfer of power to the next generation."
Dictator Lee's testimony, though sometimes Queeg-like in his fear of criticism, was shrewder than his front man's. The dictator tried to drive a wedge between The Trib's owners: "There are two parties in The I.H.T.; one is The Washington Post and the other is The New York Times. My relations with The Washington Post have always been more equable. They are less of aggressive crusaders against me . . . so there are two parts to this and one is The New York Times [that] William Safire is on."
Thanks, but The Post is not the pushover the dictator suggests. Nor did Dow Jones, when its Far East Economic Review was "bleeding" because of Lee's advertising and circulation restrictions, fire an editor to placate the regime, as Lee intimated. (The dictator concluded by praising The Trib's counsel, "who knows me very well," and who did not presume to cross-examine.)
Despite oleaginous pretensions about a new Asian culture that transcends human rights, Lee, Goh and the dauphin represent old-fashioned European totalitarianism.
Should Williams College rescind its invitation, as "No Goh" faculty urge? Quite the contrary; let's hear his anti-freedom pitch. But a Williams political scientist (George.T.Crane@williams.edu) is organizing a serious, educational counter-award ceremony.
Christopher Lingle, out of reach of corrupt judges' crippling fines and canes, has agreed to come; so has Francis Seow, former Solicitor General who was imprisoned for his dissent, "softly tortured" by Lee's thugs and exiled to Harvard.
The college president is resisting the simultaneous appearance of the opposition; perhaps Williams alumni and trustees will reason with him.
If Goh has guts, he'll agree to a panel debate. And if The Singapore Straits wants to run today's essay under "Safire Snipes Again," as the lap-dog sheet has done before -- it's free.

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY;
A Long Day's Journey Into the Off Season

BYLINE: By Joe Lapointe 

DATELINE: EDMONTON, Alberta

 BODY:
Here in the National Hockey League's northernmost outpost, the summer sky disorients a visitor's body clock. The sun doesn't set until after 10 P.M., the dusk lingers long after that and the dawn breaks a few hours later.
This surreal setting was appropriate for the symbolic conclusion of the winter game's longest season. This was the site of the Entry Draft, Trade Fair and Gossip Flea Market on Saturday at Northlands Coliseum. 
 During the 15-week lockout of autumn and winter, it seemed as if the games would never begin. During the playoffs of spring and summer, it seemed as if they would never end.
Finally, it's all over except for the wheeling and dealing, and the sun never sets on that sort of thing. Much of it will involve unrestricted free agents who haven't already been scooped up by Mike Keenan's St. Louis Blues.
He has lured Dale Hawerchuk from Buffalo, is close to obtaining Geoff Courtnall from Vancouver and he's not finished.
"We are pretty assertive in our approach," said Keenan, the general manager and coach. "It's an avenue provided by the new collective bargaining agreement. We'll try to utilize it to our advantage."
Keenan alone could save the league from collusion allegations, but it won't please Neil Smith, the president and general manager of the Rangers. Smith, Keenan's boss until their bitter parting of last summer, complained about Keenan's free spending for free agents.
"If you show up five minutes after the store opens, they're in a Blues' uniform," Smith said.
No doubt this gripe will amuse rival general managers who grumbled that Smith and the Rangers bought themselves a 1994 Stanley Cup with their liberal spending policies of the early 1990's.
But much has changed at Madison Square Garden, where David Checketts has risen from the basketball side to supervise the whole operation. How will his monetary policies affect Neil the Deal as he tries to pry Teemu Selanne and Keith Tkachuk from the Winnipeg Jets?
Both are Group 2 free agents, meaning the Jets retain the right to either match salary offers or accept draft choices in compensation. Both are among the elite forwards in the business.
Selanne, 25, is a right wing from Finland; Tkachuk, 23, is a left wing from Massachusetts. To avoid compensation, Smith has been trying to trade for their rights. He said a team has to inquire about "10 or 15" Group 2 free agents "to have a chance at even one of them."
Others in this category include Shayne Corson of Edmonton and Pat Verbeek of the Rangers. A big bid for Verbeek by Keenan would certainly affect Smith's payroll, wouldn't it? Relax; both are more likely to compete for unrestricted free agents like Brian Noonan from the Rangers, Joel Otto from Calgary and Bob Bassen from Denver.
In the meantime, Smith has another important contract to consider: his own. With two seasons left on the current pact, he remains disillusioned that it wasn't rewritten after the cup championship.
Those who know him also note the absence of the "Ranger for Life" testimonials that Smith was known for in the early 1990's, when hockey buff Stanley Jaffe was his boss. One can only wonder how far President of the Rangers ranks below Coach of the Knicks at Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.
Smith isn't the only local executive needing a real vote of confidence. Don Maloney, going into the last season of his contract as general manager of the Islanders, said his status "is something we'll have to address."
"I don't want it to become a distraction," said Maloney.
Rest assured it will be, as long as Mike Milbury, the new coach with front-office ambitions, has a longer contract. Despite the signing of Todd Bertuzzi, the forward originally drafted in the first round in 1993, and the drafting of defenseman Wade Redden, Maloney has numerous holes to fill on his roster.
His franchise, a dynasty a little more than a decade ago, is the only one of the three in the New York area that hasn't won the cup recently. Both he and Milbury are strong-willed former players of the same generation. A new deal for Maloney might insure that the positive creative tension between them isn't replaced by destructive political maneuvering.
As for the Devils, the current champs, their visit here was a victory tour. Coach Jacques Lemaire might have a sore hand and back from all the shaking and patting. In repose, his round face sometimes looks like that of the man in the moon. The smile that stayed on in all weekend was as big and bright as the Alberta sky.
His boss, Lou Lamoriello, said there has been "progress" in the "positive" negotiations to remain at Byrne Arena and avoid a move to Nashville. That's as close to a leak as Lamoriello will ever get.
Speaking of leaks, politics and chief executives, Lamoriello's Devils will visit President Clinton today at the White House. Unlike the Rangers, who showed up late for their Rose Garden fete, the Devils will probably arrive on time for their day in the sun. With the season so out of sync, it's about time for these hockey guys to get back on schedule.

HEADLINE: After Strong Rise, Japan Stocks Level Off

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, July 10

 BODY:
Japanese stocks closed today only slightly higher after initially extending last week's strong advance in the morning session.
At the close, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 29.58 points, or about two-tenths of 1 percent, to stand at 16,242.66. At the morning break, the Nikkei had risen 332.09 points, or more than 2 percent, on optimism that lower interest rates and a weaker dollar would revitalize Japan's economy. 
 That followed Friday's performance, when the market dazzled analysts, with stocks surging 956.19 points, or nearly 6.3 percent, after interest-rate cuts on successive days by the United States' Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan.
"The new dynamic is the fact that it looks like the discount rate may go lower and finally the yen is softening," Louis Tseng, managing director of equity derivative products at Lehman Brothers Japan, said early in the day.
The dollar was trading around 87 yen in Asian markets, little changed from New York levels late on Friday, but about one yen above where it had traded over the last month.
"We expect the momentum to carry forward," Dhia Amir, an equity trader at Nomura Securities here, said early in the day. But the trader warned that concerns about the economy and approaching elections for the upper house of the Japanese Parliament could cut short the rally.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 429 words

HEADLINE: Health Care Report Cards

 BODY:
Health care reform received a potential boost earlier this month at a meeting in Wyoming of large private and public employers. They created a foundation to spur health plans to provide consumers with information that can help determine which plans provide the best treatment.
Participants in the Wyoming meeting vowed to use their collective influence -- together, they employ 80 million workers -- to force health plans to report data that would show which programs provide the most effective care. Based on the information, the foundation would produce periodic report cards on quality of care, matters like the recovery rates from colon cancer treatment or heart attacks. 
 The Wyoming meeting, run by the Jackson Hole Group -- private health care experts who developed the market-based reform known as managed competition -- was attended by executives from big employers like American Express. It also included officials from the health plan that covers Federal employees and the Federal agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, raising the prospect of public-private partnership.
The employers expressed confidence that they have, finally, brought medical costs under control. Last year employee medical costs fell by about 1 percent, after steadily rising at double-digit rates. Though costs could turn up again, the officials nevertheless agreed to move on to the elusive task of measuring quality so employees could learn which plans offer inferior care.
The explosive growth of managed care has helped bring health care inflation down. Studies show that the average managed care plan provides care that is as good as traditional fee-for-service coverage. But there is potential for abuse. Managed care plans charge a fixed premium regardless of how much treatment a patient requires. That gives these plans a short-run incentive to save money by providing fewer tests and other treatment. In theory, short-run cost-cutting ought to be tempered by a desire to keep small health problems from growing into expensive problems.
The other key to keeping health plans, including fee-for-service plans, in line is to hold their quality up to public scrutiny. Report cards measuring recovery, morbidity and mortality rates would be a good first step. The foundation will develop quality measures for several diseases each year and promises a useful report card in only three or four years.
Report cards, acting as a guide for consumer choices, can help drive health costs down and quality up. Large purchasers now seem committed to carry the process forward.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 829 words

HEADLINE: Man's Museum of Memories Relives the Terror for Blacks

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, July 7

 BODY:
A survivor of history and horror, James Cameron is the founder and tour guide of "America's Black Holocaust Museum" here.
He is also its star exhibit. 
 On an oven-hot August night 65 years ago, as a 16-year-old youth, Mr. Cameron watched a laughing and chanting white mob of thousands lynch two of his teen-age buddies from a tree on the courthouse lawn in his hometown, Marion, Ind. As he told the story the other day to a group touring the museum, it sounded as though the "time of terror" had happened yesterday.
Mr. Cameron was supposed to be the third black teen-ager to be hanged that night, without a trial or a prayer, for the robbery and slaying the day before of Claude Deeter, a white man. But after being dragged from jail and beaten, a rope thrown around his neck, Mr. Cameron's life was spared by the mob, apparently satisfied that enough had been done.
"I can forgive," he said. "But I can never forget. That's why I started this museum."
A retired building engineer and self-taught historian, Mr. Cameron opened the museum in 1988, several years after being moved to tears by a visit to the holocaust museum in Israel with his wife of 57 years.
"When I came out and composed myself," he said, "I told my wife, 'Honey, we need a museum like this in America to show what has happened to us black people and the freedom-loving white people who have been trying to help us.' "
The museum, in a former boxing gym on the edge of a weary Milwaukee neighborhood, is a collection of gruesome photographs of lynchings, including one as recently as 1981 in Alabama, plus Ku Klux Klan robes and hoods and two black wax figures dangling from a tree in the museum's "chamber of horrors."
"A lot of grown folks have to sit down after they see this," said Mr. Cameron, who moved here in the 1950's. "But it's important to remember. The Klan is still here. They send me their literature all the time."
A dozen visitors to the museum listened to Mr. Cameron's journey through "America's racist nightmare," some with their eyes closed, others sitting forward in their chairs, their heads down.
Then Mr. Cameron held up a poster-size photograph of his two friends, dangling dead in the tree, an image he called "one of the most famous lynching pictures in the world."
In the photograph, a white man with a Hitler-style mustache is looking into the camera and pointing up at the teen-agers.
"I was supposed to be hanging right there between my buddies," Mr. Cameron said. "There were thousands of people out there, acting like they were at a picnic."
Later, the photographer sold copies of the picture to sightseers for 50 cents each.
Mr. Cameron, now 81, spent four years in prison for Mr. Deeter's death. He was convicted as an accessory before the fact to voluntary manslaughter.
No one has ever been tried for lynching Mr. Cameron's buddies, Tommy Shipp and Abe Smith.
In 1993, the Governor of Indiana officially pardoned Mr. Cameron.
"The Government owed you a lot more than a pardon," said Anthony Johnson, 28, a visitor to the museum from Brooklyn. "You're like a man who's been through what all black men have been through, but you survived."
"He survived physically," said Andre X, 26. "But we're being lynched mentally and economically."
Andre X said he brought his family, visiting from out of state, to the museum instead of taking them to an amusement park because Mr. Cameron "is the only man I know who has been through something like that."
"It's breathtaking what our people have gone through," he said. "It makes me sad, but it also makes me proud. Look at him, he's still here. We're still here."
The museum is open Monday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. and charges $5 admission. Usually, Mr. Cameron and his grandson are the only staff members to guide visitors, who they said represented a cross section of Americans.
Most of the chairs and other furniture were donated by local colleges, and a black police officer's organization helped pay for the lynching display.
Last year, a man Mr. Cameron described only as "a young Jewish fellow" walked through the museum and promised to donate $50,000 "with no strings attached."
"I sat down and cried like a baby," Mr. Cameron said. "I quit begging after that. I put in air-conditioning, a new heating system, carpeting, fixed the roof. All my life, I've been helped by freedom-loving white people."
Had there been some freedom-loving whites in that Marion, Ind., mob 65 years ago, Mr. Cameron said, he and Tommy Shipp and Abe Smith might now be exchanging pictures of their grandchildren.
These days Mr. Cameron says he is concentrating on strengthening the museum to insure that it will outlive him, but he is also active on other fronts. At every opportunity, he goes to Klan rallies to heckle hate, and he said he was encouraged by the fact that the anti-Klan demonstrators almost always outnumber the Klansmen.
"And we always drown them out," Mr. Cameron said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1995, Tuesday

HEADLINE: Japanese Admit Recovery at Halt

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, July 11

 BODY:
The Japanese Government painted a grimmer picture of the nation's economy today, saying in a report that the hesitant recovery appears to have stalled.
"The recent gradual recovery trend appears to be at a standstill," the Economic Planning Agency said. 
 Hit by the surge of the yen and sluggish exports, Japan's economy had been recovering slowly from recession.
This was the first time the Government has admitted that Japan's recovery had stopped since the economy hit bottom in October 1993.
The agency said the strong yen and the recent economic slowdown in the United States were stalling growth in exports and industrial output.

HEADLINE: Politics Aside, Many in China Are Expanding Business With Taiwan

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, July 10

 BODY:
As relations between the United States and China worsen, barely a day goes by without a Chinese leader spewing invective about Taiwan and how Washington treats it.
But away from China's diplomatic huffing and puffing, senior and mid-level officials who grapple with how to modernize China's economy are steadily expanding business ties with Taiwan, the island nation that is increasingly seen by mainlanders as a model for how to do business more efficiently and profitably. 
 Shao Chun, president of one of China's largest securities firms, China Securities Company, is a good example of the business-minded officials in their 40's and 50's who now make up the bulk of China's power structure.
Although Mr. Shao does not object to China's formal view that Taiwan is an "inalienable part of the motherland," he is more interested in imitating its economic success.
"I'm going there next month," Mr. Shao said the other day. "We have a lot to learn from them."
As he discussed similarities between the securities markets in China today and in Taiwan a decade ago, Mr. Shao said that China's current problems, like insufficent regulation and uncontrolled speculation, are exactly what Taiwan experienced.
For decades, China's Communist Party has warned about how the evils of capitalist Taiwan could corrupt the mainland. Until the mid-1980's, visitors who crossed the Taiwan Strait from either direction were regarded as spies to be interrogated and jailed. The only exception was defectors. Taiwan, for example, rewarded each defecting Chinese Air Force pilot with instant celebrity and $1 million.
But now that the business of China, more and more, is business, Taiwan's combination of identical language, cultural backround and fast-growing economy offers a special role as teacher to the mainland.
"This has nothing to do with ideology," said Mr. Shao. "This is about making money."
Although Taiwan investment in mainland China is difficult to measure accurately -- direct investment is still officially banned -- David O'Rear of the Economist Intelligence Unit in Hong Kong estimates that it reached about $6 billion in 1994, compared with $2.5 billion from the United States.
Taiwan business people started coming to China in the mid-1980's as economic and political policy relaxed on each side, and Taiwan estimates that its residents conducted seven million visits to the mainland last year. Taiwan business people can now be found in every major mainland city, both as private investors and as resident representatives for multinational companies.
"It makes a lot of sense if you think about it," said a Taiwan businessman who is general manager for an American company in Shanghai. His insistence on not being identified reflects a lingering sensitivity to the issue. "We have a much greater intuitive ability to work with people here than other outsiders do."
Growing ties are not limited to individuals. Last fall, even the People's Construction Bank of Shanghai formalized ties to a venture capital company owned partly by Taiwan and partly by the United States. The company, the China Development Corporation, formed a $250 million fund aimed at a variety of Asian investment projects.
There is another side to Taiwan business activity in the mainland, too. Chinese officials complain that a large percentage of sour deals and business fraud is conducted by Taiwan business people, and point to the pirating of American and Chinese music copyrights as an area dominated by business people from Taiwan. For years, Taiwan has been a leading violator of publishing and recording copyrights.
On the other hand, Taiwan business people have cooled their enthusiasm for direct investment in the mainland during the last year because of frustration caused by China's lack of adequate legal protection when a dispute arises with a Chinese partner.
Ever sensitive to the issue of sovereignty, China's concern centers on the question of whether the United States views the mainland and the island off its southeastern coast as "one China" or as "one China and one Taiwan."
The current troubles were touched off by something as seemingly innocuous as the United States decision to allow President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to attend a reunion at Cornell University last month.
American officials have been at pains to point out that Mr. Lee's visit to Cornell did not alter their position recognizing only one China. Indeed, to American diplomats, the idea of one China seems to be sacrosant, at least in part because any change would make their own work more difficult.

HEADLINE: Chrysler to Take Big Charge For Cutting Shift at Plant

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., July 10

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would take a $143 million after-tax charge against its second-quarter earnings to cut one shift at a car plant in Newark, Del.
The unexpected 36-cents-a-share charge will take Chrysler's earnings 32 percent below analysts' estimates. Wall Street had expected Chrysler to earn $1.10 a share in the second quarter, based on the mean estimate of 14 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research. 
 Discontinuing the shift would affect up to 2,200 of the plant's 3,200 employees, Chrysler said.
Chrysler said it was negotiating with the United Automobile Workers to move up to 2,200 workers at the plant to a two-weeks-on, two-weeks-off, rotational shift. Workers would collect wages and unemployment that would provide about 95 percent of their current pay, a company spokeswoman, Nicole Solomon, said.
The company had warned two months ago that severe job cuts were likely, but there had been no hint of the 36-cent charge.
The company said the charge would cover unemployment benefits, other employee costs and the write-down of equipment and tooling. The plant, which employs 3,500, makes the Dodge Intrepid and Chrysler Concorde.
"I think they are taking the kitchen-sink approach," said David Healy, an analyst with Burnham Securities & Company, "They are going to have such a lousy second quarter, it doesn't matter what they do." Mr. Healy had been projecting earnings of about 75 cents a share.
Chrysler's second-quarter results, which will be announced July 18, will be lower because of the cost of converting factories to make new mini-vans and rebates on old models to clean out inventories, Mr. Healy said.
The charge, totaling $232 million on a pretax basis, was announced after the stock market closed. Earlier, Chrysler's shares closed at $50, up 50 cents.
Chrysler's Delaware plant is being hit harder than other factories because it made models that are being discontinued. Production of LeBaron convertibles ends this month, and the plant stopped making other LeBaron models and the Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim earlier this year.
An as-yet-unnamed 1998 model will be built at the plant beginning in the fall 1997.
The company said in May that it would cut the shift at the Delaware plant because of declining sales. The plant was idled twice in May because inventories were piling up. Chrysler also makes Intrepids and Concordes at a plant in Bramlea, Ontario.
Chrysler cut its projection for total United States 1995 vehicle sales to 14.9 million from 15.2 million after a 30 percent sales drop in April.
The nation's No. 3 auto maker set an all-time monthly record in June as sales of cars and trucks surged 12 percent, to 236,404 from 209,150.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy Visits Crusader in Chinese Jail

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
Three weeks after he was seized by Chinese authorities, Harry Wu, the American human rights advocate charged with espionage, was permitted a jailhouse interview with the American consul general today. But his jailers ordered him not to discuss the charges against him, State Department officials said.
Mr. Wu spoke with the American consul, Arturo Macias, for about 30 minutes from behind a thick glass partition, over a telephone monitored by the authorities. He said he was not suffering at the hands of his jailers, but Mr. Macias learned little about the precise nature of the charges or about Mr. Wu's immediate prospects, the officials said. 
 In Washington, the Clinton Administration pondered diplomatic ways to express displeasure at Mr. Wu's arrest and the deteriorating human rights situation in China, while trying to prevent further strains in its relationship with Beijing. Those strains are likely to deepen with the expected announcement on Tuesday that the United States will restore relations with the Vietnamese, a people the Chinese have fought, off and on, for millenniums.
"We are obviously in a period of some difficulty in U.S.-China relations," said the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns. "It's imperative that both the United States and China take steps to repair those difficulties." He said Mr. Wu was in no way an American spy, and he called again for his release.
"We're going to make sure that we do everything we can to protect Mr. Wu's rights," Mr. Burns said.
Human rights groups and some members of Congress urged the Administration to put pressure on China by canceling a trade mission to Beijing by Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and a tentatively planned trip by Hillary Rodham Clinton to the United Nations World Conference on Women in September.
The international group Human Rights Watch said the United States should ask the World Bank to postpone two large loans, totaling $660 million, for highway and hydroelectric projects in China. The group also said the White House should seek support for Mr. Wu's release from American companies doing business in China.
"If 'commercial diplomacy' means anything, responsible members of the corporate community should be doing everything they can to convince the Chinese that respect for human rights is fundamental to doing business in China," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, Washington director for Human Rights Watch/Asia..
Mr. Wu spent 19 years in Chinese labor camps, charged as a "counterrevolutionary" for questioning the conduct of Soviet and Chinese communism. Freed in 1979, he became an American citizen in 1994. He has returned several times to China, often under assumed names, to try to document human rights abuses.
Though he was carrying a valid visa and a United States passport, he was seized three weeks ago while crossing into China from the former Soviet republic of Kazakhstan. He is being held in Wuhan, a city in the central province of Hubei, his last legal residence before he emigrated to the United States.
"Mr. Wu has been accused of committing three crimes," said Mr. Burns, the State Department spokesman. "First, repeatedly sneaking into China under false names; second, stealing Chinese state secrets; and third, disseminating those secrets to institutions and organizations outside of China." But he said it was unclear whether those charges would be brought against Mr. Wu if his case comes to trial.
If Mr. Wu is tried on espionage charges, he could be denied a public hearing and a proper defense, his trial could be conducted in secret and conviction could be punishable by death. The lesser charge of disseminating secrets falls under state security laws that give the authorities the power to impose long prison terms.
As the human rights situation has worsened, so have Chinese-American relations during the last year. Wei Jingsheng, the nation's best-known dissident, was arrested in April 1994 and remains incommunicado. Chen Ziming, a prominent advocate in the 1989 pro-democracy uprising in Beijing, was reimprisoned two weeks ago after the authorities rescinded his parole.
Last month, China protested furiously after the United States granted a temporary visitor's visa to the president of Taiwan, Lee Teng-hui, so that he could attend a college reunion. The United States had, as a matter of policy, refused such visits. China regards Taiwan as a renegade province led by the vestiges of the old Government destroyed by the 1949 Communist revolution in China.
The United States has been pressing China on a variety of human rights, trade and security issues, including Beijing's sales of military equipment to Iran, Myanmar and Pakistan.
The arrest of Mr. Wu is fast becoming a lightning rod for those in Congress who want to increase the pressure on Beijing. "China's relations with the United States hang in the balance," said Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee.

HEADLINE: Defying U.S. Threat, Bolivians Plant More Coca

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: ETERAZAMA, Bolivia

 BODY:
At the coca market in this remote jungle village, where farmers lug 50-pound bags of coca leaves for miles on their backs and bicycles, the talk is of little else but the demands by the United States that Bolivia cut its coca production.
"I don't care how much pressure they put on us to stop growing coca, we will never give this up because we have no other means to survive," said Delfin Olivera, a 24-year-old farmer. "Coca is natural, it's part of our culture, and it has been here since the beginning of the world." 
 Maria Patricia Robino, 42, whose children helped her carry five bags of coca four miles to the market, said she too had no other livelihood except coca. "I tried growing other crops, like pineapples and oranges, but there was no one to buy them," she said. "We are just trying to eat and live like everyone else, and nothing pays more than coca."
Such sentiments underscore the political and economic obstacles in Bolivia to wiping out coca, the raw material for cocaine. The country produces about a third of the world's coca leaves, ranking second to Peru, which produces most of the rest.
Bolivia is also the second largest exporter, after Colombia, of refined cocaine. In 1993, according to the most recent figures available from the United States Embassy, Bolivia produced about 7 percent of the refined cocaine in the world.
In the last decade, the United States has tried a variety of programs to stem the flow of drugs from the Andes. Now, in a renewed effort to attack the source, it is turning up the pressure on foreign governments to wipe out coca crops and enforce laws against replanting.
Frustrated at seeing no reduction in coca production despite spending more than $130 million in the last decade to get Bolivian farmers to switch to other crops, the United States Government recently gave the country an ultimatum. It told Bolivia that it had better destroy 4,300 acres of coca plants by June 30 or face the end of economic aid worth $87 million this year and a boycott of international loans that it receives. There are more than 120,000 acres of coca under cultivation in Bolivia.
While the Bolivian Government persuaded farmers to destroy enough of their coca crop to meet the June deadline -- it paid them $1,000 for each acre eradicated -- drug policy experts are skeptical that it will have the same success in meeting a second United States deadline requiring the eradication of 8,125 additional acres by year's end.
"We are not optimistic that the Bolivians will meet targets this year because the Government has not been willing to crack down on the farmers who continue to plant new coca," said a senior United States drug official here.
"Not that we think we can get 100 percent reduction, or 50 percent, or even 25 percent," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But if we can raise the risk to people that can lose their money, their goods and liberty for growing coca then we can make progress in convincing them to switch to alternative crops."
The United States is facing an uphill battle, the experts said, mainly because the Bolivian Government has been unwilling to enforce laws that prohibit the planting of new coca crops and because coca is such an entrenched part of Bolivia's culture and economy.
The use of the coca leaf is an Andean tradition dating back thousands of years. The Aymara and Quechua Indians of Bolivia and Peru use coca leaves for cultural, religious and medical purposes. Peasants chew the leaves to combat hunger, thirst and fatigue, and many natural medicine doctors prescribe coca teas and coca-based concoctions as remedies for aches, ailments and digestive problems.
While there is a legal market in Bolivia for coca leaves that are chewed and are used to make tea and other remedies, most coca grown in this region goes to make cocaine. In recent years, as drug agents began infiltrating laboratories in Colombia, the cartels have been increasingly refining cocaine in Bolivia and paying peasants to make cocaine paste in crude jungle labs. The paste is further refined elsewhere in Bolivia and in Colombia.
Last year, cocaine trafficking brought an estimated $356 million into the Bolivian economy, or 6.2 percent of gross domestic product, according to estimates by drug policy experts here. About 10 percent of Bolivia's work force receive their income from drug-related activities.
The Government has been reluctant to prosecute coca growers for planting new crops because of the broad public support for the growers, who have staged large demonstrations, billing themselves as scapegoats for a drug-abusive United States.
"Our big problem is that the Bolivian people are against narco-trafficking but they are for these farmers," said President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada. He said his Government was planning new enforcement measures but needed more financial support from the United States and other countries to carry them out.
Serafin Ramos, manager of the local coca farmers association here, estimated that about half the farmers in Eterazama had planted new coca crops even though it is illegal to do so.
"I've done it and almost everyone else that I know has replanted coca," he said, "because until we are provided with the necessary markets, infrastructure and processing plants to make the other crops worthwhile, we will stay with coca."
Andres Hinojosa Orellana, 62, said that he planted new coca on his land just a few months ago because he needed the money to provide for his family. "Come on over here and take a look at my new coca," Mr. Hinojosa said. "I have no fear of what I'm doing. I have my machete. I'm obligated to plant this new coca to take care of my five children."
United States officials here calculate that an acre of coca yields about $1,000 a year while crop substitutes like bananas, grapefruit, pineapples and oranges pay $600 to $800 an acre, if farmers find buyers.
Also, coca requires very little care and is harvested three times a year. Many alternative crops require years of hard labor before they yield any fruit and are much heavier to transport through the jungle, which lacks adequate roads.
As a result, and without sufficient Government subsidies to make new crops worthwhile, many farmers who agreed to destroy coca crops have started replanting coca. Since 1987, nearly 67,500 acres of coca have been eradicated in Bolivia, but new cultivation has more than offset the reduction. Last year, a record 89,800 metric tons of coca leaf was produced in Bolivia, 6.4 percent more than in 1993, United States drug officials say.
Sandro Calvani, country director for the United Nations International Drug Control Program in Bolivia, said that more than $200 million had been spent by the United States and the United Nations on a variety of programs that had provided people here in the Chapare jungle with new roads, electricity, potable water and help in developing alternative crops.
"This effort has been successful in terms of providing coca growers with options," Mr. Calvani said. "But it has been a failure in that they are not taking full advantage of it because of a lack of enforcement."

HEADLINE: Managua Journal;
For the Pride of Nicaragua, a Home Run in Politics?

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 10

 BODY:
In the United States, Dennis Martinez is regarded by baseball fans as a crafty veteran pitcher, an All-Star, the ace of the Cleveland Indians' staff. Here in his baseball-mad homeland, such achievements are enough to have vaulted him to the status of national hero and possible future President.
"Dennis Martinez is a factor of national unity and pride who is perhaps the most popular man in Nicaragua," said Edgard Castillo, a former sports and foreign news editor at the newspaper La Prensa here. "Everyone likes and admires him, whether they are Communists or conservatives." 
 Though Americans may be disillusioned about baseball, because of the strike that wrecked the 1994 season, that is definitely not the case here. Spurred on by the achievements of Mr. Martinez and of a national team that is enjoying a hot streak in international competition, Nicaraguans seem more passionate than ever about their national pastime, introduced by American diplomats at the turn of the century and then popularized by the American marines who occupied the country until the Somoza family dictatorship took power in the 1930's.
The only Nicaraguan currently playing in the major leagues, Mr. Martinez has been the focus of his nation's hopes since he broke in with the Baltimore Orioles in 1976. But now at 40, an age when most baseball players have retired, he is having his finest season ever, with an 8-0 record and an e.r.a. of 2.37. When the right-hander was named to the American League All-Star team last week, all of Nicaragua rejoiced.
Since then, the airwaves here have been filled with impassioned discussions of why Mr. Martinez, and not Kevin Appier of the Kansas City Royals or Randy Johnson of the Seattle Mariners, deserves to start for the American Leaguers in Tuesday night's game, to be played in Arlington, Tex.
"All three have their merits, but Dennis is undefeated and has the second lowest e.r.a in the league, so he should get the chance," said Federico Gadea, a 23-year-old medical student. But it was Mr. Johnson who was named the starter today.
Given Nicaragua's unsettled political situation, pride in Mr. Martinez's achievements, including 227 career victories and recovery from arm trouble and a battle with alcoholism, has also led to calls for him to run for President in elections scheduled for next year. Supporters formed a draft committee some time ago, and though Mr. Martinez has said he prefers to focus on bringing a pennant to Cleveland for the first time in 41 years, he has also left the door open to a career in politics once he retires from baseball.
"He's a smart guy, and as a pitcher he knows the importance of timing," said Carlos Garcia, president of the Nicaraguan Amateur Baseball Federation. "He has said this is not the time yet, but that doesn't mean he can't do it later, when he thinks the time is right."
Some of those who admire Mr. Martinez, who comes from humble beginnings and as a teen-ager cut short his studies to play professional baseball, argue, however, that the country cannot afford to wait. "The professional politicians haven't been worth a dime and haven't kept any of their promises," said Erick Miranda, a 36-year-old truck driver. "Dennis is a man of the people and a real leader, so certainly he can do better."
Other fans think that assuming the presidency would actually constitute a step down for Mr. Martinez. They want him to continue in the major leagues at least until he has won 17 more games, which would allow him to surpass Juan Marichal, the Hall of Famer from the Dominican Republic, as the Latin American pitcher with the most career victories in major league history.
"Anybody can run for President, and if Dennis wants to, that's all right by me," said Luden Espinoza, 22, a computer technician who was wearing a Cleveland Indians cap at a game played here Sunday. "But Dennis is a national treasure, one of the few Nicaraguans who has achieved renown in the outside world, so I would rather see him go for the record."
Fans here, and that includes almost all of Nicaragua's 4.5 million people, have also been buoyed by the exploits of Nicaragua's national baseball team, which is enjoying a run of success that contrasts sharply with the fortunes of the nation as a whole in recent years. A constitutional crisis paralyzed the Government for five months, unemployment and corruption are rampant, and political parties are at each other's throats, as usual.
Everyday speech here is full of slang terms borrowed from baseball, like "caught off base" and "hitting a home run," and Nicaraguans have long been accustomed to drawing parallels between baseball and politics. For that reason, the national team's current string of victories is seen as a boost for a fragile transition to democracy that began in 1990 after nearly 50 years of the Somoza family dictatorship and more than a decade of rule by the Sandinista National Liberation Front
"Baseball is our only means of reconciliation, the only place where we can erase our differences and begin to understand each other," Mr. Garcia said. "This team sends a message to the whole country, that yes, you can get things done if you respect each other's principles and help each other on and off the field."
At the Managua stadium on Sunday, there was plenty for the fans to cheer as they munched fried plantains and chicken and sipped cold La Victoria beer and sodas under a blazing tropical sun. After the national team pummeled Taiwan 14 to 6 in the second game of a five-game series, youngsters wearing baseball caps of American and Nicaraguan teams rushed to the winners dugout to beg players for autographs, using Mexican-made baseballs.
Nicaragua won the silver medal at the Pan-American Games in Argentina in February, and the gold last week at the Pacific Games in Cali, Colombia.
Later last week the Nicaraguans also beat the American Olympic team in a game played in Homestead, Fla., raising hopes that the country will qualify for the Olympic Games in Atlanta next year.
"We know that we are defending the cause of an entire people, and we want to bring home a medal for them," said Julio Vallejos, the team's catcher. "We think we have the dedication, the passion, the discipline and the love to do it."
