HEADLINE: In Blow to Mayor, Credit Agency Lowers New York's Bond Rating

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
A major credit agency yesterday lowered its rating of New York City's long-term credit worthiness, citing both the sluggish economy and fiscal gimmicks it said were used by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to balance the city's budget.
The decision by Standard & Poor's lowers the city's rating from A-, where it has been since 1987, to BBB+, among the lowest ratings of any major city in the country. Of major cities, only Detroit, Philadelphia and Washington have lower ratings. 
 It is unclear whether the downgrade will have any practical implications for the city, because Moody's, the other major credit agency, had already downgraded the city's rating several years ago, and the city's bonds have been trading at the lower level. Normally, a downgrade would force the city to pay millions in higher interest costs, because investors would be more reluctant to lend their money to the city and would demand more interest in return.
But the decision is clearly a symbolic blow to the Mayor's claim to be a financial housecleaner, single-handedly beginning to turn around decades of unsound financial practices by previous mayors -- which explains why mayoral aides had worked feverishly in recent days to change the agency's mind. Though Standard & Poor's praised Mr. Giuliani's "strong track record" in restraining the growth of spending, its announcement said he "continues to rely on budget practices that are inconsistent with a single A- rating."
The Mayor dismissed the action, saying no one would remember it by next week. He said the agency was simply correcting a mistaken decision not to downgrade in the middle of the 1993 mayoral campaign, and had created criticisms of his budget to justify the action. Even some of Mr. Giuliani's critics acknowledged that he was to some extent the victim of bad timing, paying the price for the failures of earlier administrations.
Standard & Poor's cited specifically Mr. Giuliani's use of one-time measures, also known as one-shots or gimmicks, to balance the budget for a single year without rectifying the underlying problem. The agency said the city's estimates of $600 million in labor savings had not been met, and said it continues to rely too heavily on overly optimistic projections of state and Federal aid that might not come through.
It also cited the possibility that the city could use the proceeds from the proposed sale of its water system for current expenses, and said the city's debt level was too high.
Mostly, however, it blamed the feeble local economy, noting that employment had declined by 9,000 jobs in the first quarter of the year and projected a weak prospect of continued job growth. The city's economy, it said, remains too reliant on the financial-services sector, which has historically been volatile.
Mr. Giuliani, who said he has known since his inauguration that the downgrade was coming, angrily accused Standard & Poor's of covering up the real reason for downgrading by citing a series of "disingenuous" criticisms of his budget. In every possible way, he said, the city is in better shape than it was two years ago, when the agency decided to retain its A- rating.
"The things they're picking on are small points to try to justify a decision that they can't really justify," he said at a news conference yesterday. "In 1993, they wanted to downgrade the city, and they didn't do it because they felt it might interfere with the incumbent mayor's chances of re-election. There isn't a person in this city that doesn't know that. So that release had to cover a lot of mistakes they made in the past."
Vladimir Stadnyk, Standard & Poor's executive managing director for public finance, said the 1993 decision had nothing to do with yesterday's downgrade, and denied that there was any political consideration involved. Rather, he said, the city's credit risk is simply greater now than it was in 1993.
"We're not saying the city was better run in 1993, or that it's better run today," he said. "We're just saying, in our opinion, the combination of credit factors today makes the city a heightened credit risk. We have no hidden agenda here." An agency spokesman said the ratings of Standard & Poor's and Moody's are often different by one increment, as they were in New York until yesterday.
The city's new BBB+ rating is still considered an investment-grade rating, though it is considered by Standard & Poor's to be in the mid to low range of investment quality. The lowest possible investment-grade level is BBB-, which is Philadelphia's rating. Washington's B-rated bonds are considered junk bonds. There are, however, some institutional investors who will not buy bonds below the A- level, which may have the effect of further raising interest costs in New York because the pool of potential buyers is smaller.
Municipal bond traders said the bond market agreed with Standard & Poor's decision, and most said that its stated reasons for doing so were legitimate.
"Giuliani has done an excellent job in trying to create more long-term structural balance, but everyone in the industry sees what the city has to do each year to keep from running a deficit," said Alexandra Lebenthal, president of the Lebenthal & Company, which deals heavily in the city's bonds. "Everyone has a less-than-positive feeling about all those one-shots in the budget."
The city and state comptrollers both issued statements calling the decision disappointing. But both also said it should be seen as a warning that the city must take additional steps toward a long-term balance of the city's financial situation.
"This downgrade does not create a crisis," said City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, "but it is another serious indicator that the city's fiscal situation needs additional strong corrective action."
Standard & Poor's has urged the city for months to stop using one-shot measures to balance its budget. In January, the agency placed the city on "negative credit watch," one step short of a downgrade, after the city decided to borrow money to close its budget gap instead of asking the Board of Education to find an additional $120 million in midyear savings. At the time, the agency said it would downgrade to the BBB level if the gimmicks continued.
But the 1996 budget, passed last month, still included some possible one-shot measures, including the sale of the water system. Though the city has said it would use $800 million of the proceeds from that sale for long-term capital projects, it has not promised to avoid using such proceeds for daily operating expenses, a fact that the agency criticized. And the agreement with the unions includes $150 million in savings by deferring the city's pension costs over several years, although the total amount would eventually have to be paid.
Mr. Stadnyk said Standard & Poor's executives have met with city officials repeatedly over the last four months to discuss these issues. A planned downgrade in May was postponed after the Mayor and City Council leaders persuaded the agency to wait until after the city and state budgets had been passed. Finally, he said, the agency's City Rating Committee, a group of six or seven senior officials, including three managing directors, agreed by consensus to lower the rating.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK'S BOND RATING IS LOWERED
A major credit agency lowered its rating of New York City's long-term credit worthiness, citing both the sluggish economy and fiscal gimmicks it said were used by Mayor to balance the city's budget. The decision by Standard & Poor's cut the city's rating from A-, where it has been since 1987, to BBB+. [Page A1.]
For months, the Giuliani administration watched as the downgrading of New York City's credit rating approached like a slow-moving but inexorable train. After the train had struck and moved on, the question around City Hall was whether the Mayor might have done anything to move out of the way. News analysis. [B4.]
MOBSTER PORTRAYAL STIRS DISBELIEF
A Federal indictment last month depicted Paul H. K. Lai, a well-known Chinatown businessman, as a top leader of an organized crime group that law-enforcement officials believe has begun to rival the Mafia in influence and brutality -- a man who cold-bloodedly ordered murders to protect his gambling and extortion rackets. But many in Chinatown, and Mr. Lai himself in an unusual two-hour interview, describe him as a classic immigrant success story, an honorable businessman and benevolent civic leader who even served on an advisory panel for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. [A1.]
CHILD SUPPORT GUIDELINES UPHELD
Upholding New Jersey's child-support guidelines, the state Supreme Court rejected a divorced father's arguments that his support payments should be reduced so he can spend the money as he sees fit when he is caring for his children. The decision, in a case involving James Pascale, a divorced father of three who pays $1,150 a month in child support, overturns a ruling by a state Appellate Court. More broadly, it runs counter to a trend in other jurisdictions to develop equations for child support. [A1.]

In what Federal officials suggested could be the last big infusion of homeless-assistance money for years to come, the Government awarded New York City $100 million for emergency shelter, permanent housing, drug treatment and day care. [B3.]
ORTHODOX JUDGES OVERTURN BETROTHAL
First, Sarah Leah Goldstein was ambushed by a biblical passage that had been ignored for centuries. Then she was saved by a voice from beyond the grave. A special assembly of Orthodox Jewish religious judges declared that Miss Goldstein, whose father betrothed her at age 11 to a man whose identity he would not reveal, was free to marry anyone she pleased. [B3.]
 
ROUGH START FOR NEW D.M.V.
The administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman switched the 23 motor vehicle offices in New Jersey from state to private operation in the name of efficiency and economy. But the campaign's start was hectic and bumpy across the state, with new clerks working after only a weekend of training on recognizing and processing the multitude of forms and documents for titles, licenses and registration plates. [B5.]
JORDANIAN GETS 15 YEARS FOR MURDER
A man who strangled his wife in New Jersey was sentenced in his native Jordan to 15 years of prison and "hard labor." [B5.]

HEADLINE: A Battle on the Waterfront;
Conflicting Visions for the Renewal of the Passaic River

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
It is unusual for a skipper to advise his passengers to remove their bright red life jackets in midstream to be safe, but the stretch of the Passaic River flowing through downtown Newark is no ordinary waterway.
"I tell people to take their life jackets off because they make an easy target," said Paul J. Lerin, a self-appointed guide who hopes to turn his love of the river into an environmental cleanup business. "We are in a sniper zone here." 
 As he gunned his small green launch past the shattered windows of a housing project onshore, he also kept an eye peeled for debris that can make the boat veer sharply or choke the propeller. "Crack heads with guns sometimes like to shoot at the little boats," he said. "If you see anything pinging in the water, let me know."
It would not be the only sniping along the river.
Newark is embarking on an ambitious transformation of its waterfront, hoping to turn the clock back 100 years to a time when people swam in the river, or at least to a time before the now-defunct factories burped up wastes that blighted the shoreline.
By August, the Army Corps of Engineers will publicly unveil plans for a $25 million pedestrian promenade curving along two miles of the downtown riverbank. It is designed both to block erosion and to braid together key pieces of urban renewal, including a redesigned train station and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which is just beginning to carve a place in the skyline.
City planners envision the now barren downtown bubbling with all sorts of life -- more jobs, outdoor concerts, Rollerbladers -- and say the proposed strip of pathways and trees will prove the magnet. With public hearings scheduled for the fall and final sketches not due until January, Glenn A. Grant, the Newark business administrator coordinating the project, called any criticism premature.
But a committed band of environmental groups and river lovers are already taking potshots at the drawings that have been leaked thus far. They fear that instead of sparking a love affair with the river, the stolid concrete corniche will turn into more of a barrier to the water than a draw.
"It is mediocre and I think the Passaic River deserves more than that," said Ella F. Filippone, executive director of the Passaic River Coalition and doyenne of the 25-year battle to clean the waterway. "To design a park for a river you have to give it some kind of personality. It has to relate the city to the river."
It is almost impossible to get close to the river now. In the few places where parking lots might allow a glimpse, the banks are so weak that attendants avoid riverside spaces for fear the cars will sink. Elsewhere its like playing dial-a-contaminant, depending on what unused factory ground you tried to cross.
Only by jumping aboard one of the few available boats like Mr. Lerin's, cobbled together from an old fiberglass hull and bits scavenged from other craft, can you get a sense of the waterway.
At age 28, Mr. Lerin is a rare man: He has swum in the Passaic River. Soon after his family arrived as immigrants from Portugal in 1971, hot August days were spent leaping off a gargantuan Conrail bridge, now unused. "Kids still tell me I have got the record for the highest jump," he said. "That was in my heyday."
Look at the trash-infested, dun-colored water, smell the faint odor of formaldehyde coming from an onshore factory and the question arises: Who would possibly seek such a title?
It's a man who greets the flotsam like old, if not quite welcome, acquaintances. Piloting his boat, Mr. Lerin spots an empty propane tank. "This is a familiar piece of debris," he said. "I have been watching this thing float around forever."
The river is a tidal estuary. The water never quite makes it into Newark Bay. The trash bobs downriver as the tide ebbs and then bobs right back in again. Mr. Lerin points out a half canoe that he said has been floating around for years. He sees a Pepsi bottle with a design that is no longer sold.
He thinks the rats are great. Writing in the monthly newsletter that he produces to track environmental problems and try to drum up business for his fledgling cleanup company, Mr. Lerin said the rodent dinners are attracting birds like the red-tailed hawk to the riverbank. He hails by name the drawbridge keepers. The Army Corps says barges hauling petroleum or gravel make about 3,600 trips annually, a trickle of the former traffic.
It is no easy river to love. In 1970, the Passaic could easily have been an understudy for the river Styx. It was listed among the 10 worst polluted rivers in the country. Researchers burned their hands taking samples of the acidic black gunk oozing from drainpipes along the banks.
Traces of those days are easy to find. A chunk of the shore and the entire six-mile riverbed in the city are a Superfund Site, the tag used by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency for areas holding the kind of pollutants that can cause cancer or birth defects if ingested. This spring the E.P.A. began investigating the river basin to gauge the suspected high level of pesticides, dioxins, PCB's, metals and other hazardous substances in the sediments. Signs are posted in English, Spanish and Chinese warning against eating any fish, shellfish or crustaceans from the river.
Thinking about all that possible toxicity makes Mr. Lerin's heart sink. When asked about the worst thing that he has ever encountered on the river, he said: "It has to be the blue drums, aside from the human corpses, of course. You never know what substance is in the barrels. It is probably someone trying to get rid of something really bad, and they put it in the container and threw it into the river."
Both environmentalists and city officials are relieved that the worst polluters were shut down in the days when the New Jersey had an environmental prosecutor, a post eliminated in 1994 by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. They worry that Republican attempts in Congress to alter the Federal Clean Water Act of 1970 will undermine all the advances made since then.
Swimming crabs bump up against empty gin bottles, and the cormorants, egrets and blue heron nesting in mired tires are a sure sign that the fish are back. The next big step is eliminating all the debris. So many plastic foam cups skitter across the water that they could be mistaken for some kind of indigenous surface species. Flies swarm over the carcasses of dogs. The crew teams from the Nereid Boat Club, back after a nearly 30-year hiatus, sometimes get beached midstream on chunks of debris and occasionally cannot even launch their sculls.
Everyone hopes that construction of the waterfront park will prove the catalyst to get rid of the trash. The park was originally financed as an adjunct to a multibillion-dollar flood tunnel, but has since been separated and thus far saved from budget cuts.
"The whole idea is to attract people back to the river," said Frank Sudol, chief of program development in the city's engineering department. Construction is to begin in two years.
Besides people like Mr. Lerin, there is little evidence that public attitudes are prone to change soon.
A public defender in Sacramento, Calif., called the Passaic River Coalition this month, saying that he had a client who faced the death penalty in a murder trial. The lawyer said the man went swimming in Newark in the 1960's and wondered if something in the water could have caused neurological damage.
"What do you suppose his defense is going to be?" Mrs. Filippone, the head of the coalition, wondered. "The river made me do it."

HEADLINE: City's Bond Rating: Did Giuliani Do Enough to Help It?

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
For months, the Giuliani administration watched as the downgrading of New York City's credit rating approached like a slow-moving but inexorable train. Yesterday, after the train had struck and moved on, the question around City Hall was whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani might have done anything to move out of the way.
Even his critics agreed with the Mayor that there was an element of unfairness in the decision by the Standard & Poor's Corporation to lower its rating on the city's long-term bonds, which the agency said was based mostly on the sluggishness of the city's economy. 
 Having cut billions of dollars from city spending, Mr. Giuliani has by virtually all accounts put the city's finances in better shape than they were in July 1993, when Standard & Poor's last considered -- but then decided against -- cutting the rating.
At the time, the rating agency yielded to the pleas of Mayor David N. Dinkins, who said it would embarrass his administration in the middle of a political campaign with Mr. Giuliani.
But in the subsequent two years, the agency has had to sit back and watch while the bond market sided with its competitor, Moody's Investors Service, which had cut its bond rating in 1991. The city's bonds have since traded at the lower level, and Standard & Poor's has been under increasing pressure from the market to bring its rating in line.
Felix Rohatyn, the former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said that yesterday's cut was not so much a slap in the face to the Mayor's budgeting as it was a way of rectifying the agency's 1993 mistake. The business community considers the city's credit to be better now than it was two years ago, he said.
"This was a rating that for some time now was probably not justified," said Mr. Rohatyn, who has often urged Mr. Giuliani to look harder for new sources of revenue. "The Mayor has shown an obvious willingness to take on the city's budgetary problems in a hard way, but in this case he is a victim of bad timing. He just happens to be the right man in the wrong place at the wrong time."
Nonetheless, Standard & Poor's, as well as many fiscal experts, said much of the responsibility for the downgrading falls on the administration's shoulders. One Standard & Poor's official said yesterday that the previous rating of A- could not be justified for any city that must struggle each year to balance the budget with a patched-together medley of spending cuts and one-time fiscal gimmicks that have the effect of pushing the real problem off to future years.
Other experts said that although Mr. Giuliani reduced city spending, particularly on services and benefits for the poor, he had made little progress toward eliminating the structural imbalance.
"The measures the Mayor has taken to reduce the deficit are typical of the measures taken in the past to close city budget gaps," said Ester R. Fuchs, director of the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy. "Every mayor since the fiscal crisis has used a combination of reducing the work force and cutting back spending at the agencies to close budget gaps, and Giuliani has done the same thing. It has nothing to do with reducing the structural deficit over time."
Ms. Fuchs, author of "Mayors and Money: Fiscal Policy in New York and Chicago," agrees with leaders of the business-financed Citizens Budget Committee who say that two enormous shadows continue to hover over the city's long-term financial picture, all but untouched by Mr. Giuliani in his initial 18 months.
The first is the inability of the city to persuade the state to pay a bigger share of social-service and criminal-justice spending, which virtually every other state picks up entirely. A study by Ms. Fuchs shows that New York City spends far more per person than any other city in the country, three times more than Philadelphia and five times more than Houston.
The state forces the city to pay about a quarter of its budget on social services, compared with 6 percent in Chicago, 3 percent in Houston and 15 percent in Philadelphia.
Mr. Giuliani had hoped to reduce these costs by asking the state to cut its own social service spending, which, because of a system of matching formulas, would have allowed the city to do the same. He was largely unsuccessful in that effort, and many state legislators say he is unlikely to achieve any significant change in the foreseeable future.
The second and most controversial shadow is the intractable size of the city's union-dominated payroll, which now constitutes 51 percent of the city budget, up from 50 percent in 1993.
Administration officials announced last month that they had reached agreement with the municipal labor unions on the details of $440 million in savings, as well as a commitment to another $160 million in savings to be negotiated by October. Mayoral aides say they have gotten more from labor than any previous administration. But none of the concessions yet announced include reductions in wage levels, holidays or benefits.
The Mayor argued that no one expected him to achieve such results in citywide labor negotiations, as opposed to talks yet to come with individual unions. The weakness in his labor strategy, however, was one of the prime factors cited by Standard & Poor's in yesterday's decision.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
From the Yearbook Incident to the 'Boot Camp' Parade

BYLINE: By Raymond Hernandez 

 BODY:
THE five Greenwich High School seniors went into deep seclusion last month after news broke that they had slipped a coded message of racial hate into the school yearbook. Reporters searched all over Greenwich for them, camping outside their homes, knocking on the doors of their neighbors and phoning their relatives. But the teen-agers were nowhere to be found.
Then, as part of their punishment, they were put in Roy Innis's hands. 
 Mr. Innis -- a controversial conservative civil rights leader whose claims to fame in recent years include getting into a televised scuffle with the Rev. Al Sharpton on the Morton Downey Jr. program -- volunteered to help the seniors redeem themselves with his own brand of community service.
Not since Hester Prynne in "The Scarlet Letter" have sinners been thrust so suddenly into the glare of public scrutiny. To kick off their penance, Mr. Innis invited the teen-agers and their parents to join him at the Manhattan office of his civil rights organization yesterday for a frank discussion on race and diversity.
He also invited television crews, newspaper reporters and photographers.
Dozens of them came.

 SUDDENLY it dawned on the "Greenwich Five," as they've come to be known, exactly what they had agreed to. As the camera crews waited for their big photo opportunity, the five teen-agers and their parents would not come out of a room in the Congress of Racial Equality's ninth-floor office.
"The mothers are upset about all the pictures and stuff," Cyril Boynes, a CORE board member, said.
"Parents are parents," he added. "They're sensitive about this."
No kidding.
Part of the meeting -- announced on press releases that proclaimed " 'Greenwich 5' to Start CORE's Civil Rights Boot Camp" -- was apparently spent trying to coax the students and their parents to be good sports and pose for just one photograph so that the reporters would be on their way once and for all.
"The idea is we get one pool shot," Mr. Innis suggested to CORE's national spokesman, Niger Roy Innis, who also happens to be Roy Innis's son.
"The people are very nervous about the cameras," the national spokesman protested, as the reporters clogged the halls and rooms of CORE's SoHo office.
So how did it come to this? Well, the elder Mr. Innis -- who was a passionate defender of Bernhard H. Goetz, the subway gunman, and is a National Rifle Association member -- phoned and then visited the Greenwich Schools Superintendent, John A. Whritner, last month and offered to give the students a summer course in racial relations and civil rights. Because of the coded message the students had planted in the yearbook -- "Kill all niggers" -- school officials had barred them from the graduation ceremony and were casting about for some way out of the sensitive situation.
Greenwich school officials jumped at the chance to turn the students over to Mr. Innis, calling it an opportunity for "redemption." It seemed like a keen idea at the time.
In fact, school officials even agreed to allow the seniors to take their final exams and receive their diplomas once they have completed the course, which began with yesterday's meeting at CORE's office.
Mr. Innis's assistants explained yesterday that as part of the Roy Innis Boot Camp students will visit New York City neighborhoods like Chinatown and Harlem. Not to suggest that the focus will be entirely on minority communities. "We're going to take them to rural New York State so they can see poor white farmers," said George Holmes, CORE's executive director. They'll also have to read books about black history and write essays on them.
Mr. Innis is so confident about his Boot Camp that he suggested it should be extended beyond the Greenwich Five as a "preemptive" measure. "One need not be a sinner to seek salvation," he said.
Yesterday's meeting got off to a decent start after a private meeting between Mr. Innis and his guests. Angelique Wimbush, another CORE member, eventually led the families through the office, stopping to introduce them to the staff at various departments.
"This is our immigration department," Ms. Wimbush said, pointing to a woman sitting in a cramped cubicle with a couple from Bosnia.
"Serb or Muslim?" Mr. Innis interrupted after learning where the couple came from.
Muslim, they replied.
"I hope we can help you," he said before heading off with the discombobulated teen-agers, who were dressed in baseball caps, T-shirts and jeans.
Things rapidly began to fall apart as the families became unnerved at the sight of "journalists" fumbling with cameras, cables, tape recorders, beepers and cellular phones. To the dismay and frustration of reporters, Mr. Innis eventually had to hold his press conference without the families.
"I thought we were invited here to meet with the families," one reporter protested.

 AFTER extensive back-room negotiations, the Greenwich Five -- Keith Dianis, Patrick Fox, Ed Oberbeck, Robert Texiere and Aaron Valenti -- and their parents marched into Mr. Innis's office and stood behind him for a photo op, not uttering a word. Then the defenders of the First Amendment were asked to leave.
Even people at the office on other business were stunned by the spectacle. Gloria Bell arrived to see about a job but wound up being distracted by what was going on around her.
"I'm sure those boys didn't expect things to get this serious when they did what they did," said Ms. Bell, an unemployed television actress. "This is really big."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roy Innis of CORE led teen-agers in a news conference in Manhattan. The five had put a coded message of hate in their school yearbook. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PNC Buying Midlantic for $3 Billion

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
In one more sign that independent banking in New Jersey is fast becoming a thing of the past, the PNC Bank Corporation, based in Pittsburgh, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Midlantic Corporation, based in Edison, N.J., for $3 billion in stock.
Just last month, the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., announced that it would buy the First Fidelity Bancorp of Newark for $5.4 billion and create a banking empire stretching along the East Coast from Connecticut to Florida. 
 That purchase was regarded as setting off a wave of consolidation in New Jersey in particular and the Northeast in general -- areas that had largely escaped the series of mergers that created the superregional banks like Nationsbank and First Union, both in North Carolina, and Banc One in Ohio.
"New Jersey is a very affluent and very urbanized market with a tremendous amount of opportunities for a banking company, both in the commercial area with strong local businesses and in the consumer area," said Charles M. Nathan, a lawyer at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson and a former investment banker who specializes in advising financial institutions. "If you look at New Jersey, and in fact, the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states, they haven't been consolidated to the extent others have by the superregionals."
Midlantic's share price jumped $6.25 yesterday, to $47.625; PNC closed at $25.125, down $1.75.
Many analysts say that the UJB Financial Corporation of Princeton will be the next home-grown New Jersey bank to be swallowed by a superregional bank. Its share price jumped $2.625 yesterday, to $35, after the announcement by PNC.
The Summit Bancorporation, a smaller New Jersey banking company, and the Corestates Financial Corporation, which operates in New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania, are also considered prime candidates for consolidation.
"Certainly, the last two transactions indicate the major incursion by big regional banks into New Jersey," said Elizabeth Randall, the New Jersey Commissioner of Banking. "But I think that's got some potentially good ramifications for us."
She said the consolidations would bring banks with larger capital bases into the state and that might increase lending to businesses. And bigger banks, with operations spread over more regions, can better afford the investment in the latest technology for consumer banking services, Ms. Randall said.
The acquisition of Midlantic will bump PNC's ranking up one step, making it the 11th-largest United States bank, with $79 billion in assets.
It will also extend PNC's reach into the Philadelphia area and northern New Jersey, giving it the second-largest slice of those two markets. PNC, which was formed in 1982 from the merger of the Pittsburgh National Corporation and the Provident National Corporation, also has a deal pending to buy the Chemical Banking Corporation's New Jersey branches, which are concentrated in southern New Jersey.
As much as the Midlantic acquisition will strengthen PNC's power in the region, it is also a quick fix for PNC's balance sheet, bankers said yesterday. PNC has been more reliant than most banks on borrowing in the capital markets, a more expensive source of funds than deposits.
Midlantic, on the other hand, has an unusually high level of core deposits, like checking, savings and money market accounts, on which it pays a much lower interest rates than it would have to pay on money borrowed in the financial markets. Merging the two balance sheets will bring the proportion of PNC's funds that are borrowed down to 30 percent from 41 percent, Mr. O'Brien said.
"With this merger, PNC will have higher profit margins going forward and a more stable base of funds," said Joseph C. Duwan, an analyst who follows regional banks for Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
Thomas H. O'Brien, chairman and chief executive of PNC, who will keep his titles, said: "This merger creates a unique opportunity for PNC Bank to achieve several strategic objectives. It greatly expands our market share in Philadelphia and New Jersey, and it represents a major step forward in our balance sheet realignment."
The opportunity did not come at a bargain for PNC. Midlantic's shareholders will get PNC stock worth about $55.09 for each of their Midlantic shares, or more than two times Midlantic's book value of $25.93 at the end of the first quarter.
By comparison, the First Union Corporation paid 1.92 times book value last month in its bid for First Fidelity.
Investment bankers familiar with the deal said that other banks looking at Midlantic had considered making offers of about $50 a share, but PNC wanted to close a deal quickly, so it made an offer few would try to top.
Mr. O'Brien did not directly answer a question about other offers, but he did say that PNC and Midlantic had been discussing a merger "off and on" for 18 months. He also said that while the First Union-First Fidelity deal had some impact on negotiations, "that happened after we had intensified discussions."
"Because of the adjacent-market nature of this transaction and similarity of cultures at the two companies, we're going to create a tremendous amount of value," Mr. O'Brien said.
PNC plans to close as many as 70 branch banks, eliminate overlapping jobs and consolidate back-office, marketing and other functions to reduce costs by $80 million to $85 million. Job cuts "will run into the hundreds of people in a 35,000-people company, but beyond that we don't know," Mr. O'Brien said.
PNC may not, however, be able to reduce costs by as much as it expects. Midlantic, which was floundering a few years ago from troubles brought on by recession and a decline in the real estate market, has become something of a textbook turnaround for the banking industry largely because Garry J. Scheuring, its chairman, president and chief executive, took an axe to the company's costs and successfully sold off problem assets. Mr. Scheuring will become vice chairman of PNC and oversee all its consumer banking operations.
"This kind of merger represents the fundamental dilemma of the banking industry today," said Gerard L. Smith, an investment banker at UBS Securities. "They've all been pared pretty much to the bone, so it's hard to find expenses to cut. So to increase revenues, they have to start new businesses, add new products, but that increases expenses."
But Mr. O'Brien said that even though PNC would issue 113 million new shares as part of the transaction and would take a pretax charge of $190 million for merger-related expenses, the Midlantic acquisition was expected to add to earnings the first year after the deal was completed, which should occur by the end of this year. He said the acquisition was expected to add 7 cents to per-share earnings in 1996 and 20 cents in 1997.
"If we're correct, the combined company in 1996 will make a billion dollars after tax, so it's a powerful engine we have here," Mr. O'Brien said.
The acquisition of Midlantic, which has 338 branches, vastly increases PNC's network of branch banks, which it, like many other banks, has been working to reduce. In addition, PNC's deal with Chemical involves acquiring 84 branches.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Treasury Prices Finish Mostly Flat

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed in quiet trading yesterday.
Prices were supported by a strong dollar and by lingering momentum from Thursday's powerful rally. On Thursday, the Federal Reserve reduced its target for the Federal funds rate to 5.75 percent from 6 percent. The move matched the market's expectations given recent reports showing a sharp slowing of the economy. 
 But the rally was cut short on Friday and yesterday by profit taking. Traders said they needed more evidence of slowing economic growth and mild inflation before driving bond yields lower.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 3/32, to 114 15/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 6.52 percent. The yield on the two-year note was also unchanged at 5.54 percent.
"There's fair value right here; this is it," said Jack Ablin, who manages $8 billion of bonds at Bank of Boston. "What could give that yields could really get much lower than this? Inflation is pretty much in check where it is."
The Fed's willingness to cut rates will support higher Treasury prices in the weeks ahead, said Michael McGlone, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York. "I'm still bullish," he said. "The trend remains completely intact. The Fed doesn't stop with just one."
Bond prices were also helped by a stronger dollar, which prompted speculation that international investors would not exit American markets to stem foreign exchange losses, analysts said. Dollar-buying by the Fed and the Bank of Japan on Friday has bolstered the value of the dollar.
Some analysts, however, say bonds could soon fall. "The market has gotten a bit ahead of itself, anticipating more economic weakness than we've gotten," said Fred Leiner, a trading analyst at Prudential Securities in Chicago.
Bonds are not expected to move much "until we get further data that shows the economy going one way or the other," said Terrence Pigott, head trader at Daiwa Securities (America).
Reports later this week could give traders and investors more clues on whether the economy's growth is moderating enough to restrain inflation.
The Government is scheduled to report on producer prices on Thursday and on consumer prices on Friday. Producer prices probably will show a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in June, when consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, according to a survey of economists.
At the Treasury's regular weekly auction yesterday, rates on three-month and six-month bills declined. The Treasury sold $13.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.40 percent, down from 5.53 percent last week and the lowest since the bills sold for 5.35 percent on June 26.
The Treasury also $13.6 billion in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.30 percent, down from 5.46 percent, and the lowest since they averaged 5.22 percent on Sept. 26.

HEADLINE: The First Day Is a Long One at the Privatized D.M.V.

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: WAYNE, N.J., July 10

 BODY:
David Green arrived bright and early this morning at the newly privatized motor vehicle office to take the test for a truck-driver's license. His promptness did not help.
Mr. Green, of New Milford, spent an hour in line before a newly hired clerk took his application and other paperwork about 9 A.M. Then he waited for another new clerk to call his name for the start of the test. And he waited. One hour. Two hours. Three hours. Noon passed, and still no mention of his name. 
 "The paperwork is all in there," he said with a shrug and a sigh. "All you hope is it doesn't get shuffled off to the floor."
The administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman switched the Wayne agency and 22 other motor vehicle offices in New Jersey from state to private operation today in the name of efficiency and economy. But the campaign's start was hectic and bumpy across the state, with new clerks working after only a weekend of training on recognizing and processing the multitude of forms and documents for titles, licenses and registration plates.
"There's some glitches," said Bob Thompson, a Division of Motor Vehicles spokesman. "There's a learning curve. It'll keep improving."
To help ease the transition, the state had given a month's extension to all licenses and registration expiring in July and August. Despite the grace period, customers poured into the agencies as clerks struggled to learn new jobs today.
The Wayne agency and branches in North Bergen and Eatontown stopped accepting new customers at 3 P.M., 90 minutes before the regular 4:30 closing. At 3:30, backlogs forced three other agencies -- Oakland, Freehold and Jersey City -- to bar new customers.
For the Wayne agency, the first morning of privatization meant long lines, long waits and hundreds of glum and listless faces at the service counter, at the office's bank of pay phones, along its walls, and in its chairs.
It also meant traffic jams outside the building. In late morning, all parking spaces were filled and perhaps 75 cars circled the building, bumper to bumper, hunting for an open slot. Tempers frayed, shouts erupted, and Wayne police officers on Monday-moonlight duty as security guards worked to keep the peace.
At one point, the officers parked a police car across the mouth of the agency's entrance for 45 minutes. The blockade was removed about noon. But an hour later, the lot was filled again and about 25 cars spilled back onto Route 23.
Motorists lucky enough to find a parking spot after lunch entered the agency to a police lieutenant's admonition of a four-hour wait. Most Mondays, he said, the longest wait was perhaps two or two and a half hours.
"This is horrible," said Michelle Wagman of Fair Lawn, who came to get a boat registration. She wheeled her baby into the agency, took one look at the crowd, turned around and walked out. She had come to the Wayne office after refusing to wait in a crowded D.M.V office in Lodi about 15 miles away.
"It was just as bad there," she said.
Maryann Szczesny, a doctor's receptionist, took the morning off to replace the lost title for her car and was getting jittery about getting back to work after waiting nearly three hours.
"This is a nightmare," she said. "It's all very frustrating."
Robert Gillis, a service worker for a car dealer, came to get his drivers' license restored after a six-month suspension. He wound up in a long wait with a new acquaintance, Mr. Green, the applicant for the truckers' license.
"I think I got the short shaft," Mr. Gillis said. "The day I'm eligible to get the license back, they go private."
But he endorsed Governor Whitman's privatization campaign, which she says will save $4 million, and praised the new clerk who waited on him.
"If it saves money and if it's just a matter of getting through a few bugs, I'm all for it," Mr. Gillis said.
A Nutley resident, Robert Beleskie, weary from a three-and-a-half-hour wait for a boat registration, had little sympathy for privatization.
"They think they're saving tax dollars, but 300 workers with families to support are out of work, and that's no joke," he said. "I'd rather see those people working."
The state will finance the 23 newly privatized agencies the same way it does 23 other D.M.V. offices that have always been run by private agents. State money pays for each office's lease, utilities, custodial services, staff wages, health benefits and the salary of the agent who runs the office. Agents earn $42,000 a year and can receive bonuses up to $23,000 based on the number of their office's transactions.
The savings envisioned by Governor Whitman would come from lower staffing levels, lower clerks' wages, less extensive health benefits, and elimination of pension costs, state officials say.
The new private offices will have 238 clerks, 54 fewer than the 292 who staffed the agencies during state operation, officials said. The new salaries range from $14,800 to $24,200. Clerks had earned from $18,400 to $38,200 during state operation. The position of agency supervisor, which carried a maximum salary of $53,600, has been eliminated.
Of the 334 clerks laid off under privatization, 74 have been hired to the lower-paying jobs by the new private agents, Mr. Thompson said.
After privatization's bumpy start today, Mr. Thompson said officials started thinking about keeping the private agencies open longer each day and possibly on Saturdays. Asked if longer hours wouldn't consume the projected $4 million in savings, Mr. Thompson said the state "will be offering more services at reduced costs."
As privatization started, two former clerks abandoned a hunger strike they started late last week in a camper outside the State House in Trenton. "It is clear the Governor will not be moved," one of them, Andrea McGann, said in a statement.

GRAPHIC: Photo: It was the first day of operations for 23 new, private motor vehicle offices in New Jersey, as the state sought to save money with fewer and lower-paid employees in the department. In Wayne yesterday, customers jammed the first-floor offices at the agency, seeking help from new clerks and officials. (William Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Trucks, rails and airlines of the Dow transports surge on the Fed cut.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE stock market has seen the Federal Reserve cut rates, and it thinks that a recession will be avoided.
In the last three sessions after the Fed's move on Thursday to reduce the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point, stocks that are sensitive to the economy have performed much better than others. The Dow Jones transportation average, which is very economically sensitive, has surged 7.3 percent over the last three sessions, the best move over such a period since late 1991. 
 Similarly, Morgan Stanley's broadly based index of cyclical stocks has risen 4.3 percent over the period, while its index of consumer stocks, which is much less sensitive to the economy, has slipped half a percent.
The surge in the transports, which include truckers, railroads and airlines, sent that index to a new high for the first time in more than 17 months. Its gain of 51.47, or 2.8 percent, to 1,890.98 yesterday put it above the old record of 1,862.29, set Feb. 2, 1994.
As virtually every American stock index climbed to new highs this year, the Dow transports had been the most prominent laggard. But the index has leaped by more than 100 points in two sessions, with the move continuing yesterday even as the Dow industrials fell back by a fraction of a point.
Every one of the 20 stocks in the Dow transports was up yesterday.
The Fed's move on Thursday is being seen as a sign that the central bank is determined to avoid letting the economy fall into a recession, notwithstanding concerns that lower rates could damage an already weak dollar.
With the transports finally in record territory, one of the oldest of stock market indicators therefore turned bullish, albeit a bit belatedly. The Dow Theory, which traces back to Charles Dow, a founder of Dow Jones, holds that the economy and the stock market are in gear if both the industrials, which make the goods, and the transports, which move them, are both setting highs.
Until yesterday, it was possible to cite the transports as having failed to confirm the peaks being regularly set by industrials. While yesterday was the first record of the year for the transport index, the Dow industrials have set new highs 43 times, the last being on Friday.
It is the airline stocks that have led the transport index up 37.8 percent from its low last Dec. 13. Six of the 20 transport stocks are up more than 50 percent over that stretch, and five are airlines: USAir, Delta Air Lines, UAL, AMR and Southwest Airlines. The only interloper is Santa Fe Pacific, the railroad that is being acquired by Burlington Northern.
For the airlines, the good news has been evidence that they can avoid the price wars that have ravaged profits. This summer's discounts appear to have been milder than those in the past.
Some of the other transports, which depend for their profits on moving goods rather than people, have lagged. Until yesterday, Roadway Services, the trucking company, was the only one of the Dow transports to be trading below its level of last Dec. 13, when the index hit its lowest level since late 1992. But it leaped $4.375, to $52.875, making it the biggest contributor to the transport index's move yesterday.
Roadway last week reported a loss for the second quarter, through June 17, blaming "stiff pricing competition in the industry and a lackluster economy" for its problems and promising it would continue cutting costs. There was no obvious reason for yesterday's price surge, and it may represent little more than investors searching for laggards.
Most rail stocks remain below where they were in early 1994, when the index hit its most recent high, as do most truckers, but all have been rising recently, with the rails having an especially good day yesterday. Clearly, confidence in the strength of the economy is not as great as it was early last year. But equally clearly, it has been improving recently, even before the Fed move. Over the last month, the transports are up 13.7 percent, while the industrials are up 5.8 percent.
While the transports have taken longer than most other indexes to get to a new high, that reflected in large part the fact that they were hammered worst than most last year, falling 26.3 percent from their early 1994 peak to their December low. By contrast, the Dow industrials suffered a maximum loss of just 9.7 percent.
There is, of course, almost always something to cite if you want to take a negative view of the stock market's progress. Now the Dow utilities are available. That index, whose performance is quite sensitive to interest rates, peaked on Sept. 13, 1993, at 256.46, and is down 21.2 percent since then. Yesterday it fell 0.07 point, to 202.08. Early last month, it hit a 1994 peak of 209.86, but has fallen back since in what could be a sign that interest rates are not likely to fall much further. And that, too, could be seen as a sign of a strengthening economy.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Error

BYLINE: By James K. Galbraith; James K. Galbraith teaches economics at the University of Texas at Austin.

DATELINE: TOWNSHEND, Vt.

 BODY:
The Fed's reduction of one set of interest rates on Friday marked the beginning of the end of Alan Greenspan's war on inflation. The war began in February 1994 with the Fed's quarter point increase in the rates that banks charge one another for overnight loans and led to a doubling of those rates, to 6 percent from 3 percent. The financial markets expect further cuts.
The war was phony. So was the enemy. Despite nonstop fretting by Mr. Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, no serious evidence of accelerating inflation ever emerged. For the first five months of 1995, consumer prices rose at a very modest 3.6 percent annual rate. 
 The economy is more fragile than the Fed had been willing to admit. For 18 months, we have been reassured that stable growth lay ahead. But now major indicators of growth like industrial production and the sales of cars and appliances -- all battered by needlessly high interest rates -- are down.
Yes, the economy may rebound from its multiple slowdowns. Sales of new homes -- not a generally reliable indicator -- looked good in May, but most other signs are bad. On balance, the risk of recession is rising. The Fed's action showed that even its chairman had lost confidence in his earlier optimism.
The war against inflation was fought against an enemy that existed only in the imaginations and perhaps in the economic models of Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues. Yet there were casualties, as in all wars.
The middle class was hit hardest by rising adjustable-rate mortgages and the falling values of stock portfolios and pension funds most of last year, because when interest rates soar stock prices tend to fall.
The five-year Federal deficit rose by some $200 billion in prospective interest costs, reversing much of the 1993 reduction. President Clinton's credibility has been damaged, for he had promised falling deficits and lower interest rates.
The Fed should have done nothing last year. Stable and low short-term rates would have generated stronger growth, lower long-term rates, higher investment and lower deficits -- without bringing on inflation.
If the Fed's campaign was based on a potpourri of prejudices, hunches and assumptions, an excessive fear of rising inflation and an insufficient fear of rising unemployment, then the operating methods and the biases of the decision-makers must be questioned.
The Fed's analytic methods are dubious. It has underrated fundamental changes in the economy, and it still places too much weight on the hoary assumption that inflation will rise if unemployment falls below 6 percent. (It is currently 5.6 percent.)
The Fed's economists apparently failed to predict that wages would stand still. Since wages are always the largest element of costs, stagnating wages mean fairly stable, not inflating, prices.
There has been no increase in average wages despite falling unemployment, which reflects an increased demand for labor. Why this stagnation? One big reason is the decline of unions. Another is intense competition from imports from low-wage countries.
When Mr. Greenspan next appears before Congress, he should be pressed for a full accounting of the forecasts and the theories underlying the needless war.
Congress should request the full records of Fed meetings and supporting analyses so that it and outside experts can try to understand what went wrong. And when President Clinton nominates his next candidate for the Fed's board, he and Congress should insist on a new spirit of openness in Fed deliberations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs, Still Benefiting From U.S.-Japan Intervention

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed against other leading currencies yesterday, continuing to benefit from Friday's intervention by the United States and Japan.
The Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan surprised traders on Friday, buying dollars for yen as the dollar was rising. Generally over the last few years the world's central banks have bought dollars only when the currency was falling. 
 "They're catching the market at surprising times," said Steve Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "There's no doubt they're looking to push this dollar higher."
The surprise intervention "puts the market on alert that there is some risk to selling the dollar," Mr. Flanagan said. The fear of selling dollars also supported the value of the dollar against other currencies.
Against the German mark, the dollar was also bolstered by mounting speculation that the Bundesbank would follow the Fed and the Bank of Japan by cutting interest rates when its policy-setting council meets on Thursday.
Although the dollar's gains were pared late in the day, many traders said they remained optimistic about the currency's prospects over the next several days. "Over all, the market still has bullish sentiment toward the dollar," said Jeffrey Yu, senior currency dealer at the Sanwa Bank in New York.
The dollar rose as high as 87.59 yen, its highest level against the Japanese currency since May 22. In late New York trading, it was quoted at 86.88 yen, up from 86.76 yen on Friday. The dollar rose to 1.3949 German marks from 1.3925 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5939 from $1.5951.
The dollar-buying spree by the Fed and the Bank of Japan followed the Fed's cut in short-term interest rates on Thursday by a quarter of a percentage point. Typically, lower interest rates weaken a country's currency by reducing the return on investments.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
In a Season of Discontent, Japan Hails a Conquering Hero

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 10

 BODY:
When Hideo Nomo, a star pitcher for Japan's Kintetsu Buffaloes, decided some months back to leave his team and try to make it in the American major leagues, he was regarded by some people here as almost a traitor to Japanese baseball.
But when Hideo Nomo, Los Angeles Dodger and National League strikeout king, takes the mound as his league's starting pitcher in Tuesday's All-Star Game, his countrymen back home will be rooting for him as a new hero. For by leaving Japan and showing that a Japanese player can succeed in America, Nomo has given a bigger boost to the reputation of Japanese baseball than he ever could have done by staying. 
 In the process, Nomo has provided Japan a needed lift in a year that has brought nothing but bad news -- a killer earthquake, poison gas in the subways, a religious cult, a soaring yen, a slumping economy and more nasty trade disputes with the United States. His success has inspired a rabid following among Japanese citizens, while also raising concern that other top Japanese players will follow him to the United States, a clear sign of the respect he has earned for baseball in this country.
"Until now it's been said that Japanese baseball is inferior," said Hajimu Tamaki, a writer for Nikkan Sports, a Japanese sports newspaper. "For a Japanese player to play equally among the Americans is an honor."
Major league scouts are now searching here for the next Nomo. "All of a sudden, they don't consider it little-league baseball any longer," said Marty Kuehnert, a sports broadcaster here who is part owner of the Birmingham Barons, an American minor league team.
The result has been Nomo fever in Japan. People have been gathering on street corners in Tokyo and other cities to watch the 26-year-old and his trademark tornado-like delivery on giant television screens. The screens were set up in public places by NHK, the public broadcasting corporation, which has been broadcasting Nomo's games live on one of its satellite channels. Both NHK's satellite channel and a commercial television station will broadcast the All-Star Game live, at 9 A.M. Wednesday Japan time.
To those for whom the television is not enough, Japan Travel Bureau, a large travel agency, has begun offering "Dodgers Watching" tours to Los Angeles. The tours include a round-trip flight, three nights in a hotel, a game at Dodger Stadium (hot dog included), and side trips to Disneyland and other attractions. Prices range from $1,250 to $2,700.
At the Major League Baseball Japan Shop in Tokyo, customers have been snapping up Nomo caps, shirts and other merchandise. About 40 people waited outside the store before it opened last Saturday, when a new shipment of Nomo goods arrived, said a store official, Hisao Kanayama.
If this were international trade, it would be a rare area in which the United States would be running a surplus with Japan. There have been dozens of exports of American players to Japan. But until Nomo there was only one other Japanese import into the major leagues -- Masanori Murakami, who pitched for the San Francisco Giants in 1964 and 1965.
Japan has responded to this trade imbalance in just the way it had said it would never do in the recent automobile trade talks -- by setting quotas. There can be no more than three foreigners on a Japanese team and no more than three on each all-star team.
Nomo, whose first name actually means "hero," is not the first Japanese player to achieve fame by beating the Americans at their own game. In the first baseball games ever between Japanese and Americans -- in 1898 -- a ragtag American team made up of merchants, traders and missionaries living in Yokohama was repeatedly trounced by a Japanese preparatory school team that trained so intensively that its players were said to urinate blood at the end of a practice.
According to "You Gotta Have Wa," a book by Robert Whiting about Japanese baseball, the school's pitcher, Kotaro Moriyama, became such a celebrity that he spawned a popular saying: "To be hit by Moriyama's fastball is an honor exceeded only by being crushed under the wheels of the imperial carriage."
In 1934, 18-year-old Eiji Sawamura, facing a team of American stars touring Japan, struck out Charlie Gehringer, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Jimmie Foxx in succession.
Nomo had been a stellar pitcher in Japan's Pacific League since his debut in 1990, when he was named most valuable player and best pitcher as well as rookie of the year. But last year he had a poor season in which he won only eight games and was plagued by arm trouble. That seemed to bode ill for his chances in the United States.
"Frankly speaking, no one imagined such a great achievement," said Masaru Ikei, a professor of political science at Keio University and a self-described "crazy" baseball fan.
One Japanese manager predicted Nomo would fail because he threw too many "foa boru" or "four balls," the Japanese term for walks. Control has indeed been a problem for Nomo, but not a fatal one, as testified to by his 1.99 earned run average and 6-1 record.
Now there is some worry that other players, prompted by Nomo's success, will seek fame and fortune in the United States.
Pitchers are considered the best candidates. "The top 20 pitchers here are all major league standard or above," said Bobby Valentine, the former Texas Ranger manager, who now manages Japan's Chiba Lotte Marines. Players at other positions are not as strong, he and others said, in part because they lack the power for bigger American ball parks.
Some Japanese players have said they would like to play in the United States. But it might be difficult for Japanese players to cross the Pacific Ocean because Japanese contracts are very strict. Free agency is a new concept in Japan and applies only to veterans of 10 years.
The commissioners of baseball in Japan and the United States have an agreement that controls trans-Pacific raiding. Even if a player were to retire from Japanese baseball and move to the United States, an American team could not hire him without first getting permission from the player's old Japanese team, said Masaru Madate, assistant director of baseball operations in the Japanese commissioner's office.
In Nomo's case, the Buffaloes let him go after his bad season and after arguments over his demands for a multiyear contract, something that is extremely rare in Japan. Many other teams and commentators criticized Kintetsu for setting a bad precedent by letting its prime property go without even demanding a payment from the Dodgers.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Science Desk

HEADLINE: Prairie Dog Colonies Bolster Life in the Plains

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: BADLANDS NATIONAL PARK, S.D.

 BODY:
A RISING sun was just beginning to illuminate the harsh beauty of the Badlands when an early-rising prairie dog emerged from one of thousands of small dirt mounds decorating a swale of the Great Plains. By midmorning the ground was alive with the golden-tan, foot-long rodents, which are only now becoming recognized as an ecologically crucial species with uncommon power to affect the lives and surroundings of other creatures.
"Look at that landscape out there," said Dr. Glenn E. Plumb, the wildlife biologist for Badlands National Park, as he gazed out across the prairie-dog town. "That's a real concentration of biological activity, a lot of complex nature." 
 Its verdant carpet produces more new growth in a given year than is produced in similarly sized patches of the surrounding plains, attracting a crowd of plant and seed eaters from insects to mice to birds to bison. Predators like hawks, coyotes and bug-eating birds follow.
The prairie dogs, as architects and custodians of their immediate environment, are largely responsible for this concentration of life. Their constant cropping of vegetation stimulates faster and more nutritious growth, while their burrows provide homes and hunting grounds for many organisms, large and small. The resulting patches of habitat make the Plains ecosystem more complex, diverse and biologically active than it would otherwise be.
Dozens of vertebrate species may depend on prairie-dog colonies to one degree or another, some scientists believe. At least one species, the black-footed ferret, cannot survive without them. As the prairie dog goes, conservation biologists say, so may go a raft of other creatures; save prairie dogs and you may also save a sizable and particularly valuable slice of the Plains ecosystem. This late-blooming realization -- that prairie dogs may be what ecologists call a "keystone" species -- is pushing the prairie dog into the forefront of conservation concern for the first time.
Prairie dogs have long been viewed, particularly by urban dwellers, as the epitome of cute. The scene here a few days ago was typical. When the animals emerged from their dens, some touched teeth in "kisses" of recognition. They romped, rolled, wrestled and chased each other around. They assiduously tended their burrows, dirt flying from their busy paws, bundles of grass for lining underground nests drooping from their mouths.
Many stood watch, erect and alert, scanning the countryside for unwelcome guests like coyotes, hawks or people. A few executed a comically winsome maneuver called the jump-yip display: standing upright, the animal throws its head back and its forefeet high in the air. The movement is accompanied by a sharp half-whistle, half-squeak that rises in pitch and then falls off again. Some experts think it is a territorial gesture, but it looks like nothing so much as an expression of joy.
Despite such charming and popular behavior, prairie dogs have for more than a century been generally regarded by humans who share their home range as noxious pests that ruin grazing land and must be exterminated. Billions have been poisoned over the decades, and the poisoning continues today with aid from both state and Federal governments.
When the Sioux ruled these parts, as many as 100 million acres, or 20 percent of the land area of the Plains, may have been covered by prairie-dog colonies. Today, although two of five North American species are imperiled, hundreds of thousands of the rodents remain, which may help explain the previous lack of conservation concern. The black-tailed variety that lives hereabouts is the most widespread. Formerly endangered, it made a comeback after the most devastating forms of poison were banned in the 1970's and is no longer in jeopardy.
But conservation biologists say that the land area covered by prairie-dog colonies has been reduced by 98 percent since pre-settlement times. As the prairie dog's ecological role becomes clearer, this continuing loss of habitat is raising alarms about the future of less abundant species whose existence is tied to its colonies. These include the burrowing owl, which lives in prairie-dog burrows; the mountain plover, which prefers the close-cropped surface growth of prairie-dog towns, and, most notably, the black-footed ferret. The ferret, which dines almost exclusively on prairie dogs and also inhabits their burrows, is so endangered that it has had to be bred in captivity and is now being reintroduced in several places, including the Badlands.
"The trends are pretty clear, and if those trends continue, we're going to lose a lot of these species if something isn't done," said Dr. Tim W. Clark, a Yale University conservation biologist based in Jackson, Wyo. Dr. Clark was one of several scientists who explored the subject at a meeting of the Society for Conservation Biology last month in Fort Collins, Colo.
For all their air of fun, frolic and industry, prairie dogs -- not dogs at all but a variety of ground squirrel -- live in a violent and unforgiving world. They are continually beset by predators of one kind or another. The defense strategy they have evolved lies at the heart of their ecological role.
By organizing themselves in colonies and living underground, they have set up a cooperative detection-and-escape network against attack by surface and aerial predators. Any human visitor can easily see it in action, although tourists who stop at roadside pullouts on the edges of prairie-dog towns might well miss it. Prairie dogs living near the pullouts have become so habituated to humans that one can approach to within two or three feet. Biologists call these animals "Twinkie dogs," after the pastry confection to which they have sometimes presumably been treated.
But move just a little farther into the colony, and things change. Soon one prairie dog issues a warning call, a high-pitched "chirk" that it repeats incessantly, head and little black-tipped tail jerking in what looks like indignation. Others take up the call, starting a chain reaction of noise that rises in pitch, volume and speed of repetition if the intruder walks faster. Soon there is bedlam. One by one, all the animals dive into their burrows as the intruder approaches. When the danger has passed, it is high time for the jump-yip display.
The defense system is extremely efficient. "In 22 years, I have seen a mere 22" successful above-ground predations, said Dr. John L. Hoogland, a behavioral ecologist at the University of Maryland, who has studied prairie dogs extensively at Wind Cave National Park near here. He is the author of a new book, "The Black-Tailed Prairie Dog: Social Life of a Burrowing Mammal" (University of Chicago Press).
But the system has its drawbacks. Predators like snakes and badgers find the burrows little or no hindrance, and lethal black-widow spiders often take up residence in burrow entrances. The black-footed ferret, a nocturnal predator about half the size of a prairie dog, slips easily into burrows and exacts an especially grisly toll: it locks its teeth on the throat of its prey, strangles the victim, and then eats it bones and all -- except for the feet.
In some densely packed colonies, prairie dogs express a dark side of their own. In the spring, after babies are born, many mothers go on an orgy of infanticide, killing and often eating the offspring of others. They do it to reduce competition for food, and possibly also to get an extra shot of protein at nursing time, Dr. Hoogland said, adding, "It is a real slaughterhouse for four to six weeks."
Whatever the trade-offs for the prairie dogs, the big byproduct of the colony-based defense system is its impact on the Plains ecosystem, which in this region is dominated by grasses of short and medium length, as distinguished from the tallgrass prairies farther east. (Prairie dogs do not live in these eastern prairies, presumably because they cannot function well in the taller grass.)
The most obvious ecological effect arises from the burrows themselves, which attract a concentration of predators, underground-living invertebrates and other tenants like the burrowing owl. A shy bird about the size of a pigeon, it can sometimes be observed here at a distance, posted near a prairie dog on its burrow mound. (The owls do not eat prairie dogs, but batten instead on smaller prey.)
More subtle is the impact of the prairie dogs' "mowing" of the land. In foraging, as well as in creating a better view of approaching predators, the rodents clip all vegetation to within three or four inches of the surface. This changes the temperature and moisture content of the soil, encouraging some plant varieties to replace others; broad-leafed, nonwoody plants like wildflowers and legumes take over from grasses, for instance. The constant cropping also makes plants more nutritious and digestible by eliminating the decline in nutrition and roughness that come with aging. And the more rapid plant growth and recycling of energy inherent in a regime of constant grazing simply increases the amount of vegetation over time.
"Things happen quicker in a prairie-dog colony," explained Dr. April D. Whicker, a wildlife biologist with the National Biological Service in Fort Collins, who has long studied the ecological role of prairie dogs. "Although at any one time there is less biomass, overall productivity is higher."
Naturally enough, this accelerated energy machine attracts more plant-eaters, from herbivorous insects to pronghorn antelope and bison, both of which tend to hang around prairie-dog colonies in summer. The antelope are drawn by the succulent forage, while bison come both for the eating and for a place to rest and take dust baths to shed parasites.
Some studies have suggested that yearling bison that feed randomly and intermittently in a prairie-dog town gain 14 percent more weight than if they feed elswhere. The gain is 46 percent higher, the studies suggest, if the yearlings feed regularly in colonies.
Other studies have found that the total density of animal life, apart from prairie dogs, is higher where colonies exist. Some species are especially abundant: deer mice, grasshopper mice, horned larks and some species of grasshoppers, for instance. Badgers, coyotes, swift foxes, golden eagles, bobcats and hawks are drawn to the colonies by the abundance of prey, including the prairie dogs.
While as many as 170 vertebrate species are said to appear in prairie-dog towns, it is not yet clear how many are significantly dependent on the colonies. Clarifying this picture is one purpose of a four-year study on which Dr. Whicker and two other National Biological Service scientists, Dr. Bruce Baker and Dr. Tasha Kotliar, are working.
Conservation biologists are especially concerned that although prairie dogs still exist throughout their historic range, the colonies are smaller, fewer and more fragmented. One fear is that because colonies are so widely separated and so hemmed in by farms and ranches, the overall colony system will slowly disintegrate.
Each colony has a life cycle; eventually, the vegetation plays out under intense grazing. Historically, prairie dogs simply moved to new ground, leaving the abandoned territory to recover its vegetation. Now, it is feared, they may not be able to do so as easily. And given the wide separation between colonies, it may not be possible for relatively immobile animals like the tiger salamander, which has adapted to the colony habitat, to move to a new colony.
Another concern is the threat posed by plague, which is believed to have been introduced from Asia early in this century. Once established in a colony, the plague organism, which is passed from one rodent to another by fleas, kills almost all the prairie dogs living there. A number of colonies have been ravaged in recent years, mostly in the Southwest. Since 1970, according to a laboratory of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Fort Collins, 16 cases of plague in humans have been associated with prairie-dog contact. The disease responds to antibiotics.
The biggest difficulty, from the standpoint of conservationists, may be human attitudes. Though not all ranchers are unsympathetic to prairie dogs and ecological concerns, the view of the prairie dog as a pest to be exterminated is by all accounts still dominant in the West.
Cattle ranching operates on a thin economic margin, and any grazing land that is not fully productive is a liability. Ranchers commonly insist that productivity is reduced when prairie dogs compete with cattle for forage. Some conservationists argue that if the forage is sufficient for bison, it ought to be sufficient for cattle. But the jury is out on this. Dr. Whicker says that what applies in the wild, where wildlife populations are below the carrying capacity of the ecosystem, may not apply in the case of higher-density cattle herds.
National parks like this one may provide the best sanctuary for prairie-dog habitat, with other public lands second. But national forests, national grasslands and lands owned by the Bureau of Land Management are open to grazing, and much contention surrounds their use. In one area comparatively rich in prairie-dog colonies, on bureau lands in Montana, the Government and local ranchers have agreed to maintain overall prairie-dog occupation at 1988 levels.
Many conservation biologists see the struggle to reach some accommodation between the interests of the Plains economy and its natural ecology as critical. Some Federal land managers committed to ecosystem protection worry that Congressional pressure to weaken or gut the Endangered Species Act may remove their main tool for forging such compromises. Protecting the endangered ferret, in this view, has been the key to protecting prairie-dog colonies.
"To be frank," said one land manager, "if there wasn't public land and the Endangered Species Act, we wouldn't be in the prairie dog or ferret business. They'd be gone."
