HEADLINE: OPENING TO VIETNAM;
Clinton on Recognition: A Move 'to Common Ground'

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Following are excerpts of President Clinton's announcement today establishing full diplomatic relations between the United States and Vietnam:
Today, I am announcing the normalization of diplomatic relationships with Vietnam. 
 From the beginning of this Administration, any improvement in relationships between America and Vietnam has depended upon making progress on the issue of Americans who were missing in action or held as prisoners of war. Last year, I lifted the trade embargo on Vietnam in response to their cooperation and to enhance our efforts to secure the remains of lost Americans and to determine the fate of those whose remains had not been found.
It has worked. In 17 months Hanoi has taken important steps to help us resolve many cases. Twenty-nine families have received the remains of their loved ones, and at last have been able to give them the proper burial. Hanoi has delivered to us hundreds of pages of documents shedding light on what happened to Americans in Vietnam, and Hanoi has stepped up its cooperation with Laos, where many Americans were lost. We have reduced the number of so-called "discrepancy cases," in which we have had reason to believe that Americans were still alive after they were lost, to 55, and we will continue to work to resolve more cases. . . .
Our strategy is working. Normalization of relations is the next appropriate step. With this new relationship, we will be able to make more progress. To that end, I will send another delegation to Vietnam this year. Vietnam has pledged it will continue to help us find answers. We will hold them to that pledge.
By helping to bring Vietnam into the community of nations, normalization also serves our interest in working for a free and peaceful Vietnam in a stable and peaceful Asia . . .
Our policy will be to implement the appropriate United States government programs to develop trade with Vietnam, consistent with United States law. As you know, many of these programs require certifications regarding human rights and labor rights before they can proceed. . . . The Secretary of State will go to Vietnam in August where he will discuss all of these issues, beginning with our P.O.W. and M.I.A. concerns.
I believe normalization and increased contact between Americans and Vietnamese will advance the cause of freedom in Vietnam just as it did Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. I strongly believe that engaging the Vietnamese on the broad economic front of economic reform, and the broad front of democratic reform, will help to honor the sacrifice of those who fought for freedom's sake in Vietnam. . . .
This step will also help our own country to move forward on an issue that has separated Americans from one another for too long now. Let the future be our destination. We have so much work ahead of us. This moment offers us the opportunity to bind up our own wounds. They have resisted time for too long. We can now move on to common ground. Whatever divided us before, let us consign to the past. Let this moment in the words of Scripture, "Be a time to heal, and a time to build." Thank you all. And God bless America.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: OPENING TO VIETNAM: IN CALIFORNIA;
For Many of Those Who Fled Vietnam, a Day of Sadness, Anger and Hope

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: WESTMINSTER, Calif., July 11

 BODY:
For Yen Do, editor of the largest Vietnamese-language daily in America, the establishment today of diplomatic relations between Hanoi and Washington marks the end of a half century of war that has tortured his nation and scattered two million of its people around the world.
It welcomes Vietnam into the community of nations, opens new possibilities for its economic development and may help efforts to foster democracy and human rights after 20 years of Communist rule, said Mr. Yen, who edits Nguoi Viet Daily News here in the community known as Little Saigon, 30 miles south of Los Angeles. 
 But for Mr. Yen and many of his fellow refugees, the day was nevertheless colored by sadness, symbolically laying to rest the homeland they fought for, whose yellow-and-red flag is still flown by overseas Vietnamese groups.
"It is something like a pair of lovers who know it is time to leave each other," he said. "Reasonably, rationally, they know the time has come, but emotionally it is hard to accept."
Among many overseas Vietnamese, the sadness found expression in angry words.
"I feel very angry and bitter, but then, it's very clear that business interests have been put in front of human rights," said Diem Do, who has been a leading opponent of normalized relations in the highly fragmented emigre community.
Tran Van Ngoc, past president of the Vietnamese Air Force Veterans Association, said he saw the move as a cynical attempt to use Vietnam once again as a geopolitical pawn against Chinese expansion.
Mai Cong, who heads the Vietnamese Community of Orange County, a private social and cultural agency here, issued a statement saying, "It is as if a decisive step has been taken to sever us from the past, or from any lingering attachment with the past, even though the past only means war and misery for many of us."
She added: "There may be joy in Hanoi, but there certainly will be no celebrations in Little Saigon."
And on Little Saigon Radio, which interrupted its Vietnamese-language broadcasts to carry President Clinton's announcement live this morning, the news was immediately followed by interviews with non-Vietnamese opponents of normalization, who said things like, "I truly believe that this is one of the blackest days in the history of America."
In the three hours following the announcement, 32 callers to an open line at the radio station opposed the reestablishment of relations, while just 13 supported it, said Trang Nguyen, president of Little Saigon TV and Radio.
Since the fall of Saigon in April 1975, some 800,000 refugees have fled to the United States, many clustering in Vietnamese communities like this one where the question of whether to open business and diplomatic contacts with Hanoi created sometimes violent divisions but also helped to define emigre politics and discourse.
For years, right-wing groups collected donations for a fantasy guerrilla war that would succeed where the Americans had failed. Journalists and others who advocated improved relations with Vietnam were attacked and, on a handful of occasions, were killed.
Opposition to improved relations with Hanoi has been kept alive by the recent arrival of about 10,000 former labor camp prisoners, mostly elderly men whose lives have been consumed by the war and its harsh aftermath and who could be counted on to join anti-Communist demonstrations here.
But in recent years, particularly after President Clinton lifted a trade embargo in February 1994, an increasing flood of emigre Vietnamese tourists and entrepreneurs has visited Vietnam, crossing paths with the final trickle of postwar refugees.
Twenty years after Saigon's fall -- and 50 years after the start of the war against the colonial French government that preceded Washington's involvement -- many Vietnamese here say the passage of history has made the debate over normalization as anachronistic as the continuing departure of refugees.
"I think it is good that we finally can put everything behind us and move ahead, and for the community to concentrate on the problems at hand," said Le Kim Dinh, a journalist and writer.
There are signs that that might be happening. On Monday, on the eve of Mr. Clinton's announcement, 10 groups from among the many feuding emigre factions signed a resolution urging Washington to press Hanoi on two substantive issues that overseas Vietnamese agree on: democratization and human rights.
And in a signal that they might leave their political isolation and join mainstream politics, the groups also called for strong action on an issue of greater interest to non-Vietnamese Americans: the search for missing American servicemen.
"In the past, it was all divisiveness," said Mrs. Nguyen. "People were all calling each other Communists. Now they can unite on real issues, and from now on they will have some real doors to knock on. They can protest directly at the Vietnamese Embassy and consular offices."
Mr. Yen said he foresaw other benefits from normalized diplomatic relations. Many former South Vietnamese officials and high-ranking military men who feared revisiting Vietnam may now feel safe in doing so, given the protection of an American Embassy.
In addition, he said, today's announcement could result in the freeing of some political prisoners who have been held because of Hanoi's fears of outside threats.
Some other Vietnamese-Americans were aggressively eager to move ahead both with their integration into American society and their business ventures in Vietnam.
Frank Jao, a leading developer who owns much of the property in Little Saigon and is exploring business opportunities in Vietnam, rejected any talk of the past.
"Speaking in the context of being an American businessman -- nothing to do with Vietnamese-American, because I am no longer a Vietnamese -- it's good for the United States," he said of today's developments. "It is good for business in the United States of America."
And T. T. Nhu, a Vietnamese-American who is a columnist for The San Jose Mercury News, said she was glad to be able to move on to other issues.
"I've almost run out of things to say," she said. "Thank God we are at the end of the road. This should have happened in 1945. It's all been so unnecessary. What a waste of life. What a tragedy it has all been."

HEADLINE: OPENING TO VIETNAM: IMPLICATIONS;
Finally, Opening the Door All the Way

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The wonder is not that the United States is establishing normal diplomatic relations with Hanoi, two full decades after the fall of Saigon; the wonder is that it took so long.
Presidents have come and gone since those final apocalyptic scenes of a long, wretched war -- the American Ambassador fleeing from Saigon with the embassy's flag folded under his arm, the fevered scramble for the last seats on the last helicopter out. Neither Gerald R. Ford nor Jimmy Carter nor Ronald Reagan nor George Bush could bring himself to recognize the government that Washington had demonized for so long, though Bush started down the path. 
 Instead, fate chose an unlikely pair of men: Bill Clinton, liberal Democrat, who like many thousands of his contemporaries managed to avoid fighting in a war that never won the full-hearted support of the American people, and John McCain, conservative Republican, son and grandson of admirals, who not only fought as a Navy pilot, but, shot down, spent more than five years in an enemy prison camp.
President Clinton provided the political impetus, Senator McCain of Arizona the political cover without which Mr. Clinton might have feared to act.
There were other key players as well, notably American business, eager for its share of the riches that Vietnam, its talented people and its offshore waters seem to promise, and American diplomats, who see friendship with Vietnam as an important asset for the United States as it seeks to counter Chinese influence in Asia.
The conventional explanation for the delay was the difficulty in accounting for the Americans still carried on military rolls as missing in action. According to the Pentagon, there are 2,202 of them if you count all of Southeast Asia, 1,618 if you count only Vietnam. Of that total, only 55, by official tally, are known to have been seen alive in captivity at some stage.
But the real reason lay much deeper within the national consciousness.
Far, far more Americans are listed as missing in the Korean War (8,170) and in World War II (78,750). Yet no one ever suggested it would be possible to account for more than a handful of them -- not to mention the hundreds of thousands of north and south Vietnamese whose fate remains unknown.
A few years after World War II, the United States was engaged in huge rebuilding efforts in Germany and Japan, even though Germans had killed millions of Jews and Japanese had tortured prisoners on a vast scale.
The difference, of course, is that the United States lost in Vietnam. It is never easy for the big guy to shake hands after losing the fight to the little guy, especially when he has never lost before, and so it was after the Vietnam War. The open wound of defeat was salved, for some Americans, by continuing to regard the Hanoi Government as an evil, outlaw, untouchable regime.
The resentment over the loss of so many American lives and the stunting of so many others, combined with the unresolved confusion and controversy over the purpose of the war itself, made it possible for the relatives and friends of some of the missing Americans to delay, but not ultimately to prevent, this last acknowledgment that the war is truly over, that it is time, as President Clinton suggested today, to move beyond "the haunting and painful past."
Not everyone will agree, of course. A group called "The Last Firebase," composed of veterans and relatives of the missing, said that "today will forever be known by America's veterans as Black Tuesday." The American Legion opposed the decision, and so did Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the leading contender for the Republican Presidential nomination next year.
It was "a strategic, diplomatic and moral mistake to grant Vietnam the stamp of approval from the U.S. Government," Senator Dole asserted.
But the most recent survey of American opinion suggests strongly that he and other critics of the President are in a distinct minority. A new CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll shows 61 percent of the public backing recognition and only 27 percent opposing it.
Mr. McCain's support is invaluable to Mr. Clinton, because he is by far the best known of the survivors of the infamous "Hanoi Hilton." He not only endorsed the President's action but said "it required some courage."
So is the backing of Jan Scruggs, who was wounded in Vietnam and later sparked the creation of the black granite Vietnam Veterans Memorial wall here. His comment was laconic: "The war is over, so let's be friends." And so is the backing of some veterans' groups, like the Veterans of Foreign Wars.
It may be that many Republican primary voters, a more conservative subset of the more conservative party, are more opposed to Mr. Clinton's action than are Americans as a whole. Mr. Dole's stance may play well with them.
But the steps along this road that Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton took earlier, including the lifting last year of a 19-year embargo on trade with Vietnam, failed to produce the groundswell of protest that the die-hards predicted. And Vietnam is now clearly a land of opportunities, which will inevitably draw much more American investment and many more visits by American tourists.
As a web of everyday political and economic links grows between the United States and Vietnam, as more and more Americans come to know Vietnam at peace, the old passions, already nearly spent for most Americans, will seem increasingly irrelevant. Normality is the enemy of grudges and hatreds.
At any rate, the deed is done. Congressional threats to withhold money for an American embassy in Hanoi are likely to come to nothing. Mr. Clinton acted just as the question of full diplomatic ties was beginning to be sucked into the vortex of the 1996 campaign. He could not have waited much longer, and by moving now, he may benefit from looking resolute on a tough issue.
Reminiscing this morning with a reporter he has known since the days of air raids over Hanoi and ground combat in the Central Highlands, Senator McCain commented that he was determined that his generation not leave a legacy of anger and vindictiveness.
"I got over the war about 45 minutes after the plane bringing me home took off from Hanoi," he said. "But not everyone feels that way. Some people hate me for backing this, call me the Manchurian Candidate, say I'm a collaborator, the most awful stuff. There will always be people like that, but fewer and fewer. Not many people talk about the dirty Japs anymore."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Executives Praise Recognition of Vietnam
American business executives hailed the Clinton Administration's decision to extend full diplomatic recognition to Vietnam as a step toward putting them on equal footing with foreign competitors there. But they said that the diplomatic move alone would not unleash an investment boom because a foundation for normal trade relations between the two countries does not now exist. One trade group urged the Clinton Administration to move quickly to negotiate a trade agreement with Hanoi. [Page A9.]
 
Market Drifts to a Loss
In what analysts called a drifting market, stocks pulled back as many traders sold issues that have had strong run-ups this year. The Dow fell 21.79 points, to 4,680.60. [D8.]
 
The dollar climbed against leading currencies on expectations that the German central bank would cut interest rates. The dollar rose to 1.4065 marks and to 87.54 yen. [D15.]
 
Consumer Borrowing Rises
The Federal Reserve said consumer borrowing increased to $11.51 billion in May, the 24th consecutive month it has risen, led by strong credit-card use. [D3.]
 
Marketer to Head Cordiant
Cordiant, the agency holding company, named Robert L. Seelert, who has led companies that market brands like Maxwell House and No Nonsense, as chief executive. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Motorola Earnings Up 31%
Motorola said that its net income rose 31 percent in the second quarter, to $481 million, and that it had resolved a nagging problem of bulging cellular telephone inventories. [D3.]
 
Russia's First Hostile Bid
Bank Menatep, one of Russia's largest banks, made an unprecedented hostile offer for a controlling interest in the Red October candy company, arguably Russia's favorite chocolatier. [D4.]
 
U.P.S. Pact With J. C. Penney
United Parcel Service has agreed to a five-year, $1 billion contract to become the preferred carrier for J. C. Penney's small-package air deliveries. [D3.]
 
New Chief for Burger King
Grand Metropolitan reached within its own executive ranks and named Robert C. Lowes as chief executive of Burger King. Mr. Lowes had been the Paris-based chief executive of the European food operations of Grand Met, which is Burger King's parent. [D2.]
 
AT&T in Internet Deal
AT&T is expected to announce today that it will spend $8 million to buy a stake in the BBN Planet Corporation, one of the largest corporate Internet access providers. [D3.]
 
Contractor Charged in Fraud
A New York City contractor, whose company was a subsidiary of American Express, has been charged with bilking major corporations out of more than $7 million. [B3.]
 
Venezuelan Gold-Mining Boom
Harnessing free-market policies and looser environmental rules, and driven by recession, Venezuela is among the leaders of a Latin American boom in mining investment. [D4.]
 
Report on Travel Crime
A recent report shows that the crime rate against adult American travelers is 40 percent less than the rate for Americans in general. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Black Caucus Tells the President of Its Fears for Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
President Clinton met with the Congressional Black Caucus today to hear its concerns on affirmative action, voting rights and the Federal budget and said that next week he would announce the results of his long-awaited review of Federal preference programs that are based on race and sex.
The 80-minute meeting in the State Dining Room of the White House, the President's first with the group this year, was a sensitive one because many black officials adamantly oppose any effort to scale back job and contracting programs intended to redress past discrimination, or basing them on financial need instead of race. 
 But a recent Supreme Court ruling has sharply limited the Administration's flexibility and prompted the Justice Department to issue new guidelines for evaluating Federal affirmative action programs, ones that may make many harder to justify legally. So caucus members leaving the meeting exhibited a certain air of resignation.
While taking pains to note that Mr. Clinton had not elaborated on the Administration's plans in any detail, the caucus chairman, Representative Donald M. Payne, Democrat of New Jersey, said, "I'd be surprised and disappointed if it was something we couldn't live with."
Mr. Payne said that the group had voiced its concerns to Mr. Clinton but that "one of the problems is we don't have as much contact with him as we should." Members of the group have met with Mr. Clinton and senior White House officials in recent months, but the group as an entity has not met with the President since last year.
Even such an occasionally sharp critic of the President as Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, was low-key.
Mr. Rangel said the President had offered "some vague words" about his coming proposal "that allowed us to believe it would not cause us undue ill feelings toward him, but obviously it's not going to be everything we want to hear."
Caucus members and White House aides said Mr. Clinton had said little about his own views, preferring to listen. The White House is still trying to decide where Mr. Clinton should deliver his long-promised speech on the issue. Aides said he would give the speech on July 19 somewhere in the Washington area.
Mr. Clinton ordered the review last winter, after Congressional Republicans vowed to scale back preference programs. Several times, the President or top aides suggested that he would prefer to see programs broadly based on redressing economic inequities where possible, and they have described the intent of the review as preserving programs that are necessary and effective while curbing those that are not.
For weeks, the White House suggested that the review might be completed at any time, but delays persisted, and the Administration's position was ultimately both simplified and complicated by the Supreme Court's ruling on June 12 in Adarand Constructors Inc. v. Pena. In that case, the Court held that any Federal program classifying people by race could be considered constitutional only if it was "narrowly tailored" to serve a compelling governmental interest. The Court had long applied that standard to state affirmative action programs but had given the Federal Government far more leeway.
Under new Justice Department guidelines, the Administration considers programs whose sole rationale is promoting diversity to be legally suspect, and officials have said a number of programs, especially business set-asides that reserve a specific percentage of contracts for minorities, would have trouble passing that test.
Mr. Rangel said it would be politically unwise for the President to back away from a commitment to redressing discrimination. That, he said, would be "a very dangerous thing to do" when Mr. Clinton needs the active support of traditional Democratic constituencies like blacks. "He didn't disagree with that," Mr. Rangel said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Pull Back, With Dow Falling 21.79 Points

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market pulled back yesterday, with many traders taking profits in issues that have had strong run-ups this year.
"It was a drifting market," said Robert N. Gordon, president of Twenty-First Securities Corporation. "Selling was predominant all day, but it wasn't anything major. A real correction would have been a lot more." 
 After the market closed, the Federal Reserve announced that consumer borrowing in May rose at a faster pace than economists had expected. Consumer installment credit gained $11.5 billion for the month, led by heavy credit card use and marking the 24th straight monthly increase. Some analysts believe that this continuing spree might be a sign of economic distress if consumers are borrowing to meet their routine expenses.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.79 points, to 4,680.60.
Most other major indexes also fell, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropping 2.41 points, to 554.78, and the Nasdaq composite index declining 6.41 points, to 970.22. But the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.88 points, to a record high of 509.05.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange topped advances by 1,332 to 1,045. Big Board turnover fell to 376.8 million shares, from 409.7 million shares on Monday.
Paper stocks, which have jumped almost 33 percent since the end of January, tumbled yesterday. Morgan Stanley downgraded four companies in this industry from a strong buy to outperform. The companies were Mead, off 3 1/8, to 60 1/2; Champion International, off 2 3/4, to 56 1/4; Consolidated Papers, off 1/8, to 59 1/8, and Bowater, off 2 3/8, to 51 1/8. International Paper, which said its second-quarter earnings more than tripled, still came under selling pressure, with its shares dropping 4 1/8, to 86 5/8.
Auto issues also fell, partly attributable to an announcement by Chrysler late Monday that it will take a $143 million after-tax charge against its second-quarter earnings. Chrysler was down 1 1/8, to 48 7/8; Ford was off 5/8, to 32 1/4, and General Motors was off 1 1/4, to 50 1/2.
Many technology stocks, part of a group that has led the stock market for many months, were off yesterday. Advanced Micro Devices reported unexpectedly weak second-quarter profits late Monday and eased 1/4 yesterday, to 34 3/8. Microsoft declined 2 3/8, to 96 1/2; Compaq fell 1 1/8, to 45 7/8, and VMark Software dropped 5 1/8, to 15 5/8. The semiconductor industry's new orders report is scheduled to be released tomorrow.
Brokerage and other financial-services stocks sunk amid losses in the bond market, which pushed the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond to 6.58 percent, from 6.52 percent Monday. A standout was Salomon, which dropped 3 5/8, to 37 1/4, after saying that it anticipates a second-quarter loss of around $65 million.
Some issues bucked the downward trend, however. United Technologies picked up 7/8, to 81 3/8, after Prudential Securities raised its 12-month target price for the stock to $100 from $84. Sensormatic gained 1 1/4, to 25 7/8, following a report by Raymond James that upgraded the issue to a buy from neutral. And Greenbrier, which reported a sharp increase in third-quarter earnings, jumped 2 1/8, to 15.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Net Up 31% At Motorola In 2d Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SCHAUMBURG, Ill., July 11

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. reported today that its net income rose 31 percent in the second quarter, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, and that it had resolved a nagging problem of bulging cellular telephone inventories.
The inventories had constrained earnings earlier in the year, but Motorola said they came into line toward the end of the second quarter. 
 The electronics company said its earnings climbed to $481 million, or 79 cents a share, in the second quarter, from $367 million, or 63 cents a share, a year ago.
Wall Street was looking for 73 cents a share, and the company's stock rose in after-hours trading.
Motorola's shares had closed down $1.875, at $68.375. on the New York Stock Exchange. But after the company released its second-quarter results late this afternoon, the stock jumped as high as $70.50 in after-hours electronic trading.
Sales in the second quarter rose 26 percent, to $6.9 billion, from $5.4 billion in the corresponding period last year.
In its general systems sector, which includes cellular phones, sales jumped 39 percent, to $2.9 billion, and operating profits increased.
"Cellular continued to boom," said John Lazlo, an analyst with Paine Webber. "Shipments were strong, but orders were muted because of the inventory situation. Now that the inventory situation has been corrected, I think you'll see an acceleration in the third and fourth quarters."
Aside from resolving the inventory problem, orders grew rapidly in Asia and Latin America.
Semiconductor segment sales, which have lagged behind in the last few quarters, rebounded, rising 22 percent, to $2.1 billion. Both orders and operating profits increased. Motorola said all major regions showed double-digit growth, led by Europe and Asia-Pacific.
"While robust growth continued in Asia, Europe and Latin America, we began to experience some effects of slower economic expansion in the United States in several of our businesses," Gary Tooker, vice chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement.
Sales in the messaging, information and media sector rose 24 percent, to $895 million, and orders rose 42 percent. It said order growth for pagers was especially strong in Asia.
"Motorola did well almost across the board, meeting or exceeding expectations," Rakesh Sood, a Hambrecht & Quist analyst, said. "The one area that had less than spectacular results was the land mobile sector, and that should turn around in the second half."
Analysts said they expected to see improved sales in the land mobile unit now that Nextel Communications Inc. had obtained financing and shareholder approval to build its digital wireless network. Motorola's equipment sales to Nextel for the network, they said, could be realized as soon as the second half of the year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Treasury Prices Drop On New Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices slipped yesterday after new economic data gave traders little incentive to advance an eight-month rally.
The data, the Johnson Redbook weekly report on retail sales, failed to provide evidence that the economy was slowing enough to drive the rate of inflation lower. Traders are waiting for more clues in the Government's report on June producer prices, due out tomorrow, and the report on June consumer prices, scheduled for Friday. 
 Traders were also cautious ahead of a large supply of new corporate securities that was expected this week. The corporate debt could lure a number of buyers away from the Treasury market.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 30/32 of a percentage point, to 11319/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.58 percent from 6.52 percent. The price of the two-year note also fell, driving its yield up to 5.61 percent from 5.54 percent.
"In order to sustain this rally, you need some more weak economic data," said Eric Cheung, who oversees $2.8 billion in fixed-income investments at the Wilmington Trust Corporation.
The Johnson Redbook Service reported yesterday that retail sales in the first week of July were up 7.3 percent, compared with the comparable period a year earlier, and four-tenths of 1 percent compared with last month.
Still, the increase was less than what many analysts had expected. That buttressed some investors' optimism that the bond market rally will soon resume.
"It's clear for the economy to pick up steam the consumer's going to have to get back in, buying not just houses, but other things as well," said Bruce Holmquist, a director at Riggs Investment Management, a Washington firm with $2 billion of bonds. "We don't expect that to happen."
In the corporate market, Nabisco Holdings and the Ford Motor Company sold $1.5 billion of bonds and related securities yesterday amid strong investor demand.
Nabisco sold $400 million of 12-year bonds at a yield of 7.061 percent, or 95 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The sale was the second since an exchange offer that allowed Nabisco to sell its own debt separate from its parent, RJR Nabisco Holdings.
Ford raised $1.1 billion by selling repackaged auto loans with an average maturity of 1.44 years at a yield of 6.018 percent, or 42 basis points more than the comparable Treasury security.
Other companies that sold debt yesterday included American General, Household Bank FSB, Aristar Inc. and the Central Power and Light Company.
Other big offerings are expected this week. The World Bank and the Canadian Government are planning to raise at least $2.5 billion by selling global bonds in the days ahead. The World Bank is expected soon to sell $1.5 billion of 10-year global notes, while Canada is selling at least $1 billion of 10-year global notes as early as today.
Municipal bonds were little changed.
Among yesterday's offerings, the Florida Department of Transportation's sale of $347 million of revenue bonds drew interest from investors seeking discount securities, or bonds priced below their maturity value, because they offer the best chance for gains if rates fall. Bonds maturing in 17 years and more from the Florida sale were priced at an original issue discount.
"They appear to be doing well," said Michele Poirier, who manages about $5 billion in tax-exempt bonds for Nationsbank Investment Management. "Florida paper always trades in a world of its own."

HEADLINE: Taking On the Management;
Irate Guests? No, the Hotel Owners Are Up in Arms

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
The verdict amounted to a loud wake-up call for the hotel industry.
In February, a Federal jury ordered the Stouffer Corporation to pay $7.85 million to the one-time owners of a failed hotel in the Philadelphia suburbs that had been run by Stouffer's hotel management arm from 1987 to 1992. 
 Stouffer attributed the failure to the 1991 recession and the falloff in business travel after the Persian Gulf war. But the owners said it was mostly caused by Stouffer's refusal to lower room rates in the face of stiff new local competition, a refusal tied to a decision to position all 40 properties in the Stouffer chain as luxury hotels. (Stouffer has not yet decided whether to appeal.)
In awarding the big verdict, the jury was putting legal teeth into a trend that has been reshaping the hotel business for several years: shifting power back toward the owners and away from the management companies that have long called the shots. Another lawsuit against a management company, this one involving Ritz-Carlton hotels, could go to trial as early as this fall.
The shift in the hotel industry is producing lessons for many business alliances, particularly national franchise operations, in which the power of the parties is often unequal and the interests and agendas are typically at odds. On a legal level, some industry consultants say, it is a reminder that one party cannot ride roughshod over the other without risking a jury's judgment that such behavior is unfair. On a practical level, they add, it underscores the need for compromise in the face of changing market conditions.
For the last 25 years or so, many owners of hotels have used outside companies to manage their properties, turning to such big-name management chains as Marriott, Hyatt and Sheraton and such relative unknowns as Richfield Hospitality Services and Interstate Hotels. Under such arrangements, the owners not only get to bear the financial risk but typically get virtually no say about staff, marketing strategy -- or room rates. They also get to turn over as much as 5 percent of the gross revenues.
"Management companies told owners, 'You have no right to approve our budgets, our general manager or anything other than to give us more money when we need it,' " said Laurence Geller, a hotel consultant in Chicago.
In return, the owners get a well-trained and experienced staff -- everyone from maids to managers. And for those who use a management chain, they get clout, from a marquee name to a nationwide marketing program and advertising campaign.
The arrangement worked well enough in good times, when the owners were taking in more than enough money to pay the managers' generous fees.
But when the 1991 recession turned on the owners, the owners turned on the management companies, particularly those that seemed to put their own national image ahead of the local needs of the properties they were tending.
The owners started demanding concessions. For one thing, they wanted shorter-term contracts, and they have succeeded in cutting the typical chain management pact in half, to about 10 years.
And they began to whittle down fees, which are now at their lowest rate ever -- as little as 1 percent of revenues, according to Michael Mahoney, a hotel consultant with Coopers & Lybrand in Houston. Some management companies, including Hyatt, have agreed in some cases to tie their fees to a hotel's profits.
"Owners have finally taken smart pills," said Anthony G. Marshall, dean of the School of Hospitality Management at Florida International University in Miami. "Now they're saying, 'If you're so good, why not make your fees based on results.' "
Indeed, many contracts now contain performance provisions "so that an operator can be removed if he doesn't reach certain income levels," said James J. Eyster, a professor at the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration.
To align their interests even further with those of the owners, management companies are increasingly taking equity stakes in properties they manage and even providing loans. In those cases, the contracts typically are longer term.
While much of this turnabout can be attributed to the 1991 recession, the change has been hastened by lawsuits.
In January, for example, in another move that caught the industry's attention, the owners of Ritz-Carlton hotels in New York, Washington, Houston and Aspen, Colo., filed suit against the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company, seeking at least $200 million.
The accusations in the suit include mismanaging the hotels, charging excessive fees and misappropriating millions of dollars of the owners' money. Ritz-Carlton, which is owned by W. B. Johnson Property Inc. of Atlanta, has denied the accusations and said the suit was filed by the plaintiffs as a way to hold on to the Ritz-Carlton name, which would otherwise be forfeited if the management agreement was terminated.
Though the suit has not even gone to trial yet -- it is expected to be ready to start in Federal court in Manhattan this fall -- the fact that a company as prominent as Ritz-Carlton was sued has sent shivers through the operators' ranks, industry experts say. In 1992, Ritz-Carlton won a coveted Baldrige award for quality; it remains the only hotel company to win that honor.
But what riveted attention was the February verdict involving the Stouffer Hotel Management Corporation of Solon, Ohio. The plaintiff, U.S. Penn Associates, owner of the Stouffer Valley Forge Hotel in King of Prussia, Pa., had sued for breach of fiduciary duty, misrepresentation and gross negligence.
Under Stouffer's management, the hotel's performance plummeted from a $653,000 profit in 1987 to a $1.4 million loss in 1992 -- the year Citicorp foreclosed on the 289-room hotel because its cash flow was inadequate to pay the mortgage. During that period, Stouffer collected more than $3.5 million in fees and assessments.
The Stouffer Valley Forge, which opened in 1973, was not a luxury hotel, yet Stouffer management steadfastly refused to lower its rates -- even as its occupancy fell after the opening of six hotels in the area in 1987 and 1988, followed by the arrival of Sheraton and Marriott hotels between 1989 and 1991. For much of that period, the rates at Stouffer Valley Forge were consistently higher than the competition.
The hotel's general manager at the time, Varty Arakelian, repeatedly provided his superiors with detailed analyses of room rates at nearby hotels, and pleaded to be allowed to drop his rates to remain competitive, court testimony showed. But Stouffer management just as repeatedly ignored or rebuffed him, according to testimony.
"It was my obligation as a Stouffer's employee to follow orders," Mr. Arakelian said recently. "But I still believe there should have been greater flexibility for Valley Forge, which was a fine hotel but didn't fit with their management philosophy."
Owned since 1973 by Nestle S.A., the giant Swiss food manufacturer, Stouffer sold its hotel operation in April 1993 for an undisclosed sum to New World Ltd., a private Hong Kong company controlled by the Y. T. Cheng family. Hotels still bearing the Stouffer name are part of New World's Renaissance hotel group, which also owns the Ramada name on all but a few Ramada hotels outside North America.
Even before such suits, hotel owners began turning for advice and counsel to consultants and to a new breed, asset managers, who are retained to look over the shoulders of management companies.
"Our responsibility is to make sure the management companies are performing up to the level they promised and that they're keeping expenses down," said Stanley Turkel, a New York-based consultant and a charter member of the recently formed Hotel Asset Managers Association.
Many consultants say that owners are not blameless for their traditional economic impotence. "Neither side is a bunch of choirboys, but nobody held a gun to the owners' head," said David A. Berins, a Dallas consultant. Still, he added, "it's also true that the relationship between owners and operators is more fair now."
An important reason for the historical imbalance, according to Douglas G. Geoga, president of the Hyatt Hotels Corporation, one of the biggest management companies, is that owners in the 1970's and 80's tended to be institutional investors rather than individual entrepreneurs.
"So at a time when everybody was making money, they were not very interested in operating hotels and tended to defer to the judgment of hotel management companies," Mr. Geoga said. "But when times got tougher, owners rightly wanted to get more involved."
Accordingly, Hyatt has since rewritten many of its management contracts, shortening their duration and tying fees to profitability levels. (Hyatt, a private company, does not disclose financial details of its contracts.)
"After taking a chance during the recession that things would get better," Mr. Geoga said, "we're earning rewards from the recent improvement in the hotel industry."
In the first quarter of this year, hotel room revenue nationwide increased 7.5 percent over the corresponding period a year ago and occupancy increased 2.2 percent, according to PKF Consulting.
Meanwhile, the former Stouffer Valley Forge Hotel, which Citicorp is apparently on the verge of selling, received a $3.2 million renovation and reopened last July as the Park Ridge at Valley Forge.
Managed by Benchmark Hospitality of Woodlands, Tex., the property has been repositioned as a conference center during the week (it has 19 conference rooms) and as a hotel for leisure travelers on weekends (it has been slimmed down to 265 guest rooms).
According to Kelly Commerford, its sales director, "The hotel is doing incredibly well."
 
 
 
Who's in Charge Here? Owners Fight to Retain Control of Hotels
 Inside the hotel business, a battle is being waged. The people who own the property are taking on the management companies that often run their hotels. Here are some ways the system is changing to address the owners' concerns.
 
Payments
Management company fees are increasingly based on profits, rather than on revenues, so that management doesn't collect large amounts while owners suffer losses alone.
 
Contracts
Owners can terminate contracts if management companies don't perform, rather than being being tied to contracts that run as long as 40 years, including renewals.
 
Budgets
Owners have a say on staffing matters and in how the operating budget is put together. Before, the owners had little, if any, influence.
 
Equity
Management companies are becoming investors in the hotels, holding as much as 20 percent. Before, they typically held no equity stakes.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Surge as a Drop In Supply Reflects Brisk Demand

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Copper prices surged yesterday after a drop in inventories on the London Metal Exchange showed strong demand in Europe.
Copper for September delivery rose 1.85 cents, to $1.391 a pound on the Commodity Exchange of New York. 
 On other commodity markets, grain and soybean prices advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 0.47 point, to 230.50.
The London Metals Exchange said yesterday that its warehouse stocks of copper fell 2,000 tons, while the Commodity Exchange said its stocks were unchanged.
The Federal Reserve Board's recent interest rate cut, along with matching moves in Japan, Canada and other countries, is renewing demand for base metals, the raw materials used in construction and manufacturing, said Fred Demler, an analyst at E.D.& F. Man International Inc. in New York.
"We've got particularly strong demand in Europe and the Far East and we still have another -- if history is any guide -- three years of worldwide expansion to go," Mr. Demler said. "That points to spot world shortages of the metal."
Short-term supplies have been unexpectedly tight this year, in part because of production problems at mines in Chile, Canada and the United States. That has driven prices up to six-year highs.
Prices also advanced after large gaps separated nearby contract prices from cash prices, a further indication of supply tightness, said Bernard Savaiko, an analyst with Paine Webber.
Grain and soybean prices advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade as investors bet crops would be damaged by extremely hot weather and too little rain.
Wheat futures for July delivery rose 9.75 cents, to $4.24 a bushel. July corn rose 2.75 cents, to $2.80 a bushel. July oats rose 0.75 cent, to $1.5175 a bushel, and July soybeans rose 4 cents, to $6.1125 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Borrowing By Consumers Continues Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Consumer borrowing rose for the 24th consecutive month in May, led by strong credit card use, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Consumer installment credit rose $11.51 billion for the month, exceeding analysts' expectations. In April, borrowing rose a revised $11.6 billion. A month earlier, the Fed initially estimated April consumer credit rose $11 billion. 
 Before today's report, analysts anticipated a $9 billion increase in consumer credit for May.
The Fed also said that consumer installment credit was rising at a 14.6 percent annual rate in May following a 14.9 percent gain during April.
Analysts are divided about the meaning of the prolonged surge in borrowing. Some say it could be a sign of distress if consumers borrow more to meet routine expenses. Others, though, say it may simply be signaling a shift in habits, as people find it more convenient to charge daily purchases like groceries on credit cards.
Still, analysts said the borrowing spree could not go on forever. "This credit trend should prove unsustainable," said a research report by Gary Ciminero, chief economist at Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I.
Statistics in the latest Fed report were revised back to January 1992. Without those revisions, May's gain would have been the 30th consecutive monthly increase.
Analysts pay particular attention to the Fed's credit statistics because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of United States economic activity. In May, spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, according to Commerce Department figures published last week.
But the consumer credit numbers tend to be erratic on a month-to-month basis, and analysts said the statistics should be viewed cautiously over the short haul.
In today's report, the Fed said installment credit totaled $956.822 billion in May. By category, revolving, or credit card, use showed the biggest increase, rising $6.636 billion in May.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Broad-Based Gain As German Rate Cut Is Expected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed against most leading currencies yesterday, buoyed by expectations that the German central bank would soon cut interest rates.
The dollar was also bolstered by concerns about possible political turmoil in Russia after reports that President Boris N. Yeltsin had fallen ill. Mr. Yeltsin, 64, was hospitalized with what his spokesman described as "acute" heart pains. Doctors said he had had an attack of ischemia, which means that the heart is not getting all the oxygenated blood it needs. 
 While the German mark is typically the traders' choice as the safe-haven currency in times of politial turmoil, the mark was considered vulnerable because of Germany's proximity to Russia. As a result, the dollar surged against the mark.
"The Yeltsin situation has caused a flight to the quality of dollars," said Karl Halligan, vice president of strategic trading at CIC Bank New York.
Against the Japanese yen, the dollar was supported by lingering concern that the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan could stage another coordinated dollar-buying spree. The two central banks caught many investors by surprise Friday when they bought dollars for yen as the dollar was rising.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4065 marks from 1.3949 marks on Monday. The dollar rose to 87.54 yen from 86.88 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5876 from $1.5939.
The recent advance by the dollar could accelerate if the Bundesbank lowers interest rates this week, traders said. The Bundesbank's policy-setting council meets tomorrow . The central bank said yesterday that it would hold a news conference after the meeting, which is its last before a four-week recess.
Both the Fed and the Bank of Japan trimmed overnight loan rates late last week, and many traders expect the German central bank will follow suit.
"It's more a question of timing than anything else," said Cynthia Johnson, vice president of foreign exchange at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York. "Are they going to do it now, or after their summer vacation?"
Many traders said they expected at the least that the Bundesbank would trim the 14-day securities repurchase rate. The Bundesbank last cut the rate, to 4.5 percent from 4.51 percent, on June 7. The discount rate, which acts as the floor for German money market rates, was cut to a six-year low of 4 percent on March 30.
Lower German interest rates would hurt the mark against the dollar by making mark-denominated deposits less attractive.

HEADLINE: Microbrewery With Big Plans Opens in Hong Kong

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
DAVID TOLLIDAY-WRIGHT bellied up to the wooden bar, squinted at a beetle-brown bottle with an unfamiliar label -- Crooked Island Ale, it said -- and watched as a reddish, pale liquid was caressed by a bartender into a tall glass. Mr. Tolliday-Wright moved the glass to the light, dim as it was, humphed theatrically, lifted the glass to his lips and inhaled a mouthful of foamy brew.
Silence.
"Eh," he said, the words gradually forming. "Not bad. It's not bad, not bad at all." 
 For only the third time in 154 years, Hong Kong has a new locally produced beer, a beer brewed at a microbrewery with the sort of craft brewing that has swept the United States but just taken its first steps in Asia. For as long as anyone can remember, only two beers have been made here: by San Miguel, the Philippines' largest brewer, and Carlsberg, a Danish company with a typically Danish advertising slogan -- "Perhaps the best beer in the world."
Like many of Asia's major cities, where wheeling and dealing are the life blood of daily life, Hong Kong witnesses evening stampedes of the business-suited and skirted to the local bars. Whether in Manila or Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur or here in Hong Kong, the admixture of intense work and sweltering climates drives people into bars and pubs. And an icy foaming brew, often from Australia, England, Germany or Holland, is usually the drink of choice, especially for expatriates and visitors.
"I was drinking a beer in a pub and said to a friend, 'What we really need here is a microbrewery,' " David K. Haines, a native of Colorado, recalled. "Everybody just laughed. I started drawing labels on coasters."
That was 18 months ago. Today, Mr. Haines, a clinical psychologist by training and beer lover by profession, is bottling the first Crooked Island Ale, the product of his new South China Brewing Company.
"I'd been here for about three years," Mr. Haines explained. "My wife and I came from Vail, and I was working as a psychologist. She's a China analyst at Jardine Matheson, so she makes enough money for both of us. She said, 'Go for it.' "
So Mr. Haines decided to find out about microbreweries. "I went around the United States tasting beer, visiting microbreweries, talking to people about beer," Mr. Haines said. As things happened, he found himself at a dinner with Peter Bordeaux, the president of the Sazerac Company, a major American distributor of alcoholic beverages. "We started talking," Mr. Haines recalled. "He asked lots of questions. And after a while, he agreed to help finance this idea."
With money in hand, mostly provided by Sazerac, all that remained was to surmount Hong Kong's bureaucracy, more efficient than those of most Asian countries but finely layered, like a well-made mille-feuille. "When I started calling government people, they all laughed," Mr. Haines said. "They said: 'You want to start a brewery? You can't do this.' Well, I went ahead and applied. There was all kinds of red tape. It took about a year, but we finally got approval."
Sitting behind a worn wooden desk from Indonesia, Mr. Haines waved a piece of paper with a crimson seal at the top. "Here it is," he said, "the right to brew beer."
On the second floor of the Vita Tower in the industrial Aberdeen district of Hong Kong, hundreds of white sacks filled with malt, 40,000 pounds in all; a room filled with 150,000 brown bottles; huge mirror-shiny steel vats; pumps, and filters make up the innards of South China Brewing. Up a ladder, Ed Tringali, the company's brewing consultant, was stirring malt with a huge wooden paddle as it poured into the mash tun, a massive kettle filled with hot water. From this first mix comes wort, which is pumped into the brew kettle, and the first steps of the company's brewing are under way. From speakers on the walls pumped the sound track from "Pulp Fiction."
"There are more than 500 microbreweries in the United States," said Mr. Tringali, who most recently worked in Seattle at the Big Time microbrewery, which is the source of the yeast for Crooked Island Ale. Now, he plans to travel through Asia and to help formulate brews for the burgeoning microbrewery industry here.
"There are two or three micros in Japan, but that's about it right now," Mr. Tringali said. "It'll definitely go pretty big. Next week, I'm leaving for Manila to help San Miguel open up a micro." Even before the first Hong Konger sipped the first Crooked Island Ale -- named for one of the islands that make up Hong Kong -- South China Brewing was making plans to issue $6 million in stock on the Vancouver stock exchange to finance startup microbreweries in Thailand, Malaysia and Taiwan. The offering is planned for next month. "It's all being researched right now," Mr. Haines said. "We want to be the biggest international microbrewer."
But making beer in Hong Kong, a place known more for Genghis Khan-like developers and gut-wrenching property prices, yachts in sea-borne traffic jams and Cognac-soaked banquets, is odd enough to raise eyebrows. One set that perked up belongs to David Chan, who owns the Royal Castle Pub in Tuen Mun, a burgeoning town in the New Territories.
Clutching a clipboard, beeper hooked on his belt, Mr. Chan walked into the brewery even before it opened. "I own a small pub," he explained to Mr. Haines, who was eyeing the mixing of the malt. "I saw this mentioned in a magazine and wanted to come by." Mr. Haines found a glass mug, washed it out and filled it from a brew kettle. A medium-dark, slightly cloudy liquid with a head of tannish foam filled the mug. Mr. Chan scrutinized the liquid, took a sip, and then another.
"That's good," he pronounced, "but I would prefer a taste that is not so strong. I'd say that 70 percent of the people who come into my bar drink beer, but for Chinese people, they prefer a beer that is not too strong."
Crooked Ale's creator took his visitor's address, but afterward said he was not optimistic about selling to the Royal Castle. "We're looking at a higher socio-economic end, which means mostly the people who go to bars in the main business districts," Mr. Haines said.
"We're looking at connoisseurs who enjoy beer," he continued. "We're looking at expats, people who go to high-end bars. We're looking at tourists. We think the tourist market is going to be big."
On opening day last week, Mr. Haines delivered 15 cases of Crooked Island Ale to a pub called Mad Dog's, down the street from the San Lo Shu noodle shop and across from the Hang Seng Bank on D'Aguilar Street. Nervously, he and his team of brewers stood around the bar rail, waiting for the regulars.
Finally, the hefty Mr. Tolliday-Wright, a local barrister, arrived. "I'm a lawyer," he declared to one and all. "I have no interest whatsoever in the law. I'm interested in beer." ) He maneuvered toward his favorite corner, overseen by a Richard Caton Woodville print titled "Saving the Guns at the Battle of Maiwand."
"We need a new brewery," he said after his second Crooked Island Ale. "It's a really good idea. We need a different type of brew. We need an ale to compete with the usual lagers."
Steven Pinn, a Scot whose brogue was uncracked by Hong Kong's heat, was managing the pub that evening and keeping a shrewd eye on the goings-on. "I think it will be difficult to break in," he said of the new ale. "You're dealing with some very big guys -- Carlsberg, San Miguel, Foster's. It's quite difficult to get people to change their ideas about what beer is."
Part of the problem is the relatively steep price of a bottle of Crooked Ale, nearly $6, or $45 Hong Kong. "A lot of people's decision is based on price," Mr. Pinn explained, and the mass market brews, Carlsberg and San Miguel, sell for less: about $4.60, or $35 Hong Kong. "But still, the younger crowd is much easier to influence," he added. "We will see how it goes."
Mr. Haines patrolled the bar, his ears perked for the comments of patrons who were sampling the beer -- at an introductory offer of two for the price of one. "I'm happy," he exuded. "This is going to be great."

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;
Raiders' Move Is Approved

 BODY:
After 13 years in Los Angeles, the Raiders are being welcomed back to Oakland, Calif., with near unanimity. The Alameda County Board of Supervisors voted by 5-0 yesterday to approve the deal that would make the Raiders the first American team to return to its roots. The Oakland City Council gave its seal of approval last night, 9-0.
"It is an economic shot in the arm and one that is symbolic of good things to come," said Councilwoman SHEILA JORDAN, who had been a critic of a failed 1990 deal for the Raiders' return. 
 The city and county voted to approve a 16-year agreement with the Raiders' owner, AL DAVIS, and to issue up to $225 million in bonds to pay for stadium modernization, including the 175 luxury boxes Davis covets.
If the deal goes ahead as planned, it will become final on Aug. 10 -- two days before the Raiders are scheduled to play host to the St. Louis Rams in a preseason game between Los Angeles runaways. (AP)

HEADLINE: Why Are Lawyers Taking Over the Country?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Law School Cartel" (editorial, July 7): I'm neither familiar with nor particularly interested in the American Bar Association's law school pay structure cartel. There are more serious problems with a profession that has come to dominate civil discourse and institutional leadership in the United States. 
 The United States, with 5 percent of the world's population, is home to three-quarters of the planet's lawyers. One-third of this nation's legal billings take place on Manhattan Island. We now have law firms the size of major corporate headquarters.
Somewhere along the way, a law degree and admission to the bar became the management credential for industry, commerce, finance, government, academic and medical leadership. No one else need apply.
Why are master's degrees in business, public or health administration offered? How does the proliferation of lawyers impact our judicial system or assist or retard our global economic competitiveness?
Here in New York, a city given its birth by a harbor it no longer uses, and not long ago the nation's manufacturing center, we have over the past two decades added new law schools while closing engineering schools, the latter integral to our position as a center of industry.
Not a single major marine, rail, air, trucking or freight-forwarding company any longer calls New York City home. The commercial and investment banks, securities firms and insurance companies that we have based our city and region's livelihoods on are shrinking.
They are often headed by lawyers. The publicly funded voluntary medical centers and private universities and colleges, which have become our economic generators and chief employers, are too often headed by members of the legal profession to the exclusion of others.
 
BRUCE ROSEN
New York, July 7, 1995
The writer is a city planner.

HEADLINE: OPENING TO VIETNAM: IN CALIFORNIA;
For Many of Those Who Fled Vietnam, a Day of Sadness, Anger and Hope

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: WESTMINSTER, Calif., July 11

 BODY:
For Yen Do, editor of the largest Vietnamese-language daily in America, the establishment today of diplomatic relations between Hanoi and Washington marks the end of a half century of war that has tortured his nation and scattered two million of its people around the world.
It welcomes Vietnam into the community of nations, opens new possibilities for its economic development and may help efforts to foster democracy and human rights after 20 years of Communist rule, said Mr. Yen, who edits Nguoi Viet Daily News here in the community known as Little Saigon, 30 miles south of Los Angeles. 
 But for Mr. Yen and many of his fellow refugees, the day was nevertheless colored by sadness, symbolically laying to rest the homeland they fought for, whose yellow-and-red flag is still flown by overseas Vietnamese groups.
"It is something like a pair of lovers who know it is time to leave each other," he said. "Reasonably, rationally, they know the time has come, but emotionally it is hard to accept."
Among many overseas Vietnamese, the sadness found expression in angry words.
"I feel very angry and bitter, but then, it's very clear that business interests have been put in front of human rights," said Diem Do, who has been a leading opponent of normalized relations in the highly fragmented emigre community.
Tran Van Ngoc, past president of the Vietnamese Air Force Veterans Association, said he saw the move as a cynical attempt to use Vietnam once again as a geopolitical pawn against Chinese expansion.
Mai Cong, who heads the Vietnamese Community of Orange County, a private social and cultural agency here, issued a statement saying, "It is as if a decisive step has been taken to sever us from the past, or from any lingering attachment with the past, even though the past only means war and misery for many of us."
She added: "There may be joy in Hanoi, but there certainly will be no celebrations in Little Saigon."
And on Little Saigon Radio, which interrupted its Vietnamese-language broadcasts to carry President Clinton's announcement live this morning, the news was immediately followed by interviews with non-Vietnamese opponents of normalization, who said things like, "I truly believe that this is one of the blackest days in the history of America."
In the three hours following the announcement, 32 callers to an open line at the radio station opposed the reestablishment of relations, while just 13 supported it, said Trang Nguyen, president of Little Saigon TV and Radio.
Since the fall of Saigon in April 1975, some 800,000 refugees have fled to the United States, many clustering in Vietnamese communities like this one where the question of whether to open business and diplomatic contacts with Hanoi created sometimes violent divisions but also helped to define emigre politics and discourse.
For years, right-wing groups collected donations for a fantasy guerrilla war that would succeed where the Americans had failed. Journalists and others who advocated improved relations with Vietnam were attacked and, on a handful of occasions, were killed.
Opposition to improved relations with Hanoi has been kept alive by the recent arrival of about 10,000 former labor camp prisoners, mostly elderly men whose lives have been consumed by the war and its harsh aftermath and who could be counted on to join anti-Communist demonstrations here.
But in recent years, particularly after President Clinton lifted a trade embargo in February 1994, an increasing flood of emigre Vietnamese tourists and entrepreneurs has visited Vietnam, crossing paths with the final trickle of postwar refugees.
Twenty years after Saigon's fall -- and 50 years after the start of the war against the colonial French government that preceded Washington's involvement -- many Vietnamese here say the passage of history has made the debate over normalization as anachronistic as the continuing departure of refugees.
"I think it is good that we finally can put everything behind us and move ahead, and for the community to concentrate on the problems at hand," said Le Kim Dinh, a journalist and writer.
There are signs that that might be happening. On Monday, on the eve of Mr. Clinton's announcement, 10 groups from among the many feuding emigre factions signed a resolution urging Washington to press Hanoi on two substantive issues that overseas Vietnamese agree on: democratization and human rights.
And in a signal that they might leave their political isolation and join mainstream politics, the groups also called for strong action on an issue of greater interest to non-Vietnamese Americans: the search for missing American servicemen.
Mr. Yen said he foresaw other benefits from normalized diplomatic relations. Many former South Vietnamese officials and high-ranking military men who feared revisiting Vietnam may now feel safe in doing so.
In addition, he said, today's announcement could result in the freeing of some political prisoners who have been held because of Hanoi's fears of outside threats.
Some other Vietnamese-Americans were aggressively eager to move ahead both with their integration into American society and their business ventures in Vietnam.
Frank Jao, a leading developer who owns much of the property in Little Saigon and is exploring business opportunities in Vietnam, rejected any talk of the past.
"Speaking in the context of being an American businessman -- nothing to do with Vietnamese-American, because I am no longer a Vietnamese -- it's good for the United States," he said of today's developments.

HEADLINE: New York's Haunted Houses

BYLINE: By Patrick McGrath; Patrick McGrath, co-editor of the anthology "The New Gothic," is author of the forthcoming novel "Asylum."

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki of New York is expected to sign a bill that will please real estate agents, stifle writers of horror stories and shed light on a strange current of medieval thought that has never been purged from the American psyche.
The legislation, passed by the State Senate and Assembly, would exempt realtors from having to disclose if a property they are selling has a stigma, that is, if it is haunted or if some ghastly catastrophe -- a suicide or gruesome murder -- has ever occurred there. 
 More than half the states have such laws on the books. This is a serious matter because the property tends to be harder to sell once it is known to have a nasty history. This simple economic truth explains why the Legislature wants to let the real estate industry triumph over advocates of the buyer's right to know.
That there should be so many properties with macabre histories as to make the legislation necessary says something about violence in America. In Britain, where I grew up, a house with a stigma tends to be a rarity and, as a result, may command a higher price. The British love a juicy murder, particularly if it was committed in their own home and they can boast about it to the neighbors.
More intriguing is what all this tells us about consumer psychology in the real estate market in the United States. If a house becomes less desirable once it is known that a grisly event occurred there, the belief must be widespread among prospective buyers that such an event leaves a sort of malignant spiritual residue and that that residue will blight the lives of future occupants.
This is bizarre. In almost all areas of their lives, Americans explain the world in ways that are more or less based on scientific rationality. But rationality seems to break down when we encounter phenomena that smack of "evil." Then it's as if our post-Enlightenment habits of mind are peeled away and more primitive forms of thinking take over.
Writers of horror stories could not make a living if this were not the case. They rely on the pleasure created by stimulating the brain's superstition centers. This typically involves descriptions of horrible things happening without rational explanation in sinister buildings where equally horrible things happened in the past. Those events usually leave left behind exactly the sort of malignant energies that home buyers attribute to a house with a stigma.
The simple pleasures to be had from such tales of terror do not, of course, provoke people to commit unspeakable acts. Entering into a fantasy is a form of play, a safe and innocent discharge of suppressed emotion. Problems arise only when superstitious thinking exerts influence in the real world, as when people lose money because their house is thought to be haunted.
What the real estate lobby has asked Governor Pataki to do is defend it against a streak of irrationality that is more deeply ingrained in the American psyche than is the instinct for commerce.
Realtors will celebrate if he signs the bill allowing them to keep a house's past a secret. But the rest of America will find that one conduit to the messy, monster-ridden collective unconscious has been obscured lest it inhibit the business of selling houses to people who can't be trusted to manage their own superstitious proclivities.

HEADLINE: Two Exchanges Plan a Move Across the Hudson

 BODY:
The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange said yesterday that they intended to shift their trading operations to Jersey City, in a move that could transfer more than 5,000 jobs out of New York City.
The two commodities exchanges, which have signed a letter of intent with the state of New Jersey, said they planned to build a nine-story, 275,000-square-foot building adjacent to Jersey City's Exchange Place financial district, which they planned to occupy by the second quarter of 1998. 
 They said the incentives offered by New Jersey and Jersey City to move from New York were too attractive to turn down.
Carl Golden, a spokesman for Governor Christine Todd Whitman, said the New Jersey Economic Development Authority offered an incentive package worth $17 million to offset the cost of construction, estimated at $115 million. In addition, Jersey City offered the exchanges a sharp savings on the property taxes for the next 15 years, charging them 2 percent a year on the construction, or $2.3 million, rather than the standard rate, which currently would have run about $4.6 million.
Brian Kelly, chairman of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, said New York City could not match the New Jersey offer.
Mr. Kelly said the exchange's present trading floor at 4 World Trade Center in lower Manhattan was overcrowded and obsolete. The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange now shares a 25,000-square-foot trading floor with the Cotton Exchange and its subsidiary, the New York Futures Exchange, as well as the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange of New York.
"We have to do what we see is best for the exchange, the membership and our clearing members," Mr. Kelly said.
The New York Futures Exchange is also planning to move to the Jersey City building.
New York City officials could not be reached for comment last night. Last year, the city tried to include the two exchanges in a deal it reached with the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange to keep those exchanges from moving to New Jersey.
Those exchanges will be relocating from 4 World Trade Center to new offices in Battery Park City. They received a package of incentives from the city and state, including $125 million in capital construction money and tax abatements worth $43 million.
About 5,300 people are directly or indirectly employed by the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: China Is Insisting Clinton Reaffirm One-China Policy

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 12

 BODY:
Delivering its first outline of "practical steps" to begin thawing its relations with the United States, the Chinese Government said today that President Clinton should reaffirm that there is only one China and that Taiwan is part of China, and declare that Taiwan's President will not be allowed to make any more visits to the United States.
A senior Chinese Foreign Ministry official, speaking on the condition that he not be identified, cited a restoration of the status quo on Taiwan before last month, when its President was allowed to visit the United States, as a minimum requirement for Washington before another high-level meeting between the two countries could be held. 
 Such a meeting could take place, Chinese officials said, as early as the end of this month, when Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, go to Brunei for a regional security forum convened by Southeast Asian countries.
American officials have reaffirmed the "one China" policy in recent days, and President Clinton could do the same without risking serious political damage. But a declaration that the Taiwan President was no longer welcome in the United States would be seen as an admission of error, and could well be unacceptable to the President and to the Republican-controlled Congress, which pressed Mr. Clinton to allow the Taiwanese visit.
The senior Foreign Ministry official did not specify any actions Beijing might take to meet American concerns, which center on China's human rights record and trade issues. But Chinese officials hinted for the first time that the American human rights campaigner Harry Wu, detained on June 19 as he entered China and charged with espionage last Saturday, could be released after the conclusion of a formal investigation.
One official urged Americans to be patient in allowing the investigation to be completed before pressing for Mr. Wu's release.
A second official, also speaking on the condition he not be identified, said today that China had followed an unwritten policy of not imprisoning Americans charged with carrying out illegal political activities inside China.
Though Chinese officials have taken pains to say Mr. Wu's case is in the hands of the authorities in central Hubei Province, these statements today indicate that the strong outcry in the United States over Mr. Wu's arrest is beginning to have an impact on the Chinese leadership.
But it also seems clear that the case of Mr. Wu has handed the Chinese leadership a high-value bargaining chip to use to force Washington to reaffirm its commitments on Taiwan's status.
The Foreign Ministry official's remarks appear to signal a Chinese willingness to find a way out of the crisis that has undermined constructive communication between Washington and Beijing and has threatened to spill over to the rapidly developing trade and economic relationship between the United States and China.
The official acknowledged that there were powerful voices within the circle of Chinese leaders that viewed American intentions toward China as increasingly hostile, and he said these voices would only grow in strength if a new diplomatic accommodation cannot be reached.
Still, he said, Beijing insists that President Clinton take the first step.
The Clinton Administration's decision to admit President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan reversed 16 years of Washington policy and infuriated Beijing, which regards itself as the sole legal government of Taiwan.
Chinese officials said Washington should reaffirm the American commitment to the three joint communiques that form the bedrock of diplomatic relations between China and the United States, beginning with the 1972 Shanghai Communique negotiated during President Nixon's first visit to China.
Each of these communiques affirms that the Beijing Government is the sole legal government of China and that Taiwan is part of China.
Communist Party leaders say Mr. Clinton's decision to reverse policy and allow President Lee's private visit to attend a reunion at Cornell University last month has undermined the communiques.
"If the American administration knew that Lee Teng-hui was seeking to create the image of two Chinas, or one China and one Taiwan, and still allowed him to visit the United States, this indicates that the United States has changed it policy toward China," an official said.
The Foreign Ministry official also said Washington should reaffirm that only one China can be seated at the United Nations.
Taiwan is seeking international support to regain the United Nations seat it lost to the People's Republic of China in 1971. But China, as a permanent member of the Security Council, can veto any proposal to seat Taiwan.
[The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said today: "We have made abundantly clear from the President on down for the past several months that we have a one-China policy and that we recognize the People's Republic of China as the sole representative of the Chinese people."
[Regarding Taiwan, Mr. Burns said, "We've also made it very clear that on the subject of Taiwan we will retain unofficial relations only. We will not change that policy, and we have assured the Chinese Government to that effect."
[A senior State Department official said, "I doubt very much there will be many visas forthcoming for Taiwan's President or other senior Taiwanese officials. We've always said we would do this on a case-by-case basis only."]
But China appeared to be demanding a more elaborate statement, especially on the question of the future access of Taiwan's leader to America.
"Since the President made the decision for Lee Teng-hui to visit the United States," the Chinese Foreign Ministry official said, "the President should make a statement. The statement should be clear about the commitment the United States has made in the three Sino-U.S. communiques, and it should say that the United States doesn't allow Lee Teng-hui to visit the United States."
