Wu's Wife Urges Protest
 WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The wife of an American human rights campaigner imprisoned in China suggested today that Hillary Rodham Clinton turn down an invitation to a women's conference in China in protest.
The White House said no decision had been made on whether Mrs. Clinton would attend the United Nations International Woman's Conference in September. Mrs. Clinton is the honorary chairwoman of the United States delegation.
Ching Lee Wu, the wife of Harry Wu, said she was generally pleased with efforts being made to win her husband's release. "They are all concerned about Harry very much," she said after meeting with the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, at the White House.

HEADLINE: A Second Fed Bank Study Finds Disparities in Mortgage Lending

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
White mortgage applicants with bad credit histories were only half as likely to be rejected for loans as black or Hispanic applicants with similar credit records, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago concluded in a study released today.
But the report, the latest effort by Government experts to measure bias in lending practices, did not find that discrimination by banks was widespread in all circumstances. Black and Hispanic applicants with good credit histories were about as likely as white applicants with comparable records to receive bank approvals for mortgages, the study found. 
 And while the study found statistical evidence that banks are reluctant to issue mortgages to unmarried people, it did not find that banks discriminate between men and women.
The new study was harshly criticized by commercial bankers and conservative economists, who have spent considerable time and money during the last few years trying to discredit an earlier research effort that found broad evidence of lending bias against minorities.
Still, the study's results are the latest evidence that the financial system's regulators -- including those working for the stolid Federal Reserve -- are moving toward greater concern about lending and other social issues affecting disadvantaged sectors of society, even as Republicans in Congress have moved in the other direction.
The study by the Chicago Fed involved a re-analysis of 1,991 mortgage applications in the Boston area in 1990. Those applications also provided much of the basis of a 1992 study by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, which found a pattern in which banks approved fewer mortgages for black and Hispanic applicants.
Bankers have responded that the Boston study, which compared overall mortgage approval rates for white applicants with overall rates for black and Hispanic applicants, should have taken more complete account of differences in creditworthiness among the individual applicants. The Boston Fed has repeatedly denied this.
The latest study tried to compare applicants of different races who had similar credit histories. When the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago looked at mortgage applicants who were 60 or more days overdue on one or more other debts, it found that only 9 percent of the white applicants were disapproved, compared with 18 percent of the black and Hispanic applicants.
James H. Chessen, the chief economist at the American Bankers Association, a trade group based here, said that he still believed the study was flawed because of wide variations among applicants even with similar overall credit records. He also objected to the Chicago Fed's use of the 1990 data.
"It's the continuing saga of trying to beat up the banking industry," he said. "What's incredibly frustrating is that bankers are working every day to make sure there is not even inadvertent discrimination."
William C. Hunter, the research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago and the author of today's study, said that the results pointed more to a cultural gap between white loan officers and minority applicants than to overt racism. The finding that black and Hispanic mortgage applicants with marginal credit histories were rejected more often that whites with similar problems on their records suggested that loan officers, most of whom are white, are more willing to extend themselves for white applicants, Mr. Hunter said.
"It may be unconscious; they just may make an extra call; they know where the person works or where they live," Mr. Hunter said. The same loan officer might not make this extra effort for a minority applicant, he added,possibly because a white loan officer might be less likely to know the neighbors or employers of black applicants.
The study's conclusions echoed those remarks: "These findings are consistent with the existence of a cultural affinity between white lending officers and white applicants, and a cultural gap between white loan officers and marginal minority applicants."
The Chicago Fed's findings are certain to fuel an already vigorous debate on Capitol Hill over Republican efforts to weaken Federal laws that require banks to lend money to minorities and residents of low-income neighborhoods. The House Banking Committee approved such a bill two weeks ago, but its fate on the House floor is unclear because of a dispute about unrelated provisions concerning the insurance industry.
Bankers have never forgiven Alicia Munnell, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy, for her role in writing the Boston Fed study when she was there. Heavy lobbying by bankers prompted the Administration to cancel plans two weeks ago to nominate Ms. Munnell to the Federal Reserve Board, which regulates banks, and instead nominate her for the Council of Economic Advisers, which does not regulate banks and is in danger of extinction because of Republican budget cuts.
Neither the Boston study nor the one released today contained specific recommendations. But the research has been cited by the Clinton Administration to support vigorous enforcement of fair-lending laws and to oppose Republican proposals to weaken the laws.
Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, one of the chief deputy Democratic whips in charge of gathering votes for floor fights, said that today's report "is another overwhelming argument to derail this misguided legislation."

HEADLINE: Ribeirao Preto Journal;
Newcomers Flood Brazil Interior: Count the Pools

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RIBEIRAO PRETO, Brazil

 BODY:
With its swimming pools, shopping malls, freeways and suburbia sprawling to the edges of orange groves, this booming region cannot shake its press label: "California brasileira."
"It wasn't so great," said Gilberto S. Maggioni, president of the local chamber of commerce, grimacing when reminded of the first newspaper comparison a few years back to an American state that Brazilians revere as the promised land. "That 'California brasileira' talk only brought us an enormous amount of migrants." 
 With high-rise apartment buildings popping like mushrooms out of old coffee fields, this city boasts living standards on a par with Southern Europe. Virtually all households have running water and sewerage systems. Three-quarters of families have a telephone and a car. The Mayor, a member of Brazil's left-wing Workers Party, estimates that only 2 percent of the city's half a million people live in shantytowns.
Hardly a middle-class oasis in a sea of poverty, this flourishing city is part of a broader economic boom that is transforming the interior of Sao Paulo, Brazil's richest state.
Reversing a decades-old trend, the state capital has seen its share of the state economic pie slip to less than one-half today, from two-thirds 25 years ago.
The economic rise of mid-sized interior cities like Ribeirao Preto, Bauru and Campinas is dashing Sao Paulo's dream -- or nightmare -- of one day overtaking Mexico City to become the largest metropolis in the Americas. During the 1980's, as job-seekers started to shun Sao Paulo for the booming interior cities, the population of the state capital grew by only 13 percent, while the interior's population grew by 33 percent.
"People follow jobs," said Antonio Vicente Golfeto, director of the Maurilio Biagi Economic Institute, a private center here. Noting that Ribeirao Preto's population had doubled since 1975, he added, "Sao Paulo now is losing population."
The Mayor here, Antonio Palocci Filho, said: "Ten years ago, the trend was to go to Sao Paulo. Now, people are going to interior centers."
If the interior of Sao Paulo State were a nation, it would have a gross national product larger than Poland's -- and half of Poland's population.
Flourishing 200 miles down a four-lane divided highway from the state capital, Ribeirao Preto flaunts a California-style affluence as obvious as the dealerships selling 13 different makes of imported cars. Bringing an American symbol to a hot, land-locked region, local franchisers are building a $15 million Wet'n Wild amusement park here.
"Most of our clients are first-time pool buyers," said Paulo Sergio de Oliveira, manager of Centerglass, a local swimming pool store.
In August, Mr. Oliveira will open a new store with four times the floor space across from Ribeirao Shopping, a middle-class temple of commerce with 159 shops, a dozen fast-food restaurants and South America's largest bowling alley. Part of the Brunswick chain of the United States, the bowling alley echoed on a recent night with rock videos and the collisions of balls and pins.
"I prefer Ribeirao to Sao Paulo," said Aline Cristina Moreira Quintana, a blue-jeaned 15-year-old, who was bowling with a group of friends. "Here, you have more freedom. You can go out at night without worrying about being mugged."
Two lanes away, Jose Guilherme Perticarrari, a sugar chemist, was bowling with his in-laws. He said interior cities were magnets for migrants because of their high quality of life: low crime, low pollution, low traffic and a wealth of jobs. A resident of another interior city, Piracicaba, he said, "The majority out here are middle class -- two cars in the garage."
Only four hours by truck from the capital, Ribeirao Preto is the center of a region that produces 70 percent of Brazil's orange juice and 30 percent of its sugar cane alcohol fuel. This agricultural wealth has brought secondary booms in banking, construction and university education.
In 1993, Simonsen Associados, a consulting firm, surveyed business conditions in all of Brazil's cities with populations over 150,000. Of the top 10, 7 were in Sao Paulo State, according to the survey, published in Brazil's leading business magazine, Exame. Ribeirao Preto came in third, after Bauru and Campinas.
At Ribeirao Preto's airport, passenger demand has been so strong that destinations served from here tripled over the last five years to 15. With the airport now ranking as Brazil's busiest interior airport, two new airlines are starting service here this year and the authorities are planning to double the terminal's size next year.
"Any destination we have added from Ribeirao has always found passengers," said Eduardo Jose A. Tao, local manager for TAM, the principal airline serving the city. "Sao Paulo is strangled by an enormous number of flights, so people look for alternatives."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Aline Quintana, 15, relaxes in the bowling alley in Ribeirao Preto; with 20 lanes, it is South America's biggest. The city is part of an economic boom that is transforming the interior of Sao Paulo, Brazil's richest state. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China Gives Big Van Deal To Mercedes

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 12

 BODY:
Snubbing American car manufacturers and fueling suspicion that China would make American industry pay for the diplomatic dispute with Washington, China today gave a much-coveted $1 billion contract to Mercedes-Benz of Germany
The decision to award what is one of the biggest automotive deals in China was announced as President Jiang Zemin, on a four-day visit to Germany, toured the Mercedes plant in Sindelfingen, about 100 miles south of here. 
 Mercedes, a unit of Daimler-Benz, beat out Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company for a project to make as many as 60,000 mini-vans and 100,000 engines a year in the southern city of Nanfeng.
The Government also awarded Mercedes a $50 million joint-venture contract to make buses in China.
"The signing of the agreement is a giant leap into the Chinese market and convincing proof of faith in our company," said Helmut Werner, the chairman of Mercedes.
And on Thursday, when the Chinese President is in Bonn meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, he is also likely to announce that China has awarded Siemens A.G., the electronics and industrial conglomerate, contracts to develop power stations and airports that could be worth more than $1 billion in total.
Chinese officials asserted that the decision to choose Mercedes and Siemens had nothing to do with the political tension rising between China and the United States after Washington granted permission to the President of Taiwan, Lee Teng-hui, to visit Cornell University last month and continuing criticism was heard in the United States of Chinese human rights violations.
"The failure of the two U.S. companies to win the bid in China was the result of commercial reasons rather than Chinese restrictions against U.S. business in the country," a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Shen Guofang, was quoted as saying by the official New China News Agency. "The Chinese Government has put great emphasis on developing trade and economic relations with other countries."
Analysts, though, were not readily convinced. Last week President Jiang said that "the U.S. side will have to pay a price for its wrong decision" to let Taiwan's leader into the country. Beijing regards the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan as illegitimate and has many times said it intends to reunite Taiwan with the mainland.
Aggravating relations further, last weekend China announced that it had charged Harry Wu, a Chinese-American human rights campaigner, with espionage, a case that has drawn considerable attention in the United States.
The contract awards to the Germans also underline a European approach to business, in contrast with that of some Americans. European governments are less inclined to risk commercial interests in Asia over political areas like human rights, and present themselves as less bellicose, more tempered trading partners to governments that find themselves in political fights with Washington.
Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel told reporters today that at Thursday's meeting in Bonn, business issues would take priority over questions of human rights.
But if American car makers felt they were hurt for political reasons, and that Mercedes got undue advantage, they were not saying so publicly.
"They've made their decision and that's their choice," a Ford spokesman said. "We have other alternatives we're pursuing. It's not as if we have nothing going on there."
And Chrysler responded, "If recent reports are true, we are disappointed that Chrysler and American companies may not be participating further in the development of the mini-van project."
Analysts did not dispute that Mercedes was technically competent to make mini-vans, even though it has so far not produced a fully appointed passenger mini-van. The Mercedes truck lineup includes utility vans without the luxury features needed for passenger vehicles. However, next year it will open a plant in Spain that will produce a luxury mini-van.
But the Chinese award decision appears at least to have been moved up, possibly in response to the growing political tension with Washington. Only last week, a Chinese auto executive said a decision on a partner would not be made for three months, and a Mercedes executive in China said in June that he expected a decision by the end of the year.
Indeed, there are hardly any auto makers that are not trying hard to get into the Chinese car and truck market. While 1.5 million vehicles were sold last year, China has vowed to double its output over the next five years, and analysts estimate that there are as many as 100 million potential car buyers in China, part of an emerging middle class.
"The Chinese vehicle market should be huge," said Stephen Reitman, auto analyst for UBS Global Research in London. "Everyone wants to be there, so the Chinese have the whip hand. A whole lot of companies can be played off each other."
The letter of intent on the mini-van deal calls for a joint venture between Mercedes-Benz and the South China Automotive Corporation. Mercedes will be a 45 percent owner, and South China Automotive, 55 percent.
Mercedes officials said 20 percent of production would eventually be exported and that they would use the chassis of their Spanish mini-van, the Viano, for the Chinese project. But it will be less luxuriously appointed to fit the price constraints of Chinese buyers.
In the bus project, Mercedes will be 50-50 owner along with Yangzhou Motor Coach, China's largest bus manufacturer, producing 7,000 vehicles a year.
In a sense, the biggest loser in the mini-van deal is Ford, which is left without a vehicle production plant in China. Chrysler is making Cherokee sport utility vehicles with a Chinese partner in Beijing.
As recently as late 1994, Ford was favored over the General Motors Corporation in a competition to produce sedans with the Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation. Shanghai Automotive already makes passenger cars with Volkswagen.
Yet Chinese officials have hinted that General Motors now has the upper hand in the Shanghai deal, and earlier this year Ford was suddenly invited to submit a proposal on the mini-van deal.
"It's not a question of if we will assemble vehicles here," W. Wayne Booker, executive vice president of Ford Motor Company International, said in Shanghai last month. "It's a question of when and where."

HEADLINE: Secret Trials Are Reported In Nigeria

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, July 12

 BODY:
With reports from Nigeria that secret tribunals have begun sentencing and possibly executing opponents of the military Government, there have been rising calls internationally for the release of political prisoners and the respect of human rights.
In recent days, Nigerian newspapers have repeatedly hinted that at least 18 military officers and 5 civilians have been secretly convicted of plotting to overthrow the Government of Gen. Sani Abacha and given long prison terms or death sentences. According to a report in The Times of London last week, some detainees may have already been executed. 
 Helping to fuel the international furor over the trials, in which there has been no public airing of the charges or right to appeal, is the inclusion among those charged of a former President, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo. According to several Nigerian press reports, a military tribunal gave General Obasanjo and his former deputy, Gen. Shehu Musa Yaradua, 25-year sentences.
A Nigerian Army spokesman, Brig. Gen. Fred Chijuka, called such reports "dangerous speculation." But General Chijuka and other officials have refused to provide any information on the whereabouts of General Obasanjo and have declined to say whether judgments have been reached against those charged.
The trials come after nearly two years during which Government opponents have been locked up without being charged, judicial orders to produce those arrested in court have been ignored and newspapers have been closed.
International rights groups say the slide into repression, the worst the country has known since independence from Britain in 1960, results from General Abacha's bid to clear the political landscape of critics after the jailing last year of Moshood K. Abiola, the apparent winner of Nigeria's last democratic presidential election, in 1993.
General Obasanjo, who is retired from the military, is the only one of Nigeria's several military presidents to have relinquished power voluntarily. His organization of elections in 1979 and his subsequent work with President Jimmy Carter in resolving international conflicts made General Obasanjo one of his country's best respected citizens.
In one of the strongest warnings in an unusually sustained round of international condemnations, the British Overseas Development Minister, Lynda Chalker, warned last week that Britain was considering barring Nigeria from the Commonwealth.
Five rights monitors, led by a former Canadian Foreign Minister, Flora MacDonald, are visiting Nigeria to prepare a report to the Commonwealth that is to be delivered in November at the group's annual summit meeting.
Coming on top of Dame Chalker's warning, the State Department has stepped up its criticisms of the Nigerian Government, calling it "unwilling to meet a basic international standard of free and fair trials." American officials have boycotted Government functions in Nigeria.
Germany, Russia, Japan and the European Union have also warned of possible sanction or pleaded for the release of political detainees.
Nigeria's military leaders have so far shown little interest in these appeals, however, and have frequently expressed contempt for their critics.
"I wonder why this same Britain, which wreaked havoc on our national life, is now telling us what to do," a minister without portfolio, Wada Nas, told reporters in Kaduna last weekend.
Diplomats say they know of no credible evidence that either General Obasanjo or General Yaradua have plotted against General Abacha. But, they add, each man has been a thorn that the dictator has been eager to remove.
According to this view, General Obasanjo infuriated General Abacha by reportedly holding political discussions abroad and was suspected by the military ruler of presenting himself as a potential symbol of national unity.
General Yaradua, the diplomats said, may have been arrested for leading a movement within the recent Constitutional Conference to demand an early end to military rule. General Abacha convened the conference last year to determine the terms for a return to civilian rule.
Asked about the possible motive for the arrests, Bolaji Akinyemi, a former Foreign Minister whose brother, Akinloye, is among those charged with plotting, said from his exile in London: "Abacha wants to silence all of those who have a voice. His plan is to stretch out the transition for a time and then remove his military uniform and declare himself the civilian president of Nigeria."

HEADLINE: First Chicago and NBD to Merge as Banks Scurry to Grow

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
The First Chicago Corporation and NBD Bancorp Inc. announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a deal valued at about $5.3 billion, providing yet another example of the relentless consolidation that is changing the landscape of commercial banking.
The merger will create a Midwestern banking powerhouse, the First Chicago NBD Bank Corporation, ranked No. 8 in the country with $120 billion in assets. Moreover, it will have the country's fourth-largest credit card business and the biggest market share in Illinois, Michigan and Indiana. 
 "Strategically, it's an excellent fit," said Joseph C. Duwan, a banking analyst at Keefe Bruyette & Woods Inc. "The combined bank is going to be a dominant Midwestern banking franchise going forward."
The First Chicago-NBD merger is the second coupling of major banks announced this week, as the whole industry rushes to lock up lucrative markets. On Monday, the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh announced that it would buy the Midlantic Corporation of Edison, N.J., for $3 billion in stock. And three weeks ago, the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., agreed to pay $5.4 billion for the First Fidelity Bancorporation of Newark. The First Chicago-NBD deal would be the second largest in terms of money involved after the First Union deal.
"Everyone is gathering assets and trying to create economies of scale and cost efficiencies,," said Stanton Feeley, chief investment officer of SunAmerica Asset Management, which owns shares of First Chicago and several other banks that are potential takeovers.
First Chicago and NBD complement each other on a variety of fronts. "Along comes an opportunity where the stars lined up just right where we have a compatibility of product lines, a compatibility of geographic areas and a compatibility of customer bases," said Richard L. Thomas, chairman and chief executive of First Chicago.
First Chicago has positioned itself as a "money center" bank like Chase Manhattan and Citibank, catering largely to corporate clients. NBD, formerly the National Bank of Detroit, has pursued more of a regional retail banking strategy, extending its reach into Indiana and the Chicago suburbs and building a mutual fund business.
First Chicago is strongest in its headquarters city and southern Illinois, while NBD dominates Detroit and Indianapolis.
NBD's management team, led by Verne G. Istock and Thomas H. Jeffs, is regarded on Wall Street as one of the banking industry's best, while First Chicago's team of executives has a spottier record, analysts said.
Unlike other recent bank deals in which one bank is buying another, the First Chicago-NBD deal is more of a classic merger. Wall Street viewed the proposed merger favorably for NBD, whose shares jumped $1.875 yesterday, closing at $34.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. First Chicago's shares closed up 87.5 cents at $61.50.
Under the deal, First Chicago's shareholders will receive 1.81 shares of NBD for every First Chicago share they hold, thus valuing the First Chicago shares yesterday at about $62.22 based on NBD's closing stock price.
Still, "We suspect there's disappointment on the part of some First Chicago shareholders that there wasn't a big premium," Mr. Duwan said.
Indeed, First Chicago's shares opened sharply lower yesterday after the merger was announced but recovered as NBD's shares surged, pushing up the value of the deal.
In the end, First Chicago shareholders will own 50.1 percent of the combined company, while NBD shareholders, whose stock in the Detroit-based company will remain outstanding, will own 49.9 percent. .
On an assets and earnings basis, then, NBD shareholders made out better than First Chicago shareholders, getting half the combined company while providing about 40 percent of the assets and about 44 percent of profits.
The companies said they expect the combination to add to earnings in 1996. They plan to wring about $200 million before taxes out of their expenses annually, as they eliminate overlaps in branch banking, cut about 1,700 jobs and consolidate back office and marketing functions.
The companies also plan to buy back as much of $300 million in their stock before the merger is completed. They intend to sell about $25 billion in liquid assets, which will create about $1 billion in excess capital for the combined company.
"This fulfills our mutual strategic vision to be a world-class financial services powerhouse, and we view this as a merger of equals," Mr. Thomas of First Chicago said.
Still, as outlined yesterday, the deal between First Chicago and NBD makes it fairly clear who will be in charge -- the team from NBD. Mr. Thomas will be chairman of the combined company until May 20, 1996, when he plans to resign. Mr. Istock, who will be president and chief executive of First Chicago NBD, will take over the chairmanship then.
Leo Mullin, who was scheduled to run First Chicago when Mr. Thomas retired, has resigned. He will be replaced by three vice chairman: Mr. Jeffs, now president of NBD; David J. Vitale, vice chairman of First Chicago, and Scott P. Marks Jr., executive vice president of First Chicago and head of its important credit card operations.
The merger requires shareholder and regulatory approval. The banks said they expected to complete the merger by early next year.
Investment bankers and analysts said privately that First Chicago, as the weaker of the two banks in terms of management, strategic direction and overall quality and profitability of business, might have been the bigger winner.
NBD is known for extremely conservative risk management and credit analysis. As such, it sailed serenely through the late 1980's and early 1990's, unburdened by the bad real estate loans and other faulty assets that saddled many other banks' balance sheets.
Meanwhile, First Chicago has struggled for years to increase its profitability and shareholder value to no avail. "They have pockets of excellence embedded in a sea of mediocrity, and the question has always been how to capitalize on the good stuff and minimize the bad," said an investment banker who spoke on condition of anonymity and is not involved in the deal. "Putting these two companies together was a very creative way of doing that."
While Mr. Thomas and Charles Fisher, NBD's powerful former chairman and chief executive, discussed a merger as long as two years ago, investment bankers working on the deal said the two companies did not really get serious about a deal until four or five weeks ago. Lazard Freres & Company advised First Chicago and Montgomery Securities advised NBD.
First Chicago's corporate banking operations, long the weakest link in its earnings stream, accounted for 39 percent of its expenses last year and only 19 percent of its net income. And its prized credit card business, which contributed 57 percent of core profits last year, has shown signs of weakening, with earnings declining 12 percent in the first quarter.
"First Chicago does not have firm control over its destiny," George M. Salem, a banking analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison, warned in a report two weeks ago that suggested it was a ripe candidate for acquisition at around $80 a share by a super regional bank like Nationsbank.
"There has never been any intent to put our company up for sale," Mr. Thomas said in response to an analyst's suggestion yesterday that shareholder might have realized greater value through a sale.

HEADLINE: A Fierce Rivalry to House Olympic Teams

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: CARROLLTON, Ga., July 7

 BODY:
Tommy knew Leah, whose husband, Love, ran track in college where his coach was Mel, whose lawyer is Bill, who is married to Laryssa, who is originally from Ukraine. That in a nutshell is how the Ukrainian Olympic team chose this small west Georgia city as its training base for the Summer Olympics next year.
It is the Southern version of networking, known here as "doin' bidness," and it has helped this city of 15,000 snatch a bit of the same spotlight that will be shining on its much larger neighbor Atlanta, 45 miles to the east. 
 The Olympics are still more than a year away, but dozens of cities within a five- to six-hour radius of Atlanta are currently vying for medals in a sort of Hospitality Games. Tugging on the loosest of connections or touting charms like a new track, a smooth lake or a bucolic setting, the towns' boosters are doing their best to persuade a country, if its whole Olympic contingent trains together, or one or two foreign teams, to train in their area.
And whether it is Hendersonville, N.C., where the New Zealand swimming team will train, or Albany, Ga., where the small Belize team will work out, or Tupelo, Miss., where the Croatian teams will limber up, the motivation seems the same: a desire to participate in the spirit of the Games and parade their communities before part of the distant world.
"This is a once in a lifetime thing, and being up close and personal with Olympic athletes would be great for us," said Kip Jolly, the executive director of the Hart County Chamber of Commerce, which is still trying to attract a team to its location along the Georgia-South Carolina border. "We have the spirit and the willingness to do whatever we need to do."
That spirit was less in evidence in May when Barrow County, northeast of Atlanta, refused to be the host for athletes from Somalia, citing the dragging of an American soldier's body through the Somali capital during the recent United States peacekeeping mission. And last year, the Olympic volleyball competition was moved out of adjacent Cobb County when county commissioners passed an anti-gay ordinance, raising the specter of intolerance that the New South has sought to escape.
So far, teams from 37 countries have signed contracts to train in communities in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee.
But with 197 countries expected to participate in the Games, negotiations are just heating up, said Kimberley Goff, the director of the Georgia Olympic Training Alliance in the Georgia Department of Industry, Trade and Tourism, the clearinghouse for most of the deals. Even the Somalis have landed on their feet, finding a training site in Gordon County, just north of Barrow County.
Some towns have already parlayed hospitality into opportunity. Elberton, Ga., population about 5,700, has spent state grants and $48,000 of its own money to build docks and rowing lanes on nearby Lake Russell, which borders South Carolina. Besides snaring rowing teams from three countries, the town has begun attracting teams from American colleges, like Northeastern University in Boston, which is training there for college competition, primarily because of favorable weather.
In most cases, though, the towns will end up spending more money than they make, Ms. Goff said. While a few cities may reap long-term economic benefits from the good will, many countries that will send teams have few goods to export and even less capital with which to buy Southern products. The visiting athletes will hardly be an economic stimulus in themselves, since most will be traveling on a shoestring and their lodging must be provided free or at cost.
Ms. Goff described what is involved in luring a team:
"The community usually has to agree to take care of providing lodging and food at cost, taking care of training facilities and building them where necessary and providing free transportation during the training period and paying for liability insurance. We have provided some state grants for some of this in Georgia for those communities which have signed contracts with teams or countries, but the chance for real economic gain is not that great."
Carrollton and surrounding Carroll County were among the first to sign contracts with an Olympic country, and their Olympic fever sets in on July 25, when 200 to 300 members of the Ukrainian team begin arriving for several weeks of "acclimatization" and training. The athletes will return next year for two more weeks of training before the Games, which will start on July 19 and continue for 17 days.
Tommy Vance, head of the Carroll County Chamber of Commerce Olympic Committee, said housing the Ukrainians would cost the city about $100,000. Much of that is being covered by contributions from local businesses, West Georgia College, where the athletes will stay, and proceeds from exhibitions by the Ukrainian athletes and T-shirt sales.
The Olympic experience of Carroll County bears out the theory that there are just six degrees of separation between any two people on earth. Mr. Vance is a friend of a Georgia State Supreme Court Justice, Leah Sears-Collins, and he learned from her that her husband, Love Collins, had trained under the track coach Mel Pender while a cadet at the United States Military Academy at West Point. Mr. Pender's lawyer, Billy Temple, is married to the former Laryssa Barabash, a native of Ukraine. Mrs. Temple is the representative of Valery Borzov, a 1972 gold medalist in track and the head of the Ukrainian national team.
But to clinch the deal, the city, county and West Georgia College had to bring their accommodations and such up to Olympic standards. The county applied for, and won, a state grant to put in an eight-lane Olympic-style track on a field nestled between the college's archaeology laboratory and the physics observatory. The pool in the college gymnasium was outfitted with underwater speakers to accommodate the synchronized swimming team, and the county turned to Southeast Asia to buy weights of the kind used in Olympic competition.
To bridge cultural gaps, residents are putting up 50 Ukrainian-speaking students from around the continent who are volunteering as interpreters. On Aug. 6, Carrollton is having a welcoming party that coincides with the centennial of the Ukrainian weightlifting team. The Ukraine Ambassador to the United States, Yuriy M. Shcherbak, plans to attend.
For officials in Tupelo, Miss., the entree to the Games was not someone they knew, but something their main representative, Stan Gusich, knew: Croatian. As a Croatian-American who had 15 years' experience with Southern ways, Mr. Gusich was able to persuade the Croatian team to choose Tupelo over Rome, Ga.
"The Croatians told us that everybody sent them invitations, but the key was that Tupelo sent them a Croatian-American," Mr. Gusich said.
The Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games got the regional sweepstakes for hosting teams and countries going more than a year ago when it published a directory of interested communities for International Olympic Committee members. The wealthier countries scooped in, grabbing up prime sites on large university campuses in the region.
The British practically commandeered Florida State University in Tallahassee. The Australians and the Swedes quickly struck a deal with the University of Georgia, in Athens, while the Russians settled on the University of South Carolina, in Columbia.
But with the help of the committee's guide, places like Gainesville, a city of 18,000 northeast of Atlanta, ended up with a bit of Olympic glory. The new boxing gymnasium in Gainesville has been chosen as the training headquarters for the boxing teams of American Samoa, Equatorial Guinea, Fiji, Tanzania, Tonga and Uganda.
"A lot of these countries have small teams and don't have the money for other facilities," said Ernie Bates, co-founder of Gainesville's Gold Rush Boxing Club, which serves many of the city's poor, black and Hispanic young men. "We're going to put them up in local homes, and we've talked to a lot of restaurants where they will probably be able to eat for free.
"But we're also going to be able to pick up some role models and training tips and techniques from these other countries for my boys, and we're thrilled."

HEADLINE: Lewis Engman, 59, U.S. Official And Drug Industry Spokesman

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Lewis A. Engman, a former senior Federal official and drug industry spokesman, died yesterday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 59.
The cause was a stroke, said a spokesman for the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association, a Washington trade group that Mr. Engman had headed since 1993. 
 In the mid-1980's as president of another trade group, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, Mr. Engman promoted legislation to make it easier to market low-priced generic copies of prescription drugs that have lost patent protection.
The result was the Waxman-Hatch Act of 1984, which added years of patent protection to certain brand-name drugs and also opened the door for speedy Federal approval of generic copies after the patents expired.
"He was instrumental in reaching an agreement that benefited both the research-based pharmaceutical companies and the generic drug companies, and in the process, the public interest," said Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who sponsored the bill with Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah.
The legislation, which was bitterly lobbied over several years by drug companies on both sides, split the big brand-name drug companies. Mr. Engman resigned as president of their trade group after it passed.
Later, after the generic drug industry was rocked by disclosures of fraud and bribery of Federal regulatory officials, Mr. Engman headed an independent investigating committee in 1990. It recommended changes in procedures of the Food and Drug Administration and industry practices.
Before becoming an industry spokesman, Mr. Engman was chairman of the Federal Trade Commission from 1973 to 1975 during President Richard M. Nixon's Administration. He encouraged competition affecting doctor's fees, prescription eyeglasses and drugs. He had been an antitrust and regulatory lawyer in Washington and his hometown, Grand Rapids, Mich.
He was a staff member in the White House before joining the commission, serving as assistant director of the President's Domestic Council, legislative counsel and general counsel to the special assistant for consumer affairs.
After graduating from the University of Michigan, he studied at University College in London and the London School of Economics. He was a 1961 graduate of the Harvard Law School.
Survivors include his wife, Patricia Hanahan Engman; three sons, Geoffrey, of McLean, Va., Jonathan, of Waterford, Mich., and Richard, of Dallas; his mother, Florence Lewis Engman of Grand Rapids, and two sisters, Ruth Engman Simmons of Williamstown, Mich., and Signe Engman of Holland, Mich.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Higher But Trading Is Lackluster

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, bolstered by expectations that price reports today and tomorrow will show moderate inflation.
"The market is trading higher on optimism about this week's inflation reports," said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds. 
 Trading was lackluster, however, as many traders chose to wait on the sidelines for today's report on producer prices for June. The Government will report on consumer prices for June tomorrow .
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 18/32 , to 1132/32 . It yield, which moves in the opposite from its price, fell to 6.54 percent, from 6.58 percent on Tuesday. It was the long bond's first price gain in four sessions. The price of the two-year note also rose, with its yield falling to 5.57 percent from 5.61 percent.
Treasury prices also received a boost from Canada's sale of $1.5 billion in 10-year global bonds, traders said. As underwriters sold the Canadian bonds, they bought back Treasury securities sold as a hedge, lifting prices, said James Kenney, head trader at Prudential Securities in New York.
Canada sold its global bonds at a yield of 6.476 percent, or 39 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. Global bonds are sold simultaneously in Asia, the United States and Europe and trade around the clock.
"It's a case of looking at attractive yields in the U.S. government market," said David Tory, managing director at Merrill Lynch International Ltd., which joined Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in leading a group of investment banks underwriting Canada's sale.
Economists expect today's report on producer prices to show a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for June. The Consumer Price Index is expected to show a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent.
If the reports come in line with expectations, it would confirm the market's view of an economy slowing enough to contain inflation and assure traders that the Fed was right in reducing short-term interest rates last week.
"The Fed has kind of promised us good numbers" on inflation, said David Capurro, who manages $520 million of fixed-income securities at Franklin Resources in San Mateo, Calif.
"The proof better be there" in the price reports, he said, "otherwise the market is going to be powerfully disappointed."
In other trading, municipal bonds were little changed as issuers continued to sell many of today's $1.3 billion in new securities at lower-than-expected yields, traders said.
"Issuers are in the driver's seat," said Reid Smith, who manages about $3 billion in bonds at the Vanguard Group of Funds. "Supply has dried up and investors are looking around and there's nothing out there."
The Pittsburgh Water and Sewer Authority sold $191 million in revenue bonds at yields that were considered too low.
The yield was five basis points too low, Mr. Smith of Vanguard said. Even with the lower-than-expected yields "apparently they are being purchased," he said. It shows "some appetite out there," he added. The bonds were priced to yield 5.57 percent in 15 years.
Los Angeles County's Metropolitan Transportation Authority sold $250 million of revenue bonds at yields as high as 5.84 percent for the 30-year maturity.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Better technology helps oil and gas drillers return to good times.

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas 

 BODY:
BOOM times seem to be here again for the oil and gas drillers.
Drilling in the Gulf of Mexico is back at the levels of its heyday in 1990, when oil and gas prices surged because of fears that the Persian Gulf war would lead to shortages. 
 That rush to drill collapsed as oil and gas prices fell. Oil plunged to $14 a barrel in late 1993 from a 1990 high of $40. And investors who had bet on the volatile stocks of oil service companies took sizable losses.
Now, some analysts and industry executives say, the current upturn is likely to be different from the last one. The key, they said, is that the drilling boom is not being fueled by a spike in the price of oil and gas.
"What we're seeing is activity not being driven by commodity prices but by a fundamental change in the economics of drilling," said Mark S. Urness, an analyst who follows oil service companies for Salomon Brothers.
Although their stock prices are reaching peak levels, he is recommending such companies as Global Marine, which traded yesterday at $5.125, off 12.5 cents; Noble Drilling, $7.625, off 6.25 cents; Tidewater, $24.625, up 12.5 cents, and Ensco International, $15.625, unchanged.
Kurt Hallead, an oil service analyst for Rodman & Renshaw Inc., is urging investors to buy Sonat Offshore, which traded yesterday at $28.125, off 12.5 cents, and Global Marine.
"This recovery is taking place in a significantly different environment than in the past," Mr. Hallead said. "Oil companies are saying internally that they have to find projects that give them a return on investment at the current level of oil and gas prices."
The price of oil has recovered to about $18 a barrel, well off its highs but at least off the bottom, while gas prices are still in the doldrums, at about $1.50 for a million cubic feet.
Mr. Hallead said technological breakthroughs that allowed companies to squeeze more reserves from existing fields were behind the current surge in drilling.
David A. Herasimchuk, the vice president of market development for Global Marine, pointed to a graph during a recent interview at company headquarters in Houston that showed a widening gap between gas production and reserves. "This gives us the confidence that it's a long-term trend," he said.
Most companies are under growing pressure to replace declining gas reserves. The better technology and growing certainty that a well will pay off are causing companies to hire more rigs than expected.
Instead of drilling for long shots, said Jon A. Marshall, group vice president of Global Marine, oil and gas companies are taking a more conservative approach to exploration, one that involves hiring rigs to drill from existing platforms in search of smaller deposits that could not be spotted with earlier sounding and imaging technology.
"What's driving the upturn are the itty-bitty fields of one million barrels," Mr. Marshall said. "They're finding pockets that they couldn't see before."
Better seismic readings and the ability to image deposits through more advanced computers have greatly lessened the risk of coming up with a dry hole in a developed field.
With wildcat wells, finding a strike of oil or gas in one of five was considered very good indeed. In the 1980's scramble to advance the frontier of exploration, the chances were often one in 100. Now, on current new wells, the success rate is about two out of three.
Companies also need little new investment since the producing platform and the pipelines to bring the oil and gas to shore are already in place. "You're looking for apples under the apple tree," Mr. Marshall said.

HEADLINE: Tussaud's and a Movie Chain Are Negotiating on 42d St. Site

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
In the latest effort to revive the ghostly corridor of deteriorating buildings along Manhattan's famed 42d Street, city and state officials are negotiating with Madame Tussaud's, the renowned London wax museum, and AMC Entertainment, a movie theater chain, over plans to open new entertainment attractions in the city's old theater district.
Under the plan being discussed, the two companies together would take over the site of three adjacent old theaters between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, spending $150 million to create a 335,000-square-foot complex housing a high-tech wax museum and the city's largest movie theater, with a total of 25 screens. 
 City and state officials are pushing to reach agreements with Tussaud's and AMC by Saturday, a deadline imposed by the Walt Disney Company, an anchor in the 42d Street revival efforts. Disney has a tentative agreement to restore the 92-year-old New Amsterdam theater, but has the option of backing out unless public officials secure letters of intent from two additional entertainment companies willing to develop attractions on 42d Street.
Earl Voelker, senior vice president of business development for AMC Entertainment, said "it would be premature" to confirm the company's plans. "I will confirm we are in arduous and laborious negotiations and an announcement could come."
Tussaud's officials could not be reached for comment yesterday evening, but a company official earlier confirmed that negotiations are taking place. Tussaud's tried unsuccessfully earlier this year to buy One Times Square, the svelte, white-marble tower at Broadway and 42d Street.
"I know they are working like crazy on it," Abby Hamlin, vice president of Weiler Arnow, co-owner of property on the southwest corner of the block, said of the negotiations. "We're sitting tight waiting for this all to come together."
Even if deals are struck with Tussaud's and AMC, Disney has until July 30 to decide if it will go ahead with the New Amsterdam development, a huge restoration project that will cost $34 million and will be financed largely through low-interest loans provided by the city. Disney plans to use the art nouveau-style theater for productions like its Beauty and the Beast, which is currently playing to sold-out audiences on Broadway.
Disney officials, who did not return telephone calls seeking comment, can also pull out of the project if they deem final construction estimates to be prohibitive. According to people involved in the negotiations, Disney and the city and state are currently discussing those costs.
The addition of Tussaud's, which is London's top attraction with 2.6 million visitors a year, would bring another brand-name entertainer to the 42d Street project, where city and state officials have been bedeviled for 15 years in their attempts to revive the once-thriving district.
The former center of live theater in the city, 42d Street has declined over recent decades, becoming a seedy center of cut-rate retailers, pornography, prostitution and drugs. The New York State Urban Development Corporation and the New York City Economic Development Corporation have been working as partners in the urban renewal effort, which has evolved from a proposal dominated by office towers to more of a tourist and entertainment center.
In May, the city and state selected Tishman Urban Development Corporation to build a $303 million hotel and entertainment complex on the northwest end of the block, and Disney is expected to provide retail entertainment at that complex.
Public officials have also been negotiating with Viacom for several months regarding the possibility of locating its MTV music network studios and operations on the north side of the street. Those talks, however, have stalled.
Under the plan being negotiated, Tussaud's and AMC would occupy a site just west of the New Amsterdam theater, where the old Empire, Liberty and Harris theaters are situated. Forest City Ratner, a Brooklyn-based company, is expected to develop the site. A Forest City spokeswoman refused to comment on the project. The city is spending $13 million to condemn the buildings, which are currently occupied by pornography shops, peep shows and small movie theaters.
The construction is expected to generate 1,600 jobs and $6.6 million in city tax revenues over a two-year period, sources involved in the negotiations said.
AMC, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., would occupy about 130,000 square feet of the 42d Street complex, and its 25 screens would have a total of 4,900 seats. Before Tussaud's became interested in the site, AMC had proposed opening a 6,000-seat facility in the space. Officials involved in the current talks estimate that AMC and Tussaud's would attract about 2 million visitors each per year. Tussaud's would occupy about 60,000 square feet.
After the construction is completed, the AMC and Tussaud's development will pay about $3 million per year to the city in rent, and it is expected to generate about 2,800 jobs throughout the city, and as much as $15 million annually in city tax revenues.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Lower as Hope For a German Rate Cut Fades

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in thin trading yesterday as expectations waned that the Bundesbank would lower German interest rates.
But the dollar was steady against the Japanese yen, helped by continuing concern that the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan could stage another dollar-buying spree to drive the currency higher. 
 Foreign exchange markets have been focusing their attention on the meeting today of the Bundesbank's policy-setting council. After the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan cut interest rates last week, speculation grew that the German central bank would follow suit. Lower German rates would help the dollar by making mark-denominated deposits less attractive to investors.
Prospects for a rate cut, however, dimmed yesterday after the German Government said western Germany's inflation rate rose an unexpected four-tenths of 1 percent in the month to mid-June. The gain was up from an earlier estimate of three-tenths of 1 percent.
Because the Bundesbank is legally bound to combat inflation, the inflation report dashed hopes for a rate cut.
"There are a lot of arguments for why the Bundesbank shouldn't cut rates now," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Smith Barney. For one thing, the mark has weakened in recent weeks, she said. "But the prospect of cuts later in the year will support the dollar."
The Bundesbank last cut rates on March 30, when it lowered the discount rate on loans to banks by half a percentage point, to a six-year low of 4 percent. Today's meeting is the Bundesbank's last before a four-week summer recess.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.4025 marks from 1.4065 marks on Tuesday.
The dollar slipped to 87.35 Japanese yen, from 87.54 yen on Tuesday. But in Asian trading, the dollar rose above 88 yen for the first time since March 31.
The dollar has been firmer against the yen since Friday, when the Fed and the Bank of Japan surprised traders by buying dollars for yen as the dollar was rising. In recent years, central banks have bought the dollar only when it was falling. Now traders say they must be wary of the banks striking at almost any time.
"The purchases by the Fed and the Bank of Japan have really helped the dollar," said Laurence Hayward, a trader at Nationsbank of Texas in Houston. "The tide is turning."
At yesterday's rates, the dollar is up about 3 percent against the yen and 2 percent against the mark over the last week.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A program that helps the working poor is in trouble.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IMAGINE a Government program that attacks poverty even as it coaxes single parents off welfare. Imagine a program that imposes no costs on employers and does not require an army of bureaucrats to administer.
Well, stop imagining and start admiring the earned-income tax credit, which in the words of Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, sends a "powerful message that we value work -- even the work of those with pathetically low wages." 
 Not surprisingly, the tax credit -- which is provided in the form of supplementary refund to working parents with earnings so low that they owe little or no Federal income tax -- has been the one antipoverty program that those on the right and in the center favor along with the poor's traditional liberal constituency. But that consensus behind wage subsidies for the poor is beginning to crack under pressure to balance the budget. If Senate Republicans have their way, benefits will be substantially rolled back.
The earned-income credit was championed by Ronald Reagan as long ago as 1972, when he was still governor of California. It was added to the tax code during the Administration of Gerald R. Ford. The credit was increased in 1986, 1990 and 1993 with support from both political parties.
By 1996, a family with two or more children is scheduled to receive 40 cents for every dollar earned up to $8,900. In effect, about $2 an hour would be added to the take-home pay of family heads working at the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour. Once a family's income passes $11,620, the credit diminishes sharply in value. One-child families receive a smaller supplement.
President Clinton led the charge for a sweeter tax credit in 1993, seeing it as a way to offset the eroding value of the minimum wage. Conservatives were almost as enthusiastic: the credit makes work more profitable than welfare for many single parents, and it gives Republicans a way to defuse charges that they are indifferent to the fate of the working poor. All told, according to calculations by Sandra Clark and Sheila Zedlewski of the Urban Institute, about 4.5 million Americans will be lifted above the poverty line under the 1996 benefit schedule.
But the Republican-controlled Senate has a different plan. Under the budget resolution adopted by the Senate this spring, benefits would be scaled back to a level even lower than those planned for this year. According to the Treasury Department, some eight million families with two or more children would lose an average of $305 from what they would take home if the 1996 schedule goes ahead as planned. That proposal will not become law unless Congress approves and President Clinton signs the legislation. But the portents are ominous. Indeed, two Republican Senators, William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, have introduced a bill to make much deeper cuts, reducing the average benefits of some eight million families by almost $900 a year.
Why the political change? The obvious explanation is that the earned-income credit is becoming much more expensive. And meeting the Republicans' goal of balancing the budget within seven years without touching Social Security, eliminating cherished weapons programs or raising taxes would require deep cuts just about everywhere else. The Senate majority's approach would spare the Government about $21 billion over seven years, while the Roth-Nickles bill would save three times that much.
The credit has also been losing friends because of charges of rampant fraud. According to Internal Revenue Service estimates, 26 percent of the benefits paid during a two-week audit period in 1994 were paid in error.
But Robert Greenstein, executive director of the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, estimates that tighter procedures already in place have cut this error rate in half. More to the point, he argues, "the answer to fraud is not to cut benefits for honest filers."
Eugene Steuerle, an economist at the Urban Institute who was a senior Treasury official in the Reagan Administration, offers another criticism. As the credit has grown more generous, he notes, perverse incentives have crept into its structure. For one thing, as a family's income rises, the credit's value falls so rapidly that it may serve as a serious disincentive to work more hours for parents on the edge of breaking into the middle class. By the same token, it creates a significant financial barrier to marriage.
For example, in 1996 a single mother with two children and earnings of $8,900 would be eligible for a $3,560 credit. If she married someone with a $10,000 income, however, the credit for both would be worth just $1,529. That would mean 9 percent less for the combined household.
Does all this justify trashing the credit? It's hard to see how. If anything, unskilled workers have suffered more than any other Americans in the last two decades. Government policies limiting antipoverty transfers, Mr. Greenstein suggests, have only added to their woes. And now, he warns, "If we pull the earned-income credit, we pull the rug from under the working poor."

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 445 words

HEADLINE: Tilting Against the Poor

 BODY:
A House Appropriations subcommittee dominated by Republicans voted this week to chop education programs for poor students and job training programs for low-paid workers. It scaled back a program designed to cut medical costs by identifying unnecessary medical procedures. It eliminated entirely a program that helps states design new educational standards.
The vision behind the G.O.P.'s 1996 budget for education, labor and health is radically different -- and woefully misguided. 
 To their credit, the Republicans have made good on their promise to produce a menu of substantial cuts. By terminating over 180 programs, they would eliminate 13 percent in discretionary spending for the labor, education and health departments. Some of their proposals are sound. Community health programs, for example, would be protected. Others are even brave, like the proposal to end the practice of having Congress, rather than scholars, decide which scientific projects to fund.
The missteps take longer to list. The plan cuts Title I aid for schools with poor children by about 18 percent, even though the program might be partially responsible for helping minority students improve test scores. Worse, the subcommittee would direct Title I money away from very poor schools, usually in urban areas. The plan also eliminates the Administration's "Goals 2000" program, which provides money for states to develop education standards. The nation's foremost economic problem is the 20-year stagnation of wages among workers who do not have a college education. Maybe Goals 2000 is not the ideal way to remedy this, but the subcommittee proposes nothing better.
The subcommittee also takes an indiscriminate swipe at Federal job training programs, good and bad. It would cut job training by 30 percent, including successful programs that help dislocated workers find new jobs. The budget plan takes better care of Health and Human Services. Still, it proposes a 20 percent cut in the agency that studies the effectiveness of medical practices -- at a time when the country is desperately trying to help doctors identify treatments that are truly effective rather than merely expensive.
The plan would also trim Head Start, the early education program for poor children, even though recent research demonstrates its effectiveness.
The Republicans previously decided to cut entitlement programs targeted at the poor, like welfare, twice as heavily as other entitlement programs. They also decided to direct most tax cuts toward the wealthy. Now we learn that they are equally determined to cut discretionary programs in ways that tilt, once again, against needy families.

LENGTH: 718 words

HEADLINE: A School! But First, Dinner at Charles's

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

 BODY:
IF reading "The Hot Zone" isn't your idea of fun in the sun, consider enrolling in the Prince of Wales's American Architectural Summer School, where no day will be a beach day and classicism will not refer to Classic Coke or classic rock. The school is to open next year.
Yes, the irrepressible Prince is at it again, this time on our shores. To raise money for the American outpost of his neotraditional Institute for Architecture in London, the Prince will give an intimate dinner party tomorrow night at Highgrove, his Gloucestershire estate. 
 The event will begin with a tour of the estate, then move on to a meal of organic vegetables and lamb bred there. Approximately 25 monied and influential converts to the classical cause are expected to attend, including Barbra (don't call her Nouveau) Streisand; Elton (no more Deco) John; Diana D. Brooks, the chief executive of Sotheby's; Geoffrey J. W. Kent, the chief executive of Abercrombie & Kent, and William Amherst Vanderbilt Cecil, owner of the 8,000-acre Biltmore estate in Asheville, N.C., which will likely serve as the summer school's first American headquarters.
The dinner, described as "a mixture of millionaires" by Colin Amery, director of development for the Prince of Wales's Foundation for Architecture, is expected to raise about $2.5 million for the summer school. Also is the planning stages is a full-time school, preferably one affiliated with an "old university," said Mr. Amery, who is also the architecture critic for The Financial Times.
For a $20,000 pledge made each year for five years, each patron will meet with the Prince twice a year and accompany him on architectural tours. "They might go off to India," Mr. Amery said (a sojourn sure to warm the heart of Kipling). "It will have a certain cachet."
The curriculum for the school is still being formulated, though its philosophical underpinnings will be the Prince's traditional and classicist approach to architecture and town planning, which has been called "retrophilia" by its critics.
The school will probably be modeled after the institute's European summer school, a five- to six-week course that currently accepts 30 students a year. They pay about $3,100 in tuition, though scholarships are available.
Students enrolled in this summer's course, "Civic Architecture," will roost at the 16th-century Palazzo Farnese in Caprarola, Italy, before traveling to Biarritz, France, where the Prince's proteges have been invited by the Mayor to rethink the city's approach to urban renewal.
The American school is being geared to Americans. "We'll give them a good look at the American country house and the American city plan," said Rodney M. Cook Jr., an architectural designer who is a founding director of the Prince's foundation and also a scion of one of Atlanta's oldest families.
The course is expected to start at Biltmore, the nation's largest house, which Mr. Cecil has transformed into what he calls a "nicely profitable" tourist attraction, with nearly 800,000 visitors a year. In addition to its architectural merits, Biltmore was selected, Mr. Amery said, because "it is an example of community renewal, where conservation has been made profitable with no public money, which is where the future lies."
After soaking up the towers and turrets designed by Richard Morris Hunt -- and also Mr. Cecil's business acumen -- students will travel on to Washington, where they will study urban planning and Mount Vernon from their base at the National Building Museum.
Meanwhile, if all goes according to plan, tomorrow evening will find Ms. Streisand -- who said through a spokesman that she loves classical architecture -- and others discussing triglyphs and metopes and oohing and aahing over the Prince's walled kitchen garden, his aromatic Thyme Walk, topiaries clipped into the shapes of crowns and Hollyrood House, his architecturally earnest treehouse.
"I'm going to listen intently and suggest the Prince come over" to open his school, Mr. Cecil said. But he seemed chagrined when he heard that celebrities would be at the dinner. "I wouldn't cross a ditch for them," he said.
If you miss the Prince's summer school (a k a Camp Carbuncle), his architectural magazine, called Perspectives, is coming soon to a newsstand near you.

HEADLINE: No. 3 Bond-Rating Service Gives City an A-, and Giuliani Cheers

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Four years ago, Moody's Investors Service disappointed City Hall by downgrading New York City's bonds. On Monday, Standard & Poor's did the same. So yesterday, when the lesser-known Fitch Investors Service declared that it would not downgrade, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani treated the announcement as a bit of a triumph.
"This is really good news for the city," he said, after aides summoned reporters for what they were billing as a major announcement. 
 Compared with the two big credit agencies, Fitch is a distant third in terms of size and influence. It had never even rated a New York general-obligation bond until 1993. But Fitch's willingness to hold steady its A- rating on the city's bonds does mean something significant for the city: it allows some institutional investors to put their money into New York bonds.
Many such investors, including some mutual funds, are restricted from buying bonds rated less than A-. A narrowing market for the bonds could mean the city would have to pay more in interest costs.
On Monday, Standard & Poor's lowered its rating of the city's bonds from A- to BBB+, citing the sluggish local economy and fiscal gimmickry by the Mayor in balancing the city budget. Moody's has rated the bonds Baa1 since 1991.
The Mayor had earlier criticized Standard & Poor's decision, saying the agency was actually rectifying a mistake it had made in 1993 when it chose not to lower the city's bond rating in the midst of the mayoral campaign. The agency's criticisms, he said, were "disingenous," and he predicted that no one would even remember the agency's decision a week later.
At yesterday's news conference, however, Mr. Giuliani went out of his way to stress the importance of the Fitch decision in contrast to that of the much larger Standard & Poor's.
"It demonstrates that an objective outside rating service, seeing both the pluses and the minuses of the budget and the future financial progress of the city, comes to the conclusion that its credit rating should continue at A-," he said.
In its announcement, Fitch said the city's newly adopted 1996 budget "reflects significant progress toward achieving ongoing balance." Standard & Poor's, by contrast, said such balance "remains elusive."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Higher Earnings Spur Rally in Stock Market
Stocks established another round of records, spurred by higher corporate earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 46.69 points, to 4,727.29. At one point, the Dow rose more than 50 points, setting off the New York Stock Exchange's circuit breakers for the eighth time this year.
Analysts said it was a wild day of trading as institutions placed five rounds of "buy" programs in about an hour, with much of the buying concentrated in technology issues. The S.& P. 500 index also set a record, rising 6.11 points, to 560.89. [Page D8.] 

The bond market expected today's producer price report to show lower inflation, and traders pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.54 percent. [D18.]
 
Aetna Adds to Reserves Aetna is adding $750 million to its reserves to cover claims for environmental damage, a move that will result in a second-quarter loss of several hundred million dollars. [D2.]
 
CBS Earnings Plummet
CBS said its net income fell 52 percent, to $51.9 million, in the second quarter, pulled down by lower profit at its television network and a one-time charge for staff cuts. [D5.]
 
Hexcel to Combine with Ciba-Geigy
Hexcel has agreed to combine with the composites division of Ciba-Geigy. Ciba would acquire 49.9 percent of Hexcel's common stock in exchange for Ciba Composites. [D3.]
 
Report Due on Barings
By the end of next week, Britain will publish a report that is expected to criticize the lack of controls at Barings and to raise questions about why the firm did not act on warnings that something was amiss in Singapore. [D6.]
 
U.P.S. Backs Off Mexico
The opening of Mexican markets to American business under the terms of the North American Free Trade agreement faltered for the first time this week with the decision by United Parcel Service to cancel some of its ground services in Mexico as of July 31. U.P.S.'s said inspections by Mexican customs authorities were "very burdensome" and time-consuming. [D2.]
 
Pfizer Appoints Executive
Pfizer appointed Karen L. Katen, a corporate vice president, as president of its United States Pharmaceuticals Group. [D3.]
 
TV Chip Gains in House
An influential member of the House Commerce Committee threw his support behind legislation that would make TV manufacturers include a chip to block violent shows in all new sets. [D4.]
 
Ship Comes in at Chemical
It was touch and go, but 38,000 workers at Chemical Banking were a little wealthier thanks to an afternoon surge in the stock market that pushed Chemical stock up 37.5 cents, to $50.375, allowing them to cash in on a special share offering that the company announced last year. [D3.]
 
Two Exchanges Plan a Move
The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange said they intended to shift trading operations to Jersey City, a move that could take more than 5,000 jobs out of New York City. [D6.]
 
Testimony Reveals Clashes
After five days of testimony in a lawsuit brought by a dismissed executive against Ronald O. Perelman's company, it has become clear that the two men clashed over much more than the time the executive took to care for his ailing wife. [D3.]
