HEADLINE: Executive's Visit May Decide Fate of New York Newsday

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
Another New York City tabloid is fighting for its life. But this time there are no eccentric millionaires, no newsroom rebellions, no angry strikers outside the newspaper doors.
The paper, New York Newsday, has always been more sedate than its rowdier tabloid rivals, The New York Post and The Daily News. So it seems fitting that, instead of the public brawl the other papers stage whenever they are in danger, this newspaper crisis is being played out in more somber settings: in executive sessions in board rooms and at quiet lunches. 
 Yesterday, amid efforts by Newsday executives to shape a business argument for keeping New York Newsday alive, the new chief executive of the corporate owner, the Times Mirror Company, visited the paper for the first time.
Although there was no word of exactly what was discussed by the new executive, Mark H. Willes, and the paper's publisher, Raymond A. Jansen, it was clear that "the New York Newsday question" was on the agenda. The newspaper is the New York City edition of Newsday, published in Melville, L.I.
Mr. Jansen, publisher of both newspapers, is arguing that New York Newsday's losses have been exaggerated and that the city edition is too entwined with the Long Island edition for the company to give up on it, his associates say.
But for Mr. Willes, a former General Mills executive who has been the company's chief executive since June 1, the issue involves more than dollars and cents, analysts said. "It is a symbol," said one investment banker with close ties to Times Mirror. "It was a sacred cow and now it's something that has to be looked at very carefully. It's one of the first things he is looking at. The decision about what to do will be symbolic."
After a 10-year effort by Times Mirror to build a New York City newspaper -- a struggle that newspaper industry analysts say has produced $100 million in losses -- Mr. Willis is expected to decide the paper's fate soon.
Mr. Willes is clearly under pressure from investors and stock analysts to improve the lagging financial performance of Times Mirror, based in Los Angeles. In addition, people who have talked with board members say that those members representing the founding Chandler family have lost patience with losses in New York City and are pressing for rapid action.
In a lunch with the paper's senior managers in Melville yesterday, Mr. Willes gave no hints about the future of New York Newsday, a Pulitzer Prize-winning paper, one Newsday staff member said. The new chief executive, a finance and economics expert with no journalism background, observed that both New York Newsday and its Long Island parent were "excellent" but said they needed to perform better financially, the staff member said.
On a tour of New York Newsday's Park Avenue newsroom during the afternoon, Mr. Willes passed the desk of a reporter, Dena Bunis, who handed him a button that the paper's union had made up after he was named chief executive. It said, "New York Newsday: Too Smart to Die."
Mr. Willes put it on his lapel. But even Ms. Bunis said she was not sure what that meant. "I can't read anything into it," she said. "He's a nice man. He took my button."
Although New York Newsday is weak in circulation, it has often been praised as an experiment aimed at reinventing the urban newspaper. It aims to appeal to a new middle class by combining the snap of tabloid journalism with the in-depth coverage of more sober newspapers.
In recent weeks, a furious effort has been under way behind the scenes at Newsday to persuade the corporate owner to keep New York Newsday alive. Mr. Jansen, who has been publisher since last November, has become a strong advocate of New York Newsday, people who work with him say.
Mr. Jansen has carefully put together a case for saying that New York Newsday's losses have been overstated both publicly and inside the company.
Two people associated with Newsday who have been briefed on Mr. Jansen's work say he is arguing that the New York edition is close to breaking even -- perhaps as soon as next year -- and that a retreat now would only harm Long Island Newsday and reduce the value of the entire paper.
Mr. Jansen's predecessor once said New York Newsday's losses were $8 to $14 million annually, but Mr. Jansen has concluded that New York Newsday lost less than $4 million last year, the people associated with the paper said. With sharp new cuts in expenses, perhaps includingstaff reductions, Mr. Jansen is arguing that he could cut this year's losses by an additional $3 million, they added.
One of those sources summarized Mr. Jansen's argument as saying that "the numbers do not support a shutdown of New York Newsday." Both of them spoke on the condition that they would not be identified.
Newsday executives have long argued that the New York edition is necessary to give advertisers a wider audience, for which they pay an added rate. In addition, the Newsday executives argue that growth will be limited if the paper is confined to Nassau and Suffolk Counties. They also say that the paper will lose the circulation gains it has made over the years in Queens and Brooklyn if it gives up full coverage of the city.
Since Mr. Jansen was appointed in November, he has moved to reverse sharp circulation losses that have made the paper vulnerable to critics inside Times Mirror. Since 1993, New York Newsday's average daily circulation has plunged, from nearly 275,000 to 216,000.
New York Newsday has experimented with cutting the newsstand cost to 25 cents in the Bronx and 35 cents in Brooklyn. In Manhattan, the paper has been experimenting with tokens that let readers buy the 50-cent paper at half-price.
A spokeswoman for Newsday said its efforts had brought the average daily circulation up to 231,000 in June, an increase of 15,000.
In preparation for the meetings yesterday, Mr. Jansen and aides reviewed the way Newsday has allocated costs between the New York City and Long Island editions. They concluded, the people who were briefed on Mr. Jansen's work said, that too many costs, like those of combined sports coverage, were assigned to the New York City edition even though both papers benefited.
Even so, some analysts who study newspaper stocks are calling for Mr. Willes to face what they say is the reality that New York Newsday has been a good journalistic idea that has not worked as a business.
But others, like John S. Reidy of Smith Barney, say they are not convinced that New York Newsday's losses, whatever they are, are significant enough to Times Mirror to make it worth the embarrassment of admitting defeat.
Mr. Reidy acknowledged, however, that Mr. Willes is a man who needs to make a mark quickly. Closing New York Newsday, he said, "would be a way to say, 'We've stanched this losing operation.' That would ring a bell with some investors."

Producer Prices Down, Easing Inflation Fear
 The producer price index fell one-tenth of 1 percent for finished goods in June, the second consecutive month with no inflation at the last stage before goods reach consumers. 
 Economists said the report reinforced the decision by the Federal Reserve last week to ease monetary policy and suggested there was more leeway for the Fed to cut rates further. [Page D2.]
 
Clinton Backs F.D.A. on Tobacco
 The White House indicated that it supports an F.D.A. proposal to declare nicotine a drug and regulate cigarette sales to minors. [A18.]
 
Hostile Bid for Big British Utility
 The Southern Company began a $1.6 billion hostile takeover bid for South Western Electricity, a British utility. [D16.]
 
Health Care Bill Introduced
 Senators Nancy Landon Kassebaum and Edward M. Kennedy introduced health care legislation that would require insurers to cover people with existing medical problems and to enable workers to keep insurance when they leave their jobs. [A18.]
 
F.D.A. Backs Merck Drug
 Fosamax, a new Merck treatment for osteoporosis, was recommended for approval by the F.D.A., and final approval could come by the end of the year. [D3.]
 
U.S. Approves Bid for Sprint Stake
 The Justice Department approved a $4.2 billion offer by the French and German telephone companies to acquire about 20 percent of Sprint. [D5.]
 
Car-Part Imports Fall Short
 Japanese automobile manufacturers bought $19.86 billion of American-made parts in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, falling short of the industry's target. [D5.]
 
McDonnell Douglas Contract
 Britain awarded McDonnell Douglas and GKN a $4 billion contract to supply 67 helicopters to the Royal Army, beating out a three-year-old joint venture led by British Aerospace. [D5.]
 
New Offer for Olympia & York U.S.A.
 A leading real estate developer and the largest creditor of Olympia & York U.S.A. made an unsolicited bid for the company. [D2.]
 
Outlook Still Solid for Archer
 Shares of Archer-Daniels-Midland have fallen after revelations of a criminal antitrust inquiry, but the stock's long-term outlook is about as good as they come for commodities-based companies. Market Place. [D6.]
 Satellite Rules Proposed
The F.C.C. proposed rules that would let new global satellite communications systems share a segment of the airwaves with a technology for transmitting TV channels over microwave frequencies. [D4.]
 
Remote-Proof Advertising
 As more consumers zap television commercials, advertisers have hit on new strategies to get their messages across in zap-proof formats. Media giants like Turner Broadcasting System, Blockbuster Entertainment and Capital Cities/ABC are now beaming programming to televison screens in places like airline terminals, subway platforms and supermarkets, where viewers can't touch that dial. Advertising. [D4.]

 The new chief executive of Times Mirror met with the publisher of Newsday, and it was likely that the future of New York Newsday was on the agenda. [B4.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
McDonnell and Partner Win $4 Billion British Copter Deal

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 13

 BODY:
The British Government awarded an order worth 2.5 billion, or $4 billion, today to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of the United States and GKN P.L.C. of Britain to supply 67 helicopters to the Royal Army.
The bid by GKN's Westland unit to supply the McDonnell-designed Apache helicopter, equipped with engines made by Rolls-Royce P.L.C., was selected over those of six others, including British Aerospace P.L.C. and General Electric of Britain. The latter company is not related to the American concern of the same name. 
 McDonnell Douglas landed another big award today, a $1 billion contract from the United States Air Force for additional testing and improvement of the company's C-17 cargo jet. It is the first order in an effort to identify, test and produce improvements at the prototype stage of the problem-plagued jet, which has drawn criticism in Congress. The work is expected to be completed in 2000.
The order from the British Government dealt a blow to Westland's main competitor, Eurocopter, a three-year-old joint venture led by British Aerospace that includes Daimler-Benz A.G.'s Deutsche Aerospace unit and Aerospatiale of France. It builds the Tigre attack helicopter.
"Apache has demonstrated its value in service with the U.S. Army," Michael Portillo, the British Defense Secretary, said after announcing the order in Parliament.
GKN acquired Westland more than a year ago to expand beyond its main business, making parts for the European auto industry.
"It means that they've got plenty to do until the year 2002," said Nick Cunningham, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd.
Eurocopter is Europe's largest helicopter maker, with a 50 percent share of the commercial market and about one-quarter of the military market, excluding the United States and Russia.
Military business has been steadily shrinking, with helicopter orders falling below $7 billion last year, from nearly $8 billion in 1993. Analysts see little prospect of a recovery in the next few years.
In April, the Dutch Government placed an $830 million order for 30 Apache AH-64D helicopters, the choice of the Defense Ministry, rather than the Tigre preferred by the Economics Ministry.
Officials said the dollar's decline against the guilder and the Apache's use in the Persian Gulf war had persuaded them to buy the McDonnell Douglas helicopter.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Buys More U.S. Auto Parts

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, July 14

 BODY:
Japanese automobile manufacturers bought $19.86 billion of American-made parts and materials in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, an industry trade group said this morning.
The figure surpassed a voluntary goal of $19 billion set during President George Bush's visit to Japan in 1992, but fell substantially short of the auto industry's target for importing American parts into Japan. Imports totaled $3.23 billion, compared with a target of $4 billion, according to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. 
 The announcement of the results by the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association closes the book on voluntary plans for parts purchases that include numerical targets, at least as far as the Japanese Government is concerned.
Late last month, as part of a last-minute trade agreement that averted United States sanctions on Japanese luxury cars, Japan's five leading automobile companies announced new voluntary plans for increasing their vehicle manufacturing in the United States and for purchasing more American parts.
But the new plans do not include specific goals for purchases of American parts. President Clinton estimated that the planned increases would raise annual purchases by $9 billion in three years, but the Japanese Government said that was an estimate by Washington that it did not endorse.
President Bush's 1992 visit to Tokyo was regarded at the time as a failure, but the agreement he achieved was actually far more explicit in setting numerical goals than the "results oriented" pact recently announced by President Clinton.
During President Bush's visit, the Japanese automobile industry, prodded by the trade ministry, set a target of purchasing $19 billion of American parts in the year that ended on March 31, more than doubling the $9 billion purchased in the year that ended in March 1991.
Of the total, $4 billion of parts were to be imported to Japan and $15 billion were to be used in Japanese-owned automobile factories in the United States.
The industry procured $16.63 billion of parts and materials for use in the United States in the last fiscal year, surpassing that target. But the auto makers said imports to Japan fell short because production of vehicles here declined. Car sales have fallen because of the Japanese economic slump and a shift of car manufacturing out of Japan as the yen has risen sharply against the dollar.
The total of $19.86 billion in American parts purchases was an increase of 28 percent from the previous year.
Despite the big gains in purchases of American parts, some American parts makers have complained that a substantial amount of the "American" parts purchased by the Japanese actually came from Japanese-owned parts companies that set up factories in the United States.
In that sense, they have said, the 1992 agreement did not succeed in breaking up the so-called keiretsu relationships between Japanese companies and their suppliers, but only extended the system to the United States.
Moreover, despite the doubling of Japanese purchases of American parts since 1991, the United States' trade deficit with Japan in car parts has continued to rise, reaching $12.8 billion in 1994, compared with $9.1 billion in 1991. This is because as Japanese companies have shifted car manufacturing to the United States, the export of parts for those cars from Japan has also increased.
All of Japan's top five auto makers -- Toyota, Nissan, Mazda, Honda and Mitsubishi Motors -- missed their targets for importing parts into Japan. In addition, Mazda fell short of its goal for parts used in the United States, while the four other companies exceeded their goals in this category. Combining imports and local procurement, Toyota, Nissan and Mitsubishi achieved their targets; Honda and Mazda fell short.
Having the Japanese companies extend and increase their 1992 plans beyond this year was a demand of Washington in the recent trade talks. But Japanese Government officials and companies this time refused to agree to numbers, saying it would constitute "managed trade."

HEADLINE: Fed's No. 2 Is Said to Be Dissatisfied

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Raising a delicate political question, Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, has been expressing dissatisfaction with his job to Administration officials, leading the White House to begin looking for a possible successor when his term ends in January, officials said today.
Mr. Blinder has long been interested in becoming chairman of the Federal Reserve. But the Administration has been strongly leaning toward reappointing Alan Greenspan -- who is popular among Republicans in the Senate whose approval is needed for the job. Mr. Greenspan's four-year term ends in March. 
 Reversing course on Mr. Greenspan's reappointment would be extremely difficult, unless the Fed's string of interest rate increases last year ends up contributing to a deep recession later this year, providing the political cover to replace him.
If Mr. Blinder is not given the chairmanship, he is expected by some associates to return to his post as an economics professor at Princeton University, where his leave of absence expires at the end of this year. Mr. Blinder, reached by telephone at home today, declined to comment.
One vacancy has already arisen on the seven-member Fed board of governors with the retirement of John P. LaWare, a New England banker, on April 30. This week, the Administration has begun assembling a list of possible nominees for that slot, but with a specific eye to finding someone who could also serve as vice chairman.
Among possible nominees for the board vacancy are Sheila L. Tschinkel, the research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, and Richard F. Syron, the president of the American Stock Exchange and a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, Federal officials said today. If Mr. Blinder steps down, Mr. Syron -- a well-known figure on Wall Street -- may have the edge for his post on the Fed board.
Ms. Tschinkel and Mr. Syron both declined to comment today.
Mr. Blinder, a distinguished economist and early Clinton supporter, has many fans in the White House, where he won praise for agreeing at the start of the Administration to settle for an unglamorous appointment as one of three members of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. But the White House has had big troubles winning Senate confirmation of nominees for positions far less important than the Fed chairman and does not relish a fight with Republicans over the Fed, particularly in an election year.
The assessment of some Administration and Congressional officials has been that it would be difficult, if not impossible, to win Senate confirmation of Mr. Blinder, a moderate Democrat who has a reputation for being slightly more willing than some Fed colleagues to accept higher inflation to preserve job growth. Mr. Greenspan, by contrast, was appointed by President Ronald Reagan and reappointed by President George Bush and has many Republican allies, dating to his time as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Gerald R. Ford.
The possibility that the vice chairman's post might be opening may make it a bit easier for the Administration to find someone willing to brave the difficulties of the nomination process and the occupational hazards of being a Fed governor.
The Administration's first choice for Mr. LaWare's slot this spring was Alicia Munnell, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for Economic Policy and a former research director at the Boston Fed. But Ms. Munnell was one of the authors of a controversial study by the Boston Fed in 1992 that found a pattern of discrimination by Boston banks against black and Hispanic mortgage applicants.
Commercial bankers have carried a grudge against her ever since and strenuously lobbied Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee this spring to block her nomination. The Clinton Administration concluded two weeks ago that fighting to put her on the Fed board would not be worth the struggle, and nominated her instead to become a member of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Fed governors, and particularly the vice chairman, face a difficult balancing act once in office. Most feel a duty to explain their reasoning to the public, yet they risk alarming financial markets if they make an unexpected comment about interest rates or the economy's health.
Mr. Greenspan has also steadily consolidated his power within the Fed, overshadowing the other governors. When the Fed reduced short-term interest rates slightly last week, the announcement was made in Mr. Greenspan's name for the first time, rather than in the institution's name. And while vice chairmen have played a strong role on international policy in the past, Mr. Greenspan has increasingly in the last year attended international meetings of central bankers.
The vice chairmanship brings no additional pay. Governors earn $123,100 a year while the chairman earns $133,600.
Mr. Greenspan's current term as Fed chairman expires on March 2. If not renominated to the post, he would no doubt give up the rest of his 14-year term, which does not expire until Jan. 31, 2006. Mr. Blinder's terms as vice chairman and governor expire together in January.

HEADLINE: Threat, and Resolve to Spend, In Debate on Capital's Finances

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Hardly a day passes that somewhere in the nation's capital local officials are not wrangling over the city's financial crisis. But today was unusual for the number of people involved.
While the city's new financial control board discussed future budgets at its first public hearing, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and a leading House Republican, James T. Walsh of Syracuse, argued over the current budget, with Mr. Walsh suggesting that Mr. Barry could face Federal prosecution for overspending. 
 The combination made for a rare and perhaps important day in a city where residents have grown accustomed to erratic trash removal, ineffective public schools and insufficient social services. Despite evident disagreements at the board's session and the Mayor's meeting, both ended with a sense of measured optimism.
In his latest go-round with Congress over the budget for the 1995 fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, Mr. Barry discussed with Mr. Walsh, who heads the House Appropriations Subcommittee on the District of Columbia, his plan to spend about $120 million. That amount would cover a shortfall for social services, including Medicaid and the chief welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. About half of the District's children are on welfare.
Mr. Walsh has repeatedly stressed to the mayor and other city officials that they cannot exceed the $3.254 billion budget approved by Congress for this fiscal year; Mr. Barry wants to spend $3.371 billion.
They have danced around this discrepancy for some time now. But Mr. Barry underscored his resolve two weeks ago with an executive order that transferred discretionary spending authority over Medicaid and welfare programs to him, even if it meant exceeding the budget would violate the Federal Anti-Deficiency Act, a rarely enforced law that is over 170 years old. His reasoning, he said, was that the entitlement programs should be maintained and that he, not cabinet members, should take responsibility for any budgetary impact.
Mr. Walsh responded on Wednesday with a letter to Attorney General Janet Reno, asking for an interpretation of the law as it might relate to Mr. Barry's over-spending plans.
"If the law is valid and enforceable, it should be enforced," Mr. Walsh said after meeting with the Mayor. "If he's violating the law, it's the Attorney General's responsibility to pursue that."
Mr. Walsh criticized Mr. Barry and his predecessor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, for creating a climate of "indigenous, intrinsic overspending" in city government. At the same time, he said that he understands Mr. Barry "has a job to do." He also said he trusts Mr. Barry.
Mr. Barry emerged from the meeting looking as if he had not a care in the world, least of all prosecution under an obscure Federal statute that outlines fines and prison terms for over-spenders and was believed to have last been enforced in the District in 1910.
Congress, he pointed out, "has overspent billions of Federal dollars" through the years and no one has been held criminally accountable. "The law needs to be re-examined," he said.
He also said Mr. Walsh "understands the problem we have."
Unlike the Mayor's meeting, which lasted only half-an-hour, the control board's session ran all day. It began with dozens of people, each with a three-minute limit, imploring the members to act one way or another, pleading with them to save this program or that. Many praised the board, which was created this year by Congress and filled by Presidential appointments, as the last real chance to correct years of mismanagement and bad government. The board has final approval over anything in city government with an impact on the budget.
But others criticized it as an invasive layer of bureaucracy that erodes the limited autonomy Congress granted the city two decades ago. One speaker threatened to challenge the Constitutionality of the board in court.
If there was one common element to their message, it was a depth of despair with the city in its current state. One leader of a local government watchdog group warned board members of Mr. Barry's apparent strategy "to face you down in a game of chicken."
Later, the board disclosed a series of recommendations to harness the next budget, and in his first news conference, Andrew F. Brimmer, the economist chosen to head the board, expressed his belief that city leaders would pay close attention.
"I am confident," he said, "that the Mayor and the city council will be very, very responsive. If I didn't believe that, I would have to conclude that the recommendations we're making would be thrown away. I don't think that's going to happen."
Mr. Brimmer also promised that the public would have access to the board and input into its decisions.
"Our phone number is not a secret," he said, turning to a staff member. "Tell them what the phone number is."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1557 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
For U.S. Business, a Hard Road to Vietnam

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, July 13

 BODY:
Like a great triumphal gateway, two newly painted, giant Coca-Cola bottles greet visitors in bold Vietnamese on either side of the four-lane highway from the airport: "Coke welcomes you to Hanoi."
There is no Coca-Cola bottling plant in the country yet -- it is on the verge of opening -- but the message is clear: American companies are here and, like the new red paint on the Coke sign, are hurrying to catch up with other foreign companies, which have been here many years. 
 Despite the lifting of the United States embargo on trade and investment with Vietnam 18 months ago, American companies are still scrambling to meet competition from Asia and Europe -- commerce that is propelling this desperately poor country toward an age of consumerism.
Billboards for Daewoo, the South Korean conglomerate, and for Sony, Toshiba, Peugeot and British Petroleum dot this city jammed with Honda motor scooters and Japanese cars. Danish, Singaporean and Japanese beer is served at little sidewalk restaurants, and an Australian telephone system handles calls.
Now, with the normalization of relations between Washington and Hanoi, people in both nations expect a welter of legislation to spur development and investment. High on the list is preferred trading status for Vietnam, which they say is sorely needed to promote American business. Still, no one here is predicting a great surge in investment in a country that on paper has a per-capita gross domestic product of $250 a year.
But few are dismissing its prospects. Vietnam has more than 73 million people, fewer than Germany but more than France or Britain. Some manufacturers see a low-wage source for parts. Consumer-products companies hope for a potentially large market, and big energy companies are curious about Vietnam's offshore oil and natural gas reserves, though some recent indications about their size have been disappointing.
"More than 50 countries with more than 1,200 investment licenses worth more than $14 billion are here," said Nguyen Mai, deputy minister of the State Committee for Cooperation and Investment, which oversees foreign investment projects. "Since the lifting of the U.S. embargo on Vietnam, there have been 44 investor projects with a total investment of $700 million."
Among the biggest so far are the oil-exploration efforts of the Mobil Corporation, an equipment-leasing operation by Caterpillar, and the installation of elevators in new office buildings by United Technologies' Otis Elevator Company.
Still, "for the time being," Mr. Mai said, "we would not put so much hope on American investment."
Over the last nine years, Taiwan, followed closely by investors from Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Japan have led the investment invasion here. In the last six months, Japan has emerged as Vietnam's biggest foreign investor, with 30 projects valued at $754 million, more than a fifth of the $3.6 billion worth approved in the first half of this year. In the same period, American investors won approval for 11 projects worth $295 million.
Yet "the U.S. has come from nowhere to No. 5 in investments," said Do Duc Dinh, who heads the economic study department at the semiofficial Institute on the World Economy here. "Clearly normalization is necessary," he said. "But there are other things that are important, like most-favored-nation status. And the second, financial-risk insurance is essential for American businesses."
Most-favored-nation status, which grants countries that trade with the United States the lowest tariffs on exported goods, must be approved by Congress as well as obtaining a Presidential finding that Vietnam allows free and open emigration.
For the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Federal agency that helps Americans invest abroad, to provide insurance or financial guarantees to businesses, Vietnam must be shown to comply with international laws on workers' rights.
Export-Import Bank financing, often a crucial ingredient in big projects with American involvement, is currently unavailable to Vietnam because it is classified as a Marxist-Leninist country, and thus ineligible.
Trade and investment have a way of playing out at a personal level. Eugene A. Matthews, an entrepreneur from western Pennsylvania, bit into a chocolate covered ice-cream bar made by a Vietnamese dairy, savored the mouthful and pronounced, "Holsteins are the Jaguars of cows. All the rest are Chevys."
Not a man familiar with the intricacies of dairy farming -- he spent several years in Japan as an investment banker -- Mr. Matthews is nonetheless days away from closing a deal that will bring thousands of big Holsteins to Vietnam from the United States to form what he says will be the country's biggest dairy. And as a longtime consultant to companies here, he points to his dairy deal as a model of what works in Vietnam.
"I don't want to look at anything the Government doesn't regard as a priority," he said. "In this case dairy is a priority, so people are nice to you. They want to get this done."
Even so, Mr. Matthews went on, conducting business here is not easy. He has been working on the dairy project for more than a year -- part of the time trying to figure out if Holsteins would do well in Vietnam's tropical climate.
"It's still Vietnam," he said. "It's still a complicated place. It's still bureaucratic. But there is a system here and it does work."
By the lean measuring rod of Government statistics, Vietnam is a country where people have barely enough to get through the year, hardly an attractive market for Pepsi and Coke, Motorola or Procter & Gamble. But the $250 a year in official annual G.D.P. belies an explosion of urban consumer consciousness.
For those who can afford such goods, the shopfronts along tree-lined boulevards bulge with cartons of Japanese televison sets. Glass cabinets in shops are crammed with Nikon and Olympus cameras, Ray Ban sunglasses from Bausch & Lomb and the competing Ralph Lauren glasses from Optique du Monde.
"There is a huge unofficial economy," said Mr. Dinh, the institute official. "For most people, we can live only 5 days or 10 days a month on our salary. But people build houses. Where does the money come from? Even in Government ministries, there are two sets of books -- one for official money and one for unofficial."
And everywhere the favored currency is the American dollar; even the meters in taxicabs count up the fare in dollars.
Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, where American influence is strongest, has witnessed the greatest surge in investment and is where Vietnamese enjoy the highest standard of living. Foreign businesses, according to Richmond Mayo-Smith, president of the American Chamber of Commerce there, argued that doing business is not necessarily easy, but easier than in many other places.
"A lot of the people who've been in developing countries say easier than most, but it's still not easy," he explained. "It takes patience and time to find the right partner and follow the right procedures. It can be time-consuming. It's expensive. For housing and office supply, the demand is greater than supply.
"But, the people here are much more cooperative than in China," he added. "It's not us and them. Once you've formed a joint venture, the cooperation is relatively smooth. And American business is very welcome here. They're very open to American business. They believe Americans are sincere when they enter in, that American business has certain standards of conduct, that it's more responsible. And they know Americans treat employees quite well."
Vietnam has a considerable distance to go before it joins the ranks of the Asian tigers.
"We're just a small elephant," Mr. Dinh joked. Plans for a stock exchange in Ho Chi Minh City have been put off twice. The banking system is primitive -- checks are virtually unknown. State-owned companies, which produced about 43 percent of the gross domestic product last year, are sluggish and more than a third are money-losers. And the country's roads, rail, telecommunications, power and airports lag well behind Asian neighbors. The legal system is skeletal.
But foreign investors keep coming. Last fall, the Exxon Corporation opened an office here to market lubricants and asphalt. It had been exploring for oil and gas for 20 years until it left the country in 1975. "In the longer term, Exxon is looking at a full range of marketing in Vietnam," said Ed Burwell, a spokesman.
Amy Myers Jaffe, senior editor at Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, said that many companies explored off shore, expecting a hot spot, and many were disappointed. But of the Americans, Mobil made the biggest discovery.
Still, she added: "I don't perceive that there's going to be a steady flow of companies going into Vietnam. I wouldn't say Vietnam was a dry hole, but it wasn't as big a find as people thought it'd be."
By contrast, Marie Belsey, the country manager for British Gas, is enthusiastic about Vietnam, particularly about prospects for oil and gas in the waters off the coast.
"It could be the North Sea," she said, referring to the abundant oilfields off Britain and Norway, "but I don't think it will be a country dominated by oil.
"Vietnam," she said, "goes through phases. It's talked up and it's talked down. Nobody's walked away yet."

HEADLINE: Decrying Base-Closing Plan as an 'Outrage,' the President Gives a Grudging Go-Ahead

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
President Clinton gave a grudging go-ahead today to closing or consolidating 105 military bases. The shutdowns, a consequence of the end of the cold war, are expected to save billions of Federal dollars but put tens of thousands of people out of work.
Furiously pounding the lectern in a Rose Garden talk with reporters, the President called an independent commission's recommendations to close two large Air Force depots in California and Texas "an outrage" that ignored the economic pain it inflicted. He said his political enemies had made "a calculated, deliberate attempt" to turn his efforts to preserve jobs at those bases "into a political thing, and to obscure the real economic impact." 
 The President was caught between a consensus in Congress that the nation needs to close military bases -- as long as they are in someone else's district -- and the prospect of throwing thousands of voters off the Federal payroll in two states crucial to his re-election. But Mr. Clinton said his sole political concern was "the political economy of America, and what happens to the people in these communities, and are they being treated fairly."
But Haley Barbour, the Republican National Committee chairman, said the White House itself had politicized the process "because they were trying to curry favor, or thought they were, with voters in California." And the White House press secretary, Mike McCurry, said the President's pique was in some part due to the "political fallout" of the base closings.
Mr. Clinton's anger focused on the recommendations to close maintenance depots at McClellan Air Force Base in Sacramento, Calif., and Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio. He had been seeking assurances from the Pentagon that thousands of jobs could be shifted to the private sector in those states.
California's Democratic Senators, Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein, expressed displeasure at the decision, and Senator Boxer said she was skeptical that the Pentagon's privatization plans would preserve jobs in Sacramento. Representative Henry B. Gonzales, a Democrat from San Antonio, called the decision "a tragedy."
McClellan and Kelly were the biggest military bases listed by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which recommended that 79 be closed and 26 others realigned, saving $19.3 billion during 20 years. Nationwide, 43,742 soldiers and civilians could lose their jobs as a direct result; thousands more could be put out of work at fast-food outlets and other businesses surrounding the bases. Congress must now vote to reject the list in 45 days or it will automatically take effect.
The commission, an independent body created to remove politics from the post cold-war process of scaling back military bases, said California stood to lose 19,372 military and civilian jobs as a result of the closings -- about 11,000 of them at McClellan.
The effect will not be immediate, Deputy Defense Secretary John White said today. About 8,700 jobs at the base will be maintained as it slowly closes during the next five years, he said, and perhaps 50 percent of those jobs, mostly maintenance work on Air Force jets, may be preserved thereafter by private employers.
That is uncertain, given that military contractors have cut more than two million jobs since Pentagon spending peaked in 1985, according to the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament, a private nonprofit group in Washington. The group said today that 145,000 civilian military workers were laid off last year, and noted that Congress plans to cut programs for retraining and counseling laid-off employees.
Commission members said California had lost so many military jobs because it had so many to lose. Several pointed out in interviews that their assignment was to first consider the military value of a base, and only secondarily the economic effect of closing it.
"Any claim that the commission acted politically is a fairy tale," said Wendi Steele, a member of the commission who has worked in the defense and aerospace industries and as a White House and Congressional aide.
Another member of the commission, Gen. Joe Robles, the former commander of the Army's First Infantry Division, said the Pentagon's instructions were to weigh eight factors of descending importance in deciding a base's fate. "The first four are military, the fifth is whether a closure makes economic sense, and the sixth is economic impact -- and we looked at economic impact very carefully and very studiously," he said.
"This is painful now." he said. "But the gain is that we save 19 billion dollars. We were chartered to make the tough calls, save money and protect military readiness. We did."

HEADLINE: It May Be Near Wall Street, But Not Shouting Distance

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Since the days of sailing ships and mercantile princes, lower Manhattan has retained its position as the place where trade deals get done. Companies may rise and fall, but the exchanges go on and on.
That historic link may now be challenged, with the plans announced on Wednesday by two of the oldest commodities exchanges to move to Jersey City. The departure would cost New York 5,000 jobs, but for both sides of the Hudson, the implications go much further. 
 The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange, which signed a 90-day letter of intent with New Jersey on Wednesday to negotiate the final terms of the move, have been part of that rarity in New York in recent years, a growth industry. Between 1991 and mid-1994, securities and commodities trading added 19,000 jobs in New York. That constituted much of the job creation that did occur, because so many other industries were shrinking. A net total of only 8,000 jobs were created during that period, according to Federal labor figures.
There is a psychological and cultural issue as well: While individual companies have come and gone on Wall Street, the major exchanges have come to seem like part of the landscape. These are not office support workers or data processors, but traders making a physical "outcry" on the exchange floor. And for the first time in this region in modern history, they will not be doing it in Manhattan.
"This is a red flag for the city and as well for the region," said Robert D. Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private group that studies planning issues. Mr. Yaro said that his organization still supported the broad view of the New York region as a single entity, and that therefore, the coffee and cotton traders are still here even if they are in New Jersey. But he acknowledged that the financial exchanges were in a category of their own, partly because of the links of culture that have bound them for so long to a particular few square miles of real estate.
If the result of the move is to loosen the industry's ties to the region, Mr. Yaro argued, then luring the traders to New Jersey may ultimately be bad for New Jersey, even setting aside the $17 million that the state is spending to get them.
"If you don't maintain the critical mass," he said, "the potential is there to say, 'as long as we're looking in New Jersey, we might as well look in Kansas City or whatever.' " The chairman of the coffee exchange, Brian Kelly, stressed that Wall Street would still be only a four-minute train ride away. But he agreed that the move could pave the way for others.
"When you look at the tax incentives," Mr. Kelly said, "it makes a lot of sense for them to follow." He was referring to other Wall Street exchanges. "The income tax is less, the corporate taxes are less, and we're still close enough that we can throw rocks at each other."
Officials of city and state emphasized yesterday that the move was not final until a contract was actually signed, and that they would continue negotiations with the two exchanges. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani also took a tough stance, indicating that the package already offered to the exchanges to help them relocate to a building on Murray Street could not be stretched much further.
"If they're asking for too much," the Mayor said, "then they're just going to have to go and we'll work on other retentions. I'm not concerned about it at all."
The Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, John S. Dyson, said that the bulk of New York commodities trading would stay in Manhattan because of a deal to help the New York Mercantile Exchange build a center in Battery Park City. That deal is the single most expensive yet struck by the Giuliani administration to retain an employer. The package includes $129 million in cash from the city and $58 million in other city and state benefits.
New York and New Jersey, in discussing the fate of the exchanges over the years, have fallen into a pattern of bluff and retreat. Three years ago, the city triumphantly announced that the five major commodities trading exchanges had agreed to stay in the city in a single new joint location. Through mergers, the five players became three, and the Mercantile Exchange decided to seek its own headquarters, leaving the cotton and coffee exchanges on their own.
Officials at those exchanges said Thursday that New Jersey had offered a better deal than the city.
One real estate broker active on Wall Street, Donald P. Eisen of Cushman & Wakefield, said it was too soon to be "writing epitaphs" about the end of an era.
But he added that if the deal did go through, one of the cores of the Manhattan economy would be threatened. "This is beyond just another tenant leaving the city of New York," he said. "There was a reason why these exchanges were located in downtown and they go back to the foundation of the city -- it just doesn't seem that it would be possible they'd move."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Archer-Daniels-Midland stock is off, but some see a buy.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

 BODY:
SHARES of Archer-Daniels-Midland have been pummeled in the last week after disclosures about an unusually broad and aggressive criminal antitrust investigation of the giant grain and soybean processor. And many analysts have been warning of more trouble ahead for the stock.
"We suspect the stock could touch $11 or $12 before this is all over," said Bonnie Wittenburg in a bulletin issued on Tuesday from Dain Bosworth, the Minneapolis investment firm where she follows the company. 
 What the analysts are not talking about much is the stock's long-term outlook, which is about as good as they come in the volatile commodities sector. No other company can match Archer-Daniels-Midland's huge and highly flexible capacity to produce and distribute hundreds of products from soybeans, corn, wheat and other crops. At a time when agriculture's competitive posture is a bright spot on the nation's economic landscape, neither customers, suppliers or the Government stand to benefit from seeing the company seriously crippled.
"A.D.M. is is the finest agricultural complex ever assembled and it cannot be duplicated," said Leonard G. Teitlebaum, a Merrill Lynch analyst who put a "near-term hold" recommendation on the company's stock as the scandal broke but rates it a "strong buy" for the long term.
Archer-Daniels-Midland shares now stand at $16.50, up 50 cents from Wednesday but down from $18.75 on June 27. The decline has been fueled by the emphasis some analysts have put on the uncertainties hanging over the company. Will criminal charges be filed? How onerous could the financial penalties from the Government's case be, not to mention suits from shareholders, customers or competitors? Will senior managers be forced out? Will Congress be more prone to cut Federal price supports that benefit the company?
Analysts say the company, which has always been hard to analyze because of the reticence of its management and the breadth of its holdings, is even tougher to judge given the uncertainties of the inquiry.
Still, John McMillan, who follows agribusiness for Prudential Securities, rates the company a buy for speculative investors with horizons as short as a year. While the spotlight has been on risk, he and most others say they doubt that an investigation will derail the company.
Nothing that has come to light so far suggests such a wide-ranging antitrust problem that the Government will be inclined or be able to demand drastic punishment of the company. The drama of the investigation has included the undercover cooperation of Mark E. Whitacre, president of the company's bio-products group, and a June 27 raid by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on company headquarters in Decatur, Ill. But customers and competitors say they have seen little to hint of any illegal activities.
The focus of the investigation has been the lysine and citric acid businesses, which were under Mr. Whitacre's supervision, and the far larger corn sweetener business, which was outside his domain. Archer-Daniels-Midland's major competitors in each of the businesses have received subpoenas requesting information.
Lysine is an amino acid derived from fermenting corn that is fed primarily to chicken and swine. Until Archer-Daniels-Midland entered the market in 1991 as part of its huge investment -- more than $1 billion to date -- in vitamins and other food and feed supplements, the market had been controlled by two Japanese companies, Kyowa Hakko and Ajinomoto, and a smaller South Korean rival, Sewon. Prices were generally dictated by the price and availability of soybean meal, the main lysine source in most livestock diets.
Archer-Daniels-Midland quickly climbed into the driver's seat because, unlike its more specialized foreign rivals, it extracts lysine from corn it is already grinding for other products. "The price crumbled in a hurry," said one purchaser, who declined to be named.
Once Archer-Daniels-Midland secured 50 percent of what has become a 500-million-pound worldwide market, purchasers say, the price rose back toward its historic relationship with soybean meal. It is currently between $1.20 and $1.30 a pound, which would generate about $300 million in revenues. Buyers say it is possible that some kind of collusive agreement helped the prices back up but that they have seen no evidence.
The company also entered the citric acid business in 1991 when it bought Pfizer Inc.'s operations. Analysts calculate that it splits the domestic market with Cargill Inc. and Haarmann & Reimer, a subsidiary of Bayer of Germany that is based in Springfield, N.J., Both those companies have been subpeonaed. Some citric acid, which is widely used as a food and beverage ingredient, is also imported from China and Europe. Archer-Daniels-Midland's share is probably producing revenues of around $350 million, analysts say. Industry sources say the transfer from Pfizer has had no noticeable impact on the market.
The corn sweetener industry is equally mystified by the investigation, particularly in light of the Government's courtroom defeat in 1991 after a long-running battle to undo the company's acquisition of the high-fructose corn syrup capacity of Nabisco Brands Inc. Prices for the biggest sweetener product -- high fructose syrup for the beverage industry -- are currently a third lower than their 1991 peak.
The company has a one-third share of the high fructose market, followed by Cargill and A.E. Staley, a subsidiary of Tate & Lyle of Britain, with just over 20 percent each and CPC International with about 11 percent. Some analysts believe corn sweeteners in general may account for more than half of Archer-Daniels-Midland's earnings although they are just about one-fourth of its sales, which are expected to top $12.3 billion in the year that ended June 30.
Perhaps the most unnerving aspect of the investigation for Wall Street is that it appears to have blossomed out of Mr. Whitacre's group, the part of Archer-Daniels-Midland that company executives had been calling their prime growth vehicle. In fact, the company had said that such bio-products would account for one-third of earnings by 1997. Now it is unclear who will manage the group and whether the company will have to tiptoe instead of moving at its usual full speed ahead.
Analysts also fret that the board, viewed as a docile extension of Dwayne O. Andreas, the 77-year-old chairman, lacks the influence, will or insight into the company's operations to control any negative developments at a time when transition issues could become pressing.
On top of all this, the company is coming off a record year when grain prices were low and demand for many products high. Once earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter that ended June 30 are reported on Monday, the next few quarters could prove disappointing by comparison.
"The easy thing is just to sell and get out of the way," Mr. McMillan, the analyst, said. But not necessarily the smart thing for investors with the long-term view.

HEADLINE: Facing High-Tech Issues, New Patents Chief Is Reinventing a Staid Agency

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If control of the rights to intellectual property, technological innovation and pure invention is to be a legal battleground of the 21st century, then Bruce Lehman might be called the United States' field general.
As the head of the Patent and Trademark Office, Mr. Lehman realizes that most of the nation may not regard his obscure agency as pivotal to the success of American industry in a global, increasingly high-tech economy. But he does, and he is determined to use his stewardship of that office to reshape patent laws that have prevailed since the Civil War. 
 But Mr. Lehman is meeting stiff resistance from some of the people whose work he is pledged to protect: independent researchers and inventors.
These critics contend that tampering with a system that dates to Thomas Jefferson's tenure as the first patent commissioner betrays an American tradition and imperils the kind of innovation that led to the cotton gin, the airplane, the transistor and many other hallmarks of American industry.
Mr. Lehman asserts that his detractors are mostly weekend hobbyists who do not realize that his agency is crucial to the economy because it regulates the ideas behind high-tech businesses. It regulates, for example, the software, schematics and intellectual inventions that drive the computer, telecommunications and biotechnology industries. "We're talking knowledge-based industries," he said.
For that reason, said Mr. Lehman, a 48-year-old veteran of Washington politics, his agency must plan for the 21st century. "It would be ironic if the agency responsible for innovation isn't able to change and innovate itself," he said.
But Charles Mullen, an independent inventor and president of the Houston Inventors Association, says Mr. Lehman's changes would undercut American innovation.
"In the 21st century, the country with better inventions will be the world leader," Mr. Mullen said. "Sixty percent of important patents in America in this century came from independent inventors and universities. The patent office thinks it's doing the right thing by changing regulations to help big companies compete with Japan. But wiping out the little guy is not the way to do that."
Mr. Lehman, a former general counsel to the House Subcommittee on Intellectual Property, is respected by Republicans and Democrats alike as someone with years of hands-on experience with patent issues. Since taking over as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks 22 months ago, he has overseen more changes at his agency than occurred in the two decades of his predecessors.
He has held public hearings on who can claim an invention, on software and biotechnology inventions, and on terms of patents and publications rules. After the software hearings, he ordered new guidelines for examining software-related inventions. The guidelines, for the first time, make it clear that software can be patented if it is a part of computer hardware or a disk.
Mr. Lehman has also ordered his agency to reopen controversial patent files. He has reorganized key departments, including the corps of examiners who study patent applications, and he has supported technological changes to move the Patent and Trademark Office into the computer age and away from reliance on cramped cubicles and archives jammed with miles of color-coded paper files.
But most critical -- and most criticized -- are new regulations that will fundamentally alter some of the most basic patent laws. Last year, under his aegis, agency officials persuaded Congress to approve a section of a global trade agreement that for the first time in 134 years changed the length of time that a patent is valid. The new law on patent terms took effect on June 8.
Since the Civil War, inventors have been awarded patents that are good for 17 years from the issue date. In Japan and in countries covered by the European Patent Convention, inventors receive patents good for 20 years from the date that the application is filed. The new regulation makes patents issued here valid for 20 years from the filing date as well. Agency officials say that on average it takes 19 months for a patent application to be approved in the United States. But because the approval process can take much longer, opponents of the new regulations say that many patent holders will now be effectively short-changed.
But Mr. Lehman asserted: "Our changes make U.S. and world patent systems similar, to operate under the same rules everywhere. The reason for patent 'harmonization' is that the economy is becoming very globalized."
Mr. Lehman's agency is also preparing to order that all patent applications be made public after 18 months, instead of being kept secret until patents are issued. That is supposed to eliminate "submarine" patents, which pend for years while inventors deliberately amend their applications to keep up with advancing technologies. Because of the secrecy of patent applications, others in an industry or research field do not know about these inventions until the patents are issued and their owners suddenly claim the rights to a breadth of technology. Mr. Lehman also plans to issue regulations to let a third party participate in disputes between an inventor and the agency over patent rights.
The House Committee on the Judiciary held hearings on both proposed regulations during the first week in June. Neither proposal has yet been scheduled for a vote.
But Mr. Lehman has gone ahead and created a one-year informal application for researchers or academics who want to publish their work but are not ready to apply for a patent. That would enable those inventors to make their work public through speeches or papers without losing exclusive rights to ownership.
This overhaul of patent regulation has provoked a firestorm of debate between independent inventors, on one side, and patent lawyers and experts in intellectual property, who largely support the agency's new policies. Many individual inventors strongly oppose Mr. Lehman's plans, but they are struggling to organize. They have support from a small, bipartisan group in Congress hoping to undo the changes made to the term of a patent.
"It's very dangerous that two men, Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and Bruce Lehman, can change our whole system with a stroke of the pen," said Beverly Selby, an official at the American Alliance of Innovators.
Ms. Selby's group and other coalitions of independent inventors say publishing patent applications will let unscrupulous people steal ideas before they are patented. And they worry that the new rules on patent duration will significantly shorten the life of many patents, making it difficult for inventors to attract investors or license an idea.
Mr. Lehman's opponents also say his plans constitute a dumbing down of American intellectual property policy to please foreign governments and multinational corporations who want less competition.
"The patent office has been maneuvered into the pockets of foreign interests," said Ron Riley, a Michigan inventor and member of the American Alliance of Innovators. "Each change is moderately damaging, but in combination they are very bad."
"They just facilitate technology transfer form the developing nations to the Asian states," he argued, asserting that shortened patent terms and early publication of applications would allow foreign competitors to copy American inventions.
Yet much of the impetus for the patent overhaul arises from economic competition with Japan. For decades, American corporations, businessmen and inventors seeking patent rights in Japan have complained about the Japanese Patent Office.
"American inventors were forced to file in Japanese," Mr. Lehman said, "and the Japanese Patent Office does not touch the patent application for 18 months. But at 18 months the whole thing is published."
Eager to eliminate those obstacles, Mr. Lehman agreed to reshape American patent regulations to more closely resemble those used in Japan and Europe. In return, he said, Japan agreed to accept patent applications in English and eliminate challenges to them while they are being evaluated, to speed examinations and abolish an arcane licensing regulation that allowed Japanese companies to pay a royalty for an American invention but manufacture it themselves.
"This one agreement has the capability of closing the entire U.S.-Japan balance-of-payment gap," Mr. Lehman said, theorizing that looser policies toward American inventions would open new markets in Japan.
Mr. Lehman's critics say he is being naive. They say Japan has simply repeated a decades-old promise to speed up its patenting process in return for great sacrifices in a tried-and-true American system. Mr. Lehman says that is short-sighted.
"We're well beyond the point of saying this is the heart of some future economy," he said. "It's what puts Americans to work today. The new technologies that drive the U.S. economy and help us retain our edge over other nations are protected initially by patent laws."

HEADLINE: Stock Market Drifts in Lackluster Trading

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
A day after hitting record levels, the stock market drifted yesterday in lackluster trading.
The three leading averages finished at new highs, but not by much. On the other hand, declining issues exceeded advancing stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,230 to 1,044. 
 "It was a digestive day after the big run-up," said Edwin D. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A. "It seems that the market may be stabilizing."
Analysts said a Labor Department report showing a slight decline in the Producer Price Index for June indicated that inflation remained under control. The second key inflation report for June, the Consumer Price Index, will be released today.
The Dow Jones industrial average inched higher in the final minutes of trading, closing at 4,727.48, up 0.19 point. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 561, up 0.11 point and the Nasdaq composite index closed at 994.15, up 5.52 points.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell to 388.5 million shares, from 413.6 million shares on Wednesday.
The major follow-through from the previous day's surge came in computer-related stocks, which have long been leading the market. I.B.M. rose 2 1/8, to 103 3/4, its highest price since October 1991. Intel gained 1 3/8, to 73 5/8; Micron Technology 5/8, to 61 3/8, and Dell, 1 7/8, to 68 3/4.
Capital-goods stocks also performed strongly, perhaps because yesterday's Government statistics suggest that the Fed will continue to lower interest rates through the end of 1995 to spur an economic expansion. Caterpillar was up 3/4, to 72 3/8; Boeing, 1 1/4, to 65 1/2, and Micron Technology, 5/8, to 61 3/8.
Tobacco stocks, however, declined after the Food and Drug Administration submitted proposed regulations to the White House urging that nicotine be regulated as a drug. Philip Morris fell 1 5/8, to 75 1/2; RJR Nabisco, 1/2, to 27 1/2; UST Inc., 1/2, to 29, and American Brands, 1/8, to 39 1/4.
Also on the down side was J. P. Morgan, which slumped 1 1/4, to 75 3/8, after the company announced a 10 percent drop in second-quarter earnings. Tandem declined 3 1/2, to 13, after warning that its fiscal third-quarter earnings would be below analysts' projections.
Gainers included Acclaim Entertainment, up 3 1/2, to 24 7/8, on a report of higher earnings. Intuit, which analysts anticipate will announce a number of alliances with banks today, gained 4 3/4, to 83. And MEMC Electronic Materials soared 5 1/2, to 29 1/2, on its first day of public trading.
A big gain was also notched by Merck, which advanced 1 3/8, to 50 7/8. An F.D.A. advisory committee issued a favorable recommendation for the company's Fosamax treatment for osteoporosis.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Little Changed After Producer Price Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday after a report on producer prices failed to provide enough evidence of the direction of the economy.
While the report on producer prices showed inflation receding, traders were hedging their bets ahead of today's report on consumer prices and retail sales. 
 "People are looking for a bit more information confirming the slowdown," said Mark Taborsky, who manages $280 million in bonds at the Abacus Financial Group in Chicago.
Treasury prices were also hurt by weakness in the dollar, which fell against the German mark and other currencies after the German central bank left interest rates unchanged.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 3/32 , to 11328/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged up to 6.55 percent from 6.54 percent. The price on the two-year note also fell, and its yield rose to 5.59 percent from 5.57 percent.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that its Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent for finished goods in June after showing no change in May. While the data were somewhat better then expected, they failed to prompt much buying.
"The market is still dominated by people who think rates are going lower, but they're not so sure they want to push bond yields down to 6.25 percent," Mr. Taborsky of Abacus Financial said.
Some traders said they were waiting until today's report on consumer prices in June. Economists expect an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index. The Government will also report today on retail sales in June.
"The market wants to see evidence that the consumer continues to stay home and keep his purse strings tightly drawn," said Terry Rose, who helps manage $2 billion of bonds at Advisers Capital Management in New York.
For now, some traders are betting long-bond yields could hover just above 6.5 percent, as they have since early last month, or even rise.
To stay at those levels, the data have to continually show the economy weakening enough to warrant more interest rate cuts by the Fed, said Terrence Pigott, head trader at Daiwa Securities America.
In the corporate market, the Raytheon Company sold $1.125 billion of bonds yesterday, 50 percent more than originally planned, in its first public bond sale.
"There's still tremendous demand out there for corporate bonds," said Dan Portanova, who helps manage $3.5 billion of fixed-income securities at the General Reinsurance Corporation. "It's a good time for issuers to come to market."
Raytheon, the military electronics company, sold $750 million of 10-year notes at a yield of 6.58 percent, 50 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. It also sold $375 million of 30-year bonds at a yield of 7.511 percent, 96 basis points more than the 30-year Treasury.
The company is using the proceeds to refinance debt stemming from its $2.3 billion acquisition of E-Systems Inc. in April.
In other sales, the Comsat Corporation, a provider of communications and information services, sold $200 million of monthly income preferred stock, which combines features of debt and equity.
Municipal bonds were steady yesterday amid a dearth of new bonds scheduled for sale and investor reluctance to pay more for some bonds offered on the secondary market, traders said.
"Literally there is no product around and the only thing left is unattractive," said George Buchholz, the manager of trading at Tucker Anthony Inc. "What gets any market going is supply, and when you don't have any we just ground to a halt."

HEADLINE: Under Inquiry, Miami Bond Firm Is Closed

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 13

 BODY:
Two brothers best known as Florida sugar barons have closed the Miami securities firm that had been the target of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The brothers, Alfonso and Jose Fanjul, said they had decided on the shutdown after unsuccessful efforts to sell FAIC Securities Inc. to its 22 employees. They also cited the increasing costs of the S.E.C. investigation. 
 The S.E.C. is investigating whether the brothers illegally made political contributions while seeking state and municipal bond business.
In December, FAIC was selected by the Florida Housing and Finance Authority to serve as co-managing underwriter of the authority's single-family mortgage revenue bonds. Before that contract was awarded, various companies owned or controlled by the Fanjuls contributed $88,000 to gubernatorial and other candidates for state office, the S.E.C. said.
Additionally, Dade County in November approved FAIC to be an underwriter for aviation bonds; three Dade County commissioners received a total of about $7,250 from the Fanjuls before the contract was awarded, according to the S.E.C.
The S.E.C. went to court saying FAIC ignored repeated subpoenas to comply with the investigation. The brothers have denied wrongdoing.
The brothers own Flo-Sun Inc., a leader in the state's $2 billion sugar industry. FAIC was established in 1980. Originally, it purchased jumbo certificates of deposit from federally insured financial institutions offering the highest interest rates.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell In June

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
The nation's producers received slightly lower prices for finished goods in June, the second consecutive month with no inflation at the last stage before the goods reach consumers, Labor Department figures showed today.
Economists said this latest report of price stability, which was somewhat better than expected, reinforced the decision by the Federal Reserve last week to ease monetary policy to insure against the economic slowdown's degenerating into recession. And it suggests that there is more leeway now for the Fed to cut rates further in the months ahead. 
 Last Thursday, the Fed said "inflationary pressures have receded enough" to warrant a quarter-point cut in a benchmark short-term interest rate and the latest figures fueled hopes of at least one more cut later this summer.
"The worst of inflation is behind us," contended Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers, noting that it is rare to be in the fifth year of an economic expansion without significant price acceleration.
The latest readings on goods at earlier stages of production were also largely reassuring, unlike late last year and early this year when it appeared that the production pipeline was filling with goods whose higher prices would before long show up at retail counters.
Most such increases "are continuing to dissipate by the time they reach the consumer," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
Still, some analysts fret that consumer prices have accelerated, albeit modestly, this year and that higher costs of grain and imported goods could add to inflation pressures in coming months. They also note that services, which tend to be "stickier" than commodities and have been rising faster, account for more than half the Consumer Price Index, which is to be published Friday.
"There seems to be a little more pricing power at the consumer level, which may be why corporate profits are as good as they have been," said John Silvia, economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
The Producer Price Index, which largely excludes services, fell one-tenth of 1 percent for finished goods in June after showing no change in May, the Labor Department's report showed. Not counting food and energy, which tend to swing sharply from month to month, finished goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in both April and May.
Energy prices tumbled 1 percent last month, the biggest decline since September and October, as gasoline fell 3.1 percent and heating oil dropped 5.8 percent, both reversing hefty advances in May. Food prices, down three-tenths of 1 percent, have now fallen four months in a row.
Capital equipment moved up two-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in May, bringing the annual 1995 pace to 2.7 percent, triple that of the preceding six months, the report also showed. Machinery for the paper industry surged 3.2 percent.
Among goods at the intermediate stage of production, such as a bolt of cloth, prices edged up one-tenth of 1 percent following a two-tenths of 1 percent May increase. Nondurable materials used in manufacturing, such as wood pulp, climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent, but this was partly offset by a two-tenths of 1 percent decline for such durable factor goods as flat glass and plywood. Construction materials were about unchanged for the second straight month.
Among crude goods, like a bale of cotton, prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent but this followed a slightly larger decline in May. With food and energy excluded, the rise was six-tenths of 1 percent, to bring the pace for the first half of 1995 to 12.7 percent, about half that of the final six months of 1994.
Michael S. Rome, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, concluded, "The outlook for inflation is that it will stay well contained."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germans Decline to Cut Rates, Sending the Dollar on a Slide

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the German mark yesterday after the Bundesbank left interest rates unchanged.
Many currency dealers had expected the German central bank to cut rates after the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan pushed short-term interest rates lower last week. And expectations mounted earlier yesterday after the Swiss central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates by half a percentage point, to 2.5 percent. The Swiss National Bank typically takes its cues from the Bundesbank. 
 The Swiss rate cut sent the dollar soaring to a four-week high against the mark and a six-week high against the Swiss franc. Lower German and Swiss rates often help the dollar by making deposits in those countries relatively less attractive.
When the Bundesbank held rates steady after a meeting of its policy-setting council, the dollar plunged.
"People bought dollars after the Swiss National Bank cut, expecting the Bundesbank to cut rates," said Jim Raphael, a currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City. "They didn't, and now you're seeing the panic."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.3877 marks from 1.4025 marks on Wednesday. Earlier, the dollar rose as high as 1.4137 marks. The dollar fell to 1.1584 Swiss francs, from 1.1674 francs on Wednesday.
Hopes for a German bank cut had been dampened somewhat on Wednesday after a Government report showed that western German inflation rose to 2.4 percent in June from 2.2 percent in May. Indeed, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said yesterday that the central bank had left rates unchanged to uphold its credibility as an inflation fighter.
The Bundesbank left its benchmark discount rate unchanged at 4 percent, a six-year low. It held its 14-day securities repurchase rate at 4.5 percent.
The dollar, however, remained steady against the Japanese yen yesterday. Since Friday's surprise bout of dollar-buying by the Fed and the Bank of Japan, many traders are convinced that the United States and Japan are willing to act to weaken the Japanese currency.
"There's a very real sense the dollar will be supported by the Bank of Japan above 85 yen, and that 90 to 93 yen is desirable," Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 87.35 yen, unchanged from Wednesday.
