HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Expensive in Tokyo
Ever since the Museum of Contemporary Art in Tokyo opened four months ago, it has been trying to get as much attention as, say, the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris or the Tate Gallery of Modern Art in London, which has already had a flurry of publicity even though it is not scheduled to open until 2000.
Unfortunately, most of the attention has been critical. The city-run institution is Tokyo's first contemporary-art museum, and the cost has been astronomical. Its six-story, 330,000-square-foot building, designed by Takahito Yanagisawa, a local architect, cost $481 million. And its location, about 40 minutes by car from downtown Tokyo, is too out of the way, experts say, to attract many visitors. 
 The museum has about 3,500 works, 3,000 of them from Tokyo's Metropolitan Art Gallery. "Five hundred works are recent acquisitions, mostly paintings both by domestic and international artists," Yasuyoshi Saito, the museum's senior curator, said in a telephone interview this week. He added that the museum's priority was to establish a permanent collection of Japanese contemporary art.
The recent acquisitions have been another sore subject, Mr. Saito reluctantly admits. In the last year, officials have bought 39 works, each costing more than $600,000 but many less than $2 million, by artists like David Hockney, Tom Wesselman and Anselm Kiefer. (Approval from the city authorities is required for purchases of more than $2 million.)
By far the most criticized of its recent acquisitions is Roy Lichtenstein's "Girl With a Hair Ribbon," which the museum bought from the artist for $6 million. The price is gigantic, considering that similar cartoon images by the artist have recently sold for $1.6 million to $2.5 million.
"I was involved in the Lichtenstein purchase," Mr. Saito said. "I don't think it was too expensive. Yes, we know it's not cheap, but we decided to buy it three years ago, when prices were higher."
But it seems everything the museum does costs a bundle. To mount the current show, its second, a major retrospective of the work of Sir Anthony Caro, the English sculptor, the museum spent about $3 million, Mr. Saito said. The show has about 100 sculptures in a zenlike setting designed by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando.
"Although our inaugural show dealt only with Japanese contemporary art, we are trying to appeal to an international audience," Mr. Saito said.
After that the museum plans an international survey of art from the 1960's and an Andy Warhol show in the spring.
 
Estate Auction
 While it seems as if the important round of Impressionist and modern art auctions just ended (they were held in New York in May and in London last month), Sotheby's is already announcing the auction of paintings valued at more than $30 million from the estate of Joseph H. Hazen, a lawyer, film producer and philanthropist who died last year. The collection is to be the cornerstone of Sotheby's important November sales in New York.
Mr. Hazen, who produced classic movies including "Sorry, Wrong Number," "Barefoot in the Park" and "Becket," looked to curators like James Johnson Sweeney, the Guggenheim's director from 1952 to 1960, for advice about which art to buy. Among the highlights of his collection is van Gogh's "Thicket" (1890), a lush forest scene painted a month before the artist killed himself. It is expected to sell for about $10 million. Mr. Hazen also owned Kandinsky's "Last Judgment" (1910), a highly colorful abstract work with a $5 million estimate.
Christie's competed for the estate but lost, art experts say, because Sotheby's had placed higher estimates on the paintings and promised the Hazen heirs a more generous guarantee (an undisclosed minimum price that an auction house promises the seller regardless of a sale's outcome).
"Yes, we've guaranteed the pictures," said Diana D. Brooks, who heads Sotheby's auctions worldwide. While declining to disclose the figure, she called it "a number we're very comfortable with."
 
Decline of Shows
 The growing number of art and antiques shows in the world's art capitals is beginning to take its toll. Dealers are dropping out of some shows to join others. Some dealers say it's not worth going to any because of the rising costs of shipping and insurance, not to mention booth rents. Moreover, there are only so many top dealers to go around.
The International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show, held every October at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan, is a case in point. This year, 11 dealers either dropped out or were not invited back by Anna and Brian Haughton, the organizers. But the Haughtons had no trouble filling the spots. Among the new dealers are Galerie Vallois, a French dealer that specializes in Art Deco; S. Bernstein & Company, a San Francisco gallery dealing in jade and Asian art, and Carlton Hobbs, a London furniture gallery. Three important London galleries will be missing: Spink & Son, Partridge, and Pelham. "These shows are just not conducive to selling furniture," said Clifford Henderson, the director of Partridge. "They're too expensive. The last show cost about $80,000 to mount." Anthony Spink, one of the directors of Spink & Son, said: "It's hard to rustle up business in New York. We're doing the Art Fair in New York in May instead. Specialized fairs are generally better for us."
The Haughtons, pioneers in specialty fairs, run the International Ceramics Fair in London every June. They've had flops, like an international fair at Harrods, the London department store, where one season of poor attendance and grumbling dealers put a stop to that idea. They also ran the International Silver and Jewelry Fair in London, which had an eight-year run but was a casualty of the recession and folded four years ago. Undaunted, they are planning an International Asian Art Fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory from March 29 to April 3 next year.

HEADLINE: Poverty Rate Is the Highest In 16 Years, A Report Says

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN 

 BODY:
Nearly 3 out of every 10 New Yorkers live in poverty, more than at any time during the last 16 years, according to a new analysis by an advocacy group using data from the Census Bureau.
The analysis, by the Community Service Society of New York, found that 1.9 million New York City residents -- more than 27 percent -- had incomes in 1993 that fell below Federal poverty standards. The figure has fluctuated since the group began keeping statistics in 1979, but has risen steadily since the city's economic boom began tapering off during the late 1980's. 
 David R. Jones, president of the society, an antipoverty group, attributed the increase to the continuing effects of the recession that gripped the New York region in the early 1990's, and to other social shifts such as the loss of factory jobs, which pushed those at the bottom off the economic ladder.
"We see this as the result of the contraction of the New York economy," he said. "We've been caught up in a regional recession and it has had the worst impact on unskilled workers."
The report defined poor as single people with an income of less than $7,363 a year, and families of four with annual incomes of $14,763 or less. The income guidelines are based on Federal figures.
But Mr. Jones said that relying on the federal poverty rates may vastly underestimate the size of the problem in New York because the cost of living is much higher than in other parts of the country.
The group's analysis was based on a March 1994 survey by the Census Bureau in which 4,573 people were interviewed. Although the sample may have been too small to determine precisely the amount of poverty in New York at any given moment, it does accurately reflect the trend in poverty over the last 20 years, said Terry Rosenberg, director of population studies for Community Services group.
The analysis also reflected a report from the Census Bureau released this year, which placed New York City's poverty rate at 26.6 percent in 1993.
The Community Service analysis found that poverty was highest among Hispanic residents, with 46 percent of that population living below the poverty rate. And it found that although the amount of poverty among blacks has remained relatively stable since 1984, the number of poor Hispanic and white New Yorkers has increased sharply during that time.
The report also found that 44 percent of New York's children are poor, double the national rate, as are 21 percent of the city's elderly.
Mr. Jones said the increase in poverty was especially alarming given local and national efforts to move people off welfare programs by tightening eligibility requirements or imposing time limits.
"This shows that a large number of the poor are not getting enough entitlements to maintain a standard of living," he said. "If we're going to shove more people off welfare, we'll see an even larger increase."

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Colgate-Palmolive Company said late yesterday that it expects its second-quarter earnings to be below Wall Street's expectations because of economic conditions in Mexico. LENGTH: 530 words

HEADLINE: Squatters' Rights vs. City Rights

 BODY:
A group of rundown tenements on Manhattan's Lower East Side lived in by squatters for years may well have benefited from their occupation. The squatters have fixed up the city-owned buildings with their own money and sweat, securing them from drug users and criminals. Now the buildings are a vicious battleground.
New York City is trying to clear the property and sell it to a community group committed to renovating the buildings for low-income families and returning them to the tax rolls. The squatters are resisting, on the streets and in the courts. The city has acted slowly and clumsily, but it is pursuing the right objective and deserves a chance to proceed with the renovation project. 
The confrontation has drawn citywide attention because of a police raid in May that forced the squatters from two of their buildings on East 13th Street. Over the July Fourth weekend the squatters tried to retake a building, and managed to get to the roof and throw firecrackers and debris into the street before the police could regain control. Squatters remain in two other buildings on the street, which has taken on the look of an armed camp.
The same group has also been a vociferous advocate in causes ranging from the homeless to alleged police brutality to the occupation of Tompkins Square Park a few years ago. Many are artists, handymen and waiters with families and resources to wage a bitter legal battle for the right to remain.
The squatters say that under an old legal principle known as adverse possession, their 10-year occupation has made them the effective owners of the tenements. They argue further that the city cannot simply send in the police without going through eviction proceedings in the courts. The city claims it can do whatever it wants to oust illegal trespassers on property it has seized from previous owners because of unpaid taxes. These disagreements will take months to adjudicate.
For now, the city must exercise a measure of restraint and not use police force until it has exhausted legal proceedings to get rid of the unwanted tenants. Both sides should try to negotiate their way out of their confrontation, perhaps by finding other places for the squatters to live.
With New York City's housing shortage growing more severe, squatters have taken over dozens of city-owned buildings. The city should accelerate its process of getting rid of the 2,500 buildings it still owns after seizing them for nonpayment of property taxes.
The Giuliani administration is trying to step up the sale of abandoned buildings to private or nonprofit groups that can obtain Federal subsidies and outside financing for their renovation. But many buildings in middle-class neighborhoods could become economically sustainable if sold off to the highest bidder in a simple auction. Squatters could be given a chance in some cases to see if they could get financing to get buildings into good shape.
But this is a problem best headed off before it develops. The city needs to find a way of helping landlords keep their property viable instead of abandoning it to avoid taxes. The city government should not generally take over as landlord.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Heat Wave's Effects Will Linger on Farms

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 14

 BODY:
Livestock is no longer dropping dead in droves, but farmers in the Midwest expect to be suffering the effects of this week's heat wave for weeks to come.
 "The real loss to the economy comes from the millions of animals that didn't put on weight, not the few thousand that died," said Lee M. Reeve, who operates a cattle feed lot in Garden City, Kan. 
 The livestock deaths were concentrated in western Iowa, where the 100-degree days that have taxed animals across the region for much of the week were made worse by unusually high humidity and virtually no wind. But those conditions eased somewhat today.
 Most of the thousands of steers that died were in the Iowa counties just east of Omaha. Hundreds of thousands of turkeys and chickens also died in several parts of the state.
 The most vulnerable cattle were those in feed lots, where most of them spend their final weeks before being slaughtered.
 The lots are typically shadeless dirt pens. A dead steer might cost a farmer $500 to $600, but a farmer could lose just as much from 35 to 40 survivors having eaten too little to get up to their potential market weight during the blistering weather.
 Hot weather also reduces output from cows and inhibits the growth of swine and other animals bred for meat.
 Few farmers are insured for the kind of losses caused by the heat wave.
 For some in the hardest hit counties, the losses from dead animals alone run into the tens of thousands of dollars.
 "You normally lose less than 1 percent of the cattle you're feeding in a year," said Lowell Evans, manager of T&K Evans Grain Inc., a co-op in Elliot, Iowa. "We're hearing of people around here losing 6 or 7 percent in two days."
 The heat wave struck at a particularly difficult time for farmers who raise cattle.
 Since March, prices have been below the cost of raising cattle, and many farmers have already been losing $50 or more per animal in recent months.
 "I don't know that there's ever been a time we've had this combination of factors -- the temperature, the humidity, the lack of wind," Don Baker of the Iowa State University extension service told The Associated Press. "It's like a 100-year storm or a 100-year flood."
 Mr. Baker said 2,500 head of cattle, mostly feed lot steers, were dead in three counties of western Iowa. He estimated the loss to farmers at $1.75 million.
 Mark Gardner, a farmer, said, "It's always the biggest and the best ones that die first."
 Mr. Gardner said he had lost 23 cattle, The Associated Press reported.
 "When they've got their tongues hanging out 8 to 10 inches and they're panting for air, you'd better get water on them or they'll fall over dead pretty soon," Mr. Gardner said on Thursday. "It's never been this bad in my 40 years."
 More than 240,000 turkeys have died this week in Minnesota because of the 100-degree weather, according to news reports.
 At a northwestern Iowa turkey farm, the heat killed more than 100,000 birds in the 24 hours that ended on Thursday night, the A.P. said.
 "To the best of our knowledge, over the past 24 hours, we have lost an estimated 118,000 turkeys, or 2 percent of our annual slaughter," said Greg Steenblock, operations manager of Bil Mar Foods in Storm Lake.
 According to the Iowa Turkey Federation, each turkey is valued at about $12, putting Bil Mar's loss at about $1.5 million.
 The weather was less of a problem for crops in most of the Midwest. But with corn just entering the crucial pollination stage that determines how much grain is in each ear, a similar heat wave in the next two weeks could drastically reduce the potential harvest. Reserve stocks are low, so another heat wave could send prices soaring.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The heat was so intense in Van Meter, Iowa, yesterday that Bob Jones turned a sprinkler on his cattle. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Treasury Bonds Fall On Solid Retail Sales
Treasury prices ended lower after a Government report showed surprising strength in consumer spending, shaking the market's view of a slowing economy. The report cast doubt on the prospects for another cut in short-term interest rates.
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell, pushing its yield up to 6.60 percent, from 6.55 percent on Thursday. [40.]
 

Higher bond yields helped depress the Dow Jones industrials, which fell 18.66 points, to close at 4,708.82. The index rose 6.09 points this week. The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.18 points, to 999.33, on the strength of technology issues. Also, the S.& P. 500 index fell 1.11 points, to 559.89. [41.]
 
The dollar was slightly higher against most leading currencies, rising to 87.83 yen and 1.3903 marks. [36.]
 
New York Newsday to Close
Times Mirror has decided to close New York Newsday, which will publish its last edition tomorrow. The paper was the victim of corporate pressures for profits and a New York City newspaper market that changed sharply over the last decade. It was estimated that in its 10 years of publication, the paper lost $100 million. [1.]
 
The news came a little before 5 P.M. -- with the stock market closed -- as Don Forst, the paper's editor, famed for his snappy tabloid headlines, walked brusquely through the desks and cubicles, summoning his staff into a big main room. [26.]
 
Boeing Announces Charge
Boeing will take a pretax charge of $600 million for the second quarter because 9,500 employees have accepted early retirement packages. The charge will reduce second-quarter net income by about $500 million. [40.]
 
Quicken Gets a Boost
Intuit announced that 19 financial institutions, including many of the nation's largest banks, credit card companies and brokerage firms, would use its Quicken software for home banking services beginning this fall. The move signals the company's intent to compete aggressively with Microsoft after the collapse in May of plans for the two companies to merge. [39.]
 
Report Criticizes B-2
As Congress considers additional financing to build new B-2 stealth bomber, a draft report by the General Accounting Office says that the $44 billion bomber, which is built by Northrop Grumman, may not be as stealthy as advertised. After 14 years of work, including 6 years of test flights, "the Air Force has yet to demonstrate that the B-2 design will meet some of its most important mission requirements," the report said. [1.]
 
Chrysler Comes to Vietnam
Just days after President Clinton extended full recognition to Vietnam, Chrysler opened showrooms Ho Chi Minh City and in Hanoi this week. The moves reflect the efforts by American companies to gain a piece of a consumer market that is already being tapped by Asian and European competitors. [38.]
 
Blacks Make Labor Demands
Black labor union leaders see the struggle for the presidency of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. as a rare opportunity to demand a much greater voice for blacks in the nation's labor movement. The leaders have prepared a list of 11 demands, most of them calling for more blacks in the federation's hierarchy and the hierarchies of its individual unions. [6.]
 
Drug Company Goes It Alone
Express Scripts is the only major manager of prescription drug networks that has not been gobbled up or embraced by a pharmaceutical giant, and the company is using that fact as a big selling point. [40.]
 
Heat Hits Midwest Farmers
Livestock is no longer dropping dead in droves, but farmers in the Midwest expect to be suffering the effects of this week's heat wave for weeks to come. [29.]
 
Coffee Prices Climbing
Coffee prices steepened their climb after the Brazilian Coffee Exporters Federation endorsed a plan to limit shipments to one million bags a month. Coffee for September delivery surged 5.5 cents, to $1.447 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. [36.]

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE STRATEGY;
Frustrated Croats Are Openly Preparing a Major Assault on a Serbian Enclave

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, July 13

 BODY:
As the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Bosnia reels from fresh attacks by rebel Serbs, the Government of Croatia is planning to open a major new front in the Balkan war.
Increasingly frustrated at the failure of diplomacy to recover the large chunk of their country that has been occupied by Serbian rebels since 1991, Croatian leaders are urgently preparing a major attack on the Serbian enclave. 
 Thousands of Croatian soldiers, with scores of tanks and hundreds of artillery pieces, have been moved near the enclave in recent weeks. Jet fighters, which the Croatian Air Force has obtained despite the United Nations arms embargo on former Yugoslav republics, are being readied for action.
The Croatian Serb rebels hold more than one-fourth of Croatia. Croatian troops recaptured a sliver of land, Western Slavonia, in May; now they appear to be preparing for a much larger action against the much larger Serb-held region called Krajina.
"Their last operation showed that they have the capacity for extremely smart military maneuvering," a foreign ambassador said of the Croatian Army. "Their morale is very, very high. They know what they're supposed to do, and they're prepared to go and do it."
There is no indication that the current fighting in eastern Bosnia, where Bosnian Serbs have captured the United Nations "safe area" of Srebrenica, will affect Croatia's timing.
Military planners here do not expect large numbers of Bosnian Serbs to come to the aid of Krajina if it is attacked. The Bosnian Serb army is stretched thin, holding more territory than it can effectively defend, and in any event the Krajina Serbs and the Bosnian Serbs have separate armies whose troops are committed mostly to defense of their own home regions. Nevertheless, the two forces have cooperated in the past, most notably in coordinated attacks against the Government-held enclave at Bihac, Bosnia.
More worrisome for Croatia would be the entry of the army of Serb-dominated Yugoslavia in defense of the Krajina Serbs, but many Croatian and foreign analysts say this is unlikely.
As they plan their attack, Croatian Government officials, both civilian and military, are making no effort to disguise their intentions.
"We would very much prefer to recover the occupied territory peacefully, but we are coming to the conclusion that the international community is not going to bring us a solution," Gen. Anton Tus, the chief military adviser to President Franjo Tudjman, said in an interview this week. "We have to do it ourselves. If we do nothing, we are essentially giving away part of our country and permitting the establishment of a Serb-run state on our territory."
Foreign governments, including the United States, have warned President Tudjman that an attack risks strong international condemnation, which would set back his efforts to bring Croatia closer to NATO and the European Union. But foreign criticism of his last attack was mild, and he apparently believes that the risks of inaction are greater than those of war.
"We're all pessimistic about the possibility of avoiding another round of fighting," said a Western diplomat in Zagreb. "It's going to be a bigger and bloodier operation than the last one, which was a rout. But Tudjman seems convinced that it's worth the gamble."
Diplomats and United Nations officials here are speculating not on whether Mr. Tudjman will order a new attack, but when it will come. Most guess that it will be sometime between the end of the tourist season and the onset of winter, probably in late August or September.
After the attack in May in which Croatia recaptured Western Slavonia, Serbian gunners fired volleys of cluster bombs into Zagreb, killing 11 civilians and wounding about 200. Milan Martic, leader of the breakaway authority that calls itself the Republic of Serbian Krajina, warned recently that he would use the same tactic if there were another attack.
"We have enough missiles to hit all important targets in Croatia," Mr. Martic said on television. "Retaliation against Croatian cities remains one of the most important aspects of our military strategy."
Despite this threat, interviews with Croats in Zagreb and elsewhere in the country suggest that public support for a new attack on the Krajina Serbs would be strong.
"Serbs will retaliate by shelling Croatian cities, including the capital," said Vera Golubic, a Zagreb accountant. "We all know that. So let's pay the price. It's better than being hostage to the Serbs for years and years."
Croatia's envoy at the United Nations office in Geneva, Miomir Zuzul, took a similar position in an interview broadcast on Zagreb television this week.
"We have a cancer in our body," Mr. Zuzul said. "When you have such a disease you cannot wait forever."
Apparently in preparation for an attack, the Croatian Army has reinforced positions near potentially vulnerable areas of the Serb-held territory. One set of positions is along the northern edge of the enclave, between Sisak and Karlovac. Another is around Canak, where the crescent-shaped occupied region is narrowest.
In addition, a combination of Croatian Army units and Bosnian Croats has taken up positions in hills and mountains overlooking Knin, where the Krajina Serbs have their headquarters.
There are about 10,000 United Nations troops in the threatened area, and any attacking force would have to overrun at least some of their positions to establish control.
The rebel Serbs have also been strengthening their forces, with substantial help from President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia.
After Croatia's victory in May, Mr. Milosevic sent a senior officer from the Yugoslav Army, Gen. Milan Mrksic, to take command of the Krajina military. According to Western intelligence reports, Mr. Milosevic has also sent dozens of tanks and scores of field officers to Krajina.
In an effort to bolster the Krajina infantry, Mr. Milosevic's police have rounded up several thousand Serbs born in the Krajina region and sent them home, where they are being forced into the rebel army.
But Croatian and foreign analysts are convinced that Mr. Milosevic would not send the Yugoslav Army to counter an attack on Krajina. Such an action would bring Serbia itself directly into the war and expose it to serious retaliation.
Croatian officers have apparently not decided the scale of their planned assault, but it will almost certainly be considerably more ambitious than their recapture of Western Slavonia.
At the Croatian Foreign Ministry, planners have prepared maps showing key roads and rail lines in Krajina, as well as the route of the region's only oil pipeline. Officials say their aim is to recover as many of these assets as possible, as well as to take at least enough territory to cut Krajina into several pieces.
Serbs, whose families have lived in parts of Croatia for centuries, rebelled against Croatian authority in early 1991, after Croatia broke away from Yugoslavia. With considerable help from the Serb-led Yugoslav Army, they established control over their parts of newly independent Croatia and turned them into the so-called Krajina Republic.
United Nations peacekeepers moved into Krajina, but after they failed to bring it back under Croatian control, the Croatian Government threatened last year to force them to leave. The Government later extended the mandate, but it is scheduled to expire at the end of November.
"The major factors all point in a negative direction at the moment," said a senior European diplomat in Belgrade. "We have a critical situation in Sarajevo and the other Muslim enclaves.
"The Bosnian Serbs are showing no willingness to come to the negotiating table. There is no prospect of an agreement between Yugoslavia and Croatia, or of an accord under which Yugoslavia would agree to recognize Bosnia in exchange for a lifting of economic sanctions.
"And we are facing the very real possibility of a major conflict in Croatia late this summer or early in the autumn. All this leads me to believe that things are going very badly on all major issues."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK NEWSDAY TO STOP PUBLISHING
New York Newsday, a bold experiment by a suburban newspaper to break into the largest and most competitive city market with a new type of tabloid, will publish its last issue tomorrow, its publishers said. The paper, which emerged in the economic boom of the mid-1980's, was the victim of corporate pressures for profits and a market that changed sharply over the last decade. [Page 1.]
 
When its final issue rolls off the press, New York Newsday will have lasted 10 years, 3 months and 1 day. Begun with expectations that it would outlive at least one of its competitors, it will be survived by the same three newspapers that it squared off against on Day 1: The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times. [26.]
 

In the newsroom, stunned reporters, editors and photographers tried to console one another over the brief, blunt announcement. [26.]
 
MIDWEST HEAT WAVE ROASTS NEW YORK
The scourge of heat that killed at least 15 people and thousands of cattle in the Midwest descended upon the New York area yesterday, bringing a high-misery combination of near-record temperatures in the mid-90's and the heavy wetness of a tropical rain forest. [1.]
 
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
STREET CORDON ANGERS RESIDENTS
East 13th Street between Avenue A and Avenue B in the East Village has been cordoned off by the police since late May, when the city evicted squatters living in two tenement buildings. The intention was to quiet a volatile situation and keep the squatters from returning, but the tactics have effectively shut off the flow of customers for many businesses on the block and have enraged many residents. [25.]
 
MAN ARRESTED IN UPPER EAST SIDE RAPE
A 24-year-old Manhattan man paroled less than a month ago from a Federal penitentiary was arrested at his mother's apartment on the Lower East Side and accused of raping a young woman Wednesday night in her penthouse apartment off Fifth Avenue. [25.]
 
TEACHER'S DEATH PUZZLES INVESTIGATORS
The fatal shooting of a remedial reading teacher in the Bronx on Wednesday has shaken many people, particularly at a time when officials are boasting of a safer city. At first, her death appeared to be the result of a botched robbery. But nothing seems to have been taken from her pocketbook, and the way she was shot has led some investigators to suggest it was an execution. [24.]
 
REGION
 
CASINO PLANS ARE REQUESTED
Taking an important step toward opening a casino in Bridgeport, Connecticut officials issued a formal call for proposals that required developers to guarantee the state hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue. The call represents the latest round in a three-year-old campaign by the financially ailing city. [27.]
 
RAIL DISPUTE IS FAR FROM SETTLEMENT
Negotiations between the Metro-North Railroad and 17 of its unions intensified, but officials on both sides of the dispute said they were far from a contract settlement. The unions are threatening to strike as early as 12:01 tomorrow morning. [27.]

HEADLINE: Reflecting on Vietnam Ties, Many Agree That It's Time

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: JOLIET, Ill., July 14

 BODY:
A generation ago, when the Vietnam War was driving a wedge through America, Marco Scolari, a union concrete worker and World War II veteran, could scarcely bring himself to speak to any man who had avoided military service. Back then, it seemed that passions over Vietnam might never cool, on either side.
But when President Clinton extended diplomatic recognition to Vietnam on Tuesday, a move that once would surely have ignited a firestorm, the response across the nation, in interviews with dozens of Americans, was measured, and mostly favorable. 
 Even Mr. Scolari, the onetime hawk now 77 and retired here in Joliet, merely shrugged. "You know, even the draft dodgers don't bother me anymore," he said. "They were halfway right about Vietnam."
A majority of the 75 or so people interviewed this week -- from this faded factory town on the Illinois River to the pinstripe-and-starch district of downtown Houston, from immigrant neighborhoods of Boston to the espresso cafes of Portland, Ore. -- looked on the Vietnam War as a finished chapter in American history. Although there was still some disagreement about the meaning of Vietnam, it was rarely expressed in the shrill tones of the divisions a quarter-century ago.
"It's been 20 years, and you can't hold a grudge forever," Bruce Donald, a 39-year-old banker, said as he browsed through a bookstore in Boston. "Look, my father-in-law lost a limb in World War II. It doesn't mean that if he saw a German today he'd turn the other way."
Joliet is the sort of working-class place that sent more than its share of sons and brothers to Vietnam. Indeed, it seems to be the rare person here who does not have a relative who fought in the war. John Adams, a 31-year-old auto sales manager whose father and grandfather both did, said: "It's time to let it go and move on. We shouldn't be paralyzed by our past."
Florine Johnson, 50, of Pikesville, Md., said there was only one reason the Government had waited so long to restore relations: Vietnam was the war America lost. "If we had won," she said, "this wouldn't be an issue."
To be sure, some people saw Mr. Clinton's move as a betrayal of those who fought, and especially of the families of men still missing in Vietnam. Several argued that the nation's most important bargaining chip in negotiations to gain more information about missing American troops had been squandered by the President's move.
"There's nothing to dangle over the Vietnamese Government's head," said Arguetta Ruffin, a 38-year-old administrative assistant in Atlanta. Ms. Ruffin said she believed that some American soldiers were still being held in prison camps.
But that view was in the minority. Even among those who said they opposed formal recognition of Vietnam, few held out much hope that any missing Americans were still alive.
"The family members and their friends are clinging to a little bit of hope -- it's an irrational hope," said Phil Kothmayer, a 37-year-old high school teacher in Ocala, Fla. "I can empathize with them, but look at it from a realistic standpoint. It's not going to happen."
Among those opposing recognition was Mark Sayers, 34, who works at a nuclear power plant near Joliet. "We lost 58,000 people in that war," he said, "and it's still a Communist country. Recognizing Vietnam is offensive to the families who lost somebody there."
Elizabeth Jessup, whose husband, Joseph, was wounded in Vietnam, said she could never bring herself to forgive its Communist leaders. "It's the same Vietnam that took our sons and brothers," she said. "I could never forgive them for that."
But others argued that the United States was not blameless either.
"The question should be, Can Vietnam forgive us?" said Billie Stokes, 40, who works as a customer service representative for a telephone company in Joliet. "I mean, look at all that we did to that country -- all the bombs we dropped, all the kids we killed."
Among some people, Mr. Clinton came in for renewed criticism for his avoidance of the draft. "He has no credibility on military matters," said Cheri Carhill, a 47-year-old housewife. "It's a joke for this coward to be making decisions about a war he refused to serve in."
Others, though, said that Mr. Clinton had surely known that he would be subjected to some criticism over his decision of this week, and that he deserved praise for taking the political risk.
"If he would just stand up for what he believes once in a while -- just because he believes in it -- people would have more respect for him," said Rita Adelman, a 51-year-old nurse in Joliet.
Warren Carlin, a 62-year-old English teacher at the College of St. Francis here, said he hoped that Mr. Clinton would stay the course on normalization with Vietnam, even if opposition mounted in Congress.
"He did the right thing," Mr. Carlin said. "Now, if he backs away from this, I will be very disappointed. But I won't be surprised."
Besides bringing closure to a traumatic chapter in American history, recognition of Vietnam opens a potentially important market, most of those interviewed said.
"We're in a world economy now," said Tom Fewox, a 42-year-old Houstonian. "We need to get on with business. They've allowed a lot of foreign investment in the oil industry."
And Steve Brinker, 46, a technician for a waste-water treatment company in Joliet, added, "Wasn't the whole war about capitalism anyway?"
Among younger Americans, of course, the Vietnam War is a matter of the distant past. "I know nothing about Vietnam," said Cris Glenn, a Joliet disk jockey born in 1973. "It seems like a lot of people are dwelling in the past. We should learn from the past mistakes and move on."
Pat Jordan, 73, the commander of a Veterans of Foreign Wars post in Portland, said he also supported Mr. Clinton's move. "You can't go on hating everyone for the rest of your life," he said. "It's going to tear you up if you do."
Charles Loveless, a 53-year-old Joliet welder who served in Vietnam in 1967 and 1968, said that the war had been "senseless" and that in any case he saw little to be gained by holding grudges against Hanoi. Withholding diplomatic recognition would only hurt ordinary Vietnamese, he said.
"The people of Vietnam are not my enemy," Mr. Loveless said. "They never were my enemy."

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
Why the liberal agenda might one day include the battle over euthanasia and assisted suicide.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Are euthanasia and assisted suicide about to become part of the liberal agenda? That question is raised by the case of George Delury, a Manhattan man charged with second-degree manslaughter after he willingly acknowledged helping his wife, who was incapacitated mentally and physically from multiple sclerosis, kill herself.
 Until now, most big battles over euthanasia or assisted suicide have occurred on the West Coast in court cases and in referendums at the polls, or in Michigan where Dr. Jack Kevorkian has made himself a kind of composite of the Lone Ranger and the Grim Reaper. Despite national media attention, euthanasia and assisted suicide have not been plotted on the ideological grid. 
 For example, the American Civil Liberties Union, certainly a flagship of liberalism, has rallied in support of individuals being able to decide their fates. Yet many advocates of rights for the disabled, most with liberal credentials, have rallied in opposition.
 In the West Coast voting, a trickle of feminist, trade-union and Democratic groups endorsed proposals to give doctors more latitude in dealing with these matters. Yet Bill Clinton, during the 1992 Presidential campaign, came out against such measures.
 New York, however, is where public issues are generally packaged and labeled. True, no one took much notice last December when a Federal District Court in Manhattan rejected a suit challenging the state's prohibition of assisted suicide. But that is likely to change now that the question has a face and is embedded in a drama that runs from love of a spouse to defiance of the law.
 That euthanasia and assisted suicide are unlikely to become part of the conservative agenda hardly needs discussing. It is true that justification for these practices can be found as readily on the libertarian right as on the liberal left. But conservatism almost by definition is apt to oppose radical departures from a longstanding moral consensus about not taking human life. By default, then, euthanasia and assisted suicide could become liberal causes.
 In addition, there are at least three natural affinities between these causes and the principles and history of liberalism. First, liberalism generally holds that the state should remain as neutral as possible toward competing concepts of how people should best live. The liberal-inspired state should merely establish and enforce the rules so that individuals will have fair and equal chances to pursue their own ideals and goals.
 From that perspective, the more personal and basic a matter -- and what could be more personal and basic than when and how one dies? -- the more it should be left to the individual's free choice.
 Second, modern liberalism has long been wed to a humanitarianism that focuses on the relief of overt suffering and pain. That is why, for example, liberal proponents of abortion rights feel more compelled to rebut the anti-abortion movement's claims about fetal pain than the movement's philosophical arguments about fetal "personhood."
 Third, liberalism has historically been linked with a faith in human progress through the rational control that science promised over nature. A medically procured death is the last-resort exercise of such control.
 But there are counter currents in liberalism. Some philosophers, for example, question the notion that liberalism can be thoroughly neutral toward rival conceptions of the human good. Liberalism, they argue, must have at least a minimal vision of what constitutes a good life and good person, a threshold beyond which diversity can flourish. Conceivably that threshold vision might include some absolute principles about the inviolability of human life.
 Others point out that John Stuart Mill, the 19th-century champion of the freedom to do whatever does not harm others, drew the line at choices that would irreversibly preclude all further choices, notably selling oneself into slavery. This, they say, is comparable to euthanasia or suicide.
 Then, too, from the Progressive Era through the New Deal, much of American liberalism departed from its individualist heritage to stress human interdependence and social solidarity, which could possibly (although not inevitably) motivate opposition to euthanasia and assisted suicide.
 Modern liberalism has also been sensitive to the ways in which freedom-of-choice arguments can be used to defend practices that are actually coercive because of social inequities. Turn-of-the-century courts, for example, struck down laws setting minimum wages or maximum hours in the name of "freedom of contract." Liberals have also argued that theoretically neutral practices like capital punishment operate in highly biased fashion.
 Such elements in the liberal tradition are often behind the fears that legalized euthanasia or assisted suicide, at least in the absence of a vastly improved and equitable health-care system, will subject the aged, disabled or gravely ill to psychological or economic coercion or lead to outright abuses.
 So it is possible that these proposals, even after they move center stage in New York, will remain ideologically homeless. It is even possible that the guardians of an already beleaguered liberalism will be a little relieved at that.

HEADLINE: Buchanan Challenges Gramm to Debate

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 14

 BODY:
Raw Presidential politics intruded on the Republican Party's hopes for a harmonious summer meeting here today as Patrick J. Buchanan challenged Senator Phil Gramm of Texas to a televised debate over who is the true conservative seeking the party's nomination.
That prompted a third contender, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, to jump into the crossfire, presenting himself as the voice of civility and warning that such rivalries are no way to attract voters. 
 "Before long," Mr. Lugar said, "the whole platform is tilting to the right -- everybody's about to fall off, almost oblivious to the fact that we want to win a general election. You cannot win it that way."
But, for now, few Republicans are looking beyond the primaries. Mr. Buchanan, a commentator who honed his sparring skills on the CNN program "Crossfire," made plain why he was escalating his assault: "Right now, Phil Gramm is in my way, and I'm in Phil Gramm's way."
Mr. Gramm, who earlier this week snapped that Mr. Buchanan's knowledge of economics and agriculture "you could fit into a thimble," immediately rejected the challenge. "It's impossible to have a serious discussion with somebody who is so obviously distorting the facts about Phil Gramm's record and he knows it," said Gary Koops, Mr. Gramm's spokesman.
The feuding today offered a taste of what is to come as the Republicans try to keep their hold on Congress and not allow intraparty backbiting to deter their drive to win back the White House next year. But the Presidential contenders, who appear increasingly impatient with Senator Bob Dole's standing as the undisputed front-runner, cannot seem to resist turning more aggressively on one another as they compete for second place. Mr. Dole, who was not present today, is to address the three-day conference on Saturday.
Other prominent party members warned Republicans at the meeting here that such behavior -- and a preoccupation with abortion and other social issues -- might be destructive. "We're trying to pitch the tent here to have both libertarians and social conservatives," said Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts. "We should not lead with social issues -- we should be leading with economic issues."
Republicans did not turn all of their venom on each other. Speaker Newt Gingrich, who has been flirting with running for President himself, urged those who are in the race to stick to issues. And he offered the highly partisan audience one of his most ferocious attacks on President Clinton.
"We have the least competent, least adult, least structured, and least disciplined and least reasonable Administration, I think, probably in our country's history," he said. Still, Mr. Gingrich reminded the gathering not to underestimate the President's political skills, saying, "If the 1996 election is about personality, there is a fair chance that Bill Clinton will get re-elected. I do not know in our lifetime of any political figure with a greater capacity to make you feel good for 30 seconds."
But the biggest sideshow for Republicans, at least recently, has been the hostility between Mr. Gramm and Mr. Buchanan, two of the most combative figures in Republican politics. Although Mr. Gramm has far outpaced Mr. Buchanan in fund-raising and organization, Mr. Buchanan has launched a full-scale drive to stop the Senator from cornering the support of conservative voters. He has come on stronger than many party leaders had expected -- to the point of running ahead of Mr. Gramm in some early polls in the crucial primary state of New Hampshire.
"Phil Gramm says he is the heir to Ronald Reagan's legacy, that he wants to complete the Reagan revolution," Mr. Buchanan said. "I think the Gramm claim is bogus."
He cited Mr. Gramm's votes on issues from taxes to his support for the confirmation of Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer as Justices of the Supreme Court. Asked why he did not go after Mr. Dole for many of the same votes, Mr. Buchanan said, "Because we have to get past Phil Gramm if we're going to have a run at Bob Dole."
Mr. Gramm, who is addressing the convention on Saturday, along with Mr. Dole and most of the other candidates, has retorted that Mr. Buchanan is too extreme in his views and lacks an adequate campaign structure to win the nomination.
The usually mild-mannered Mr. Lugar, who has been overshadowed by other candidates during the early jockeying, chastised Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Gramm. "There's often a rivalry to appear to be the sternest, most mean-spirited candidate in the field -- really pounding down into the pavement almost everyone who doesn't seem to fit," he said. "Once again, that's a loser." Mr. Lugar also accused Mr. Dole and other rivals of going too far in seizing on "wedge issues" like racial quotas and immigration.
But Mr. Lugar himself engaged in some personal attacks. Responding to a reporter's question, he said because Senators Dole and Gramm and Gov. Pete Wilson of California have been divorced they are less credible when talking about family values. "I think they have a problem," he said, adding that "a President has to lead by example."
Most people attending the conference were not party to the political combat here because the candidates saved their sharpest barbs in conversations with reporters outside the convention hall.
Nevertheless, when the conference opened on Thursday, Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, dismissed the notion that there was undue tension in the party in general and between Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Gramm in particular.
"We shouldn't expect a campaign to go to its conclusion without understanding where Candidate A and Candidate B differ on issues," he said. "That's what politics is all about."

HEADLINE: Intuit Signs 19 Deals for Home-Banking Software

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

 BODY:
Intuit Inc. announced yesterday that 19 financial institutions, including many of the nation's largest banks, credit card companies and brokerage firms, would use its popular Quicken software for home banking services beginning this fall.
 The move signals the company's intent to compete aggressively with the Microsoft Corporation after the collapse in May of plans for the two companies to merge. 
 Yet while the alliances are expected to enhance Intuit's lead over Microsoft in the fast-growing home banking market, many of the banking companies that have signed on with Intuit -- including Chemical Banking and Sanwa Bank California -- also have relationships with Microsoft. Officials of those banks say they will allow customers to choose which service to use.
 "I think we can expect a pier-six brawl between Microsoft and Intuit this fall," said Adam Schoenfeld, vice president of Jupiter Communications Inc., a market research firm in New York that specializes in on-line services.
 With a new version of Quicken, customers of American Express, Chase Manhattan Bank, Smith Barney and other institutions will be able to transfer money between accounts, pay bills and retrieve data from their accounts directly into financial files on their personal computers. All electronic transactions will be processed through the Intuit Services Corporation, a unit of the company that acts as a data clearinghouse between the customer and the bank.
 The customer will probably pay a monthly fee to the institution for the electronic banking services, though in some cases, said Scott Cook, the chairman and founder of Intuit, the service might be free. Intuit will collect fees from the institutions.
 Shares of Intuit rose $2.75 yesterday, to $85.75, in Nasdaq trading. The stock jumped $4.75, or 6 percent, on Thursday in anticipation of yesterday's announcement. Shares of Microsoft also rose yesterday, closing at $103.675, up $3.50, in Nasdaq trading.
 The new service could accelerate consumer participation in the long-nascent market for electronic banking services. Only about a quarter of home computer users regularly use a financial software program, but that number is growing quickly. And Quicken has between 60 and 70 percent of the personal finance software market, with about eight million users. Mr. Cook of Intuit called the endorsement of Quicken by the 19 financial institutions " a giant leap forward" in the way both home computer users and small-business owners manage their books.
 For banks, home banking will lead to lower costs as they cut back on labor and branch costs, much the same way automated teller machines have led to lower bank staff costs. Small and midsize banks are eager to offer home banking to give them an edge over larger institutions. "It levels the playing field for smaller banks without the branch reach," said Keith H. Karpe, vice president of Sanwa Bank California, which has 110 branches.
 Intuit's announcement comes at a time of rapid change in the electronic banking industry. Two months ago, Microsoft withdrew its $2 billion bid to acquire Intuit amid an antitrust investigation by the Justice Department.
 In addition, the No. 3 company in financial software, Meca Software of Fairfield, Conn., a unit of H & R Block, announced in May that it was being acquired by a union of the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco and the Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. The two banking companies plan to offer electronic banking services over their own private networks, with Meca's Managing Your Money software installed on customers' personal computers.
 After the merger of Intuit and Microsoft collapsed, there was some question in the software industry as to whether Intuit would have enough influence on its own to woo large financial institutions.
 Mr. Cook of Intuit said negotiations with many of the institutions announced yesterday were begun during the merger negotiations, but that the collapse of the merger had no impact on their decisions. "We lost no financial institution partners that were with us at the time of the merger," he said.
 The other institutions that will work with Intuit are Bank of Boston, Centura Bank, Compass Bank, Corestates Bank, First National Bank of Chicago, First Interstate Bank, Home Savings of America, M&T Bank, Marquette Banks, Michigan National Bank, Texas Commerce Bank, Union Bank, U.S. Bancorp and Wells Fargo Bank.

HEADLINE: Technology Issues Move Up As Some Other Sectors Slip

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Technology stocks held up yesterday as many other widely followed issues posted losses. The Nasdaq composite index, laden with technology issues, ended higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined.
 "The technology sector came back from early weakness," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president of Interstate/Johnson Lane, a securities firm in Charlotte, N.C. "And most of those issues have yet to report their earnings." 
 The overall market was dragged down in part by higher bond yields. Bond prices, which move in the opposite direction from their yields, fell after a stronger-than-expected retail sales report lowered expectations that interest rates would be cut again this summer. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.60 percent, from 6.55 percent on Thursday. "Higher yields tend to depress business activity," Mr. Harrington noted.
 The Nasdaq index rose 5.18 points, to 999.33. The Dow industrials dropped 18.66 points, to 4,708.82, and the S.& P. fell 1.11 points, to 559.89.
 Declining issues outnumbered those that rose on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,321 to 921. Big Board volume was off, sinking to 312.9 million shares, from 388.5 million on Thursday.
 At the opening bell, technology issues slumped in reaction to a report, issued late Thursday, that showed weakness in semiconductor orders for June. According to the Semiconductor Industry Association, $117 worth of new orders were received for every $100 of goods shipped, compared with $120 of new orders in May.
 But this group rebounded later in the day, based partly on strong sales during the traditionally slow months of the year. Microsoft was up 3 1/2, to 103 5/8; Intel rose 1 7/8, to 75 1/2, and Texas Instruments gained 1/2, to 154 1/8.
 Another group that moved against the general trend was the retail stocks, which benefited from the larger-than-expected June retail sales gain and indications that the trend would continue this month. Sears, Roebuck rose 1 3/4, to 34; Kmart was up 3/8 to 15; Woolworth gained 1/4, to 14 5/8, and J. C. Penney increased 3/4, to 48.
 Household-products companies declined, starting with Colgate-Palmolive, which said that its second-quarter profits would drop below analysts' projections. Colgate was down 3 7/8, to 68 1/4; Procter & Gamble lost 1/8, to 69 1/2, and Clorox slipped 1/2, to 62 1/2.
 Some tobacco stocks were off, just as they were on Thursday, as traders sold in reaction to a Food and Drug Administration proposal that would increase Federal regulation. Philip Morris fell 3/4, to 74 3/4, and UST lost 1/8, to 28 7/8.
Amid projections that oil industry earnings reached their peak in the second quarter, oil stocks also declined. Mobil was off 5/8, to 98 5/8; Exxon slipped 1/4, to 71 5/8, and Chevron fell 1/2, to 47 5/8.
 Comair sank 5 1/2, to 31 7/8, after being downgraded from a buy to a market performer by J. P. Morgan Securities. And Mapinfo plummeted 12 1/4, to 22 3/8, after announcing that its fiscal third-quarter net income would be below that of a year earlier.
 In Japan, stocks ended slightly higher. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 12.03 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 16,517.70.

HEADLINE: Data Suggest Turnaround For Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Fresh Government figures today lent strong support to the notion that the slow economy of recent months is heading for better times, not a recession.
 Fears of recession ebbed as the Commerce Department reported that consumers spent less warily this spring than had been thought. Retail sales were up an estimated seven-tenths of 1 percent in June on top of a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, which was originally reported as a rise of just two-tenths. 
 In addition, industrial production ended a streak of declines to post its first gain, albeit a minimal one, since January.
 "The economy is not slipping into recession as some had feared," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist for North America at Paribas Capital Markets. "We may be nearing the end of the inventory correction," he added, referring to the pileup of unsold goods during the spring that increasingly looks as if it is about to shrink. .
 And while the economy may wind up recording some modest growth in the second quarter after all, most analysts said the current evidence that a rebound was ahead did not rule out further easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve.
 That is because the Government also released figures today that showed inflation remaining quite subdued. The Government calculated that consumer prices edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in June, the smallest rise since November.
 "On the surface, today's spending data will fuel skepticism about the wisdom of the Federal Reserve's latest easing move as well as the prospect of any further steps," John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, told clients. "However, the underlying pattern of moderate growth and relatively low inflation suggests a period ahead of stable to lower bond yields in which the Fed is more likely than not to find additional opportunities to pare short rates."
 Just over a week ago the central bank cut the benchmark overnight interest rate it controls by one-quarter of a percentage point, reversing policy after seven upward steps between February 1994 and February 1995. Those increases doubled the overnight rate, from 3 percent to 6 percent.
 Another factor providing leeway for further rate cuts is that the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities -- a closely watched gauge of potential inflation pressure -- continued to decline in June, according to the Fed report. At 83.5 percent, utilization is now two full percentage points below the peak set in December and January.
 But it was the sales report that captured much of the attention today, contributing to a rise in interest rates that dragged the stock market down.
 The climb of seven-tenths of 1 percent was dominated by a rebound in the automotive sector, where dealers' receipts climbed 1.9 percent with the aid of hefty incentives. Merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent while those selling furniture and other home equipment took in an estimated three-tenths of 1 percent more money than in May.
 But excluding the automotive sector, sales rose just three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department's report also showed. That was primarily because sales of nondurables, which account for 60 percent of retail sales, were less robust. Indeed, food stores had a decline of four-tenths of 1 percent in sales, and restaurants and bars saw receipts fall two-tenths of 1 percent.
 Total sales of $196 billion were 5.9 percent higher than in June 1994, without any adjustment for inflation.
 Just as important as the June gain, analysts said, was the upward revision that lifted the May gain to nine-tenths of 1 percent. Some analysts said these results suggested -- contrary to expectations by many that the economy had dipped in the spring -- that there was at least some economic growth during the second quarter.
 Today's figures, said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities, "diminish the probability of a recession."
 The Fed's report on production showed a modest rise for consumer goods following months of sizable declines, with motor vehicle assembly running at the same 11.5 million annual rate as in May.
 Factory output edged up one-tenth of 1 percent after two declines averaging five-tenths of 1 percent; mines produced 1 percent more than in May, but utility production resumed a decline that has pushed output 2.5 percent below the June 1994 level.
 As for the Consumer Price Index, a second straight month of sharp declines in automobile finance charges and used-car prices helped limit the overall rise to a negligible one-tenth of 1 percent, the Labor Department report showed. The price of used cars had surged 15.8 percent in the 12 months through April.
 On the other hand, air fares jumped 8.4 percent in June, to bring the increase so far this year to 20.4 percent. Energy prices rose substantially for the third month in a row. Drugs and medical supplies posted their first monthly increase of 1995 but this did not accelerate overall medical costs, which have risen every month so far this year by three-tenths of 1 percent.
 Excluding food and energy, consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as in May.
 Services, which account for nearly 57 percent of the index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month while commodity prices were unchanged, the report also showed.
 The index for all urban consumers now stands at 152.5, which means that a group of goods and services that cost $10 in the 1982-84 period now costs $15.25.

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasuries Retreat On Strong Retail Spending

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday after a Government report showed surprising strength in consumer spending. The report shook the market's view of a slowing economy and cast doubt on the prospects for another cut in short-term interest rates.
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 22/32 yesterday, to 1139/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its prices, rose to 6.60 percent, from 6.55 percent on Thursday. The price of the two-year bill also fell, pushing its yield up to 5.68 percent from 5.59 percent. 
 The Commerce Department said yesterday that retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, exceeding analysts' expectations of a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent.
 "If the consumer continues to go out on a spending spree, it's going to be much more difficult to see rates moving lower," said Barbara Kenworthy, who manages $3 billion in bonds at Prudential Investment Advisers in Newark.
 Many traders have been expecting another cut in interest rates since last week, when the Fed reduced its target for the Federal funds rate to 5.75 percent from 6 percent. The move matched the market's expectations given recent reports showing a sharp slowing of the economy, and bond prices rallied.
 But prices have slipped this week on profit taking and as traders await further clues to the direction of the economy.
Contributing to a picture of a resilient economy yesterday was the Federal Reserve's report on industrial production, which showed a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
 Still, these signs of growth came amid further evidence that inflation was restrained. The Labor Department reported yesterday that consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in June, the best performance since a similar small increase in November.
 And some traders said that the retail sales report did not necessarily indicate a resilient economy.
 "The key number was the retail sales less cars, and that was actually a little lower than expected," said Andrew Brenner, senior trader at Nomura Securities International. "If you take into account all the discounted sales, they were just kind of winnowing down inventory."
 Bond prices were also hurt by a report that indicated that Americans were more optimistic about the economy, suggesting that spending by individuals, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, could keep rising.
 The University of Michigan's preliminary consumer sentiment index for July rose to 94.1 from 92.7 in June and 89.8 in May, analysts familiar with the report said. The index is released only to paying subscribers. Americans are also growing more hopeful about the future, according to the university's preliminary expectations index, which rose to 85.5, from 84.1 in June.
 In the corporate market, "the environment is still very favorable" for new supply, said Michael Gray, who manages $2.5 billion of fixed-income assets at the Fidelity Management and Research Company in Boston.
 Funds that buy investment-grade bonds received $178.1 million in cash in the week ended Wednesday, bringing to almost $1.5 billion the cash that has flowed into these funds in the last two months, according to AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif., which tracks mutual fund money flows.
 On Thursday, the Raytheon Company sold $1.125 billion of bonds, 50 percent more than originally planned, in its first public bond sale.
 Two more large bond sales are on the way. The World Bank is planning to sell another $1.5 billion of 10-year global notes as early as next week, Hakan Lonaeus, the bank's chief financial operations officer, said.
 Global bonds are sold simultaneously in the United States, Europe and Asia and trade around the clock.
 The Swiss Bank Corporation is expected to sell $500 million of debt with maturities of 10 and 30 years in the days ahead, according to MCM Corporate Watch, which tracks sales of fixed-income and other securities.
 In the municipal bond market, bonds fell as investors continued to demand higher yields, amid concern that tax proposals in Congress would trim the advantage munis hold over other fixed-income investments, traders said.

HEADLINE: State Seeks Casino Offers With Hefty Guarantees

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: NEWINGTON, Conn., July 14

 BODY:
Taking an important step toward opening a casino in Bridgeport, Gov. John G. Rowland issued a formal call today for proposals from developers that required guarantees to the state of hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue.
 The request for proposals represents the latest round in a three-year-old campaign by civic and political leaders in Bridgeport to win state approval for a gambling and entertainment complex to revive their ailing city. And again there is one central question: Will any prospective developer be able to guarantee that it can cover the money that the Mashantucket Pequot Indians would stop paying the state if they were stripped of their monopoly on casino gambling? 
 The tribe, which operates the Foxwoods casino in Ledyard, has said it will cut off its monthly payments to the state the moment the Legislature passes a law that threatens to end the monopoly on slot machines that the state granted the Pequot and Mohegan tribes. That would cost the state a projected $150 million next year and $230 million in 1997, when the Mohegans are expected to open their casino.
 At a news conference at the Division of Special Revenues here today, Governor Rowland, a Republican, laid out the process for insuring that the state would not lose money by allowing a new casino. Both he and gaming company representatives at the event were cautiously optimistic that the state could find a satisfactory deal.
 "I am delighted to be spearheading a plan that should result in one of the finest casino and entertainment complexes in the country," Mr. Rowland said, calling the casino "the most realistic bridge" to bringing in more economic development to Bridgeport.
 "I remain excited by the prospect of the thousands of jobs that will be created by this dramatic initiative."
 Whether any developers can actually meet the state's requirements will be determined by the end of September, when a special commission must select a proposal or rule that none is adequate. If one is selected and Mr. Rowland accepts it, a special session of the Legislature will be convened to decide whether to authorize it and break the agreement with the Mashantucket Pequots.
 Under the process started today, developers have a deadline of Aug. 18 to submit proposals that show they would equal this lost revenue through gaming taxes on their operation and other sources. All proposals must also be accompanied by a $610 million letter of credit that the state could immediately draw upon if the developer failed to meet its monthly payment.
 The $610 million equals the $150 million expected next year from the Indians plus a projected $230 million that could be lost from them in each of the following two.
 "Most of the major casino operators have lines of credit of $1 billion that they can draw down from," said Brendan Kennedy, a consultant representing Harrah's Casinos Inc., which operates 16 casinos in the United States. "That's not a great amount of money when paid out over a period of time."
 The casino operator would also be required to make a $150 million payment the first year, followed by annual payments of $230 million until 2006. To guarantee this, the operator would have to renew its letter of credit every three years.
 In return, Mr. Rowland said, the state would not allow any other casinos to open during that time.
 All proposals are expected to provide two scenarios for providing the state the revenue it seeks. In one, the developer must consider only money from a tax on the casino's gross gaming revenues. In the other, the developer may also include revenues from placing 6,250 slot machines at dog tracks, Offtrack Betting simulcast parlors and Jai Alai frontons.
The gross gaming tax would be at least 16 percent, making it the highest such tax in the nation.
 Richard D. Bronson, a Mirage Resorts director who has been lobbying to open the Bridgeport casino since 1992, said that the company was likely to submit a proposal but that it would need time to review the 112 pages of criteria that the state released today. The amount asked for in the letter of credit did not faze him, he said, adding that the time frame was longer than he had expected.
 Still, some critics remained skeptical that any casino could make a profit under these conditions and noted that new casinos are expected to open in the next 10 years in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New York, making the gaming market more competitive.
 "I have questions whether this area, New England, can support all of this gambling," said State Senator James T. Fleming, Republican of Simsbury, a leader of the anti-casino forces.
 Yet Mr. Fleming and others praised Mr. Rowland for starting the process, saying his efforts would help resolve a divisive issue.
 Charles J. Duffy, a lobbyist for the Pequot tribe, which has worked to stop the opening of a Bridgeport casino, said: "I think it's a sound and reasonable way to come up with an answer to the question that has been before the state for years: Can the state come up with a better deal than the one we've given them?"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Bailout Defended Amid G.O.P. Criticism

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Top Treasury officials today defended the American-led bailout of Mexico last winter as a success, but Congressional Republicans criticized the Administration for lending more money to Mexico this summer.
 Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Lawrence H. Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, told the Senate Banking Committee that the Treasury's $20 billion line of credit was essential in preventing a financial crisis in Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America that would have threatened economic growth and national security in the United States. 
 "The objective of promoting United States exports, jobs, security of our borders, in our judgment, is being accomplished," Mr. Rubin said. "We have also avoided the spillover into other emerging markets that we think could easily have happened."
 Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, the committee's chairman, criticized the Administration for lending Mexico $2.5 billion on July 5, on top of the $10 billion lent during the first half of this year. He was particularly critical of Mr. Summers, who had told a House panel in March that the second half of the $20 billion would only be lent if "contingencies" justified it.
 The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, and Senator D'Amato called last week for the United States to stop lending money to Mexico.
 Democrats and Republicans have been maneuvering this summer to avoid any blame from the public for Mexico's sharp devaluation of the peso last winter, which drastically reduced sales of American goods there and provoked a financial panic that the United States stopped only with huge loans. Mr. D'Amato in particular, who scheduled today's hearing, has contended that the Administration should have disclosed early last year the concerns of some officials that Mexico's reliance on short-term foreign investments was not sustainable.
 Yet the potential for partisanship on the issue has been limited by the fact that Mr. Dole and Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia both supported President Clinton's efforts last winter to help Mexico. When Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, noted this at today's hearing, Mr. D'Amato, a key supporter of Senator Dole's Presidential campaign, shifted uneasily in his chair.
 Mr. Summers said today that the United States had to lend the additional $2.5 billion to reduce any uncertainty about Mexico's ability to make payments on a clump of $7 billion in bonds coming due in the next several weeks. But he insisted that the overall Mexican economy remained sound, and apologized for having indicated in the spring that the second half of the $20 billion might not be spent.
 "I think in retrospect the word 'contingencies' may have been poorly chosen," he said. Mexico's financial plight turned out to be worse than expected during the first month of the American bailout, prompting large loans, but the Mexican economy has recovered faster than expected since then, Mr. Summers added.
 Mr. Rubin noted that the first announcement of the bailout had said that once the first half of the money had been lent, "using the same terms and conditions, another $10 billion will become available -- as needed and in stages -- beginning in July."
 But Mr. Rubin added, "We regret any incorrect impression we might have left that the second $10 billion would be available only for an emergency."
 Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, also assailed the Administration for having bailed out foreign investors in Mexico, who were effectively repaid with the money from American loans to the Mexican Government. California investors in the bonds of bankrupt Orange County have no similar guarantee of getting their money back, she said.
 Mr. Rubin said that foreign bondholders were the unintentional beneficiaries of an American financial rescue aimed at helping Mexico. Mr. Summers said that while large chunks of the initial American loans might have been used to repay foreign investors, more and more of the money was being used in Mexico. About $8 billion of the $22 billion lent by the United States and international financial agencies has effectively stayed in Mexico, he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Modest Advance On Signs of Stronger Economy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The dollar was slightly higher against most leading currencies yesterday, helped by economic reports showing resilient strength in the United States economy.
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales were up seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, a greater rise than expected. The strength in consumer spending seen in the report suggested that the Federal Reserve would not have reason to cut short-term interest rates anytime soon. Lower rates often hurt the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits less attractive. 
 The strong retail sales figures "question the view that the consumer is shriveling," said Amy Smith, senior currency market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm.
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said that the Consumer Price Index inched up one-tenth of 1 percent in June.
 The report seems "to confirm the view that price pressures are receding," said Callum Henderson, senior currency analyst at MMS International in New York. "That's positive for any currency, and very good long term for U.S. assets."
 The dollar rose even as American bond and stock markets fell.
 The gains in the dollar, however, were limited by lingering disappointment over the Bundesbank's decision not to lower interest rates. A number of currency dealers had bet that the German central bank would take its cue from recent rate cuts by the Fed, the Bank of Japan and several European central banks. When the Bundesbank held rates steady after a policy-setting meeting on Thursday, the dollar tumbled.
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.3903 German marks from 1.3877 marks on Thursday. The dollar rose to 87.83 Japanese yen from 87.35 yen.
 The dollar was also supported by worries over the health of President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. Concern mounted after Russian officials said Mr. Yeltsin had canceled a trip to Norway and would remain in the hospital until Monday.
 While the German mark is typically the traders' choice as the safe-haven currency in times of politial turmoil, the mark is considered vulnerable during turmoil in Russia because of the close economic ties between the two countries.
 Questions about Mr. Yeltsin's health "prevent people from being very bearish on the U.S. dollar because of the fact that there could be a politically unstable situation in Russia if he is removed," said Belal Khan, chief customer dealer at Bank of Tokyo in New York.
