HEADLINE: Tactics Used Against Squatters Anger Neighbors and Stores

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Art Guerra, a painter, supports his art with the business he runs on the Lower East Side, Guerra Paint, a supply store frequented by other artists and interior decorators. But for the last several weeks, business has been seriously down, he said -- and not because of a market slowdown, rising costs or any of the other ordinary economic hazards.
 It is Mr. Guerra's misfortune to have his store at 510 East 13th Street, between Avenue A and Avenue B, a block that has been cordoned off by the police since late May, when, in quasi-military fashion, the city evicted squatters living in two tenement buildings. Since then, officers have been stopping drivers and sometimes pedestrians, asking them their business on the block and encouraging mere passers-by to go elsewhere. 
 "A lot of my customers are from Westchester and Connecticut, and they're already scared to come down here," Mr. Guerra said. "Then they see the police barricades and forget it. We're strangled. We're down 60 or 70 percent."
 Indeed, Mr. Guerra, whose shop is near Avenue A, is not the only businessman suffering. Hermes Hernandez, who owns the City Water Meter Repair Company in midblock, said the deliveries he has had to make because customers have not been allowed through the barricades had cost him $2,000 so far.
 The barricades at both ends of the street and a 24-hour police presence on the block, often more than a dozen officers at a time, were supposed to quiet a volatile situation and keep the squatters from returning.
 But the tactics have effectively shut off the flow of customers for many businesses on the block. They have also enraged many residents, who rail against being asked for identification scant feet from their front doors. People complain of having to meet visitors at the corner, contending that the police officers are disrupting their lives far more than the squatters ever did.
 "I had to come down from my fifth-floor walk-up to wait for my babysitter in the heat on the corner because they won't let her car on the block," said Marisa Dedominicis, an 11-year resident of 544 East 13th. "I'm so outraged at the whole scenario. The cops have been abusing their authority. They're obnoxious. When are they going to leave?"
 The police said yesterday that no one knew when the captain of the Ninth Precinct would decide to open the street.
 The 500 block of East 13th Street is largely residential, with a handful of businesses. It's a bohemian environment, home to artists and blue-collar workers. It also has a drug trade, although it is no longer as prevalent as it once was. Small trees line the street, and a couple of makeshift gardens have sprung up between the tenements, none of which are taller than six stories. Five squatters buildings, three still occupied, line the north side near Avenue B.
 In yesterday's heat, people were baking but busy, battling sweat and lethargy. The police themselves were less than vigilant, as pedestrian traffic moved relatively freely through the barricades, but that failed to soothe the irate.
 "There's an uncertainty about who can enter the block and who can't," said Joan Nicholson, who has lived on East 13th for 16 years. "There's a tense atmosphere here. The squatters never threatened us, but I have felt threatened by the police."
 Most of the angry residents admitted that many neighbors were not upset by the police presence, but those people were not much in evidence yesterday. One man who expressed support for the police was Butch Johnson, a squatter in one of the still-occupied buildings.
 "You don't have hooligans running up and down the block, frightening my wife, frightening my children," Mr. Johnson said, referring to the angry demonstrations that had taken place during and after the evictions. "The police are calming things down. All I know is I'm getting a good night's sleep."
 Sgt. Peter Wang, who was in charge of the 16-officer force on the block yesterday, said he was aware of some disgruntlement among the residents.
 "But you're never going to please everybody," he said. He denied that the officers were harassing anyone and said the policy dictated that the officers go out of their way not to disrupt the life of the block.
 "If they live on the block, they're free to come and go as they please," Sgt. Wang said. "Anyone who has business on the block, we're letting them through. Or even if they just want to park on the block, we let them."
 That perspective was widely disputed, most loudly by Danny Lord, a professional clown. Mr. Lord, 45, admits that he has a smart mouth and that he regularly glares at the officers at the barricades. On Monday night, just after midnight, Mr. Lord left his apartment at 513 East 13th to go to the delicatessen and glared at a police officer.
 When he returned 15 minutes later, he said, the officer would not let him back in because he had no identification. An argument ensued, and he was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct.
 While many longtime residents of the block seem to feel under siege, some newcomers are feeling the heat as well. On the corner of Avenue B, where the police presence is the heaviest, Dante Wilder, a new store owner, is looking for customers for On Point, a small T-shirt boutique he opened in mid-May. Since the squatters were evicted at 541 and 547 East 13th, On Point, which is at 549, next to the now-boarded-up buildings, has been empty. Police cars parked on the corner keep passers-by on Avenue B from seeing his shop, and potential customers are being questioned by police.
 "If someone gets hassled, they're not going to come back," Mr. Wilder said. "I really want to make this work, and it feels like it's not working."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Police barricades on a block of East 13th Street are inconveniencing more people than the squatters they were intended to control. Art Guerra, a business owner on the block, said many of his customers at Guerra Paint are intimidated by the officers and are staying away. (Marilyn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Heroes, Icons and Monuments

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
EARLIER this week, a small group of amateur athletics officials gathered in Manhattan to celebrate a monumental moment in track and field as the New York Athletic Club became the official home of the Jesse Owens International Trophy.
 Since 1981, the trophy has been awarded annually to the amateur or Olympic athlete who best personifies the qualities attributed to Owens: great athletic achievement, sportsmanship and a sincere commitment to cooperation among people of all nations. 
 Herb Douglas, the founder of the trophy, said that the New York Athletic Club is the perfect home for the Owens trophy because of its commitment to amateur athletics. The N.Y.A.C. was the country's first governing body for amateur athletics. In 1876 it sponsored the first national track and field championships and later put on the first national boxing and wrestling championships. It is the home of an exclusive collection of trophies and memorabilia, including a small American flag from the 1912 Olympics signed by, among others, Jim Thorpe.
 For some, however, the biting irony of keeping the trophy in the N.Y.A.C. is that the club at one time did not admit African-Americans or women.
 During the ceremony, Douglas, a bronze medalist in the 1948 Olympics and close friend of Owens, said that Owens was forgiving and that his response to racism was to pull together. "Jesse used to say: 'We all came here on different boats,' " Douglas said, " 'but if we all don't row together America will sink. I'm going to do all I can do to keep it afloat.' "
 So it is, the New York Athletic Club not only houses one of the most prestigious awards in track and field but also, according to Douglas, the first international sporting trophy named after an African-American.
Fifteen years after his death, Owens has extended his legacy and given us yet another reason to remember him. How many young athletes today think for even a moment about how they will be remembered next week, much less 20 years from now?
 Athletes have difficulty achieving the same level of importance after their careers. They operate in a world of action, of the here and now, of short term gain. When the action stops, the athletic life ends.
 Owens's legacy has less to do with athletic feats than with the way he symbolized profound truths about the United States and problems not yet resolved.
 What legacies will his heirs leave?
 Mike Tyson, regardless of what he does from this point on, will be remembered for serving a prison term for rape. Dwight Gooden, once regarded as one of the greatest pitchers in baseball, will be remembered as a player whose career was cut short by drugs.
 This failing of foresight is not just a contemporary phenomenon in sports. Everyone talks about the good old days, but sports did as much to obscure an athlete's vision then as it does now. Certain types of misbehavior were tolerated, even encouraged, as an expression of the American male way.
 Mickey Mantle's news conference before the All-Star Game was a poignant testament. The Mick essentially repented moving blindly, recklessly through his career with no direction or higher goal. "God gave me the ability to play baseball and I wasted it," he said. "I'm going to spend the rest of my life trying to make up. I want to start giving something back."
 Still, the young contemporary athlete who wants to use visibility as a forum to effect change faces a greater challenge than Jesse Owens.
 Causes are not defined in black and white as they were in previous generations. They are defined by green, by economic disenfranchisement, by thwarted access to quality education.
 If courage was the watchword for Owens's generation, sharing is the challenge of the 21st century. This concept is an anathema to a generation of athletes weaned on self interest, blinded by celebrity and counseled by barracudas. Contending with these forces makes it difficult to see oneself in a larger role.
 Yet, vision needs to be expanded. The fundamental issues of race, gender and equality that Owens faced 50 years ago persist today but in a different form.
 Contemplating the so called "new breed" of athletes, I wonder how many of their careers will stand for more than dunks and touchdowns.
 Who will stand the test of time?

HEADLINE: Journal;
Such Stuff as Dreams

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
The moon hanging right over the stage wasn't quite full. Not everything can be perfect. But for a vision of ecstasy in New York City, it would be hard to top the scene in Central Park last Sunday night as 1,900 people watched "The Tempest."
The tickets were free. The performance transformed an urban patch of green into an island paradise, carpeted in sand and bewitched by apparitions. And there was Patrick Stewart as Prospero: as the old magician finally gave up his powers at evening's end, the actor pointedly spoke the final verses of Shakespeare's valedictory play without a microphone. Mr. Stewart's metallic baritone, nurtured at England's Royal Shakespeare Company and known to Americans from "Star Trek: The Next Generation," carried effortlessly -- even though the house is as large as any Broadway barn, with an acoustically worthless canopy of stars for a roof. 
 Theater doesn't get more timeless; for a moment, you would think there had always been Shakespeare in the park. But in fact it dates only as far back as government arts funding. "There was art in America before 1965," goes the rallying cry of those who would kill the National Endowment for the Arts, which was founded in that year. Yes -- but not for everyone.
On Sunday night George Wolfe, who now runs the New York Shakespeare Festival and who directed this "Tempest," introduced the show with a dedication to the festival's founder, Joseph Papp. As Congress pushed the N.E.A. to the edge of oblivion this week, it was the perfect moment to remind audiences of Papp's old dream. Papp died in 1991, and at this time of crisis his pit-bull defense of public culture is conspicuously missed. Like Patrick Stewart, he always made himself heard.
When Papp began campaigning in 1957 for a free theater in Central Park, the goal was simple but revolutionary -- to find a new mass audience for the author he most loved. He likened his scheme to that of the public library: only if tickets, like library books, were free might newcomers to the classics, especially the young, be tempted to check them out.
Shakespeare had once been popular culture in America. As the historian Lawrence W. Levine reminds us, those con men in "Huckleberry Finn," the "duke" and the "king," look upon performing "Richard III" and "Romeo and Juliet" as a get-rich-quick scheme -- such plays were the rock concerts of the 19th century. In our century, though, Shakespeare has become high culture, seen and read mainly by an intellectual and economic elite. Papp rather madly thought he could reverse the tide.
He badgered city officials for financial support, but Robert Moses, the all-powerful Parks Commissioner, argued that audiences should pay instead. Papp wouldn't budge. Not only did he believe that government had a civic duty to disseminate culture, but as a practical matter he knew he needed the imprimatur of city backing to persuade foundations and arts patrons to pitch in. Like today's N.E.A. critics, Mayor Robert Wagner at first declared that culture "is not an operation of government." Then he relented, anticipating the role Washington would play in the arts (Papp's theater included) a few years hence.
This year it costs the New York Shakespeare Festival $1.7 million to put on "The Tempest" and its upcoming "Troilus and Cressida" in the park. Though public funds account for only 26 percent, or $440,000, of that amount -- and the N.E.A. only $50,000 of that -- that figure still exceeds contributions by foundations ($283,000), corporations ($66,000) and individuals ($300,000). And even with all these donors, the summer season will leave a $661,000 debt.
No, not every park production is great, and no, Papp alone could not prevent pop culture from becoming that nightmare of depravity politicians now deride. But the best publicly funded theater, like "The Tempest," towers over most of what passes for serious drama in the commercial marketplace, at $60 a ticket. (Have you seen "Indiscretions"?) And better still, every child attending the New York Shakespeare Festival or the countless others created in its image with N.E.A. support is one less child consuming Rupert Murdoch TV trash and gangsta rap.
Or such is the case this summer. Enjoy Papp's dream, like Prospero's enchanted island, while it lasts.

HEADLINE: Those Few Cents Give Us Clout in the World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
John R. Kasich, House Budget Committee chairman, argues that the Overseas Private Investment Corporation should be eliminated from the Federal budget (Op-Ed, July 9). 
 As Mr. Kasich notes, the money involved is a pittance: $58.2 million of a $1.6 trillion budget. In the budget of a typical middle-class family -- let's say $40,000 a year -- this would be about 15 cents.
We Americans have had a bad habit of trying to avoid involvement in developing nations until a crisis demands we send in troops to restore order. OPIC's purpose -- encouraging investment in developing countries through loan guarantees, insurance against political risks and providing financing for overseas investment -- is the best way to encourage stable economic growth in countries where it is most needed.
Mr. Kasich should address the real problems at the root of excessive government spending, instead of wasting his time and energy on this 15-cent issue.
 
TODD M. MCHENRY
Tokyo, July 12, 1995

HEADLINE: Federal Chill Is Felt By Those in the Arts

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
For some time now, arts groups around the country have been bracing for big cuts in Federal spending on the arts. But few were prepared for Thursday's move by Republicans in the House of Representatives to shut down the national arts and humanities endowments altogether within the next two years.
While the outcome of the House's actions remains unclear -- the proposals must first pass the entire House and then the Senate -- the mere fact that the abolition of the endowments had come to a vote jolted many arts groups into grappling with the unthinkable: life without Federal money. 
 At a three-day Arts and Business Council conference coincidentally being held in Manhattan late this week, dozens of arts representatives, grant givers and business leaders were already convening panels on how to deal with an anticipated financing shortfall. Still the news from Washington drastically changed the atmosphere.
"We're already talking about the post-N.E.A. era and the vote has not even been held yet," lamented Lindy Zesch, deputy director of the Theater Communications Group and a former endowment aide. "I think everyone agrees that the private sector cannot possibly close the gap created by the Contract With America."
In other parts of the country, reaction was also somber. Roche Schufler, the executive director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago and chairman of American Arts Alliance, blamed "people in Congress who are determined to misrepresent the picture of what the agency has accomplished over the past 30 years."
But he added: "This didn't start yesterday and it isn't going to end tomorrow. We are going to keep working and we are going to prevail in the end. We aren't going away. The arts are not going to cease to exist. And people in the arts are not going to stop speaking out."
Others also said they saw events as part of a sequence of developments that have been reconfiguring the culture world, much as economic retrenchments after Wall Street's high-flying years created sober new realities in the corporate world.
"We went through shock, denial and advocacy," said Robert N. Sellar, the northeast community relations manager for the International Business Machines Corporation. Anticipating cutbacks in arts financing, Mr. Sellar convened arts groups for a series of round-table discussions five years ago that helped lead to the business-arts seminar this week. The final stage, he said, was "recognition of reality."
The talks, he said, were therapeutic, reminding hard-pressed arts groups: "You are not alone."
Others were just plain angry. Robert T. Buck, the director of the Brooklyn Museum, pronounced himself surprised by "the the scorpionlike swiftness" of the two-year deadline. "I think this sounds like the result of total madness," he said.
"It sounds like Congress in total zoolike disarray," he said. "Jurassic Congress."
Jane Alexander, the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts, who was in New York yesterday to preside over an awards ceremony at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, declined to comment on the Congressional action.
The arts and humanities endowments, which distribute grants totaling about $300 million a year, were to have at least three to five years more to run under House and Senate measures. The debate in the so-called culture wars is to resume next week.
At the Arts and Business Council conference, which was held at the Smith Barney building in lower Manhattan and ended yesterday, updates on the events in Congress were distributed by Nancy Meier, the executive director of the council, which brings together people in the arts and business and has affiliates in 30 cities.
Many of the arts representatives went to the conference seeking to make contacts with businessmen seeking affiliations with cultural groups. Ms. Meier cautioned some of the hopefuls against expecting quick results.
"Building a sponsorship takes time," she said. "You've got to build a relationship."
She said there was a danger, particularly in the current climate, that arts groups might be tempted to tailor their programs to attract corporate sponsors.
Mr. Sellar, of I.B.M., said corporations were driven by self-interest in sponsoring arts groups. The relationship, he said, has to enhance the corporate image, and companies shy away from controversy: a sobering thought for anti-establishment artists.
Private giving to the arts (fostered by tax deductibility) vastly overshadows the public contributions, a fact that cuts both ways in the debate. Opponents of Government financing argue that the arts are already largely relying on private support, so the Federal endowments are dispensable. Proponents of the status quo counter that private givers are doing a big part, so the Government can do a small part.
According to figures compiled by the Trust for Philanthropy of the American Association of Fund Raising Counsel, however, private giving to the arts -- which accounts for about a third of all income to nonprofit arts groups -- is not making up for government cutbacks.
The figures, distributed at the conference, showed arts giving totaling $9.6 billion last year, a drop of nearly 2 percent from the year before when inflation was factored in. Overall, private giving to all causes stayed marginally ahead of inflation at nearly $130 billion last year.
But while private support is a much larger factor than Federal and state grants in the arts in general and helps sustain leading arts institutions, many small arts groups in particular rely on public grants for survival, which explains in part why the proposed Federal cuts are so bemoaned.
Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, called the House action "not only short-sighted, but it ignores the fact that the arts, unlike almost everything else that's funded by the government, are an economic engine."
"The sad fact is that after all these years we still have to justify support for the arts," Mr. Leventhal said. "It's discouraging to have to make the same arguments over and over."
Martha Wilson, the director of the Franklin Furnace Archive, an avant-garde performance space in Manhattan, said events were moving faster than anyone had predicted.
"The small institutions have seen the writing on the wall for years." she said. "Since 1990 we've been aware that the avant-garde is not popular. The big ones are now seeing that the waves of conservativism are lapping at their steps, too. The climate that was once warm is now cold, and we will have to find other ways to survive."
Jonathan Katz, the chief executive officer of the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies, whose members get block grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, said the value of the Federal dollars was that they provide stability and predictability for arts organizations and artists.
"This is not an issue of government agencies," Mr. Katz said. "It's an issue that affects people who live in cities and suburbs and rural areas. It's about the frequency and quality of the art available to them to participate in."
"The war isn't lost," he added. "The thing that arts organizations do have is the power to get elected officials to an arts event and turn them into arts advocates."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nancy Meier, executive director of the Arts and Business Council, at an arts panel discussion yesterday. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Blacks See Opening in A.F.L.-C.I.O. Leadership Fight

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Black labor leaders, who have protested for years that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has ignored their concerns, now see in the struggle for the presidency of the union federation a rare opportunity to demand a much greater voice for blacks in the nation's labor movement.
The black leaders have drawn up 11 demands, most calling for more blacks in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s hierarchy and the hierarchies of its individual unions. The two candidates vying for president of the federation have promised to bring more "diversity" to the labor movement. But so far neither has explained in any detail how he would do this. 
 "The contest for the presidency that is now taking place is really a debate over how to revive the labor movement," said William Lucy, president of the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists, "and as organized labor redefines itself, our needs must be clarified and addressed."
The coalition presented the 11 demands to John J. Sweeney, one of the candidates, on July 7.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O., in its 40 years, has never had a struggle for the presidency. One aging white male president has passed the mantle to another, and leadership was confined to an executive council composed almost entirely of white men, as it still is. But the decline of union power and the arrival of a Republican-controlled Congress hostile to unions prompted insurgents in the federation to push for the resignation of Lane Kirkland, president since 1979.
Mr. Kirkland plans to retire this summer, and two rivals, both white, have emerged to succeed him: Thomas R. Donahue, who has been Mr. Kirkland's second in command as secretary-treasurer, and Mr. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union.
Black union leaders say they were not consulted in selecting either candidate for the October election.
"Decisions were made that Donahue and Sweeney would be the candidates," said William Burrus, executive vice president of the American Postal Workers Union, "and those decisions were made without including us. Now, after the fact, they are reaching out to hear our views.
"Well, we have demands for internal changes in the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and while we don't speak for women, Asians and Hispanics, collectively we represent a sizable force in organized labor."
While white male membership in American unions has declined to 49.7 percent of the total as of 1994 from 55.8 percent in 1986, the percentage of blacks and white women in unions has risen to 46.6 percent from 41.1 percent over the same period. Blacks alone represent 15.5 percent, up from 14 percent in 1986.
Mr. Burrus is to lead a delegation of black leaders who will meet with Mr. Donahue in the next week or so.
Responding to the coalition's petition, Robert Moore, a vice president of the service employees union, said Mr. Sweeney was "supportive of all the points."
Mr. Donahue said in an interview, "My initial effort is to get the advice of all the minority groups."
So far, the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists has been the most critical of the groups representing minority workers, with some of its leaders even declining invitations to run for the No. 2 spot on the Sweeney or Donahue ticket -- describing such invitations as "tokenism."
The coalition came into existence in 1972 after the A.F.L.-C.I.O. leadership decided not to endorse either President Richard M. Nixon or George McGovern, his Democratic rival, in that year's Presidential election. Black union leaders avidly supported Mr. McGovern, and the coalition became their vehicle for backing him.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. leadership ignored the coalition for years, and only in the mid 1980's began sending representatives regularly to its annual conventions. Instead, the federation has subsidized other organizations representing women and minorities, including blacks. These have not been particularly vocal in the current leadership struggle.
Today the coalition's 20,000 members, all of them members of mainstream unions affiliated with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., turn to the coalition for support in pushing their views in their local union chapters. Since some of these affiliated unions support Mr. Donahue and others Mr. Sweeney, the coalition has decided not to favor either man.
"What we are trying to do is to provide a positive set of policies and directions that both candidates can embrace," said Mr. Lucy, who is also secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
The coalition, in its formal demands, asked that the federation's executive council be altered to include more minorities. Among the other demands were these: More minorities and women should be included in union delegations sent to A.F.L.-C.I.O. conventions; the federation should hire more blacks for staff jobs as department heads, and black leaders should be included "in the drafting of strategies for organizing industries and plants that employ a higher percentage of minorities."
If changes like these had been made earlier, Mr. Lucy said, the debate on issues like the North American Free Trade Agreement would have been different. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. opposed Nafta on the ground that Americans would lose jobs as companies shifted operations to Mexico.
What should have also been stressed in that debate, Mr. Lucy said, was a civil rights issue: The agreement diverts corporate investment away from urban communities where unemployed blacks might have gained employment.
"With a black viewpoint included, the campaign against Nafta might have been a lot deeper and broader," Mr. Lucy said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Black union leaders say the leadership struggle in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. offers blacks the chance to demand more of a voice in the labor movement. William Lucy, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, at the union's Washington offices, is also president of the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists, which is pushing for change in the federation. (Amy Toensing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: International Briefs;
Jaguar to Get State Aid To Build Car in Britain

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Jaguar has decided to build its new model in Britain, with help from a grant of 80 million ($128 million), which was announced yesterday by the Government. The Ford Motor Company, which owns Jaguar, had threatened to build the car in the United States unless it received substantial assistance. The Department of Trade and Industry said the Government was contributing 48 million and the rest was coming from local agencies. 
 Jaguar's X200, which is scheduled to reach the market in 1999, will be smaller than Jaguar's current cars. The Department of Trade and Industry said the X200 would create about 1,300 jobs at Jaguar's plant near Birmingham and at Ford's plant near Liverpool.

WINDOWS 95 SENT TO MANUFACTURING PLANTS

HEADLINE: Decade-Old New York Newsday To Cease Publishing Tomorrow

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
New York Newsday, a suburban newspaper's bold experiment in breaking into the largest and most competitive city market with a new type of tabloid, will publish its last issue tomorrow, its publishers said yesterday.
The paper, which emerged in the economic boom of the mid-1980's, was the victim of corporate pressures for profits and of a newspaper market that changed sharply over the last decade, as the paper struggled to build a readership from a new middle class in the city, particularly Brooklyn and Queens. 
 New York Newsday won critical praise -- and three Pulitzer Prizes -- with an approach to news that tried to mix the entertaining elements of old-style tabloid newspapers with the in-depth news coverage of more serious newspapers. It was called the "tabloid in a tutu," and among journalists the nickname stuck.
But in its 10 years of life, the paper lost an estimated $100 million. In the end, the new chief executive of the paper's corporate owner, the Times Mirror Company, decided that New York Newsday was not economically feasible.
The executive, Mark H. Willes, praised the paper in a statement announcing the closing. "We have been pleased to provide New Yorkers with a strong and vibrant newspaper, and it is a sad event to have to end that role," the statement read.
"But we have concluded," it continued, "that in spite of its superb editorial content, New York Newsday's opportunities to earn an appropriate rate of return are limited."
Newsday executives said that after a 60-day severance period, 700 to 800 of New York and Long Island Newsday's 3,200 employees would lose their jobs. The layoffs, the company said, would be based on seniority.
At the paper yesterday, the mood was one of disbelief. "It's like knowing a plane could crash but thinking it would never be yours," said Steve Gunn, the deputy metropolitan editor. Cornelia Caraballo, a news aide, was rushing to finish her first article when the news hit that there would no longer be a newspaper where she could dream about becoming a reporter. Susan Forrest, a police reporter, called in when her beeper went off. "Baby, it's over," her bureau chief told her.
Readers, journalists and public figures expressed shock yesterday at the suddenness of Times Mirror's move. Many said they were particularly saddened at the loss of yet another journalistic voice in the city.
"This is a very big blow to the city," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, "particularly because this is a city that used to have, when I was young, a dozen newspapers, before that even more. And the diversity of opinion I think was very, very valuable to a city like New York, and each one of the newspapers is made a better newspaper by competition from the others."
According to senior officials at Times Mirror, Mr. Willes, a former executive of General Mills, was hired by a board of directors restive about the company's poor financial performance and was given a clear directive to improve profits. People who have talked to board members said Mr. Willes's primary sponsors on the board were members of the founding family of The Los Angeles Times, the Chandlers.
The Chandler family members, according to Times Mirror executives, have grown increasingly hostile to high operating costs at the company's Eastern newspapers, which include Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant.
Analysts had predicted that Mr. Willes would move abruptly, and yesterday several managers of the company's flagship newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, said privately that that newspaper was preparing to reduce its newsroom staff by 150 people next week by attrition and other voluntary measures. The paper's spokeswoman said she could not confirm or deny that report.
One senior editor at The Los Angeles Times said he had been told that the New York Newsday announcement and The Los Angeles Times cutbacks were among several other moves Mr. Willes planned to list as examples of financial progess to securities analysts next week. Times Mirror stock has long lagged behind that of other media companies, in part because many Wall Street analysts have considered the company's costs too high.
In New York, at separate meetings with stunned staff members at New York Newsday's Park Avenue newsroom and at the Melville, L.I., headquarters of Newsday, the city paper's parent, editors and executives said that beginning on Monday, Newsday would publish a scaled-down Queens edition that would no longer carry the masthead New York Newsday. It is to be called Newsday The Queens Edition.
Newspaper executives and industry analysts said that the closing of New York Newsday would strengthen the city's two remaining tabloids, The New York Post and The Daily News, and could set the scene for a fierce new competition between them. Analysts have said for some time that declining advertising revenue and newspaper readership may leave room for only two New York City newspapers, The Times and one of the tabloids.
The announcement came just a day after Mr. Willes had completed his first visit to the paper, taking a helicopter tour of the metropolitan area and greeting staff members, like New York Newsday's columnist Murray Kempton, nearly jauntily.
Associates of the paper's publisher, Raymond A. Jansen, had said he was struggling to convince Mr. Willes that there was a financial justification for keeping New York Newsday alive, but many staff members said that they simply had not believed the paper would be closed.
As the day wore on yesterday at New York Newsday's offices, and top executives remained closeted in meetings, anxiety took hold of staff members. About 4:30, senior officials at the paper called the staff together in a large space outside a conference room where staff meetings were usually held.
"It was funereal," said one senior journalist, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "You didn't even have to wait for them to speak. You knew. The word was on their faces."
Mr. Jansen looked at the assembled staff. "I can tell from the silence you know what's coming," he said, according to one of the paper's staff writers, Jonathan Mandell. "It's not good."
Mr. Mandell began taking notes. Curtis Rist, an editor, laughed.
"You're a reporter," Mr. Mandell remembers Mr. Rist saying.
"Not anymore," Mr. Mandell responded.
The executives who called the meeting were: Donald Forst, New York Newsday's editor; Anthony Marro, the editor of both Newsdays; Mr. Jansen, the publisher of both ; Steven I. Isenberg, the publisher of New York Newsday, and Richard Galant, New York Newsday's managing editor. Mr. Willes was not there.
"This was a gutsy newspaper," Mr. Forst said later. "You came in and tried to elbow and knee your way, literally, onto newsstands. We gave it a hell of a shot. We came up short. But going from zip to 231,000, folks, is a hell of a play."
New York Newsday, which battled for circulation with only limited success, had said it was selling 231,000 copies a day last month, which represented the first significant gain after a sharp slide began in 1993. At that time, the paper's average daily circulation was 275,000.
At times yesterday, some Newsday staff members both in New York and in Melville seemed desperate. Jim Dwyer, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his column in New York Newsday, asked Mr. Jansen to discuss a plan Mr. Dwyer said he had worked on to launch an employee buyout of the paper. Mr. Jansen said nothing would change the outcome.
In Melville, the newspaper's executive vice president for operations, Alberto Ibarguen, told anxious staff members that two companies had made offers to buy all of Newsday and that they had been rejected. "Newsday is not for sale," he said. Several people who talked with New York Newsday's editor, Mr. Forst, an irascible newsroom veteran of 40 years, said they were sure they saw tears in his eyes yesterday. And they said they understood.
Mr. Forst and his longtime corporate patron, David Laventhol, an influential newspaperman for decades who is now Times Mirror's editor at large, were more closely identified with New York Newsday than anyone else.
As publisher of the powerful Long Island Newsday more than a decade ago, Mr. Laventhol pioneered what was widely seen as a creative publishing strategy. At the time, both The New York Post and The Daily News appeared doomed, and Mr. Laventhol pressed the idea that Newsday could create a new type of newspaper by coming into the city through its stronghold in Queens and building a responsible tabloid.
Newsday executives called it a "creeping acquisition" and said they would build a newspaper through annual investments and gradual growth. But in time, when The News and The Post regained their footing, some analysts said it was only a matter of time before New York Newsday would be forced to conclude that the strategy, which might have worked, had been beaten by circumstance.

 BODY:
A leading bond-rating agency flashed approval of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's recently passed $16 billion budget yesterday. SECTION: Section 6; Page 12; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1122 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
How 'Shrunk' Snuck In

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
TRIVIALIZE HAD ITS MOMENT in the vogue-verb sun," I wrote, "until the usage of this older verb shrunk to the very occasional."
Louis Jay Herman, noted Gotcha! Gangster, objected: "Permit me to join the Uofallpeople Club, to upbraid you for shrunk. All usage manuals consider shrank the preferred or exclusive past tense of shrink, shrunk being the past participle." Kerry Wood of Palo Alto, Calif., adds, "I never thunk you'd have done such a thing." 
 For the irregular verbs shrink and sink, the simple past tense is "He shrank the material and sank the boat." The past participle is the form of the verb used in the present perfect tense, which shows action completed at the time of speaking: "He has shrunk and has sunk." Thus, the natural progression is shrink-shrank-shrunk, sink-sank-sunk.
At an embarrassing moment for the prosecution in the O. J. Simpson trial, Christopher Darden gulped, "The gloves appear to have shrank somewhat." Incorrect; the past participle is shrunk or shrunken.
Shrink-shrank-shrunk is orderly enough; why, then, did Iofallpeople sink into using shrunk as the past tense? Because Walt Disney got to me, I guess: the 1989 movie "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" did to shrank what Winston cigarettes did to as: pushed usage in the direction of what people were casually saying rather than what they were carefully writing. Mr. Herman dutifully objected to one and all about that Disney title (adding a note of praise for the well-placed comma).
In the past-tense dodge, usage is all. The learner of English, having mastered sink-sank-sunk and begin-began-begun and drink-drank-drunk, would assume fling-flang-flung and swing-swang-swung. But there ain't no such animal as swang or flang, except in some far-out dialect; in those and other cases, the past tense hops over the expected word to the past participle.
"Shrunk is much less common as a past tense than shrank," notes Fred Mish of Merriam-Webster, "but sunk has somewhat greater frequency of occurrence in relation to sank. These occurrences can be unsettling at times. A local sportswriter here likes to say of high-school athletes that they 'shined in the contest' instead of 'shone.' "
In the face of the language's weakness of grammatical discipline, what's a poor usagist to do? Be a stiff. Make the new form work for its acceptance. Stick with shrank in the simple past, at least until the movie and its offspring -- like the Heritage Foundation's "Honey, I Shrunk the Tax Base!" -- fade from memory, even if it snuck up on us and makes us feel like something the cat dragged (not drug) in.
Snuck up? "How did snuck ever sneak in?" asks Doris Asmundsson, professor emerita of English at Queensborough Community College in New York. (So that's the feminine of emeritus.) "Words like creak, critique, eke, freak, leak and tweak do not, in the past tense, become cruck, crituck, uck, fruck, luck and twuck. Why then snuck? Eventually a sneaker might turn into a snucker."
Evidently Charles M. Schulz, the cartoonist of "Peanuts," agrees; Rerun says to Charlie Brown, "If you sneaked up behind him, you could hit him with a stick." This is formal English.
On the ABC sitcom "Step by Step," however, a teen-ager tells her parents, "I know I shouldn't have snuck out."
Here's a perfect example of a usage that has crept (informally creeped) up on us. "He grubbed ten dollars from de bums and den snuck home" is the first print use cited in the CD-ROM O.E.D., in an 1887 edition of The New Orleans Lantern. The novelist James T. Farrell used it as the past participle in the first part of his Studs Lonigan trilogy, the 1932 "Young Lonigan": "They had all snuck in and were having a good time, making trouble." Raymond Chandler, the great mystery writer, used it in the simple past tense in his 1940 "Farewell, My Lovely": "I snuck in there and grabbed it."
The Random House Webster's notes this in accepting the term as a standard variant: "Snuck occurs frequently in fiction, in journalism and on radio and television, whereas sneaked is more likely in highly formal or belletristic writing."
John Algeo of American Speech goes further: "Snuck is now educated, standard use; sneaked is rare." He notes that sneak has mysterious origins; it first appears in Shakespeare's "Henry IV, Part 1": "A poor unminded outlaw sneaking home." Professor Algeo notes that the Old English verb snican meant "to crawl," but that word would have become snike, not sneak, in Modern English; curiously, the past tense of snican would have become snuck.
Thus, we should hold off a few years before caving in to shrunk as a simple past tense; I'm sorry, it snuck up on me.
 
Exclamatives
I'm a pop grammarian and word maven who makes no pretense of living in syntax. Every now and then one of my innocent pitches gets slammed out of the park by a heavy hitter in the field of linguistics. In this year's Bloopie Awards, I noted the trend among advertising copywriters against using question marks at the end of interrogative sentences. One was "Isn't It Great to Be in Luvs," which seemed to me to call for a little squiggle with a dot under it at the end.
Wrong, I'm told. "That slogan is clearly an exclamative sentence and not an interrogative," writes Prof. James D. McCawley of the University of Chicago's linguistics department, author of the seminal "Syntactic Phenomena of English."
"While two of the major exclamative patterns in English evolved through the adaptation of interrogative structures to exclamative uses," Jim notes, losing me before he even gets to his sentence's subject, "they now diverge from interrogatives both phonologically (the word with the primary stress, here, great, is pronounced with a fall in pitch, not the rise that an interrogative would normally have) and syntactically (the inverted exclamative, as in the Luvs example, allows a use of ever that doesn't mean what ever in an interrogative means: Was I ever hungry! vs. Have you ever been arrested?). . . . If the Luvs copywriter had used the question mark that you demand, he/she would have thereby pinned an unwarranted and misleading badge of interrogativity on the sentence."
I disagree; the Luvs ad asked for a response, if only "Yes!" But criticism from geniuses who could give short festschrift to Noam Chomsky doesn't faze me; I am a synstrategist, not a syntactician.
McCawley's insights are also accessible to the layman, however; after an observation about metaphoric inflation in a piece I wrote about "$40 words," he conjectures, "The obsolescence of the expression 'Dollars to doughnuts' is partly due to the narrowing of the gap between $1 and the current price of a doughnut: it no longer is a bet with long odds."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 14; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1088 words

HEADLINE: The Capitalist;
Fidelities

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
JEFF VINIK WAS SOMEWHERE between the women's shoes and the men's accessories at the Salvatore Ferragamo boutique on Fifth Avenue when he mentioned Silicon Graphics. He appeared to be trapped in a pincer of several hundred investors, who had come at the behest of Worth Magazine to celebrate his success, when he mentioned, by the by, to a couple of men sipping Champagne that he expected the share price of Silicon Graphics to double. I believe only a few people heard him, though just about everyone would have liked to. The economist John Maynard Keynes once described the art of investing as "anticipating what average opinion expects average opinion to be." Vinik represents average opinion. He runs the Magellan Fund, the huge mutual fund that controls $45 billion of Fidelity Investments' $200 billion portfolio.
The crowd of hundreds trailed closely behind the human bellwether as he left the clothing store and traveled down to the University Club, where he was scheduled to deliver a lecture. On the way I thought he might drop a further nugget, but when I asked him (discreetly, of course) about the stocks in his portfolio, the only name that he mentioned was Silicon Graphics. Then he strolled to the podium and explained to a standing-room-only audience that America is in a "boom-boom era, . . . in only the third or fourth inning of the current bull market." His best guess was that the stock market would rise for another 7 to 10 years. 
 It's a wonderful thought. The Dow Jones Industrial Average essentially remained flat between 1962 and 1982. Since 1982 it has risen 450 percent. Already we have lived through the greatest bull market in our nation's history. But according to Vinik it's just the start.
The most recent official explanation for the miracle boom is that the economy is weak, and interest rates are falling. This sounds plausible, except that a couple of years back the official story was that the market was rising because the economy was strong. In any case, I don't buy the official explanation. I believe that the stock market is rising because mutual fund managers like Vinik cannot afford to stop buying stocks. At the start of the bull market, mutual funds that invest primarily in stocks held less than $75 billion in assets; they now hold $1 trillion. And every day Americans are handing fund managers more money to invest. This, in turn, drives up the share price of stocks and lifts the market, thereby encouraging more people to invest more money in mutual funds, and so on.
If that seems flaky, consider these numbers. In 1992, according to Paul Goldman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, 96 percent of all new money entering the stock market came from mutual funds. (That year Fidelity accounted for 10 percent of all market transactions.) In 1993 mutual funds pumped into the market so much new money that without them the stock market would have experienced net outflows of capital. The statistics for the past 18 months are not yet available but I am pretty sure that the trend has continued. Just look around. The smart money (the hedge fund types) largely missed out on the great surge of early '95. The dumb money (the people who read Smart Money) did not. Their success has spawned a culture of personal investment in which several hundred people find nothing strange about packing into a small clothing store just to be near a fund guru. If it continues for another decade, as the guru predicted, they'll fill Neiman Marcus.
THE MORNING AFTER VINIK SPOKE I bought my first 500 shares of Silicon Graphics. I did not study its balance sheet, lunch with its C.E.O. or interview its customers and suppliers. I did not bother with any of the chores that an old-fashioned stock market investor would complete before casting his lot with a company. I still have no idea where Silicon Graphics is or what it does -- for all I know they publish dirty pictures of women with breast implants. In other words, my strategy is similar to that of the two million American households with shares in Vinik's Magellan Fund, except that I circumnavigated Magellan's fees. Of course my portfolio is not quite so diverse as Magellan's, but then I own what Vinik likes best. And of course I won't know when Vinik changes his mind about Silicon Graphics, but then I'm not sure that matters very much. The main point is that investors in Magellan, like me, own Silicon Graphics not because they understand the company and believe it will prosper but because they believe in Jeff Vinik, and Jeff Vinik believes in Silicon Graphics.
I, too, believe in Jeff Vinik, but more important, I believe the beliefs of all parties will persist for some time. If enough people give their money to Vinik, and Vinik injects enough of that money into Silicon Graphics, the share price of Silicon Graphics will soar. When this happens even more people will give Jeff Vinik their money to invest in Silicon Graphics, and another round of capital gains will accrue in my portfolio.
Of course there is always the danger that some event -- a trade war, a dollar crisis -- will put Vinik's followers on edge. No one can say what they might do if word gets around that the jig is up. Will they become disillusioned in proportion to their original illusion? Will they try as a group to get their money back? If so, one can imagine a run on mutual funds analogous to the run on the banks in the 1930's. The mere rumor of mutual fund investors fleeing the market would no doubt lead them to flee faster -- and everyone else to flee with them.
That is the fear, but also the beauty, of following Jeff Vinik into the stock market: because he can't be seen to be bearish he'll continue to be bullish, and Fidelity will continue to scour the land for new money to invest. Will Fidelity decide one day that the stock market is overpriced? Of course not. The sight of Fidelity's billions, or even Vinik's lesser billions, in panicked flight would incite riots on the stock exchange. Will Vinik sell off his $20 billion worth of small technology stocks, including Silicon Graphics? Of course not. Who would buy them, if he does not? But as long as he buys, everyone will.
And so I'm feeling pretty good these days. Within a week of my purchase of Silicon Graphics, the stock had risen nearly 10 percent, and my broker had called to congratulate me. He'd grown used to watching me lose money in the stock market. I think he suspected I'd finally resorted to inside information. In a sense, I had.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Surviving a Fame That Insists on Surviving

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
DANNY BONADUCE LIKES being recognized. By the waitress at the Four Seasons. By the man who parks his car. By random people on the street.
It is not your usual celebrity vanity, however. It is more like the twisted pleasure of the damned. 
 Twenty-five years ago, Mr. Bonaduce became Danny Partridge and so attained a fame as deathless as an old tire. It has already far outlasted his earnings from "The Partridge Family," which he smoked and snorted his way through by the time he was 18. It has endured two drug busts, an arrest for punching out a transvestite in Arizona and several gigs as a waiter. It has persisted through Mr. Bonaduce's success as a deejay on WLUP ("the Loop") in Chicago. And it will almost certainly live on after the next stage in his career: his return to television as the host of a talk show, "Danny!"
The show, which is syndicated by Buena Vista Television, a Walt Disney subsidiary, will make its debut in September. In New York, it will appear on WWOR, Channel 9.
Mr. Bonaduce, who is 35, is nothing if not philosophical about his fame. During the 1980's, he made regular appearances on the talk show circuit with other washed-up child stars: Dana Plato (Kimberly of "Diff'rent Strokes"), Butch Patrick (Eddie of "The Munsters"), Lauren Chapin (Kitten of "Father Knows Best"). While the others routinely blamed their early success for their later failures, Mr. Bonaduce (pronounced bon-ah-DU-chee) used his air time to muse on the vagaries of fortune. "Shut up!" he remembers saying to his fellow guests. "You had a great free ride. Everybody works for a living. Why don't you go bus tables?"
Now that Mr. Bonaduce is about to have his own talk show he promises to avoid the kind of humiliating spectacle in which the point is to make the guests look and feel like idiots. "I've been the object of ridicule for a long time," he says. "You know how many people called me a jerk and said, 'You had the American dream, and you threw it away?' All true things but still pretty mean to say on television."
Mr. Bonaduce is discussing his future show and his checkered past at a corner table in the cafe of the Four Seasons Hotel here. He has just finished his daily radio program, which runs from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., and he is wearing jeans, a white long-sleeved T-shirt and very blue cowboy boots. He is joined by his wife, Gretchen, who has driven in from their home in the suburbs with their 4-month-old daughter, Isabella. Isabella's actually her middle name. Her first name is Countess.
"That's just for her credit card," Mr. Bonaduce explains.
Two decades after "The Partridge Family" was canceled, Mr. Bonaduce still has the freckles and flaming red hair of his youth, and his scratchy voice, made that much more gravelly by years of heavy smoking, is still eerily familiar. Talking to him, one can't help but think that he is very much like what Danny Partridge, the schemer of the family, would have become, had he done a lot of drugs, lived below the poverty line for a while and had a few of his teeth knocked out.
Mr. Bonaduce grew up in Los Angeles, where his father was a sitcom writer, and had made his first television commercial by the time he was 4. He was cast as Danny Partridge when he was 10 and was out of a job by 15. At that point, he took his accumulated earnings -- $72,000, a sizable amount in those days -- and moved out on his own. Three years later, he was broke.
The next few years, he got by on unemployment and an occasional guest appearance on the police drama "CHiPs." Fortunately, he could count on work around Christmas, when a television station or a new Kmart would pay him to sit in some greenery playing a Partridge in a pear tree. "I'd be poverty-stricken and then, a week or two a year, I'd be in jets and limousines with all sorts of money in my pocket, out of my mind on drugs, in a tree in some strange city," he said. "You must admit that that is hysterical."
A break, of sorts, came in 1985, when The National Enquirer described him as near starvation. As a joke a deejay in Chicago began a food drive for him. The joke took off, and soon other deejays were doing the same stunt. Radio stations would fly him in for guest appearances; everywhere he went, he would ask for work.
Being a deejay "seemed like the job for me," he said. "It seemed like anybody could do it." Finally, in 1988, a station in Philadelphia hired him, no doubt mostly for the publicity. "They said, 'Listen, we're going to give you a six-month contract, then we're going to let you go,' " he recalled. "It was a top-40 dance station. I'd say, 'And here is Paula Abdul,' and that was my entire job." When the six months was up, it turned out that he was tremendously popular, so the station renewed his contract, for a lot more money.
From Philadelphia, Mr. Bonaduce went to Phoenix. It was there that he got into the tangle with the transvestite, which made news across the country. It was also there that he met and married his wife, all in the same night.
The two crossed paths when Mrs. Bonaduce booked a psychic on Mr. Bonaduce's radio show. After their first date, they went to Mr. Bonaduce's apartment. "Just to be frank with you, I thought sex was in the bag," Mr. Bonaduce said. "So I put the moves on, and she goes -- I couldn't believe this -- she goes, 'I'm sorry, I was raised a Christian, and I won't do that until I'm married.' At first I thought she was kidding. And then I think about it and I go 'O.K.,' and I get the yellow pages out, and I find a minister who is under 'marriage.' "
Mr. Bonaduce credits his wife with turning his life around. At the point they met, he had just finished a drug-rehabilitation program but was, in his words, heading "screaming toward alcoholism." Often, Mrs. Bonaduce simply refused to let him leave the house. "I was almost like some kind of savage until I met Gretchen, not to put down savages," Mr. Bonaduce said, and his wife, who is dandling their baby, did not contradict him.
After he finally sobered up, Mr. Bonaduce found himself in demand as a radio personality, and decided to do a talk show on WLUP. "The Danny Bonaduce Show" is five hours of interviews, running gags and goofy contests. Occasionally, Mr. Bonaduce plays a song so he can retreat to his office and smoke a cigarette.
The idea for "Danny!," the television show, originated with Jon Denny, a film writer and producer who became friendly with Mr. Bonaduce while working on an as-yet-unproduced television movie about his life. For the pilot, Mr. Bonaduce served as host of a segment on short men and tall women who won't date them and competed in a diapering contest against his fellow one-time child star Donny Osmond.
For all his recent success, Mr. Bonaduce does not nurse any illusions about the great acting career that could have been his. When he watched himself playing himself last year on "Married . . . With Children," he said, he was struck by what a stiff he was. "Everybody says, 'You got stereotyped, blah, blah, blah, you couldn't find work,' " he recalled. "Apparently there's a new theory: I have no talent."
Success has, nonetheless, put some order back into his life, taking some of the strangeness out of his perdurable fame. "Now that I'm doing O.K. again and I'm in show biz for a living, it's neat again," he said. "Being poor and famous was really weird. I mean, I used to sign autographs and not know if I was going to eat that day. That was odd."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1892 words

HEADLINE: They're Rebels Without a Cause, and Couldn't Care Less

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
SHOPLIFTING, TURNSTILE-JUMPING, potsmoking, pill-taking. Trespassing, assault, rape, possibly murder. Name a crime or misdemeanor, and if it doesn't involve guns, cars or syringes, teen-agers probably commit it during the day and night that are shown in Larry Clark's film "Kids," which opens on Friday.
They're not career criminals or hard-core gang members, just teen-agers hanging around in New York City, out to have some fun. When they're not breaking laws, they're having extremely unsafe sex. What makes Mr. Clark's film so controversial is that for its teen-aged characters, nothing they do registers as a transgression or an outrage. For them, it's just another day. 
 "Kids" is, for now, the most extreme of a long line of films in which teen-agers are amoral, irrational, hormone-crazed and oblivious to consequences. It's hardly the first movie about teen-agers to include drinking, drug use, sex or brutality; those have gone with the territory in movies from "West Side Story" of the 1960's to "American Graffiti" of the 1970's and beyond. Yet Mr. Clark's film is jolting -- not just because it takes place in the era of AIDS but because of its unflinching documentary style and its absence of adult authority or an adult point of view. The camera doesn't provide order or stability; it just seems to be tagging along.
"Kids" also drops the comforting conventions of most teen-trouble movies. Its main character is a skateboarding Don Juan, who lives to seduce virgins. He is not the typical character who's wavering but ultimately good-hearted and who eventually tries to do what's right. The film doesn't suggest that if only a few bad apples are controlled, the rest of the teen-agers will straighten out. Nor does it present its anti-social teen-agers as members of an organized gang that is leading them astray. In "Kids," trouble with teen-agers is no longer treated as a problem to be recognized and solved but as something chronic and inevitable.
The film has already begun to raise hackles. When it was shown at the Cannes International Film Festival in May, the Hollywood Reporter said one scene "summarizes the low-level mentality and high-level risks that characterize many kids in this dysfunctional age." Even the positive reviews expressed reservations. "Kids," said Film Comment, presents a "heartbreaking, unbearable and disturbingly erotic vision of predatory boys and naive girls." The piece went on to say that Mr. Clark's "unflinching depiction of the abandon of underage sex and drugs may make the film unreleasable."
Earlier this month, the Motion Picture Association of America gave "Kids" an NC-17 rating for "explicit sex, language, drug use and violence" all involving children. The film is being released by Excalibur Films, a new distributor set up because Miramax, which holds the international rights to "Kids," is owned by Disney and could not domestically distribute a film this raw. Though Excalibur appealed the rating last week, it has the option of releasing the film without a rating; even so, "Kids" will probably not show up in suburban malls.
On seeing the film, some moral guardians will no doubt insist that this is what happens when a pop culture of loveless sex and mindless violence takes over impressionable young minds. Less polemical viewers may end up musing about the comparative innocence of their own teen-age years; why didn't we have so much excitement at that age? They may also be left wondering whether the younger generation can survive, and whether, in fact, it's worth saving.
TEEN-AGERS, AS A DIStinct group, have provoked particular fear and bewilderment since the 1950's, when they were first recognized as a separate culture and (almost simultaneously) as a potential market for everything from hit singles to acne medication. Even before the baby boom swelled the teen-age population, post-war prosperity was keeping them in school longer, providing more leisure time and allowing more mobility -- all, as some adults saw it, encouraging children in mindless pleasure-seeking and dangerous rowdiness.
As the teen-age population swelled, worries mounted. Adolescence became an extended identity crisis, a time to test new roles and abilities; it also became a prolonged and confusing rite of passage. From an adolescent viewpoint, adults seemed intent on enforcing arbitrary rules, thwarting teen-agers' attempts at defining themselves or even enjoying themselves.
Teen-agers have taken as a badge of pride the adult notion that they are creatures of boundless appetites and nonexistent discipline; welcome to "Wayne's World." In most films the troublemakers usually look as if they're having a good time and are a lot more vivid than the goody-goody types.
Efforts to understand teen-agers and gut reactions of alarm have gone side by side for decades. Adolescents are "screaming wild animals," as one character describes them in the 1955 film "Blackboard Jungle." A gruff, disciplinarian cop explains why: They had "no home life, no church life, no place to go." "Gang leaders," the cop adds, "have taken the place of parents."
That message would be repeated down through the decades, as two-career families bred latchkey children, suburbanization brought less sense of community and more boredom, the age of puberty dropped, and youth unemployment made crime a tempting career option. While sociology could offer some explanations -- all neatly satirized by "Gee Officer Krupke" in "West Side Story" -- it couldn't reverse larger social and economic shifts.
Juvenile delinquency, the scourge of the 50's, was also blamed on the corrupting effects of the media, particularly rock-and-roll and horror comics, which were both investigated by Congressional committees. (Hearings on the payola scandal ruined the careers of the disk jockey Alan Freed and others; comic books were sanitized, though in the 1960's underground comix brought back sex and violence.)
Yet rock, comics and B movies, even when they have been crass and shoddy, address continuing teen-age concerns. Ordinary teen-age lives include a lot of frustration, uncertainty, aimlessness and floundering. The adolescent sense of time, trapped in an all-encompassing present, makes it difficult for teen-agers to weigh the effects of impulsive acts. As they grow up, teen-agers begin to reckon with adult concerns of sexuality and mortality; they also ricochet between new physical powers and continuing political powerlessness. Parents, teachers, the police: adult authority bears down on teen-agers, constantly assuring them it's for their own good.
In response, the pop media provide teen-agers with fantasies about an authority-free world. Pop songs about love and sex offer a full spectrum, from happy-ever-after romance to single-minded lust. Beach and party movies, from "Gidget" to "House Party," present teen-agers at play, with no significant obligations; television sitcoms often show teen-agers who are smarter and savvier than their parents. In hard-rock songs, rap boasts and superhero comics, powerless teen-agers can imagine themselves as invincible protagonists: riding down wide-open highways, shouting back at people who'd push them around, facing danger or (particularly in speed-metal) paradoxically identifying with the malevolent forces that are out to get them.
Horror movies, often aimed at teen-agers, take up adolescents' new-found recognition of death and their combined fear and fascination about the body as it matures. At puberty, every teen-ager may feel a little like a werewolf, with hair sprouting in new places and unfamiliar compulsions taking over. There's shame to go with the new thrills; in many horror films, the teen-agers who are most sexually active are the first victims. The symbolism is fairly obvious in "A Nightmare on Elm Street": a girl burns herself on a hot pipe, a boy is swallowed by a gaping hole that gushes blood.
But that's kid stuff; teen-trouble movies are usually pitched to adults. In movies made for adults, teen-agers are as much symbols as characters. They stand for missed chances, for all the kicks that could be had before adult obligations arrived. When teen-agers take over the country in "Wild in the Streets," indulgence reigns while adults are packed off for euthanasia.
Movie teen-agers also remind adults of all the dangers facing the unwary, from pregnancy to AIDS, from drug habits to all sorts of bad judgment. But most of all, they stand for adult guilt. Parents have spoiled their children or abandoned them, given them too much leeway or too much pressure, failed to be perfect. Generations of adolescents have recognized themselves in James Dean's tortured rebel without a cause, a good kid whose caring parents just can't cure his malaise.
Yet gradually, the concerned parent has receded from the picture. In "Over the Edge," an earnest 1980 movie about teen-agers who riot out of boredom in their planned suburban community, the father of the inevitable wavering adolescent asks, at a desperate town meeting: "Has anyone ever sat down and talked to these kids? What are they, all rotten? And we're so good?" His self-righteousness is rebuked; like the rest of the parents in town, he has never shown up for parents' week at the local high school.
By 1987, in "River's Edge," the nuclear family has just about collapsed. Mom has a demanding full-time job, her boyfriend evades anything to do with the children, and her son borrows a joint from her when he runs low on pot. In "Kids," there's only one appearance by a character's mother, just long enough for him to steal some cash. Not only can't parents discipline their children, but they can't even make contact.
AS TEEN-AGERS MOVE FURther away from adult influence, they're increasingly portrayed as a separate species, more energetic and savage than their elders. Movie teen-agers live in a world of peer-inflicted violence, from ritualized hazing to fist fights, knife fights, gun fights. Alex, the criminal in "A Clockwork Orange," is described as "enterprising, aggressive, outgoing, young, bold, vicious," and while he's a full-fledged maniac, he's hardly the only teen-aged character to fit the description.
Nice schoolboys revert to barbarism in "Lord of the Flies"; ghetto teen-agers answer verbal insults with bullets in "Menace II Society" (though its main character is a classic wavering adolescent). Unlike adult characters, they don't need much of a motive; since they're teen-agers, clearly they don't know what they're doing.
And increasingly, they don't care -- at least in the movies. Old-fashioned tormented teen-agers, the ones who were desperate for meaning and direction, are giving way to the dead-eyed kids who don't bother to report a murder in "River's Edge." Numbed by drugs and mass culture, restless but affectless, they don't feel much beyond immediate physical lusts.
The teen-agers in "Kids" are not screaming wild animals anymore, but dull, mindless ones, untouched by idealism or fear. Instead of being portrayed as alienated, they are simply aliens.
As such, they are out of reach; there's no hope for them. They are an inhuman Other, fit to join illegal immigrants, welfare mothers and other currently demonized groups. They rule their own jungle now, and there's nothing an adult can do.

LENGTH: 967 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
The Rib Tickler's Approach to Social Provocation

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
MORE THAN RATINGS ARE at stake for Michael Moore this summer as his sometimes loopy, sometimes acidly satiric news-magazine program, "TV Nation," returns to prime time. His whole world view is on the line.
Mr. Moore, the iconoclastic film maker who is destined to have his name followed forever by the phrase "producer and director of the award-winning documentary 'Roger and Me,' " says his career is propelled by the conviction that Americans are smarter and more politically sophisticated than the television industry thinks. 
 "The proof is in the Nielsen ratings," he says. "The top 10 shows are the smartest, the most risk-taking shows, shows like 'Seinfeld,' 'E.R.,' 'N.Y.P.D. Blue.' Look, '60 Minutes,' a news show, is always in the top 10. And 'Roseanne,' whatever else you may feel about it, deals with serious social issues and controversies."
Social issues, smart-aleck interviews and general rabble-rousing are what Mr. Moore plans to offer in eight new episodes of "TV Nation." The show, which he has moved to Fox from NBC, where it ran last summer, will be seen on Fridays at 8 P.M., starting this week.
"I really think this country is ready for a good dose of political humor right now," Mr. Moore said recently over lunch at a cafe near his midtown Manhattan office.
This summer, "TV Nation" will mock everyone from Presidential candidates to "whining white men"; everything from companies that don't provide enough toilets for female employees (in a memorable segment featuring portable Johns of Justice delivered by truck) to fancy-dress brigades that re-enact Civil War battles. What Mr. Moore calls his "merry band of troublemakers" will include Janeane Garofalo, late of "Saturday Night Live" and "The Larry Sanders Show"; the comedian Steven Wright, and an investigative reporter called Crackers the Corporate Crime Chicken.
"TV Nation," which is produced by Kathleen Glynn, Mr. Moore's wife, often recycles the pester-the-powers-that-be method that brought Mr. Moore success in "Roger and Me," his 1989 film about the effect of the closing of a General Motors factory in Flint., Mich., his hometown. In a new segment called "Payback," for example, Mr. Moore goes to the home of the chief executive of a car-alarm company, lines up 10 cars and sets off the alarms at 6 A.M., to see what the executive will do (he calls the police, who make Mr. Moore move the cars).
"But my idea with the car alarms and that sort of stuff is to draw people in," he explained. "Once they're in, we'll talk about real issues."
In another new segment, Ms. Garofalo takes a multiethnic group of 24 New Yorkers by bus to the town beach in Greenwich, Conn. (Only Greenwich residents are allowed.) Turned away, they rent a boat; stopped by police boats, they swim ashore. "It's a public beach," Mr. Moore said, eyes flashing behind his glasses. "You can't say only residents of Brooklyn can go to Coney Island. This is America! You can't say only people in Venice can use Venice Beach. This is America!"
Since "Roger and Me," Mr. Moore has mellowed in age, to 40, and in appearance, with a few extra pounds on his 6-foot-3-inch frame. With a Detroit Tiger baseball cap almost always perched on his mop of brown hair, he looks just like what, on one level, he is: a white, middle-class, middle-aged husband and father (he and Ms. Glynn have a 14-year-old daughter) from a blue-collar family, with no college degree and a fondness for sports. But underneath the aw-shucks demeanor beats what one critic called "a genetically subversive heart."
Mr. Moore's subversiveness takes the form of thumbing the nose at the bosses, and he was to that manner born. "My uncle was in the sit-down strike in Flint that founded the U.A.W.," he says, referring to the United Auto Workers' 1937 strike. "I think that generation, if they could see what goes on now, would be very disappointed."
He is certainly disappointed in his generation, which took part in civil rights and Vietnam War protests but faded into armchair liberalism. "To the disenfranchised, angry, alienated, unemployed worker in Michigan, what are the Democrats, the liberals, offering?" Mr. Moore asked. "Newt Gingrich, and people like the Michigan militia, they have something to offer. It's the wrong thing, but it's something people can grab on to."
He believes that his social contribution is to goad people into taking part in a search for solutions. "If we are active and involved, we'll find our way, but if we detach, we're going to be in a lot of trouble," Mr. Moore said. "So I want this show to get people riled up, to get them juiced, to motivate people to get involved, and not just sit around. If they can see a guy like me, without a college education, from Flint, Mich., walk into the headquarters of some big corporation, or into the halls of Congress, and challenge some people, maybe people will say, 'Hey, maybe I can do something like that.' "
NOT MANY PEOPLE, HOW ever, would send Crackers the Corporate Crime Chicken to ask New York Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani serious questions about tax breaks and unemployment. And some television critics have complained that such sophomoric stunts undermine whatever serious purpose Mr. Moore has in mind. He disagrees.
"Humor can be more devastating than some formal white paper," he said. "There's no reason you can't be entertained and think at the same time. You can laugh, and you can think. That's my point about the top 10 shows in the Nielsen ratings: you have to do both. And people will do that. I don't have that attitude, that looking down on the American people like they're all a bunch of dopes."
He paused, and the gleam was back in his eyes. "That's not to say there aren't a good 50 or 60,000 dopes," he said, yukking gently, "because there are."
