LENGTH: 1163 words

HEADLINE: Crusader for New York City Landmarks Moves On

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
ANYONE who has ever felt blessed walking through the Beaux-Arts grandeur of cavernous Grand Central Terminal -- or has felt frustrated grappling with the regulations designed to protect New York City's landmarks -- owes something to Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society.
Over two decades Mr. Barwick has become one of the leading crusaders for preserving the city's notable buildings. His work in the 70's in preventing the construction of an office tower on top of Grand Central Terminal not only preserved what is part of the city's heart, but also led to a United States Supreme Court ruling that established the right of local governments to preserve architecturally distinctive sites and structures. 
 "Certainly in terms of national implications, it was a significant accomplishment," Mr. Barwick said. "Not just because of the building -- but because preserving a building because of its architectural merit was something, like zoning earlier in the century, that some Americans, many people in the real estate business, probably thought was unconstitutional as well as undesirable."
Mr. Barwick, who is 54, announced earlier this month that he would resign as president of the Municipal Art Society effective in mid-September to become president of the New York State Historical Association in Cooperstown. He has been head of the nonprofit Municipal Art Society since 1983 and served as its executive director from 1970 to 1975. A search committee has been appointed to find a successor.
The organization, which was formed in 1893 to adorn the public buildings and parks of New York with murals, fountains and monuments, has evolved over the century into a leading citizen-activist group, battling developers to preserve parts of New York's past.
Besides Grand Central Terminal, among other accomplishments (or obstructions) for which Mr. Barwick can take at least partial credit are campaigns that blocked construction of a huge building at Columbus Circle and saving the community house and garden at St. Bartholomew's Church.
He also played a role in the creation of the Adopt-a-Monument and Adopt-a-Mural programs, which raised more than $1 million to restore some 40 monuments and murals around the city.
"He has been hugely important, especially after he came back to the M.A.S.," said Gregory F. Gilmartin, a designer with Peter Pennoyer Architects in New York and the author of "Shaping the City: New York and the Municipal Art Society" (Crown Publishing Group, 1995). "He brought a seriousness and a certain access that the M.A.S. hadn't had in a long time."
Mr. Gilmartin cited the society's role in setting up the zoning guidelines for the renovation of Times Square that retained its garish glitter.
"Without the M. A. S., Times Square might well have turned out to be another Sixth Avenue," he said, an area filled with sterile modernist office buildings. "In the 80's, people tended to dismiss all the lights and billboards as just cosmetics. They had no sense of the unique role that Times Square played in the city or the nation. But the cosmetics turned out to attract the music industry and Disney and has succeeded well."
Mr. Barwick said, "I don't like the word 'preservation.' A lot of what we have done amounts to preservation, but what we have been doing for New York is really finding ways to capitalize assets that were underappreciated. New York City has finally awakened to realize that tourism is the second biggest industry in the state, and all these things that we were saving, theoretically, for sentimental value have enormous economic value.
"WE really have never done anything by ourselves, either. We are the Tom Sawyers -- we start painting the fence and the next thing you know there are a hundred people on each side painting the fence. Everything we do is coalition-building. The Municipal Art Society isn't strong enough to really do much by itself."
Mr. Barwick said he felt that the society's largest contribution, at least locally, in recent years might have been its role in persuading the developer Donald J. Trump to remap a new Riverside South complex plan on the old Penn Central railyards on the West Side of Manhattan.
"We went to Trump and said, 'We want you to forget your world's tallest building and seven other 750-foot baby buildings and a regional shopping center and Television City and build something much more in character with the West Side and also a 24-acre park directly along the water,' " he said. "While there are people who live nearby who still resent this, we think that this is exactly the sort of thing that the city should be doing."
Though they may have differed with Mr. Barwick, developers praise his pragmatic approach. "I have found Kent Barwick to be a constructive problem solver, a valued quality in public interest groups such as the Municipal Art Society," said Mortimer B. Zuckerman, who owns The Daily News and is chairman of Boston Properties, which failed in its nine-year effort to build high-rise office and apartment buildings on the site of the New York Coliseum.
Before Mr. Barwick's tenure as president of the Municipal Art Society, he served in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch as chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "I didn't always agree with him, and when he returned to the private sector and became president of the Municipal Art Society, occasionally, in our respective roles, we would disagree," Mr. Koch said. "Even then, I never lost my complete respect for his fairness."
Earlier, Mr. Barwick, a graduate of Syracuse University, was executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts. He lives in a renovated schoolhouse in the Little Italy section of Manhattan and has a farm of 200-plus acres upstate in Cherry Valley.
HE said he had a few regrets or disappointments in his tenure in the Municipal Art Society. Perhaps his biggest, he said, was the failure to block or reduce what he considered to be huge tax abatements -- $1.5 billion to $4.2 billion in lost revenue for the city -- granted to the developers of four office buildings in the Times Square area. The abatements were promised to a development team led by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to compensate it for the money it had agreed to put up so the state could condemn property for the office buildings as well as for theaters and retail space.
"Think of what other uses that money could be going toward," he said.
Mr. Barwick said he was also saddened by the development in the Union Square district. One loss, especially, upset him. "Luchow's," he said, referring to the original site of the midtown restaurant, at 112 East 14th Street, where Diamond Jim Brady, H. L. Mencken and Enrico Caruso dined earlier in the century.
The building was abandoned in 1982, became a home for squatters and then was damaged by a fire late last year before being demolished. "Sadly, it couldn't be saved," he said.

HEADLINE: A Gamble on Pedigreed Grapes and Fancy Labels

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
TWENTY years ago a Connecticut industrialist became involved in a venture new to the state but so old that ancient Greece and Rome each had a god for it -- Dionysus and Bacchus, respectively.
The industrialist was Sherman P. Haight Jr., who was in the textile business. The new venture was making wine. 
 Evereyone knew that making wine, on a commercial basis anyway, was not something for Connecticut. The climate in winter was too harsh for vines that produce better grapes. Making wine in the state was confined to first generation Italian immigrants who made some for family consumption from the hardy backyard vines they nurtured with skills passed on generation to generation. But wine in bottles with fancy labels, made from pedigreed grapes, competing in a very crowded market -- that was not for Connecticut.
"We took a big chance," said Mr. Haight recently as he wandered about his Tudor-style winery and his 30-acre vineyard in the northwest hills of the state only a few miles from his native Litchfield. The "we" was himself and another Connecticut industrialist, August Loos of Pomfret, who had also decided to go into the wine business in 1975 but would later get out of it because of his many other business interests.
If Mr. Haight is considered the pioneer of the Connecticut wine business today, the person who should be credited with being the inspiration, he says, was a Russian immigrant to America, Frank Konstantin.
Dr. Konstantin, an earth scientist who has since died, was working at the Cornell University Research Center in New York State in the 1970's. He was an outspoken critic of wine production in this country, Mr. Haight said, and believed, judging from his experience in the cold climates of Russia, that vineyards could be sustained in a climate like Connecticut's if certain precautions were taken. These included bringing vines to the winter season in peak condition and making sure each plant had three or four trunks, in contrast to the single trunk used in more hospitable wine regions like the Napa or Sonoma valleys of California.
Acting on Dr. Konstantin's theories, and a lot of faith, Mr. Haight planted his first vines, Chardonnay and Riesling, to make white wine when the grapes matured in three years.
If the grapes had matured earlier, selling the wine would have been illegal. Connecticut had no law authorizing production, so Mr. Haight and Mr. Loos started to lobby state legislators for a bill to authorize farm wineries. "We had to convince them that this was good for agriculture and good for the state," Mr. Haight said.
They succeeded. The Farm Winery Act in 1978 made the business legal, just in time for Mr. Haight's first grape harvest that autumn. He was ready with the first established winery in the state.
The first harvest was only fair in quantity but excellent in quality, Mr. Haight said, a condition that still applies. "It's hard to grow fine grapes this close to the boundary line where grapes will grow at all," he said. "And we might get two and a half tons of grapes per acre here while in a place like the Napa Valley four tons per acre is routine. But the compensation is the higher quality."
Buoyed by the early success, he gave up his textile business, now managed by one of his daughters in Georgia, and entered into the wine business with an enthusiasm that seems to have only increased with the years. "I'm absolutely fascinated with this business," Mr. Haight said. "It's part agriculture, part marketing, almost like a factory, and highly complex." Now in his early 70's, he says he is just getting started.
"I learn something new every day. I'll never retire," he said. "It will take me 25 more years to accomplish what I want to do here."
Today, the Haight operation produces three white wines, three red wines and a blush wine. And it has competition. Wine making is now an established business in Connecticut, a scattered bunch of economic bright spots in an area particularly hard hit by the recession of recent years.
Connecticut even has its own wine trail, marked by highway signs so visitors can stop for tastings. They include Haight in Litchfield and Olde Mystick Village in Mystic where its wine education center is situated, Hopkins in Warren, DiGrazia in Brookfield, Chamard in Clinton and Stonington in Stonington. Other vineyards in the state but not on the wine trail include Bishop in Cheshire, Heritage in Lisbon, McLaughlin in the Sandy Hook section of Newtown and Raynham in East Haven.
They are a cooperative lot, Mr. Haight said. "We're all friends," he explained. "We help each other out. We even help out people making wine at home"
Connecticut is riding the crest of an acceptance of wine today, he said, in preference to harder alcoholic beverages, partially due to medical reports that in moderation wine can be beneficial to health.
But with the new accent on wine has come a boom in production, not only in the United States and in Italy and France, traditionally famed for their wines, but also in countries never heard from before. Today, wines from Chile and Australia, among others, are marketed aggressively in the American market.
Selling Connecticut wines, with no heritage, is difficult in such a vast market. Even getting people to taste the wine is a challenge, Mr. Haight admits. But he sees progress.
"Acceptance of wines here has come a long way in the last few years," he said. "Once people would agree to taste our wines with the attitude 'I'll try anything and expect nothing.' But not any more. Now they say the wines are better than expected. We make good wines but we face the same problem that California once had. People wouldn't even try their wines once."
And today, he said, even the wines of France, long considered in a class by themselves, are being threatened by competition. "Some vineyards in France are living on their reputations and pricing themselves out of the market," Mr. Haight said. "I have a friend who has a great wine cellar and I like to go see him because he always breaks out a bottle of a great French wine. But now he says, 'Enjoy the French wines while you can because I'm not buying them anymore.' "
The dean of Connecticut's winery owners also sees signs that some of the pretension and jargon about wine is fading and he is happy about that. The criterion for wine, he believes, is not someone blathering on in stilted cliches but simply whether a person likes it or not.
"Wine is like food," Mr. Haight said. "Some people like string beans and some people can't stand string beans. In any kind of wine, you like it or you don't."
Making wine today, in a high-tech age, is still half science and half art, he said. His winemaker at Haight Vineyards, Wayne Stitzer, agrees with him.
Like all commercial winemakers today, Mr. Stitzer is skilled in the science of times and temperatures and stainless steel vats and various kinds of oak barrels. But, having he had one credential not taught in books or learned at other wineries. He had a grandfather who made wine. In Connecticut.
The grandfather's name was Salvatore Daddona, originally from Italy, and for years he had produced wine for the Daddona clan in the Oakville section of Watertown. Several years ago, Mr. Stitzer invited him to see the wine making at Haight.
"We toured the whole operation, the vineyards, the winery, and he was very quiet, but then we came to the laboratory and Grandfather just started to laugh and laugh," Mr. Stitzer said. "A laboratory! For making wine? He thought that was really funny."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Broome Street;
When It Comes to Trucks, SoHo Is All Shook Up

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
DID you know that through trucks are not allowed on Broome Street, which at peak periods seems like their native habitat? Some local activists do not like that awful, churning feeling of living in a cement mixer and claim that heavy trucking there is not only illegal but is shaking SoHo's historic buildings to bits.
They hope that special signs planned by the city's Department of Transportation will reduce traffic and save the facades. Restoration professionals, however, say that trucks are not the source of the trouble. 
 Broome Street's problems of high volume stem from its original design width of 65 feet, compared with the typical 50-foot width of most other SoHo crosstown streets.
Historic photographs show Broome as a two-way street until about 1950, when it became one way headed west toward the Holland Tunnel, at the same time that the Lower Manhattan Expressway was in the planning stages.
That crosstown highway would have destroyed a wide swath of buildings along Broome, but would have given Brooklyn manufacturers better access to the Hudson River piers and points beyond.
The expressway was defeated in 1969 as preservation advocates like Jane Jacobs and James Marston Fitch triumphed over highway proponents like Robert Moses, who saw downtown Manhattan as a hopeless warren of tangled streets.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission designated SoHo a historic district in 1973, just as it was in the early stages of change from an industrial to a retail and residential neighborhood.
That transformation is well along now, and parts of SoHo approach the Upper East Side for housing prices and fancy shops.
Nine years ago Carl Rosenstein, a photographer who lives at 435 Broome Street, near Broadway, became upset about heavy truck traffic on Broome. Although trucks are meant to use Canal and Houston Streets for east-west travel, westbound Broome Street between Lafayette and West Broadway has a wide roadbed, no curb parking and few stop lights -- a perfect but illegal shortcut to the Holland Tunnel for a few hundred trucks a day, according to Mr. Rosenstein's estimates.
With mixed success he has been trying to get the Department of Transportation to enforce the trucking restriction.
"It's in the interest of the economy of the city -- the neighborhood just sort of dies at Broome Street," he said, noting that Broome has a much higher vacancy rate than other SoHo streets.
Mr. Rosenstein said it was not just a quality of life issue. The cast-iron facade on his building is damaged, which he says is caused by the pounding vibrations and air pollution of the trucks.
CAROLYN ALEXANDER is an officer of her co-op at the northwest corner of Wooster and Broome Streets. She said that a facade restoration of the 70's, "which should have lasted for at least 30 years," was now failing. Dislodged stones and cracked terra cotta now require a $250,000 repair project, one she said her eight-unit building could barely afford. She, like Mr. Rosenstein, is sure that the damage "comes from the phenomenal vibrations -- at nighttime they really pick up speed and when they hit the brakes it's incredible," she said.
The situation has attracted the attention of preservation groups. The National Trust for Historic Preservation, the New York Landmarks Conservancy and the Historic Districts Council have all agreed that vibrations and pollution from trucks are damaging the buildings. And Mr. Rosenstein says the Department of Transportation has agreed to make signs reading "Historic District -- No Thru Trucks or Buses" pthat also warn of a maximum $1,600 fine.
But although a stream of trucks blights any street, the hard evidence does not support claims of building damage. And indeed there is only one protective sidewalk sheds on Broome Street in SoHo.
Robert Silman, New York's pre-eminent engineer for restoration projects, said, "Every time we've tried to monitor a building for damage from truck traffic, we can't prove an effect, even if we use European standards, which are much more stringent." Sophisticated equipment can monitor vibration against known damage thresholds but this has not been done on Broome Street.
Mr. Silman was a consultant on a project to predict damage from pile driving for the new SoHo Grand hotel project, at Canal Street and West Broadway, as was Robert Dinan, a seismologist with John V. Dinan Associates in Fort Lee, N.J. Mr. Dinan said that at the SoHo Grand site even the hammering of pile drivers was less than one-fifth the standard of 0.5 inches per second used by the Landmarks Preservation Commission as a threshold.
"The truck vibration is there, it's annoying, it will be in the range where people feel it," he said. But he added that he had never seen cases where truck traffic had any direct effect on a building, unless the structure was already weak.
Ray Pepi, president of Building Conservation Associates, an experienced restoration firm, agreed. And both he and Mr. Silman said that although air pollution was a threat to New York's buildings, it was an areawide condition, rarely active within an environment like a single street.
What damages New York buildings, they and Mr. Dinan said, is age and weather, not traffic.

They hope signs like the one below will dissuade the drivers. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times); At right, cast-iron 476 Broome Street in 1944. (Office for Metropolitan History)

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Whitman's D.M.V. Folly A Homemade Mess

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Most people come in direct contact with the state about twice a year -- when they pay their taxes, and when they visit a motor vehicle office to renew their license or auto registration. Writing checks for the first of these is rarely an enjoyable event, and Governor Whitman's hastily conceived and sloppily executed effort to turn 23 state-run Division of Motor Vehicles branch offices over to private management firms has made a disaster of the other.
Late in the week, lines were still snaking out of doors and down streets at several of the branch offices, and people needing new licenses or registrations were still being turned away hours before closing time, four days after the Governor told reporters, on July 7, "We'll be fully staffed and everything will be fine come Monday." 
 In the history of New Jersey and the chronicle of state affairs, this is small stuff, likely to pass before too long. But in the 18-month history of Mrs. Whitman's governorship, the D.M.V. mess stands as a kind of milestone, the first made-from-scratch, toe-stubbing embarrassment by an administration whose mastery of administrative systems was supposed to make New Jersey state government "leaner and smarter."
Instead of operating smoothly, the privatized D.M.V. offices were chaotic. Instead of being fully staffed, the division, having laid off 300 state employees to save $4 million, had to call Kelly Girls to rush in temps at $17 an hour. Instead of giving the public the kind of crisp, market-disciplined service they had been promised, New Jersey motorists got a taste of Soviet-style bureucracy at its most bizarre:
An American returning from a sojourn in Canada, waiting at the Eatontown office on Tuesday to get a New Jersey license, was sent away hours before closing time, for example. We can do license renewals, she was told by a greeter stationed at the end of the lengthening outdoor queue, but not license transfers. Come back tomorrow.
Then, on Wednesday, the Bergen Record broke the story that 330,000 taxpayer refunds have still not been mailed because the state was saving money by cutting back on the temporary workers hired to process the checks. Leaner, yes, but not smarter from an administration based on tax aversion.
Administration officials acknowledged that the decision to place the 23 field offices under private management was made in haste, back in March, when the Governor and her staff were pulling budget options together. Half the offices are already under private management, someone pointed out, they do the same work with fewer workers, let's privatize the rest of them and save the difference.
Republican legislators began warning that it might not be so simple, particularly on the administration's headlong schedule of overhauling the offices simultaneously, instead of phasing in changes over a period of months.
Some Republicans warned that the rapid changeover would create confusion and anger voters, which it has. Others worried about the impact on the men and women, but mostly women, who would be offered the Hobson's choice between no job or one that paid $10,000 less a year, with poorer benefits. The Governor brushed these warnings and worries aside, and because she brushed them aside, the disorder that resulted is hers alone to explain.
Mrs. Whitman has come far on the best qualities a political leader can possess: sharp instincts, a commanding public presence merged with a warm public personality. She has benefited, above all, from not having much of a political history, for if she ever said or did anything stupid, New Jersey voters do not know of it. Instead, the Governor came before the voters as a blank page on which she was free to compose her public self-portrait.
Now, however, the portrait has begun to show smudges. By itself, the D.M.V. imbroglio is a transitory thing, and by itself, the delay in mailing refunds is small stuff. But then, so were unplowed streets in Queens for Mayor John V. Lindsay, an earlier handsome, well-born moderate Republican comer. So were Edmund S. Muskie's tears in the snows of Concord, N.H., or George Romney's joke about brainwashing, Gary Hart's invitation to be shadowed, or George Bush's invitation to have his lips read.
What matters in politics is the way little mistakes acquire weight by accumulation, and that is why the Whitmanauts at the State House must be watching the state and national economic indicators like Dorothy watching the Kansas sky darken and the wind kick up. If the slowdown that seems to have settled over the country spreads to the state, and the Governor's revenue projections begin tilting toward the red, problems renewing a license or registration and problems getting a tax refund will be joined with problems keeping the budget balanced. At that point, the ride starts getting really bumpy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
A Town Draws Lines in the Shifting Sand

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
ALL the Borough Council of Monmouth Beach wanted to do Tuesday night was to mollify residents who showed up to protest strict new proposed regulations for the town's recently restored beach.
Looking relieved, Mayor Louis P. Sodano told the crowd that the ordinance, which would have outlawed using the beach after 6 P.M. and banned eating, ball-tossing, changing any article of clothing and an exhaustive list of other activities, had gone back to the legal drawing board for major revisions. A new draft will be ready in the fall. 
 Cheers rose. But not from Clemens N. Jacobsen, a retired engineer who got up to address the Council. Mr. Jacobsen, whom people call Jake, has lived there for 50 years and thinks the beach should be open to everyone.
First, he told his neighbors -- who found the draft rules too harsh even for them -- that they should have no illusions about the main purpose of restrictive beach rules. Like many affluent stretches of New Jersey's shore, Monmouth Beach actively discourages outsiders by limiting beach passes and parking. In fact, a petition passed around before the meeting warned of opening up any new parking places in town. "All kinds of people" will be "wandering around," the petition said, "if we encourage them to stop and park." And in this conservative, all-white enclave, "all kinds of people" resonates with meaning.
"What you're really worried about," Mr. Jacobsen told the Council, "is that somebody is going to drive a busload of people down here and have a party on the beach."
"Jake," said the Mayor, rolling his eyes.
Secondly, Mr. Jacobsen went on, drawing up restrictions may be beside the point. Mr. Jacobsen calculates that about about one-third of the federally restored beach -- which the Army Corps of Engineers said would last for six years or more -- has already washed away. "This beach won't even be here two years from now," he declared. Quickly, the Council moved on to other business.
The opposition that forced Monmouth Beach to rethink its beach rules was led by a well-organized group of local surfers, members of the national Surfrider Foundation. Since the 1960's, surfers have felt unwelcome on some Jersey beaches -- but now many of them are middle-aged and affluent. Some even grew up to be lawyers. Last year, when a surfer was arrested for violating beach regulations in the exclusive town of Deal a few miles down the coast, the Surf riders sued. Deal backed down.
"If we had the time and energy, we could go from town to town like dominoes down the Jersey coast fighting for beach access, and not just for surfers," said Brian Unger, a 43-year-old businessman from Long Branch who has been surfing the Jersey coast since the 1960's. Mr. Unger often surfs in California, where all of the beaches are public. "Only in New Jersey do you have all of these problems getting on the beach -- even though the taxpayers paid for it. Here, they're always talking about the beach like it was basically a profit center for local businesses. In Big Sur, they don't think of a beach as a revenue producer."
Years after its previous beach washed away in natural ocean currents, Monmouth Beach got its new one this year as part of a $19.6 million project by the Army Corps of Engineers to pump in a 180-foot-wide, three-mile stretch of sand. That restoration is part of a $400 million beach-restoration project on the Jersey Shore, much of it on behalf of exclusive towns that do their best to keep the general public out. Some coastal conservationists have denounced the whole project as an expensive subsidy for well-connected property owners who insist on living atop shifting sands.
The other day the Corps conceded that in Monmouth Beach, even without any big storms, a chunk of the new beach is indeed gone, after less than a year. "We are aware of the situation," said the Corps's chief engineer for the New Jersey project, Gilbert Nersesian. "Unsettled weather activity" at sea caused the "shoreline recession," he said.
The other night, a young couple, Joseph and Marguerite DiCroce, enjoyed a moonlit picnic on the beach, saying they would savor the experience while they could. The DiCroces, both lawyers, heartily concurred with Mr. Jacobsen's view that the new beach was receding quickly toward the boulders beside Ocean Drive.
"Before long, we'll be fishing off the rocks again," said Mr. DiCroce.
"One storm and it's gone," Mrs. DiCroce sighed.
"Easter," Mr. DiCroce decided. "We'll be back to the rocks by Easter."

HEADLINE: Coalition to Focus On Support for the Arts

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
MORE than 120 arts leaders from around the country are expected to gather at Doral Arrowwood in Rye Brook on July 28 for the annual conference of the National Coalition of United Arts Funds. The Westchester Arts Council will be the host of the three-day meeting, which will focus on new approaches to fund-raising at a time of government and corporate cutbacks.
John Brademus, former president of New York University and a champion of the arts, and Leon Botstein, president of Bard College and music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, will be the featured speakers. 
 Molly K. Sasse, president of the Arts Funds Coalition, said the meeting had two main objectives. "It's a good opportunity to swap war stories and keep our skills polished," she said. "It's even more beneficial for people who are new to fund-raising and especially to the United Arts approach."
Ms. Sasse, an official with United Arts of Greater Chattanooga, Tenn., defined United Arts Funds as "any fund-raising effort that raises money for three or more arts organizations in the same region."
"When financial squeezes have the arts up against the rope," she said, "United Arts Funds groups weather the financial downturns better than individuals. During the 1991-92 recession, United Arts Funds saw a 2 percent increase in fund-raising, while other groups had a decrease."
The Westchester Arts Council conducts an annual Campaign for the Arts, which last year raised $850,000 for arts programs.
Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the Arts Council, said the goal for this year's campaign is $1 million. "A majority of the money goes to artists," she said.
County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke heads this year's campaign, which began in May and ends in September.
Ms. Langsam said one example of a new approach to fund-raising is "workplace giving," which uses payroll deductions or pledge cards to set aside money for the arts. She said the Arts Council would introduce the plan in the county this fall.
"We're going to go into the workplace and bring a visual arts or performance program with us," she said.
"I don't expect a big return this year -- I expect a snowball effect. Workplace giving is done all over the country."
Ms. Langsam said she was eager to show off the great wealth of Westchester's arts organizations. Participants at the conference will have dinner at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College and attend a performance of "High Spirits" by the Phoenix Theater Company in the Performing Arts Center, also at Purchase College.
In addition, they will tour the Katonah Museum, Kykuit and the Reader's Digest art collection and will attend a concert at Caramoor.
"We are privileged to have been selected for the conference," said Ms. Langsam, who serves on the board of the National Arts Funds coalition.
The last time the meeting was held in the county was in 1987.
The regular conference fee is $445 for coalition members and $525 for nonmembers. The Westchester Arts Council is offering a package for county residents of $225 for a limited number of events, including the two keynote addresses. Individuals may also attend the lunch at which Mr. Brademus will speak on July 29 at noon for $40.
A special fee will also be offered for events on July 31, which will focus on the government's role in arts funding and new tax regulations.
Those interested in attending the conference should call Pat Braja at the Westchester Arts Council at 428-4220.

HEADLINE: Welfare Program Helps Many Climb the Ladder

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN 

 BODY:
THIRTY-NINE-YEAR-OLD Frances S., the mother of two, was dependent on public assistance for years. In addition to battling a drug and alcohol problem, she became homeless after an abusive marriage and lived in a shelter with her children.
Now Frances, a Briarcliff Manor resident whose full name is being withheld to avoid embarrassing her family, is off welfare and working 20 hours a week with autistic children as a behavioral therapist. She credits a model program with helping her turn her life around. 
"I was despondent when I began this program," Frances said. "But I wanted to do something with my life. I was always good with kids. This program gave me the confidence to try to find a job working with kids and to get the training I'd need to do it. I feel good about myself now. I never felt so good in my life. I'm doing something important and working toward a career."
The Family Self-Sufficiency program was started by the Federal Government in 1992 for people receiving housing subsidies. It is operated by the county's Department of Planning. A participating family member signs a contract, promising to work toward individual economic and personal goals that will get them off public assistance in five years.
The program is also available to the working poor -- those earning too much to qualify for assistance. These participants sign contracts pledging to improve themselves financially. In return, each family receives job counseling and referrals to programs that will assist them.
"People in dire financial straits are forced to live day to day," said Doreen T. Capozza, employment counselor for the program. "It is unlikely that they will be able to plan ahead. I asked them what they want to be doing in five years. What they are good at. These are people who never expected to think in terms of these questions."
The program is voluntary and open to people receiving Section 8 rental assistance from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. The Section 8 program is operated by the Planning Department in 17 Westchester municipalities. Families are eligible for Section 8 assistance based on income levels. They must pay 30 percent of their income in rent, with the Federal program paying the rest.
When the Department of Housing and Urban Development started the Family Self-Sufficiency program in 1992, it invited counties and municipalities to apply. In Westchester, the Planning Department and the city of New Rochelle signed up.
The Planning Department had to have 90 of its 1,436 Section 8 clients enrolled by August 1994. That goal was met, and there are now 107 people in the program, with 220 expected by November 1997. New Rochelle is still setting up its program.
Westchester is one of 26 counties in the state involved in the program. Of the first 95 enrolled in the county, 49 were working poor and 46 were on public assistance. Sixteen of those are now off public assistance. Two of them went off welfare but are now back on.
Those who sign the contract set up short- and long-term goals with a counselor. The long-term goal is always a good-paying job that will lead to self-sufficiency, but short-term goals can vary and might include arranging for child care so a parent can work, taking part in a program leading to a general equivalency diploma, enrolling in college classes or obtaining literacy or vocational training. Ms. Capozza provides monthly job-search workshops.
Cynthia A. Wallquist, Family Self-Sufficiency coordinator for the county's Planning Department, said: "The final goal is independence, but we try to help them along the way and take care of their needs, such as if they need to learn English or find a support group for battered women. They receive a great deal of advice. The real purpose of the program is to give them somebody to work with."
The county contracts with three community groups to provide some case management. Such groups include the Westchester Hispanic Coalition, Hope Inc. in northern Westchester and Cluster Inc. in Yonkers.
The contract signer meets with a counselor every three months to assess progress and make adjustments. As an incentive, an escrow account is established for the participant; if the participant increases total household income while on the program, 30 percent of the participant's income still goes toward rent, but the amount the Federal Government saves as a result of the increased contribution goes into the account, as future money for the participant.
Participants can withdraw the money when they meet their final goal or if they stay off welfare for a year. The money can also be used to pay for education or transportation that helps them meet their goals.

HEADLINE: From Wall St. Guru to Mutual-Fund Empire Builder

 BODY:
WHEN Mario J. Gabelli was a freshman at Fordham University in the early 1960's, he had already developed a precocious interest in the stock market, poring over The Wall Street Journal and buying shares in companies like ITT. But what old friends really remember from those college years were Mr. Gabelli's business ventures -- the airline catering business, the student trips to Bermuda, the flashlights he sold from the trunk of his car during electrical brownouts.
Three decades later, the 53-year-old Mr. Gabelli has become one of Wall Street's most respected stock pickers, with a stellar record of managing money for big institutions and, through mutual funds, individual investors. As befits a Wall Street guru, he appears often in investment magazines and on television, with his shock of silver hair and his mastery of bons mots -- usually with exclamation points at the end. 
 But the entrepreneurial spirit of his school days has also remained strong, and as the mutual-fund business has boomed in the 1990's, Mr. Gabelli has become one of its certified stars. In the last several years, trading on his well-honed wise man's image, he has fashioned a growing empire of mutual funds that bear his name, including several new ones run by managers he employs.
Now, as he seeks to expand his $9 billion firm still further, pursuing a link with a foreign firm that will give Gabelli Funds Inc. a global presence, the fate of his ambitions is being closely watched as a test case for a changing industry. In the wake of some high-profile staff defections and performance that has trailed the stock market for several years in the 1990's, even some of his admirers are asking the same question: Can Mr. Gabelli build an enterprise that lives up to his reputation, or will his results suffer as he spreads himself too thin?
"Good stock pickers are not necessarily good empire builders," said Don Phillips, president of Morningstar Inc., the fund analysis firm, and himself an investor in Mr. Gabelli's funds. "You've got to have a tremendous ego, because you are sitting in judgment on corporate America."
Asked if it is possible to manage money and run a diversified fund company, he added: "I don't know of anyone who has done it successfully."
Mr. Gabelli, characteristically, has no doubts about his ability to do both. "We're much better at picking stocks than at running a business," he said in an interview. But, "the business itself is not complicated -- all you have to do is make money for your customers." While other people manage the company for him, he added, "all I do is figure out where the world is going."
Though he may be the most prominent investment guru to face the conflict between managing money and managing a business, Mr. Gabelli is by no means alone. Enormous sums have surged into mutual funds in the last few years, and this has transformed both the money-management industry and the roles of its leading lights.
Traditionally, "money management shops" consisted of a couple of men in a room with a stock quotation machine, perhaps with an outside person to woo clients, mostly big companies. Today, mutual fund companies must hire flocks of analysts, along with people to deal with thousands of individual customers. The major ones must also offer a product line so diverse that their customers are not tempted by their rivals.
For money managers who have prospered using a specific investment technique, trying to be all things to all investors has often proved difficult.
"Can it be done well? It's hard," said Ken Gregory, a partner at Litman/Gregory & Company, which analyzes mutual funds. "Even Fidelity Investments has not done it perfectly." At Fidelity, the chairman, Edward C. Johnson 3d, gave up running money two decades ago to concentrate on running the nation's largest fund company.
Mr. Gabelli's entrepreneurial instincts were forged, he says, while he was growing up on 174th Street in the Bronx, the son of Italian immigrants "who didn't get past sixth grade." But his investment philosophy was developed at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, where he studied with Professor Roger Murray, a leading exponent of what is known as "value investing."
This school of financial thought teaches investors to avoid focusing on companies' earnings or following stock market fads. Instead, value investors look long and hard at companies' assets and the amount of cash they can generate, and try to buy stocks when they are relatively cheap.
While he was absorbing this wisdom, Mr. Gabelli continued to play the market, sometimes racing his friend Leon G. Cooperman to the pay phone to place orders with their brokers. "We're both kind of equally sick human beings," said Mr. Cooperman, who now runs Omega Advisors, a hedge fund. "But I think he's sicker than I am."
After graduation in 1967, Mr. Gabelli got his first Wall Street job, as a farm-equipment analyst at Loeb, Rhodes & Company, where he replaced another investor destined for financial fame, Michael Steinhardt.
"Only someone from the Bronx would love to go to Moline," recalled Mr. Gabelli, referring to the Illinois headquarters of Deere & Company. But two years later, those trips had lost some of their allure, and he started traveling to Hollywood, beginning his long fascination with the movie business.
In 1975, he moved to another firm, William D. Witter, and the next year, when his employer was swallowed up by Drexel Burnham Lambert, struck out on his own. This took a lot of chutzpah: In 1973 the stock market had entered a prolonged bear phase and did not recover until 1982.
"Nobody believed in stocks," Mr. Gabelli said. But, he reasoned, rich people were still buying small businesses. So he started to focus on the stocks of smaller companies, trying to figure out what their value would be if they were taken private.
This was the approach that was to make him famous. One reason it worked so well was that it gave Mr. Gabelli flexibility, according to Peter Lynch, the financial superstar and former manager of the Fidelity Magellan Fund. While many investors would simply crunch numbers to see if stocks were cheap, without necessarily figuring out why or how low they might go, Mr. Lynch said, Mr. Gabelli would see value in things many other investors ignored, like cellular phone licenses. (He is known for his expertise in telephones and television.)
It was Mr. Lynch who encouraged Mr. Gabelli to get into the mutual fund business. "I was saying to him what a wonderful business it is, and he's a great investor," Mr. Lynch said. Or as Mr. Gabelli remembers it, he figured out that though his record was even better than Mr. Lynch's, he was managing a lot less money. In 1986, he opened his first mutual fund, Gabelli Asset.

BUT Mr. Gabelli would have had a hard time signing on the general public had he not succeeded so well in building a brand-name image as an investment whiz.
His breakthrough had come early on, when he sent a research report on Chris-Craft to Alan Abelson, the influential columnist for Barron's, with a note suggesting the magazine publish it because the stock was cheap. The two men had lunch, Mr. Gabelli recalled, "and that's how I got on the cover of Barron's in 1978."
Mr. Abelson suggests that there may have been a couple of steps in between the first meal and the front page. But having interviewed droves of analysts and money managers over the years, he remains an admirer of Mr. Gabelli. "He has a good wit and is a good showman," Mr. Abelson said. "If you put together a really good company analyst and an exuberant personality, what you get is a very rich guy."
Which Mr. Gabelli clearly is, though he abhors showing up on "highest paid" lists. Unlike many of his peers, he does not sport expensive suits or hand-sewn shoes. Though he does have a vacation home in Wyoming, a mecca for money managers, he likes to point out that he bought a log cabin on three acres -- and split the cost with a friend.
Old friends like Mr. Cooperman describe him as a good and loyal friend, and he is well known for giving promising young people a chance. But Mr. Gabelli is also famous for not suffering fools gladly -- and for being quick to identify them. Certainly, he does get impatient with those who disagree with him, calling people who question his expansion plans ignorant and those who doubt his vision of the telecommunications revolution simply "in the dark."
But the aspect of Mr. Gabelli's personality that awes -- and exhausts -- those who know him is his capacity for work. He travels constantly, and ships big boxes of financial documents to his destinations so he can plow through them in free moments. He researches everything exhaustively, even going to the trouble of learning a reporter's birth date before an interview.
"Nobody in this firm can match his speed and work habits," said Caesar M. P. Bryan, a portfolio manager who joined Mr. Gabelli's company last year. "My wife asked him what books he read, and he said, 'I read annual reports in bed.' "

 HE seems to expect a similar dedication from his staff. "Mario drives you, focuses you, drives you -- and teaches you in the process how to be an analyst," said Salvatore Muoio, who worked closely with Mr. Gabelli for 10 years before moving to Lazard Freres & Company in February.
Some analysts and insiders have suggested that Mr. Gabelli has trouble delegating authority, and in the early 1980's, he did do everything at his firm except deliver the mail. ("That was my job," said Douglas R. Jamieson, who runs Gabelli's institutional money management business.) Since then, Mr. Jamieson said, the company has grown tremendously, with more analysts to give Mr. Gabelli information, and more business people to manage the company.
If anyone still thinks of him as a one-man band, Mr. Gabelli said, "that image lags reality."
Neither Mr. Gabelli's management skills nor personality quirks would matter much if he stuck with money management. But, of course, Mr. Gabelli has branched out. In late 1986, he decided that some of the stocks he invested in -- what he calls asset plays -- were becoming expensive. What would do well were growth stocks, so-called because their earnings grow quickly. This was the specialty of his old friend and Columbia classmate Elizabeth R. Bramwell. So he decided to make her a star.
"I was the first one to run personality ads," Mr. Gabelli said. "I felt it was the only way we could compete."
The timing was brilliant. Though Mr. Gabelli's own Asset fund did well in 1988 and 1989, Ms. Bramwell's fund, called Gabelli Growth, did even better, scoring returns of about 40 percent each year and handily beating the overall stock market.
More funds soon followed. At first, Mr. Gabelli managed the new offerings, leading some analysts to wonder if he was spreading himself too thin. But they were even more alarmed when he started sponsoring funds run by others, in 1994 adding a gold fund and a global convertible bond fund and teaming up with another money manager to distribute a small fund family called Westwood. Including those funds, Gabelli now has 19 offerings with $4 billion in assets.
Then, in early 1994, Mr. Gabelli and Ms. Bramwell had a falling out. Mr. Gabelli said she left because she wanted to run her own business. Ms. Bramwell said Mr. Gabelli was not giving her the staff she needed and was trying to force her to move out of the company's New York office, which was to close, and into his headquarters in Rye, N.Y., which she found inconvenient.
The brouhaha, which seemed avoidable, continues to baffle many analysts -- especially since Mr. Gabelli kept the New York City office after all (he said recently that the landlord made him a deal). In any event, his search for a replacement for Ms. Bramwell, which took until early this year, may have distracted him from investing.
"The expansionary activities of the Gabelli organization have made me wonder if it detracts from the one thing he is very good at, which is picking stocks," said Tim Medley, an investment adviser in Jackson, Miss.
Investment performance has been a bit uneven in recent years. After suffering losses in 1990, Mr. Gabelli's two big funds saw performance improve the following year, though both failed to match the overall stock market's stellar performance. That changed in 1992 and 1993, when both funds were strong. Last year, the funds kept losses to a minimum in a tough market, but were not superstars, and both are lagging in this year's soaring stock market.
"Through the 1980's, he was phenomenal," said one analyst, who asked not to be identified because he feared Mr. Gabelli would stop speaking to him. "Now his record is good, not phenomenal -- he's even looked human at times."
Of course, a lot of people would be happy to have his results. Mr. Gabelli points out that over the last three years, his more aggressive fund, Gabelli Value, has outpaced Fidelity Magellan, though that behemoth fund outscores his on a five-year basis. Besides, he said, his goal is to make for his customers 10 percent a year plus inflation, and this year the big funds have already beaten that bogey.
But what really galls Mr. Gabelli are reports of glitches and regulatory problems at his firm. In April, for example, investors in some Gabelli funds were among those who received incorrect account statements, a problem that was traced to the company that Gabelli and many fund companies contract with to prepare the reports.
Last year, Gabelli settled with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which said its policies to prevent insider trading were lax, though the agency did not accuse Mr. Gabelli or his firm of profiting from inside information. In 1992, Mr. Gabelli ran into trouble with the Federal Communications Commission over his ownership of media companies, and in 1988, he and his firm settled S.E.C. charges related to a failed takeover attempt.
Mr. Gabelli said he did not feel that regulators were picking on him, but noted that when other mutual fund companies ran into trouble -- and there have been some big scandals in the last few years -- nobody pointed the finger at their chief executives. Though Fidelity was recently fined almost 50,000, or $80,000, by British regulators, for example, newspapers have not "written up Ned Johnson's difficulties with compliance," he wrote in a recent letter.
To some extent, Mr. Gabelli's many puzzled admirers seem to be reacting the way sports fans did when Michael Jordan abandoned basketball and took up baseball. And Mr. Gabelli himself cannot clearly explain why he is driven to develop a big fund company, though he allows that it may have something to do with building a family dynasty; his son Marc joined the firm in 1993.
It seems likely that Mr. Gabelli, like Mr. Jordan, will be unable to give up the job at which he truly excels. A new chief financial officer, Steven M. Joenk, recently joined Gabelli Funds from Paine Webber Inc., and will handle matters like financial reporting and human resources.
Meanwhile, Mr. Gabelli continues to think, talk, eat, drink and breathe stocks -- and he has no intention of stopping. "To do what?" he asks. "I want to come to the office and trade stocks in 2035."

HEADLINE: After the Fall: 2 Faces of Mexico's Economy

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
MOST Wednesdays, at precisely 2 P.M., Government officials gather here at the ornate National Palace to give the latest figures on declining inflation, surging stock prices and other positive signs of Mexico's steady climb back to economic stability.
While the good news is being related inside, unemployed Mexican workers sometimes mill outside on the huge Plaza of the Constitution, occasionally swaggering up to a microphone facing the palace windows. They are hungry, they call out, and they are angry because the Government is forcing them to pay for getting the nation's economy back on track. 
 The difference between what is said in the palace and what is shouted on the plaza underscores an inescapable conclusion about Mexico almost seven months after the peso was disastrously devalued: the economy here now has two faces. One is reflected in steadily improving macroeconomic indicators; the other reveals the deepening misery of Mexico's 91 million people.
The extent to which Mexico can draw those two economies together in the coming months will determine not only how well it recovers from this latest crisis, but also whether it will be able to overcome some of the fundamental problems that have for so long created appalling gaps between the rich and poor in Mexico.
Should it fail to draw the economies closer, many fear a period of deepening political and social unrest in a country that has already been shaken for more than a year by a peasant uprising and a string of assassinations.
The outcome is of critical importance to the United States, which is still waiting for the promised benefits from the North American Free Trade Agreement and is fearful of a new wave of illegal immigration if conditions worsen.
And while the Mexican Government trumpets the latest positive numbers, it is far from declaring victory.
"We are very careful not to claim that because we have made progress in returning to the market that the crisis is over," said Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz. "We will say the crisis is over when we get some real growth going and employment increasing."
Still, the palace version of the economy is positive indeed. With surprising speed, the Mexican stock exchange has bounced back to pre-devaluation levels. Inflation rates are still high, around 3 percent a month, but declining broadly after peaking at 8 percent in April. Although the peso is now allowed to float freely, it has remained at around the same level -- between 6 and 6.3 to the dollar -- for weeks.
What's more, Mexico had a $165 million trade surplus in the first quarter and the Government last week successfully placed $1 billion in commercial notes, a startlingly swift recovery considering that after the last financial crisis here, in 1982, it took seven years to regain access to international capital.
From the plaza, however, the Government's recovery program looks more like a virus than a cure.
Fearing hyperinflation, the Government essentially shut down the economy here, raising prices on basic items like electricity, gasoline and even tortillas. Interest rates on consumer loans reached 100 percent and, though dropping, still exceed a punishing 45 percent. Banks have repossessed houses and cars in record numbers. Inflation far outstrips wage increases. And perhaps worst of all, in a country with no unemployment insurance, as many as a million people may have lost jobs since January.
As the Government's March 9 recovery plan of budget cuts, tax increases, price hikes and a tight money supply continues to take hold, the gap between the palace and the plaza economies appears to grow wider. That is hard for President Ernesto Zedillo to accept because he campaigned on a promise of personal well-being and prosperity for Mexican families. But even he concedes that the hardships are likely to get worse before a real turnaround begins.
The Government hopes that as investor confidence slowly returns in the second half of the year, and exports remain strong, companies will begin to buy equipment and expand, providing jobs that will lead to some positive growth by the end of the year. Government spending will also increase throughout the rest of this year, while the national development banks will start to make more credit available.
But until then, as savings run out and the recession hits harder, more jobs will be lost and more pockets will go empty.
"There's a big difference between what the Government says and what we the people feel," said Maria Ortega, a 28-year-old nurse from Puebla, a colonial city about 50 miles southeast of Mexico City. Like other civil servants, she received a 13 percent wage increase this year, "but that's not enough to cover my bus fare," she complained.
It's not just having to pull their belts tighter that bothers many Mexicans like Ms. Ortega. They remember how just a little more than a year ago the Mexican economy was widely praised, with a booming stock market and the ability to attract billions of dollars in foreign investment. They believed the Government's promises that by entering the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexico was entering the first world.
ALL that collapsed last December when Mexico jolted world markets with the devaluation, which caught the United States and others by surprise and set off a chain reaction that sent investors and their dollars fleeing.
Faced with a spreading disaster, the Government appealed for help from the international community and dedicated itself to a major restructuring that would eliminate the $30 billion in volatile short-term foreign capital on which it had been financing much of its expansion. Squeezing out that $30 billion meant putting the economy into a straitjacket.
It was a classic response to a recurring problem. The economies of eastern Europe and many countries elsewhere in Latin America have adopted the same rigid therapy to rehabilitate their economies, with the same painful results.
The United States brokered a rescue plan for Mexico last February that includes $20 billion in loans and loan guarantees from Washington and about $30 billion in loans from the International Monetary Fund and other organizations. When they lobbied for the package last January, American officials said the help was needed to prevent the short-term crisis "from escalating into a prolonged and severe economic downturn, which would put at risk important U.S. interests," in particular 700,000 export-related jobs.
Already, what had been a positive trade balance with Mexico has turned into another deficit for the United States. Without some relief for the Mexicans who cannot now afford American imports, jobs north of the border could be lost, too.
Some members of Congress, led by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, are still opposed to assisting Mexico financially. Senator D'Amato held a hearing in Washington on Friday in which he rapped the Mexican Government for its management of the economy and for the pace with which it has been tapping the loan package. It has already made use of $12.5 billion in United States credits and another $9.8 billion from the I.M.F.
Such criticism is causing the Mexican Government to fight a battle on two fronts, trying to show American officials that the international rescue has worked while also attempting to show its own people that it is not unaware of the gap between the macroeconomic indicators and everyday life.
Mr. Ortiz said the Government knew that making a huge economic adjustment would be painful, but believed it was unavoidable. "If we hadn't got the macroeconomics right," he said, "it would be much more difficult to make progress on the real side of the economy."
The Government clearly has been getting the macroeconomics right. On almost every issue that had become a concern to international investors, Mexico has scored at least a temporary success.
The stability of the peso is one of the most surprising. Before the recovery plan was announced in March, the peso had dropped to 7.45 to the dollar, a decline of 54 percent since the devaluation.
But steps taken by the central bank have helped bring the peso back to around 6 to the dollar. Peso futures are now traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Mexico's central bank reveals the level of international reserves and the money supply every week so investors know where the country is heading. Before the devaluation, reserves were officially announced just three times a year.
The last time the reserves were announced before the crisis was in October, when they stood at about $17 billion. Within a month after the crisis began in December, the reserves stood at only slightly above $2 billion. Since then, they have bounced back to $14.35 billion, mostly with the help of the United States aid package.
AT the heart of the crisis were doubts about Mexico's ability to pay its debts. As 1994 ended, Mexico had $29 billion worth of outstanding tesobonos -- short-term Government bonds denominated in pesos yet payable in dollars. As the peso lost value, and tesobono holders demanded to be paid in dollars, Mexico faced a liquidity problem.
But Mexico was able to use the aid package to cover its obligations. Now, only $8.9 billion of tesobonos are outstanding. Of that amount, about $6.6 billion come due the rest of this month and in August. Given the current reserves of Mexico, only a few analysts are worried about its ability to make the payments.
As the peso lost value earlier in the year, so did Mexican stocks. First-quarter profits were depressed but not as badly as some had feared. As interest rates started to drop during the second quarter, the picture improved. A rate cut by the United States Federal Reserve on July 6 gave additional help to the leading index of the stock exchange here. On Friday, the index closed at 2,531.49, more than a thousand points above its post-devaluation low of 1,447.52, which was set on Feb. 27. The stock market's recovery, however, is not all that it seems because in dollar terms, the exchange is still down more than 18 percent.
In some cases, the devaluation of the peso has been both a boon and a burden for the same Mexican industry. Auto exports are soaring while domestic sales are slumping badly. For example, exports of the Ford Motor Company of Mexico have increased 50 percent since January. The company recently announced $450 million worth of direct investment, mostly in plants dedicated to producing exports.
At same time, however, few Mexicans can afford a new car and Ford's domestic sales have plummeted. In the first five months of the year, Ford sold 10,999 cars and trucks, a drop of 20,579 from the same period in 1994.
Chrysler's domestic sales are down 75 percent; General Motors 40 percent. Volkswagen, which still produces the Beetle in Mexico, has also been hit hard. It sold 503 Beetles in May, compared with 6,283 in May 1994.
THOSE harsh domestic realities have many investors nervous, notwithstanding the bullish macroeconomic indicators.
"They've really got a recession going on," said Scott Kalb, manager of the Smith Barney International Asset Management Fund. "They are going to have some very poor earnings results come out for the second quarter. They've got a tough political situation and plenty of potential for political problems, labor problems and social unrest."
Mexico's plaza economy is better reflected in the eyes of the weary than in Government figures, but statistics give a sense of the difficulty facing most families.
Of all the bad signs, unemployment is the worst. Mexico's national statistics institute estimates that more than two million people are unemployed, double the number of last December. That comes to an unemployment rate of 6.3 percent, the highest since figures started to be collected 12 years ago.
But those official figures are unreliable because virtually anyone who earns anything is counted as employed, even someone who sells gum at a traffic light. President Zedillo's own Labor Secretary, Santiago Onate Laborde, doubts the figures, saying at a news conference recently that the number of unemployed workers was closer to six million.
The only thing that seems certain is that unemployment will get worse as the recession continues. Few new jobs are being created, but this year nearly two million Mexicans will enter the work force.
Government officials expect the numbers for the second quarter of this year to show the economy contracting by as much as 5 percent, and they forecast no growth at all until the end of the year at best. The leaders of several of Mexico's most important business groups told President Zedillo last week that if the economy did not start to improve soon, there would be more unemployment, more business closings and more social unrest.
Life is hard even for those who have jobs. The minimum wage has gone up twice since December, 7 percent the first time and 12 percent the second, but still stands at no more than $3 a day. Contract wage settlements have averaged around 12 percent, with 8 percent more in fringe benefits. But inflation for the first six months of 1995 reached a compounded rate of 33 percent and even under the best of estimates will come close to 50 percent for the year.
The price of gasoline, produced only by the state oil monopoly Pemex, will have increased 48.5 percent by the end of the year, pushing up prices for everything that moves by truck. Even the price of tortillas, the flat corn pancakes that are a daily staple, has risen twice since the crisis began.
As part of its plan to avoid hyperinflation, raise revenues and suppress demand, the Government increased the national value-added tax to 15 percent, from 10 percent, on April 1.
THAT in itself produced a spike in inflation for the month of April to a post-devaluation high of 8 percent, but the shock was great enough to stop demand short, theoretically limiting a spiral of price increases.
To survive the falloff in retail sales -- down at least 40 percent in the first four months of the year -- many store owners are opening earlier and closing later. And like the Mexico City pizza shop that now serves breakfast or the Chrysler dealer who turned his showroom into a car wash, they are willing to try anything.
Even the rich have been hurt. The number of billionaires in Mexico declined this year to 10, from 24, but there is no need to feel sorry for them. The net worth of Mexico's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu, whose holdings include the Mexican telephone company, was cut in half but still totals $3.7 billion.
Mr. Slim has said in interviews that he has no doubt Mexico will bounce back from the crisis, and perhaps be even stronger than before.
For their part, international investors and analysts say they are fairly confident that the harsh medicine that Mexico's leaders have administered will be enough to revive the economy.
But they are still uncertain whether, after all the pain and hardship caused by this latest crisis, Mexico will make the long-term changes necessary to correct fundamental problems in its economy.
They are still looking for some clearly defined Government policy to create the millions of new jobs needed each year to account for Mexico's high birth rate. They are hoping to see a plan for building on the export advantage offered by the devaluation, which is rapidly being eaten away by inflation.
And they are waiting to see how Mexico intends to increase productivity and efficiency to compete with other Latin American countries as they shake off the effects of the Mexican crisis.
Out in the plaza, plenty of angry people are also waiting. For them, it will take more than a continuing stream of good news from the palace to keep the anger from boiling over.
