HEADLINE: Economic Growth Leaves States In Best Shape Since Early 80's

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
An economy that has been growing for more than four years is finally shining on state governments, easing the way for nine of them to make significant cuts in taxes and allowing many to increase spending on popular programs like education and prisons, according to a survey published today.
For the first time in a decade, the National Conference of State Legislatures reports that states, on average, have reduced taxes by more than they raised them. The survey did not examine whether some of these reductions simply represented shifts of programs to county and local governments. 
 The report, a preliminary look at state finances for the 1995 fiscal year, which ended in June, and for the current year, was released on the eve of the organization's annual meeting, an event that draws 3,000 state legislators and other state officials.
It called the states' finances "the best they have been since the early 1980's." In general, the states' tax revenues in the 1995 fiscal year grew twice as much as state budget planners had predicted.
But much as the report encouraged officials, it also brought warnings that the best was probably over. With the economy slowing and Congress planning to cut aid to the states and shift responsibility for some Federal programs to them, tax collections are likely to slow and spending to rise, making new surpluses harder to build.
As the delegates gathered in Milwaukee today for the opening session, it was the specter of Federal cuts that most dampened enthusiasm over the states' improved revenues.
"We are not sure what the actions of Congress will be," said Jane Campbell, the assistant minority leader in the Ohio House. "The discussions about block grants are not so much about giving the states power as they are about reducing Federal expenditures."
Fearing that Congress will be tempted to balance the Federal budget on the backs of the states, Ohio is using its surplus as a "state savings account, a rainy-day fund" equal to 5 percent of the state's total tax revenues, Ms. Campbell said.
Indeed, expectations of rough times ahead are widespread.
"I think this is the high-water mark," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany. "Budgeting was easy for the states this year. The only decision was whether to cut taxes, and if so, how much. Now they're worried about the changes coming out of Washington. They recognize that they might hit a brick wall."
What is more, in some states, tax cuts were fueled not by robust economies but by the political agendas of their Republican governors. In New York and New Jersey, for example, Governors George E. Pataki and Christine Todd Whitman have each made deep income tax cuts despite facing serious budget problems.
In both cases, Democrats have criticized those cuts as political sleight of hand that will simply shift responsibilities for government programs from the states to county and local governments -- pretty much the same kind of cost shifting that states now fear as a result of Federal budget cuts.
The organization's report is an incomplete picture of state finances because it was prepared before 16 states could supply material in time for the meeting. Among the 16 is California, the nation's most populous state and, by some measures, the state with the weakest economy.
For the past year, California's unemployment has hovered around 8 percent, the highest of any state, surpassing even West Virginia, which has the nation's most chronic unemployment. But despite the burden of helping the unemployed, California's economy, too, is brightening.
Kevin Eckery, a spokesman for the California Finance Department, said that tax receipts for the year ended in June had exceeded projections, even surpassing the peak three years earlier. Gov. Pete Wilson, who is seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, has proposed a 15 percent cut in business and personal taxes in the 1996 budget, which has yet to be enacted.
For the states, a balanced budget -- that is, tax revenues that match or exceed spending -- is more of a necessity than a political promise. Because of legal and political constraints, states do not have the luxury enjoyed by Congress and the White House of routinely running deficits and issuing debt to cover the deficiencies.
While states often borrow to build roads, hospitals or government buildings, they must generally keep their spending in line with their income.
Thus in October, when the next Federal budget is enacted and some Federal programs are turned over to the states, governors and legislators will face some difficult decisions over taxes and spending.
Even the larger of the states' budget surpluses are "far from spectacular," the report warned -- almost the automatic reward of a growing economy. The report said that the current surpluses "represent a return to what might be considered normal or prudent levels" after a long period of dangerously low reserves beginning in 1989.
William T. Pound, executive director of the conference, predicted that in view of the prospects for the next Federal budget, cuts in state taxes had about run their course. "Many legislators feel their revenue will not be sustained," he said.
Some improvement in state finances had generally been expected. As the economy grows, more people go to work and pay taxes, and businesses collect higher profits, which are also taxed. But tax revenues rose 6.4 percent in 1995, about twice what had been expected.
An increase in jobs and new eligibility controls for welfare programs in 1995 also meant that the states were required to shell out less than they had expected for their share of the principal Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Connecticut, Iowa and Michigan reported the largest savings -- 10 percent or more.
But in coming months continued reductions of that magnitude could be difficult. The Federal Government has been spending a little more on welfare this year than last, and it is likely to require that the states assume more of the cost.
Of the 34 states that provided budget reports, 24 reported a strong enough growth in tax revenues to allow spending increases. Two others stuck with their original spending goals, and eight spent less than they had planned.
Of 44 states that reported tax changes last year, those enacting the largest cuts were Michigan, New Jersey, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Washington, Arizona, Utah, Montana and Delaware. In sum, these 44 states cut taxes by $700 million more than they raised them -- "the first net state tax reduction since 1985," the report said.
New York would move into first place on that list, the report said, if all the tax cuts enacted in the last two years are realized.
In most cases states cut personal income taxes, but some also made sharp reductions in business taxes. Sales taxes were cut only slightly. Vermont extended a 5 percent sales tax that it had planned to cut, and South Dakota extended coverage of its sales tax to more businesses. Several other states found another way to raise revenues with new or extended taxes on hospitals and health maintenance organizations.
In general, states reported plans to slow spending growth in areas like environmental protection, economic development and aid to local governments. They were also planning for faster growth for welfare, all levels of education, prisons and Medicaid, the health program for the poor.
Utah, with a fast-growing youth population, plans a 14.2 percent increase in spending for students through the 12th grade, the nation's largest increase in education, and Nevada, also young and growing, plans the largest increase for colleges -- 11 percent.
But spending to operate prisons that states have been building to relieve overcrowding, the report said, is "by far the fastest area of state appropriations." On average, states have budgeted an increase of 13.3 percent, and that does not include construction costs.
Florida leads the nation with a 50 percent increase, or $500 million more than last year's level. The state will spend another $97 million for new prisons.

HEADLINE: Bolivia's Chief Struggles to Fulfill Promise to Indians

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia

 BODY:
By way of explaining his promise to shift political and economic power to Bolivia's majority Indian population, President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada says his reformist zeal probably stems from feeling like an outsider in the United States as the child of an exiled Bolivian diplomat.
"I know what it's like to be different from the rest and to be shut out of the mainstream because for a long time my family was banned from this country," Mr. Sanchez de Lozada said in an interview. 
 While many Bolivians questioned whether Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, a member of the white aristocracy that has ruled Bolivia for centuries, could understand the plight of the disenfranchised, high hopes surrounded his election and promise in June 1993. Bolivia, South America's most impoverished country, had long neglected its indigenous people, most of whom live in deep poverty in the countryside.
Today, at the halfway point of his presidency, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada is struggling to make good on his promises while facing growing public disenchantment with his policies and violent demonstrations by labor unions and opposition political groups. But Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, who is 61, has made some headway in carrying out reforms that could radically change the economy of Bolivia and give its Indian population an equal voice in government.
If his reforms are successful in uplifting Bolivia's rural Indians, they could serve as examples for other Latin American countries, which are facing increasing demands from long-marginalized indigenous populations for political and economic power.
Perhaps the most significant change under the President's program is an extensive decentralization that gives poor municipalities and Indian villages a much larger percentage of federal money that they can spend as they see fit.
Previously, Bolivia distributed its revenue-sharing funds according to where they were produced, meaning that three large cities received about 90 percent of the money. This year, rural towns received about 40 percent, or some $255 million, of the federal funds for things like roads, schools, soccer stadiums and water and electrification projects.
"It's very exciting because we are seeing democracy working the way it should: the people are spending their money the way they want to spend it," the President said.
But critics, mainly officials from big cities that now receive less federal money, say the plan is flawed because it puts money in the hands of municipalities that have no experience managing it and are prone to corruption.
The Government has also taken steps to integrate indigenous culture into mainstream life. For the first time, Bolivia has legalized indigenous organizations and the practice of folk medicine, and it has allowed bilingual education in Spanish and local Indian dialects. Before, schools were prohibited from teaching in any other language than Spanish.
While these measures and the decentralization plan have had an immediate influence on the average Bolivian, most of Mr. Sanchez de Lozada's reforms are not expected to show results until long after he has completed his four-year term. The Constitution limits presidents to one term only.
Bolivia, a landlocked country of seven million people, desperately needs foreign investment to reduce poverty and create jobs. According to the World Bank, about 70 percent of the population lives in poverty and unemployment stands at 30 percent.
Among the major reforms that Mr. Sanchez de Lozada is racing to complete before the end of his term are the privatizing of state-owned industries and the overhauling of the education system, goals that he had hoped to achieve in his first two years in office.
In many ways, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada, who speaks Spanish with an American accent, is an unlikely savior for Bolivia, whose indigenous people make up 70 percent of the population.
He was born in La Paz but went to the United States when a year old after his diplomat father, Enrique, was exiled in the 1930's for his opposition to the Government. After being educated in the United States, at a Quaker grade school and the University of Chicago, Mr. Sanchez de Lozada returned to Bolivia at the age of 21 to make a fortune in mining and later enter politics.
"Have we bitten off a little too much in trying to make these changes?" he said. "Sometimes I think that we have, but we are going to keep on chewing."

HEADLINE: Dutch Settlers Start Boom in Texas Dairy Farms

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: STEPHENVILLE, Tex.

 BODY:
It is near midnight on Friday at the Cutting Horse saloon, and only nine boisterous young men remain. They are drinking Coors Light and speaking Dutch.
Martin Van Beek, a thatch-haired blond, jumps from the table and, seizing the Country and Western duo's microphone, belts out a bawdy, foot-stomping Dutch ballad about life after work on a dairy farm. 
 Every Friday after the weekly cow market closes, these men, all in their 20's and 30's, blow off steam at the Cutting Horse. The rest of the time they feed and milk cows.
More than three centuries after the Dutch settled the city that became New York, and a century after the peak of European immigration, scores of these men have fled the crowded green pastures of the Netherlands for the oak-dappled ranges of north central Texas and a land that for them can still open doors to riches and opportunity. Content to leave oil and cattle to Texans, the Dutch have reinvented the Lone Star state's dairy industry.
Since the late 1970's, Dutch immigrant dairymen -- along with second-generation Dutch-American dairymen whose parents settled in California and Washington state -- have been moving into a 100-square-mile area around Stephenville, little more than an hour's drive southwest of Fort Worth. In combination with a few large dairy farmers from the West Coast, they have made this area the state's leading milk-producing region.
Other Dutch immigrants have settled east of Dallas around Sulphur Springs. No other areas in the state produce much milk.
The Dutch own fewer dairy farms than longtime Texans own, but they own most of the newest, most efficient and biggest farms. Some have herds of more than 1,000 cows, 10 and 20 times more than the typical dairy farm of the Midwest and Northeast. They have brought Texas from next to nowhere in milk production to sixth in the nation, after California, Wisconsin, New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota. They also win disproportionately high numbers of industry awards for dairy farm management.
"It ain't a walk in the park," said Mr. Van Beek, who is 30 and single and started his business here six years ago. With no established credit, it can be hard to borrow from American banks to expand, he said, and hard to meet the state's environmental regulations prohibiting the runoff of animal wastes into the Bosque (pronounced BAHS-kee) River. "But if you work hard and have luck, you can get something accomplished," he said.
Sherry Webb, editor and publisher of Texas Dairy Review, a monthly newspaper published in Stephenville, said, "Martin's a perfect example of the Dutch here. He loves America. He will never move back. He keeps asking, 'Do I sound Texan yet?' "
Mr. Van Beek has yet to master the inflections of Texas English, but he is fluent in milking profits from cows even as the economics of milk production have chopped the number of the nation's dairy farms from 282,000 in 1984 to 150,000 last year.
The influx of Dutch dairy farmers has stirred some uneasiness here. A persistent rumor has it that the Government of the Netherlands subsidizes them with low-interest loans -- an assertion that the dairymen and the Netherlands embassy in Washington flatly deny. Merchants call them tightwads who invest freely in milking and processing gear but little in homes and good living. One young Dutchman lived in his milking parlor until health inspectors forced him to buy a trailer home.
They are also blamed for attracting state and Federal regulators. Small farmers used to get away with letting their waste pollute groundwaters and the Bosque River. But the volumes of waste soared with the arrival of the bigger Dutch and West Coast operations, so all farmers had to start hiring lawyers, putting up with regular inspections and investing in lagoons and other devices to protect the river and the water table.
For the most part, however, the Dutch are accepted. Bob Traweek, a longtime Texas dairy farmer in his sixties, who also raises peanuts and cattle, said, "They're willing to sacrifice and do things our older folks are not willing to do."
No one keeps track of just how many Dutch dairymen have settled in Texas. Arnold Parzer, agricultural counselor at the Netherlands embassy, estimates that over the last 15 years, 100 first-generation dairy farmers have moved into the state, nearly all here and in Sulphur Springs. The Stephenville-area telephone book now lists almost a column of names like De Vries, De Wit, De Jong, Houtsma, Talsma, Vander Lann, Van Leeuwen, Vander Linden, Vander Meer and Viss.
Few are Miss Liberty's impoverished huddled masses yearning for freedom. They grew up on farms on the lowlands of the Netherlands and yearned to follow their fathers into the business. But chronic surpluses of milk in Europe have led to quotas to reduce production, stifling initiative and opportunity. The cost of land is forbidding, too. Mr. Parzer said a hectare in the Netherlands -- 2.4 acres -- costs $80,000.
Usually in the Netherlands, the management of most farms is passed on from parents to just one offspring. So younger children who want to stay in the business sell their interest to the managing sibling and bail out for Texas. Compared with the Netherlands, getting started here strikes the Dutch as laughably cheap.
A real estate agent in Stephenville, Ron Koonsman, has listed a 430-acre farm for $748,000, including the land, sheds and dairy equipment -- but not the house. That comes to $1,411 an acre. In the Netherlands that much land, though more fertile, would cost $14.3 million.
Mr. Van Beek was 19 and in college when his father died and an older brother took over the family's farm. "It's just not enough to support two families," he said. So he sold out, and at 22, a year after college, he went off on his own.
For two years he worked at farms in Alberta, Canada, then moved to Stephenville where he leased a farm, left it and leased another. A year and a half ago, he bought an abandoned turkey farm. Today he owns 225 acres, leases 220 more, and has a herd of 600 Holsteins -- six times the size of his brother's herd. Immigration laws are not much of an obstacle, since the laws allow for visas for jobs like these and provide for the admission of foreigners who invest in a business and hire American workers.
The Dutch immigrants seem to acclimate easily to the local culture, donning boots and cowboy hats, buying second-hand pickups, drinking American beer and insisting that their children speak English at home. Still, some work in wooden shoes, and the single men -- the majority of the newcomers -- tend to marry the second-generation daughters of Dutch dairymen.
In Stephenville, nearly 40 families -- half first-generation Dutch, half second and third -- belong to a 10-year-old outpost of the Christian Reformed Church, a conservative cousin of the Dutch Reformed Church. Their 29-year-old pastor, the Rev. Elliot Vander Lugt, is an American of Dutch descent. Three years ago the church opened the Stephenville Christian School, and Rev. Vander Lugt says 40 of its 100 students come from Dutch families. The language of both the school and the church is English.
For years, the influx of both Dutch and West Coast American dairymen stirred little concern here. Texas produced less milk than the state consumed, so there was business enough for all. But production now exceeds consumption, here and nationwide, and that holds prices down. For a decade, the price farmers have gotten for their milk has been stuck at around $1.10 to $1.20 a gallon.
Meanwhile the costs of farming keep rising, and old, less efficient farms, unable to keep costs below their revenues, have had to close or sell out. Corporate dairy farms have more than made up for the production of the 3,800 family farms that closed from 1984 to 1994, leaving only 4,200 in Texas. The population of dairy cows surged 26 percent in the decade, and milk production grew 68 percent.
George De Vries, 40, a second-generation Dutch-American dairyman, was one of the first here, and his is now the second-biggest farm around Stephenville after the single corporate farm in the area. He moved from Washington state in 1978 at 17, leaving behind his parents and 10 brothers and sisters. All five brothers have gone into dairy farming, including one who followed Mr. De Vries to Stephenville.
The De Vries dairy is an immense, pristine establishment. Inside the farm gate stand structures of concrete and steel, with none of the litter or abandoned machinery seen on many farms.
"We're milking 1,200 cows," said Mr. De Vries, wearing starched and ironed, pale blue coveralls. Off in one corner, a giant composting machinery turns mountains of manure into bedding for cows that sleep and eat nearby in open-walled sheds. "It's just unused feed," he explains. "You can feed it to heifers," or adolescent cows. The cows, each with a plastic identification number riveted to each ear, roam between the shed and an adjacent grassless lot. They are set out to pasture only during the two months of the year when they are dry of milk.
Most dairy farmers milk twice a day. But the enriched rations the Dutch serve their the cows, laced with molasses to whet lethargic appetites in the 90-plus-degree Texas heat, produce prodigious volumes of milk and immense pressure on udders. So three times a day, Mr. De Vries guides his herd into his glistening steel and battleship gray milking parlors, where each typically yields close to three gallons of milk a day.
"They're all good dairymen," said Harold Parks, a third-generation Texas dairyman, whose own business, with 450 cows on 300 acres, is still holding its own. "They come from good dairies over there. They're just here to make a living."

HEADLINE: Jordanian Is Lionized In Israel

BYLINE: By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: TEL AVIV

 BODY:
In the three months since he arrived as Jordan's first Ambassador to Israel, Marwan Muasher has become a celebrity, although sometimes a reluctant one.
He is a sought-after guest at dinners and receptions. He has appeared on television. He gives lectures. He has been interviewed by the Israeli press. 
 But when news photographers have tried to coax him into casual shots on the beaches and streets of Tel Aviv, he has declined, preferring instead the more sober setting of his office.
Back home, pictures of him at ease in Tel Aviv might cause criticism, especially from Muslim opponents of the peace treaty that Israel and Jordan signed in October. But Mr. Muasher insists that the problem is his own discomfort with star status.
Almost nine months after Israel and Jordan made peace, their peoples still view each other differently, forming a fault line that Mr. Muasher has had to straddle.
"The reception here is overwhelming, to the point where the Ambassador in some cases is almost treated as a celebrity," Mr. Muasher said, sitting in his small office, part of a hotel suite that is serving as Jordan's Embassy until permanent quarters can be found.
"People invite the Jordanian Ambassador many times because they want the Jordanian Ambassador to be there, not because they want to listen to what he has to say," he said. "And when you start focusing on the person rather than on the issue, I get worried."
Mr. Muasher, the 39-year-old former spokesman for Jordan's delegation to the Middle East peace talks, holds a doctorate in computer engineering from Purdue University in Indiana, but has specialized in public and media relations during his career in government. He is only the second Arab ambassador in Israel. Egypt has had one since signing its peace treaty with Israel in 1979.
The Israeli embrace of Mr. Muasher and his measured response mirror a larger reality. While Israelis pour into Jordan to visit and want to establish economic and cultural relations right away, ordinary Jordanians have been more reserved, lagging behind the peace policies of King Hussein and the Government in Amman. Some Jordanian professional groups have punished members who have had dealings with Israelis, and relatively few Jordanian tourists cross the border.
Mr. Muasher tries to allay concerns that relations with Jordan will turn out to be much like Israel's cool -- some would say icy -- peace with Egypt.
"The peace we seek is a warm one," he said in a recent lecture at Tel Aviv University. But he cautioned that it will take time. The Jordanian Government cannot force normal relations on its people, he said, adding that Israeli "over-eagerness" had raised fears among some Jordanians of economic and cultural domination.
Many Jordanians of Palestinian origin feel that there is still unfinished business, like the future of Palestinian refugees, Jerusalem and Jewish settlements in the West Bank.
"While Jordanians want to wait until all the political and economic problems are resolved before building relations on a people's level with Israel, Israelis tend to minimize existing problems and assume they do not affect their dreams of becoming part of the region," he said at the university.
In general, the Ambassador said in an interview, living in Israel has given him a better sense of Israeli hopes and fears.
Israel's terrain reminds him of home, he said, as do the names of Palestinian families with branches in Jordan. But he said he had been apprehensive at first about living in a country that used to be an enemy, and it intrigued him to discover that Israel is a mixture of the West and the Middle East, more raucous and faster-paced than Jordan.

HEADLINE: The House: Battlefield of Short-Tempered Partisanship

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Simmering with short-tempered partisanship, the House of Representatives has become a battlefield where Democratic obstructionism confronts Republican cockiness. The main casualty seems to be the timeliness and legislative efficiency that once marked the new Congress.
Last week, Democrats forced the House to hold 16 procedural roll-call votes, on such matters as "tabling the motion to reconsider the motion to order the previous question," or "that the committee rise and report the bill back to the House with a recommendation that the enacting clause be stricken." 
 They lost every one, but kept the Republicans from passing more than one of the three spending bills they had planned to act on last week. And what those 16 time-consuming votes on parliamentary gobbledygook showed was that the Democrats are learning the few tricks available to a House minority, to get even, if just for a moment, for what it regards as unfair treatment and to build a feeling of unity among the oppressed.
But the occasions that prompted their delaying tactics showed that the Republicans have learned to savor the power of the majority: enlarging the Ways and Means Committee to make room for the latest Republican convert; changing procedural rules midway in the debate on foreign aid spending to prevent an effort to bar aid to Indonesia, and forcing the House to work until midnight Thursday to create a four-day weekend beginning Friday.
The Republicans emphasized that power just before midnight Thursday by announcing new rules that would not only bar some of these dilatory procedural motions next week, but would also limit to 10 minutes each debate on all remaining amendments to the Department of Interior spending bill, including those dealing with the future of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, barring offshore oil drilling and curtailing the Endangered Species Act.
House Republicans insist that such moves are necessary so that they can pass 12 appropriations bills as planned before leaving on Aug. 4 for summer vacation. But they are working more late nights than they expected, and they may yet miss that deadline.
In the confusion, even committee members frequently do not seem to know what is in the bills before them, and the House is risking its reputation for knowing the substance of legislation better than the Senate.
The tie-ups on the floor are the strongest evidence of partisan disarray, but there is nothing in them original enough to take a patent out on. Democrats used to bully Republicans, of course, and change the rules or stack committees. And Republicans used to tie the House up in parliamentary knots.
That was last year, when the Democrats had the majority.
But in fact there is more flat-out partisanship in the House today, because it spreads out from the floor to reach committees, which were once largely free of it, especially the Appropriations and Ethics Committees.
On Tuesday, for example, the Appropriations Committee voted to eliminate all money for the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Representative Jim Ross Lightfoot of Iowa, a subcommittee chairman, described the agency's $3.4 million budget as "damn high-priced advice." He suggested that the Council, formed in 1947, could be replaced by a group of volunteers "or they could subscribe to the Kiplinger letter."
Democrats battled to save it, saying they had never interfered with appropriations for the Bush and Reagan White Houses. Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the senior Democrat on the Committee, called the move "a blatantly political act" as well as "a very dumb thing to do on its merits."
Only two Republicans spoke up for the cut. Several others kept their mouths closed when a voice vote was taken. But when a roll-call followed, they supported the change. Not one of the 28 Republicans joined the 16 Democrats in opposing it in a party-line vote.
There are examples of partisanship in other committees, too, from Science to Banking, and there is probably a simple explanation for it. Speaker Newt Gingrich is in control of committees, having picked their chairmen. No Democratic Speaker in recent times had that authority.
That influence, despite the occasional kind words exchanged by the President and Mr. Gingrich, is clearly behind the Appropriations Committee's moves to kill programs the President feels most strongly about, from the National Service Corps to the education program, Goals 2000, which grew out of efforts by governors of both parties to set national education standards.
Thomas E. Mann, a Congressional scholar at the Brookings Institution, said: "Committees at this stage are very much creatures of the leadership and its agenda. There is relatively little deliberation going on in committees." The committees were behaving like the relatively powerless of the British parliament.
In the Judiciary Committee, proposed Constitutional amendments are being sent to the floor unscathed, neither amended, sharpened nor softened as a result of either expert testimony or debate among committee members. That practice of reporting out a measure the way it was introduced, with witnesses merely for show, was also reflected in the vote on the Council of Economic Advisers. While Mr. Lightfoot's subcommittee heard 174 witnesses, it never asked any of them about abolishing the council.
The one committee the Speaker does not control is the Ethics Committee, because it is equally divided between five Republicans and five Democrats. But it has routinely split on party lines when it deals with how to proceed on complaints filed against the Speaker himself. In 1988, the last time a Speaker was accused of ethics violations, Democrats and Republicans decided to hire an outside counsel to give their inquiry credibility.
In general, Republicans perhaps flattered by the way the Democrats seem to imitate their own tactics of the recent past. "The Democrats are getting the feel of their role as a minority party," said Representative Bob Walker of Pennsylvania, who used to lead the parliamentary charge for Republicans against a Democratic majority. He complimented the Democrats on dreaming up at least one obscure excuse for a vote that he had never thought of.
And Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader, said Friday that there was nothing really new about partisanship in the House, but that the Democrats were having a hard time of it because they were "still grappling with what was a very unexpected and very bitter disappointment," losing the right to run the House after 40 years in power.
He acknowledged that Republicans were still "struggling to learn" how to run the House. He admitted that the 10-minute limit for debate on amendments was tight, but said, "We've lost a lot of time."
Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who serves as one of his party's full-time hall monitors trying to expose evil in Republican practices, replied: "This is the final mockery of their talk about running the place with a combination of efficiency and fairness. Gingrich is busy with his book tour and Armey isn't up to it."
The delaying tactics are only used intermittently.
Speaking from experience, Speaker Gingrich recently told Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, that the longest he could hope to maintain a full-fledged stall was two or three days. Democrats stalled last Monday and Tuesday morning, then legislated until Thursday night, and probably will speak against the plan to limit debate on amendments but not throw a full-fledged roadblock.
Some Democrats have been pleasantly surprised at how much support their stalling efforts have drawn so far. "Most of us are here to do something, so it's really kind of a pain to do this," said Representative Jim McDermott, acknowledging that stalling does not come comfortably to a party whose basic goal is to pass legislation that produces an activist government.
But with the long hours, tempers are frayed even when no stall is mounted. Mr. Walker was calm enough on Tuesday. But 24 hours later, when a neutron research project he favored was threatened by Democrats who noted he seemed not to mind cutting projects for the poor, he responded by shouting:
"The Republicans are for knowledge.
"The Democrats are for welfare."

HEADLINE: Newspaper Executives Gird for War of (Last Two) Tabloids

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
For years, the experts have held that financial troubles at New York City's tabloids were the market's way of saying that New York could not be a four-newspaper town.
The market finally spoke, with a vengeance, when an executive flew in from Los Angeles last week and, after 10 years of losses, closed New York Newsday in an instant. 
 Suddenly finding themselves in a three-newspaper town, newspaper people began to focus on a new question: What will the market say next?
Most importantly, it was clear that what had been a simmering three-way tabloid battle could suddenly become an unpredictable tabloid war between two men who have ego as well as dollars invested in the newspapers they own: The New York Post and The Daily News.
For the city's third newspaper, The New York Times, the question was whether it would continue to devote the same amount of space to local coverage, which had been increased during the years New York Newsday published. Times executives said yesterday that they would not retreat.
But there was no question that most of the attention was on Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the millionaire real estate developer who owns The Daily News, and his much wealthier rival, Rupert Murdoch, both of whom were suddenly in a new game. "I think they each want to win," said F. Gilman Spencer, a former editor of The News. "I think Murdoch would like nothing better than to eat Zuckerman with his morning oatmeal, and I think Mort would feel the same way."
The News, with a daily circulation of 725,599, and The Post, with a circulation of 408,204, differ greatly. The News is a working-class, broad-distribution paper that is cultivating a readership in the city's ethnic neighborhoods. The Post, under Mr. Murdoch, has developed a strong conservative voice that has sometimes seemed aimed more at winning political points and annoying The Times than doing battle with the other tabloids.
The consensus now, however, is that Mr. Murdoch faces a choice between sticking to a course that some newspaper analysts say is akin to running a vanity press, and diving fully into competitive newspaper publishing in the city.
John S. Reidy, a newspaper securities analyst at Smith Barney, said the death of New York Newsday would present Mr. Murdoch with possibilities. For example, he said, The Post could invest in a Sunday edition, which it has tried before, unsuccessfully. Most papers make the majority of their money with their Sunday issues, and the fact that The Post publishes only from Monday to Saturday has long been cited as a weakness.
For the six months ended in March, New York Newsday had an average circulation of 216,000 daily and 194,000 on Sundays. The News's Sunday circulation was 974,000. The New York Times's average circulation was 1,170,869 daily and 1,770,504 on Sundays.
Mr. Murdoch and his top aides were meeting in Australia yesterday and were unavailable for comment. But one person with close ties to the city's publishing executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said what was privately on the tongues of many newspaper professionals: "Murdoch has an advantage of exceedingly deep pockets now. I think you are going to see a monumental struggle."
Last week, as word spread that New York Newsday was in jeopardy, The Post cut its price to 25 cents in Queens, Newsday's longtime stronghold. Some executives saw that as a sign that Mr. Murdoch was raising the ante with Mr. Zuckerman.
Fred Drasner, Mr. Zuckerman's co-publisher, said that The News would move quickly to improve local coverage in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan and would "make a big push in Queens to convert Newsday readers to The Daily News."
Asked for his reaction to the Newsday closing, Mr. Zuckerman said it had long been clear that the market would not support the paper. "There is not enough advertising to support two tabloid papers, let alone three, in the city," he said.
Mr. Zuckerman, who has asserted that his paper is profitable, noted that some analysts believe The Post is losing several million dollars each year. But he did not predict The Post's demise outright.
Some analysts said the Zuckerman-Murdoch confrontation might not affect The Times significantly in circulation or advertising. But The Times's news coverage has arguably been affected more by Newsday than by the other two papers.
For many years before New York Newsday began to grow in the late 1980's, critics had said The Times, which had a broad national and regional circulation, was too passive in its coverage of the city. In recent years, The Times has increased its metropolitan staff, published new local sections and given added space to local news.
Some critics, and some of The Times's own journalists, have said those efforts seemed meant to fend off Newsday, and some wondered yesterday whether the paper would now retreat.
"A sharp stick prods people, and we were a sharp stick," New York Newsday's editor, Donald Forst, said yesterday. "We were a passionate, committed news organization that covered the city in a way it hadn't been covered before. I think The Times reacted to that. Whether it will continue to cover the city with the same resources and people, I don't know."
In interviews yesterday, The Times's publisher, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., and executive editor, Joseph Lelyveld, said The Times would continue to cover the New York City region energetically. "It is not just Newsday," Mr. Lelyveld said, "but our experience in the recession has taught us that our home market is very important to the health of The New York Times, and we're going to cover it aggressively as we have been."
Mr. Sulzberger said, "The Times's commitment to local coverage is absolutely unchanged by the unfortunate demise of New York Newsday. We have invested tremendously in bringing our coverage of the New York region up to the standards we are proud of."
Jon Katz, the media critic of Wired magazine, said New York Newsday was watched by publishers across the country because of its expensive bet that a new newspaper could be built in the core of the city, instead of in the more affluent suburbs where so many metropolitan papers have focused their efforts in recent years.
"The message to newspapers across the country," Mr. Katz said, "is going to be: 'Let's not put our money in mainstream urban journalism.' That's very, very sad for newspapers."

HEADLINE: Buying an Uneasy Home For New York City Waste

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: SIERRA BLANCA, Tex.

 BODY:
New York City has the people, the drains and the toilets -- more in a few blocks than in this entire West Texas county. Hudspeth County has the land, 15 times as much as all of New York. Which is why, when New Yorkers flush, their waste often ends up here, 2,065 miles away, in an isolated, impoverished county on the Mexican border whose largest town can't even afford a sewer system of its own.
Behind these simple facts lies a tale of political intrigue, legal maneuvering and big-city money, spent to persuade Texans to accept some 225 tons a day of what New Yorkers wouldn't. For a Long Island company named Merco Joint Venture, the prize was a $168 million, six-year contract, beginning in 1992, to dispose of nearly a fifth of New York's sludge, the gunk left over after sewage has been treated. Making virtuoso use of the legal means available, Merco took only 32 days to win a state approval that normally took months. 
 Merco, based in Freeport, L.I., hired former state environmental officials, handed out political contributions and threatened to sue anyone who stood in the way. Public relations costs alone had reached $598,000 by January. A $1.5 million contract to study the project's environmental effects went to Texas Tech University, which endorsed it even before the study began. Merco put more than 40 local people on its payroll, including a former county sheriff and his wife, a county auditor and several relatives of county employees, as well as a state game warden.
The company's efforts have split Sierra Blanca (pop. 700), an unincorporated county seat, pitting neighbor against neighbor, weekly newspaper against weekly newspaper, rancher against rancher. Some here have only scorn for their new neighbors from New York (pop. 7,322,564).
"They shouldn't be wearing cowboy hats," one rancher, the late Sam Dodge, said after the newcomers arrived. "They should be wearing toilet lids."
The protesters deterred the county judge, the highest local elected official, from seeking re-election, and promoted state regulations that cool the Texas welcome for New York wastes.
While experts disagree on sludge's benefits and safety, local foes say it is poisoning their land and fouling their air. They are already skirmishing over the renewal of the Merco contract, which expires in three years. They portray Merco as an outsider of the most sinister sort, citing court testimony that two of the company's partners paid tribute to a former Mafia boss several years ago, an accusation Merco has denied.
When the Hudspeth County Commission sued to halt the project in 1992, Merco responded so strongly that the commissioners, fearing that the legal battle could cost them their property, dropped the suit. When the leader of the local opposition and an Environmental Protection Agency official joined forces with Michael Moore, the documentary film maker, in a critical television report, Merco hired a legal team that included a former Maryland Senator, Joseph D. Tydings, to file a libel case seeking at least $16 million.
In legal filings and public pronouncements, Merco says what it calls "biosolids" are environmentally correct fertilizers that can make arid, overgrazed rangeland more fit for cattle. They are also reviving the county's economy, Merco executives say.
One of the Texans Merco hired is George Fore, a lobbyist and rancher who looks something like the Marlboro Man's uncle. Mr. Fore has no apologies for the way the company muscled the application through state agencies. "We got that done in record time," he said. "But even in your business, you don't take a number and stand in line. You try to get ahead of everybody else."
Merco urgently needed to jump the line. Federal laws had banned New York from dumping its sludge at sea after July 1, 1992, and Merco won the contract to haul much of it away. The firm had planned to take it to Oklahoma, but opposition there roused the state to impose requirements that might have taken a year to fulfill.
Merco says it could not locate a place to dump the sludge in New York, which has struggled for decades to find room to dispose of all its wastes. Finding the required 40,000 or more acres of reasonably flat land elsewhere turned out to be the easy part. The brother of a Merco partner who lived in Houston heard of the Mile High Ranch in Hudspeth County. A failed housing development and golf course, it has 128,000 acres, eight times as many as Manhattan.
Merco arranged to buy the land for $4.5 million, also paying $20,000 to a title company owned by the county judge, Billy Love. Merco had no choice, Mr. Fore said, because Mr. Love's title company is the only one in the county.
Mr. Love says that Merco in no way bought his support. "They had no need to bribe anybody," he said, pausing over a lunch of chiles rellenos and reflecting on the residents' outcry. "This is what they called it -- bribery. But they have poured untold dollars into this community."
Mr. Love -- dubbed "the sludge judge" -- says objections to the $20,000 payment helped keep him from running again. He now promotes Merco's cause in his weekly newspaper, The Southwestern Sun News, while the weekly Hudspeth County Herald takes the opposite view.
Merco's crucial triumph, however, came in Austin. Merco first hired Mr. Fore, a former Texas Water Commission official. He suggested that Merco hire Susan E. Potts, a savvy Austin lawyer, who in turn brought in Cliff Johnson, a former Water Commission board member and now an aide to Gov. George W. Bush Jr.
They recommended that Merco apply not for a dumping permit but for a beneficial-use registration, which could be issued by the Water Commission without potentially messy public hearings.
Still, the commission had more than 60 other applications on hand, and Merco's was the largest. The commission usually responded in months, not weeks or days. But Mr. Johnson was able to make sure that Merco's application did not get lost in the stack.
Meanwhile, Mr. Fore began asking Texas Tech officials if they would like $1.5 million to study the Merco project. A week after Merco applied to the Water Commission, Sam E. Curl, dean of the university's College of Agricultural Sciences, sent the state panel a letter stating that the college and two departments "fully endorse" the project.
"Our personnel are excited about the potential benefit of this project to the agricultural economy so essential to Texas," he said, in part because the project would train or employ some graduate students and faculty members.
Texas Tech officials say that Merco agreed to let them carry out objective, independent research. "They would not be able to tell us what to do," said the project leader, Ronald E. Sosebee. "They could not direct our research at all." So far, he said, Texas Tech has found increased grass growth and decreased erosion with no buildup of heavy metals. "Everything we have seen so far is positive," he said.
Ed Clarke, a spokesman for the Water Commission, now called the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission, recently confirmed that the Texas Tech letter had sped his agency's action. "We expedited it," he said. "It was just a matter of moving it up to the top of a stack."
Sierra Blancans hardly knew what had hit them, or what was about to. They first heard of the project from El Paso newspaper reports in March 1992, said the leader of the opponents, Bill Addington. The Hudspeth County Commission sued to stop the project, although Mr. Love recalls that he objected. Ms. Potts quickly filed a countersuit for Merco. The commission promptly backed down.
For others in Sierra Blanca, however, it was only the start of a long fight. Residents now choose between the town's two general stores based on which side they favor. At Mr. Addington's establishment, the Guerra & Company General Merchandise Store, the windows boast more protest signs -- "Don't Mess With Texas" and "Don't let New York, Chicago, New Jersey and California turn our Rio Grande communities into toxic waste dumps" -- than a 1960's campus bulletin board. The rival R & G Grocery has ordered employees not to discuss politics on the premises.
Mr. Addington, 40, is a third-generation resident, but his flowing hair and ardent manner make him seem like a community organizer from a distant campus. His tour of the ranch, now called Sierra Blanca (literally, White Mountains), in his battered Camaro Z28 afforded a view of the dark brown clumps of New York waste.
"People are saying Merco has made our name Sierra Negro," Mr. Addington said. On a hot, dry day, the smell is distinctly fecal, though not as bad, most residents say, as when it rains.
He has found an ally at the E.P.A. in Hugh B. Kaufman, Assistant to the Director of the Hazardous Site Control Division and a persistent whistleblower. Mr. Kaufman has unsuccessfully asked the Attorney General to name a special prosecutor to investigate his agency's handling of the case. The agency says his views do not represent those of the E.P.A.
Some Sierra Blancans point to 1992 testimony by a former leader of the Lucchese crime family in a Brooklyn racketeering trial unrelated to Merco that two Merco partners had paid the family tens of thousands of dollars. Jon Masters, a lawyer for Merco, denied this. Even if they had made the payoffs, he said, they were only the Mafia's prey, not affiliates. "A Mafia connection?" he said. "When you're a victim of extortion? That doesn't flow."
Merco executives readily confirm that they have tried to cultivate Texas politicians. One Merco project manager donated $11,000 to Ann Richards's failed campaign to remain Governor. "We're doing business in Texas," Mr. Masters said. "That's the way the political system works."
Mr. Fore allows that several employees have political connections, but says in a town of 700 and a county of 3,000, everybody's related to everybody else and thus has ties to local government.
His own tour of the ranch, where cattle now graze, seems to be modeled on a Sierra Club wilderness walk. Thanks to the sludge fertilizer, he said, overgrazed land has tripled its productivity. "This is some of the best grass you can see in the whole state of Texas," he said.
The sludge, some 225 tons a day, arrives in red railcars. It is dumped into spreaders the size of large trucks, which heave it high into the air as they roll across the ranch. About three dry tons are spread per acre per year, about a salt shaker's worth per square foot.
To affirm that the sludge is sanitary, Mr. Fore shows off container seals, documents and logs. But sometimes the system fails. Merco was fined $12,800 for spreading sludge in 1993 that was not processed to meet the state's requirements for reducing microbes capable of causing disease.
Although Colorado and Arizona have welcomed New York's waste, many food processors refuse to accept produce fertilized with sludge. Among experts, a consensus in favor of using sludge on arid rangeland is lacking.
John Peverly, a Cornell agronomist, said Merco's low rate of sludge application could only improve the soil. "It's so nutrient-poor out there, it can make quite a difference," he said. But John Duda, a microbiologist who taught at West Virginia University, said spreading sludge was not worth the risk of contaminating water supplies. "If it's not very good for the ocean, it sure as hell is not good for the land," he said.
But in a mostly Hispanic county where two of five residents subsist at poverty levels, many say they can't be choosy about their opportunities. Steve Gibbs, president of the local community development corporation and Sierra Blanca's only bank, punches a calculator to determine that Merco's annual revenues from its contract are close to Hudspeth County's total personal income.
"It's very unlikely that Hudspeth County is going to be able to go out and compete with El Paso or Dallas for industry, unless we have some natural resources," Mr. Gibbs said. "Well, we have land."

Chart: "Why New York Sludge Found Its Way to Texas"
 
1924 -- New York City begins dumping sewage sludge, the solid byproduct of the sewage treatment process, at a site 12 miles from New York Harbor. Sevewral decades later, the Federal Government concludes that dumping has damaged the inner coast.
 
1984 -- The Environmental Protection Agency picks a new dumping site, 106 miles off the coast of Atlantic City.
 
1988 -- Congress bans the ocean dumping of sewage sludge after medical waste from other sources begins washing up on beaches. As a long-term solution, the city plans to build five plants by 1998 to turn sludge into fertilizer and similar products. In the short term, the city signs contracts toship the sludge by rail to rural areas. One company, Merco Joint Venture, initially plans to dispose of sludge in Oklahoma and Texas, but opposition in Oklahoma prompts the company to focus its efforts on Hudspeth County, Tex.
 
JULY 1992 -- The ban takes effect, and the first train loads of New York sludge roll into Texas.

HEADLINE: Tussaud's and Movie Chain Join Disney in 42d Street Project

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Clearing the way for the redevelopment of 42d Street, Madame Tussaud's, the famous London wax museum, and AMC Entertainment, a movie theater chain, have reached agreements to open new attractions in the city's old theater district, people involved in the transactions say.
The agreements appeared to fulfill a requirement set by the Walt Disney Company, which has a tentative contract to rehabilitate the New Amsterdam Theater but threatened to pull out unless the city met yesterday's deadline to attract two more entertainment companies to invest in cleaning up the seedy block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. 
 Public officials and executives from each company involved declined to confirm the agreements until final terms are reached with Disney. Executives from Disney's development unit, based in Burbank, Calif., are in New York trying to complete their plans, and an announcement could come this week, sources said. "We are continuing to work," said Catherine Cary, senior development manager for Disney Development Company, "and negotiations are going well."
Disney has until July 30 to decide if it will go ahead with a $34 million restoration of the 92-year-old New Amsterdam theater, to be financed primarily through low-interest loans provided by the city.
Another Disney executive, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the success of the stage version of "Beauty and the Beast" had accelerated interest in the overall project. "'Beauty and the Beast' has proven to be a gold mine," the executive said. "You can't kill it with a gun. Disney would like to open something else soon." One show under discussion as a follow-up is a stage version of "Mary Poppins," to open next year or in 1997.
After nonstop negotiations in the last few days, Tussaud's and AMC agreed to join Forest City Ratner, a Brooklyn-based developer, to take over the site of the old Empire, Liberty and Harris theaters on the south side of 42d Street, spending a total of $150 million to create a 335,000-square-foot complex housing robotic and interactive wax exhibits, a 25-screen movie theater and more stores.
Tussaud's, London's top attraction with 2.6 million visitors a year, is expected to invest about $30 million and occupy 60,000 square feet. It is unclear how much AMC will invest, but the company, based in Kansas City, Mo., will operate New York City's largest movie theater, with 130,000 square feet and 4,900 seats. Officials involved in the talks estimate that AMC and Tussaud's will each attract about two million visitors a year.
Tussaud's officials did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Benjamin Fox, a partner at New Spectrum Realty Partners, AMC's broker in the project, said he could not comment. The city is spending $13 million to condemn the buildings but is not providing any public subsidies like those Disney is receiving for the New Amsterdam project.
As the first entertainment company to express publicly an interest in 42d Street, Disney jump-started long-stalled efforts to revive the former center of live theater in the city. In January 1994, the announcement that Disney might renovate the New Amsterdam "kind of blessed 42d Street," said John T. Livingston, the president of Tishman Urban Development Corporation. "It told everybody who was circling that this is an important project." In May, Tishman joined Disney to win a bid to build a $303 million hotel and entertainment complex on the northeast corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
But the executives at Pearson P.L.C., Tussaud's corporate parent, had recognized Times Square's potential value as a tourist attraction long before Disney entered the picture. For more than two years, Pearson, which operates many top theme parks and attractions in the United Kingdom and Europe, negotiated to develop an entertainment complex at One Times Square, best known as the site where the ball drops on New Year's Eve. But in March Pearson was outbid by Lehman Brothers, an investment banking firm, to buy the tower from a French bank. Pearson then attempted to buy the site from Lehman, but those talks fell apart.
People involved in the current talks with Disney said officials of the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the New York City Economic Development Corporation plan to bring executives from Tussaud's, AMC and Disney together with Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for a huge, festive announcement on 42d Street, possibly in the next few days, once Disney's contract is final.

HEADLINE: Carpenters' Union Readies For Supervised Election

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
The job now pays $360,791 a year, and on Thursday voting begins to determine who will get it: the presidency of the carpenters' union in the New York region, a union long beleaguered by corruption and mobsters.
As part of a government drive to reform the union, the election will be overseen by court-appointed monitors and investigators. And for the first time, the president and other officials will be elected by the membership instead of by delegates chosen by leaders of union locals. 
 Federal prosecutors say they have opened an investigation into allegations of fraud and bribery in the administration of the $1.5 billion pension and welfare funds of the District Council of New York City and Vicinity of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, the parent group for 17 locals in the city, Long Island and northern suburbs. Council officials, with trustees from employers' trade groups, determine how the funds are invested and select the lawyers, accountants and consultants who manage them.
The council's president, Frederick W. Devine, is opposed by three candidates in his effort to win a second four-year term. Some 24,000 active and retired members are eligible to vote in secret balloting from Thursday to Monday.
Mr. Devine's opponents assert that he has bestowed extravagant benefits on himself and his allies while the union's treasury has been depleted and about 40 percent of its members remain unemployed.
They contend that District Council officials doled out lucrative jobs at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center to their friends and relatives and to members suspected of having ties to organized crime.
Union officials are also accused of dipping into pension and welfare-fund reserves to subsidize companies that failed to make required benefit payments for their employees. The payments, the authorities say, were made in behalf of several companies controlled by mobsters or linked to relatives of union officials.
Besides receiving more than $210,000 annually and a car as president of the council, Mr. Devine is accused of secretly getting a $150,000 salary and a $25,000 allowance for a second car as the administrator of a special fund financed by contractors. The fund, the Labor-Management Cooperation Fund, was established in 1993 to promote jobs. But Mr. Devine's opponents say he has used it to pad his salary and to buy campaign advertising.
Two of Mr. Devine's sons, a daughter, a daughter-in-law and his brother-in-law are on the union payroll.
Mr. Devine, 57, was a defendant in a civil racketeering suit brought in 1991 by the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan against the District Council's leaders and several mobsters. The suit was settled last year in an agreement that called for the appointment of Kenneth Conboy, a former Federal judge, as an investigator to look into wrongdoing and to supervise the direct elections of council officials.
Mr. Devine denied charges raised in the civil suit that he had accepted kickbacks from contractors and that he was tied to organized-crime figures. He declined to be interviewed.
John Abbatemarco, the council's first vice president, who supported Mr. Devine when he ran as a self-proclaimed reform candidate in 1991, is seeking to succeed him. Mr. Abbatemarco, 43, said in an interview that Mr. Devine had disillusioned him by running the union through secret deals.
Another candidate, John J. Greany, 54, a union member for 37 years who has never held office, contends that the union has been dominated by Mafia groups since the 1950's. Describing himself as "a maverick and a dissident," Mr. Greany said he had never earned more than $40,000 a year as a carpenter because union officials refused to assign him to jobs.
Also opposing Mr. Devine is Patrick J. Harvey, the president and business manager of Local 608, the city's largest carpenters' unit, with 4,300 members. Mr. Harvey, 55, describes the secret salary Mr. Devine gave himself from the Labor-Management Fund as a prime example of mismanagement.
Law enforcement officials said that Roger M. Levin, a former lawyer for the council, has become a cooperating witness in an expanding Manhattan grand jury inquiry into possible fraud and bribery in the handling of the District Council's pension, health and welfare funds. The officials said that Mr. Levin has admitted giving kickbacks to trustees who authorized unnecessary legal fees. Mr. Levin, who is awaiting sentence on charges of filing false reports to the Internal Revenue Service, declined to be interviewed. The District Council, in a report to the United States Labor Department, noted that it had paid Mr. Levin's firm $2,158,026 in fees in the 1993-94 fiscal year.
In another aspect of the investigation, Arthur M. Blau, who was an accountant for the council until last year, was indicted on July 6 on Federal charges that he kicked back thousands of dollars to an unidentified trustee of the funds in return for obtaining union work. Mr. Blau pleaded not guilty. The union reported paying Mr. Blau's accounting firm $1,554,110 in fees in the 1993-94 fiscal year.
"The carpenters' union won't be cleaned up by a single election," said Herman Benson, the executive director of the Association for Union Democracy, a group that monitors civil rights for union members. "The rank-and-file members must be convinced that the Government and law enforcement are there for the long haul and will protect their rights until all the bums are thrown out."

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The Commerce Department reports business inventories and sales for May. 

Forecast: Inventories up 0.3 percent, after having risen 0.8 percent in April. Sales rose 0.4 percent in April.
 
This will be a busy week for quarterly earnings reports, most notably from banks and high-tech companies. Today, First Chicago is expected to report earnings of $1.71 a share; Microsoft, 61 cents, and Archer-Daniels-Midland, 34 cents.
 
Tuesday
 
The Commerce Department releases the May trade balance. Forecast: a $10.7 billion deficit, following an $11.3 billion deficit in April.
 
The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee holds a hearing on revising health insurance policy.
 
The House Economic Workforce Protections Subcommittee holds a hearing on the reorganization of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.
 
Bankers Trust New York is expected to report earnings of $1.15 a share; Chase Manhattan, $1.33 a share; Citicorp, $1.70; I.B.M., $2.39, and Intel, $1.02.
 
Wednesday
 
Alan Greenspan delivers his semiannual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on the economy to the House Banking Committee.
 
Commerce Department reports housing starts for June. Forecast: up 4 percent.
 
Archer-Daniels-Midland, under a Federal antitrust investigation, is scheduled to hold its quarterly board meeting.
 
BankAmerica is expected to announce earnings of $1.50 a share and Caterpillar, $1.57 a share.
 
Thursday
 
Apple Computer is expected to report earnings of 90 cents a share; Compaq Computer, 86 cents.
 
Friday
 
The Bank of Japan is scheduled to release its quarterly economic outlook, including its forecast for Japan's money supply growth for the July-September quarter.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Jennifer Lockhart, Matthew Nespole

 BODY:
Jennifer Lynne Lockhart, the daughter of Judy and Gregory Lockhart of Caribou, Me., was married yesterday to Matthew Eric Nespole, a son of Carol Lee and James Nespole of New York. The Rev. David Wood, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Bates College Chapel in Lewiston, Me.
Mrs. Nespole, 22, and her husband, 24, are graduates of Bates. She is a program assistant at the Tinker Foundation in New York, a nonprofit organization that gives grants to environmental and economic development organizations in Latin America. Her father owns G. L. Technology, a computer retail and service store in Caribou. Her mother teaches English and math at Caribou Middle School. 
 Mr. Nespole is an admissions officer at the Trinity School in New York, where his mother is the assistant to the director of development. His father is a partner in the New York office of Fulbright & Jaworski, the Washington law firm.

HEADLINE: The Winds Change For Claudia Shear: Now, She Blows Back

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
NOTHING in Claudia Shear's off-the-wall employment history has prepared her for her oddest job experience of all: being in demand.
Once, as an unemployed actress, Ms. Shear was so desperate for work she took a job answering phones in a Manhattan brothel. But these days, when the telephone rings in her Brooklyn apartment, the calls are often from Hollywood, conveying offers for her to star in romantic comedies or develop sitcoms or attend exclusive film workshops. 
 "I'm standing in the kitchen stirring pasta and beans, and Jeffrey Katzenberg calls," Ms. Shear said. A look of wonderment crossed her face at her own dropping of the name of the well-known movie executive, who recently formed a movie company with Steven Spielberg, the director, and David Geffen, the producer. "It is all getting a little Bunuel," she added.
That the turnaround in her life should remind her of a movie by the Surrealist film maker is a measure of how far Ms. Shear has come in the year and a half since her one-woman Off Broadway show, "Blown Sideways Through Life," opened to critical raves and played for six months to sold-out audiences. The play is an angry, moving account of the people she met and the tasks, bizarre and humiliating and mundane, that she performed over the course of taking up and then giving up a total of 64 menial jobs in her years as a struggling New York actress.
The rise of Ms. Shear continues on Wednesday at 10 P.M. as her play, tapered just a bit for the time constraints and primmer programming of public television, makes its debut on American Playhouse. Filmed in a frenetic seven days in Manhattan last December for $600,000, the teleplay features a heavyset Ms. Shear, clad in a blue organza gown, recounting her sometimes wrenching, frequently hilarious, adventures in the world of work.
The 32-year-old, Brooklyn-born actress, who has waited on tables, taken messages for doctors and even acted in a risque Italian movie (her part ended up on the cutting-room floor) says television seemed a much more appropriate vehicle than film for "Blown Sideways Through Life." Because the play deals with the everyday frustrations and incongruities of life in the most ordinary of jobs, Ms. Shear said she thought the piece demanded the broader audience television can deliver.
"There was an amazing range of people who came to see the play," Ms. Shear said recently as she sat in a bar in Greenwich Village, nursing a club soda. "That is why I believed it had to be on TV. I think both myself and the subject are accessible. If it had been a movie, it would have ended up at the Angelika, being shown to 50 people," she said of the movie theater complex in Greenwich Village known as a showcase for foreign and independent films.
In some ways, "Blown Sideways" is a daring choice for American Playhouse. Although one-person plays are not new to television, Ms. Shear's piece is not exactly "Mark Twain Tonight." It is, rather, a more personal and idiosyncratic play that may seem, by some viewers' standards, a tad racy, with its occasionally salty language and its colorful yet affecting portrayal of life in the whorehouse where Ms. Shear answered the phones.
Lindsay Law, the executive producer of American Playhouse, said some public television stations would not have run the stage version of the play. "It's tricky," he said. "It mostly has to do with an accumulation of language; when a 60-minute piece is completely sprinkled with questionable language, they can get quite hysterical. And there were several things in the whorehouse sequence that had to be removed. It's a reminder that this country diverges enormously on what it finds acceptable."
Ms. Shear is philosophical about the cuts demanded of some of the more explicit sexual references in the script. "We did have to cut a few things, which I regret," she said. "But I can't think that anyone could watch my piece and think that it is prurient or obscene. And to be fair, I think there are things I can say in person that are much more brutal if they come off your TV set in the house."
The delicacies of adaptation aside, what drew Mr. Law to the project, he says, was its wisdom about a topic that rarely gets such tender treatment. "I loved that it was funny, but I also found it tremendously moving," he said. "In New York, you see how horrible people are to service people. They really are just horrible."
The writing of "Blown Sideways Through Life" was an act of desperation by a woman who is eager to escape what seemed to be turning into a life sentence in the service industry. It all started three years ago in the offices of the New York Theater Workshop in Manhattan, where Ms. Shear, exhausted by the years of rejection for acting jobs, came to ask James Nicola, the workshop's artistic director and a longtime friend, to help her find an agent.
Instead, Mr. Nicola told her to find a pen. After years of hearing her tell tales about her life, he knew she had a natural gift. "She was a great storyteller," Mr. Nicola said. "She would come to visit us here, and I would notice that work would stop, people would gather around to listen to her stories. I thought, well maybe there was a way to focus her energy and make it pay off."
Ms. Shear, a classically trained actress with a lifelong love of books, started scribbling, and during the next two years, she worked with Mr. Nicola and another friend, Christopher Ashley, who would become the play's director, to fashion the monologue. The opening night at the New York Theater Workshop changed her life.
"I had 50 messages on my phone the next morning," said Ms. Shear, who is much slimmer than she was when the teleplay was shot, and has long blondish hair that falls in delicate curls. "After 15 years, it was overnight."
Suddenly she was a person of importance, the object of compliments from the likes of Stephen Sondheim and Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg, who also began calling, she said. Soon Ms. Shear was in Hollywood talking deals and collecting screenplay assignments. Robert Redford invited her to Sundance. The book version of "Blown Sideways" was published in the spring by Dial Press, and she has been cast in a movie, "Body Language," a comedy that may be shot this year. She says she is also writing a screenplay about two sisters who hate each other.
The desperate job hunt, it seems, is over.
"I'm not a wannabe," Ms. Shear said, finishing her club soda. "I'm a be."
