HEADLINE: Jackpot! The Lowly Slot Is a Cash Cow

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
SLOT machines are like pop songs, offering minute variations on established themes, with hooks to grab your attention. Some of them actually talk, telling the gambler in a coy digital voice, "Fill me up," or "You look like a winner."
They flash and pop and twinkle with multicolored charts that reveal a bewildering combination of payouts. The 25-cent machine that Norma Silverstein of Camden County is playing at the Trump Taj Mahal this morning has a handle that sets the fruit salad combinations spinning, as well as a button that does the same thing. But the button merely clicks; the handle comes down with an audible, ratcheting, satisfying crrrrunch. 
 And when the cherries or oranges or bars line up, the machine spews quarters into a thin, acoustically shaped metal pan that amplifies the sound until you can almost feel it in your teeth. Mrs. Silverstein loads her coin cup, puts more quarters in. In the low, indirect pink background lighting, the reels of the machine glow brightly. Her face relaxes, her mouth in a half smile. "I go here to be alone, to tune out the world," she says later. "To be honest, I'm very happy not seeing anyone or saying hello to anyone."
 These days, it is people like Mrs. Silverstein -- and not her husband, Robert, who is off playing blackjack -- who are keeping Atlantic City in business. Over the past decade, the casinos' revenue from table games -- blackjack, craps, baccarat, roulette and the others -- has barely budged. Revenue from slot machines has doubled. "They have become the most important revenue source in the casino industry," said Brian Ford, a Philadelphia-based gambling industry analyst for the accounting firm Ernst & Young.
These days, casino employees come up to slot players and ask them if they want a complimentary drink or a sandwich. These days, high rollers -- people who play machines that take up to $500 a pull, or who come to Atlantic City's 27,000 slots several times a week -- can qualify for the same luxurious comps that used to be reserved for table players, from chauffeur-driven rides to shaking the hand of Wayne Newton.
This aggressive pampering of slot players has helped keep the Atlantic City casinos afloat at a time of growing competition with those in other states (notably the Foxwoods casino in Connecticut, now the nation's largest in terms of gross revenue). But it also worries experts on gambling, who say that of all casino games, the slots may be the most seductive because they allow compulsive gamblers to be alone with their addiction.
"They see the coins coming down, or they're getting comps, and they think they're beating the system," said Edward Looney, executive director of the Council for Compulsive Gambling. "But they're not beating the system. They're paying for the system."
Most slot machine players aren't compulsive gamblers, of course. Most, like Mrs. Silverstein -- who plays once a week, and leaves her automatic teller card, credit cards and jewelry at home -- understand that the odds are against them in the long run.
The average machine has a "hold rate" of 92 percent: for every $100, it returns an average of $92 and keeps $8. These odds are actually more favorable for players than those of many table games, but what the slots have going for them is sheer volume. The average hand of blackjack, or round of dice at craps, is 30 seconds. A single pull at an Atlantic City slot machine is six seconds.
Multiply those numbers by about seven million players a year, and you begin to understand why the casinos are winning almost three times as much from the 25-cent slot machines alone as from blackjack tables. It's why the average Atlantic City slot machine generated $113,000 in revenue last year, and why Showboat is the most recent casino to join a trend in Atlantic City: in May the casino reduced the number of table games, from 130 to 88, to make room for more slot machines. In April Merv Griffin's Resorts closed its Rendezvous lounge, the most famous "little room" in the city, and put in more slot machines.
Elsewhere in town, comedians have stopped telling the joke that nobody tans in Atlantic City because the casinos haven't found a way to put slot machines on the beach.
Standing in line at the Taj to get a roll of quarters, Norma Silverstein explains the appeal of the slot machines this way: "You feel no pain on the casino floor. When I go into the bathrooms, I can hear them talking about this one that has a daughter who is in trouble, or this one with an operation. The machines take it all away."
She takes her roll of quarters, grabs a plastic, quart-sized Taj Mahal coin cup, and searches among the 3,543 buzzing, clattering machines -- the most under one roof in Atlantic City -- for the right one.
 
THE BUSINESS
Betting on the Slots
 Everybody likes to say they saw it coming," said Mr. Ford, the analyst with Ernst & Young, "but if I told you, back in 1984, that table games would become less significant than slots, people would say I wasn't playing with a full deck."
In the early 1980's, the industry considered no-tech table games to be the essence of the business. Though gamblers stood in line to play slot machines when Resorts International became the Boardwalk's first casino in 1978, table games raked in 60 to 70 percent of the casinos' winnings. The 40,000 or so gamblers who made up Atlantic City's high-roller core were exclusively table players.
Then, in 1984 in Atlantic City, long before Las Vegas's celebrated comeback as a "family" destination resort, the tide turned. For the first time in the history of the gambling industry, year-end total revenue from Atlantic City's slot machines exceeded that of table games by a few thousand dollars. A year later, the gap widened to a few million dollars.
Today, based on 1994's figures, slot machines in Atlantic City, Las Vegas and nearly every gambling mecca in the country that has them will beat the table games 2 to 1. (After a long period in which the two cities were nearly even, Las Vegas now outstrips Atlantic City in total gambling revenue, $4.4 billion to $3.4 billion in 1994. On the other hand, Las Vegas has about four times as many slot machines and three times as many table games as Atlantic City.)
Small wonder that the machines are growing ever more elaborate and the bets are getting higher: as much as $500 on a single pull. Then there are the Megabucks machines, linked by computer to several casinos, with a jackpot that increases until somebody wins, like the state lottery. (The other day the one in the Taj Mahal was at $405,000 and seemed to be growing by the second.)
"While no one in this town has given up on the table player, the economics speak for themselves," said Herb Wolfe, president and chief executive officer of Showboat, which has the second most slot machines in Atlantic City, behind the Taj Mahal. "If a table player comes here, and loses $10,000 at craps or blackjack, about 20 percent of that -- $2,000 -- will end up as profit for the casino. If a slot player comes here and loses the same amount, $6,000 is profit for the casino, because there's no dealer, there's no supervisor, there's no pit boss."
And none of the old condescension for the once humble slot machiness. "There is no difference between a slot player and a table player," said Paul Tjoumakaris, a vice president at Caesars, holding a $500 slot token. "We value their business equally. We listen to what they want and we do everything we can to give it to them."
This doesn't mean, added Mr. Tjoumakaris (once a slot player himself), that there are no distinguishing characteristics.
"Slot players like convenience," he said. "They like to find their machines quickly, so we've widened the aisles so they can get to the machine they want without bothering other players. They want to be able to sit at their machine, so we put seats in front of the machines that turn out only one way, so that people can come and go from one machine to another without bothering each other. They like to have a change machine right at the machine so they don't have to call for a person to make the change. More and more players don't smoke, so we've put in smokeless slot pits."
And like Greta Garbo, slot players want to be left alone -- with their machines.
"That's the scary part of the business," said Mr. Looney, of the Council for Compulsive Gambling. "The way the gambling industry, and the slots in particular, appeal to the desire among people to escape what's bothering them in their lives. This isn't the place to ask if they should be doing something about what's bothering them instead of squaring off with a machine."
 
 
THE CLUBS
Luring the High Rollers
 From the deck of the Black Whale III sightseeing boat, Atlantic City looks better than ever. The beach, the casinos, shops and hotels along the Boardwalk rise proudly, a flawless series of facades. A Ferris wheel turns grandly at the end of Steel Pier.
On the boat, a trio of Dixieland musicians are playing "In the Good Old Summertime." A few among the 250 guests -- members of the Showboat casino's slot club -- try their sea legs at dancing. Two weeks ago they received invitations in the mail to come down and take a free sightseeing ride. Some got follow-up phone calls from Showboat's slot hosts.
Before computer technology enabled Atlantic City to create its first slot clubs in 1985, identifying high rollers was virtually impossible. Unlike table players, whose bets are larger and more visible, slot players spend long hours at their machines making what amount to comparatively small wagers. Change makers and slot hosts had to watch a player over many hours. Now every casino has at least one slot club, each with 800,000 to 1.2 million members, and the computer keeps score.
Slot club members get a pile of discount coupons for show tickets, casino buffets and restaurant meals, not to mention an array of coin giveaways and other freebies. Members are encouraged to insert their club card each time they play; the more they do, the more comps they can earn -- and, of course, the better the casino can keep track of how much they spend.
 Sitting in the bow of the sightseeing boat, Vicki Graydon and Rod Murray don't consider themselves high rollers. Insurance underwriters from Port Jervis, N.Y., they rarely play with more than $100 each. Still, before they joined Showboat's slot club, they came to Atlantic City just two to three times a year. Then they joined, invitations and discounts began to arrive, and they began coming more often. Lately they've been in town once a month.
"When you think about it, you'd spend as much, or more, for a vacation anywhere else," Ms. Graydon said, taking in the Atlantic City skyline. "There are lots of different places to get away to, but we like this. And we happen to be winning right now."
 
THE FUTURE
Gearing for the Ultimate
 Exactly what attracts gamblers to machines is a subject of endless study. Some like the crunch of the handle, the feel of coins in their fingers, the buzz and dazzle of lights.
Others like the opposite: interactive machines in which action is committed at the touch of a very quiet button. And it is for this player that the industry is gearing up for what some feel might be the ultimate gambling device: a totally cashless slot machine -- pop in a credit card or automatic teller card, and away you go.
Since February, Larry Cole, vice president of information systems at the Sands Hotel and Casino, has supervised a cashless experiment at the Sands, in which coin and cash giveaways are credited to an individual machine rather than put in the player's hand. The idea is to stop "coin walking" -- in which players take their free rolls of quarters and leave the casino -- and to give players a gratifying up-to-the-second readout of how many comps they've earned.
Mr. Cole said the system was passing "with flying colors," but he added that "moral problems" might keep more advanced cashless systems out of casinos for many years to come. "We're not out to destroy people on their credit cards," he said. "That's not in the best interest of the player or the casino."
Larry Mullins, vice president of marketing at the Taj Mahal, agrees. "Slot players are in it for the long haul," he said. "They want to stay with their machines as long as possible. From the casino standpoint, we want them to come here, enjoy themselves, play with what they have, go home, come back and do it again."
Mr. Mullins says he has actually stopped slot players who seem to be in over their head. "It's a touchy thing," he said, "because some people can get offended if you tell them to take a breather. But the industry is moving away from the kind of desperation that put players in financial trouble. We're here for the long haul, too."
Still, like it or not, a cashless slot system is on the horizon. Within months a casino will open on the information highway. After electronically transferring money from personal accounts to a "casino bank" based on the Caribbean island of St. Martin, gamblers will be able to achieve slot machine bliss without ever leaving home, on -- where else -- the World Wide Web.
The prospect does not particularly worry Mr. Tjoumarkaris, of Caesars. "It will be like watching home videos as opposed to going to the movies," he said. "The web system can be the home video; we're the movies. There are always people who will want to go to the movies." And the others, he went on, "will come to Atlantic City to see what they're missing."

HEADLINE: Charting the Way to a Livelier Downtown

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IN a perfect world, downtowns are bustling places, full of enticing shops, restaurants and theaters. Alas, such has not been the case here in recent years, which is why the city retained Ferrandino & Associates, planning and development consultants of Elmsford, to devise a comprehensive marketing and development plan to revitalize downtown.
In August 1994, the consultants started work on the project. Eight months later, they filed the final report. 
 "Our goal was to prepare a road map, if you will, for the city to follow," said Vince Ferrandino, who heads the company. "We developed a comprehensive marketing strategy that will position the city of White Plains to embark upon a long-term downtown economic revitalization plan, focusing on both the retail and office sectors. The retail area is centered on shopping streets that include Mamaroneck Avenue, East Post Road and Main Street. We also examined the office market and ways to increase office occupancy in the city."
Mr. Ferrandino, who was formerly Commissioner of Planning and Development for Mount Vernon and the town of Greenburgh, started his own practice in 1988. He estimated that his company completes about 26 projects, of various types and sizes, a year.
"The White Plains assignment was big in scope and more complex than most," he said. "We had four people working on it; the city wanted it to be done quickly to maintain White Plains as the county's retail center and to increase office occupancy."
The consultants began by conducting in-depth surveys for months before releasing two reports: one on the retail market, the other on the office market.
The surveys revealed strength and weaknesses, Mr. Ferrandino said.
"White Plains is one of the largest retail centers in the New York metropolitan area, in a large upscale trade area," he said. "Our findings show that while there was a general positive image of the downtown, the stores and restaurants were seen as weak. One of our recommendations to the city was to devise a retail niche strategy, which translates as 'Don't compete with the malls; instead focus on market niches that you can dominate.' "
The consultants recommended that after identifying the niches the city expand and build on them. Niches under consideration were restaurants, bridal shops and sports, musical instruments and electronics stores.
"We also suggested that new niches be created," Mr. Ferrandino said. "Those might include home furnishings and design stores, specialty food shops, arts and entertainment ventures -- all latent market niches that we think could be developed successfully for the downtown."
The report on the office market suggested that the city identify industries that would be considered prime candidates for office space and then campaign aggressively to attract them.
"Downtown White Plains is competing with suburban and regional office markets in the entire tristate region," Mr. Ferrandino said. "The key in such a competitive market place is for White Plains to identify and promote its own unique assets."
The county seat, with its concentration of county, state and Federal offices and courts, is a major asset, he observed. Highway access, the Westchester County Airport and the Transcenter, which provides direct and quick rail access to Manhattan and regional bus routes, are other assets.
"We also point out the proximity to the graduate center at Pace University and the downtown branch of Mercy College in White Plains as strong assets," he said.
Such assets, he said, would attract the type of businesses identified in the report as insurance companies, business services, medical and legal services, engineering, accounting and management companies and nonprofit organizations.
But in order to carry out the downtown marketing and economic development plan, Mr. Ferrandino said the report recommended that the business community form a local development corporation, which would be responsible for administering the business development efforts on a day-to-day and long-term basis.
"The local development corporation, which we suggested, has recently been established as the White Plains Business Development Corporation," he said. "The incorporators are businessmen long active in White Plains. They are Leon Silverman, Peter Kempner and Joseph Potenza, who is the White Plains Planning Commissioner. The city has donated $75,000, and an additional $75,000 has been given to the effort by large individual property owners, which means the corporation will start with an operating budget of $150,000."
The search for a professional director has begun, and the development corporation will use the consultants' report as a blueprint to work with retailers and owners of commercial property and to recruit new businesses.
"In the report we also laid the groundwork for an ongoing marketing promotion and public relations campaign," Mr. Ferrandino said. "We have completed a brochure and other promotional materials to be used in the recruitment effort, and they are beamed at attracting new retail stores, and office tenants. We have already implemented such activities as the Farmers Market, which will be held downtown every Wednesday, and the Grand Prix auto race each September, which brings new life and recognition to the area."
Although the consultants have submitted their final report, Mr. Ferrandino said, "We're still developing a list of hot prospects that we will give to the development office to use in recruiting tenants to fill a vacant office and retail space."
He continued: "The way we operate is to go into the market, talk to brokers and owners and see who's looking for what. Then we give the list to the development office so they can aggressively call on the tenants and property owners and put the two together."
Mr. Ferrandino's list of projects ranges from a plan for the development of the Belmont section of the Bronx, which put Arthur Avenue on the map, to current assignments like a comprehensive plan for the village of Hastings-on-Hudson and an environmental study for the demolition of the existing New Rochelle Mall, which a developer, Kenneth Narva, intends to redevelop as an integral part of downtown New Rochelle.

HEADLINE: Teen-Agers Look in Vain for Summer Jobs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
WITH few prospects for employment this summer, Tarik Curry, 16, spends most days in front of "X-Men, Children of the Atom," a popular game in the video arcade at Nathan's Famous restaurant here.
"I looked for work, but it's always the same old story," said Tarik, a student at Gorton High School in this city. "They say, 'Don't call us, we'll call you,' but they never do." 
 Jason Ko, a 17-year-old from Eastchester, had a similar story. He, too, has been unable to find a job, although he has applied for work at several fast-food restaurants and grocery stores. Like other teen-agers who have little else to do during their summer vacation, he goes to Nathan's and visits with friends there. "I'm in a waiting mode," he said. "For now, I'm hanging out."
It was the same in other parts of the county -- a limited number of jobs and many idle teen-agers, said administrators of youth employment programs. Federal money for summer jobs has been in short supply and late in coming in most cities. And the few private-sector jobs that were available early in the season have been filled.
Mary E. Rainey, a site director for the Westchester Community Opportunity Program in Peekskill, said she was worried about young people who did not find work during their summer vacation.
"They say they're hanging out, but I know it's just a matter of time until boredom sets in," she said. "I'm afraid they will get into trouble."
By last week, Ms. Rainey still had no word on Peekskill's application for $467,000 in Federal money for a youth employment program. Last year, the Job Training Partnership Act sponsored jobs for 400 low-income youths. So far this year, she has been able to place only 50 teen-agers in summer jobs.
At the Youth Bureau in Peekskill's City Hall, Carol L. Campbell, an advocate for the city's children, echoed Ms. Rainey's concerns.
"It breaks my heart to tell these kids who really want to work that I have nothing for them," she said. "Our goal is to keep them off the streets and out of trouble."
Federal funds came through this year in Yonkers, where L'Judie Matt-Simmons, Commissioner of Community Services, said she was able to offer jobs to 375 teen-agers with $500,000 from the Job Training Partnership Act -- the same amount the city received last year.
Still, close to 400 young applicants were turned away, and Ms. Matt-Simmons said she worried about "the ones who don't work: we have a problem here with gangs."
Mayor Terence Zaleski hires men from 23 to 35 years old to patrol the streets of Yonkers and refer teen-agers who who are loitering to community center programs. His Urban Street Walkers Program was formed to reduce the crime rate among the young.
White Plains only received $30,000 from the Federal Government -- $65,000 less than last year -- for summer jobs. But the city made up the difference from its own coffers, offering summer work to 150 youths, 14 to 21, in municipal offices or with the White Plains Greening Project, an outdoor conservation and ecology program, said Lois L. Perlmutter, a supervisor with the city's Youth Bureau.
She said private-sector jobs have been especially scarce this summer and speculated that many of the lower-paying jobs that often go to youths -- in fast-food establishments, for example -- have instead been filled by adults unable to find better positions.
"It's a ripple effect that we're still feeling from all of the downsizing," Ms. Perlmutter said. "Executives had to move down a notch or two, and that all filtered down."
She said that many students applied to stores in the Westchester, the million-square-foot mall that opened last March in White Plains. "But the teen-agers they used in the beginning are now being phased out," she said, "and new jobs for them are few and far between."
Neil Palmer, 20, a student at the State University of New York at Buffalo, failed to find a summer job at either of the two malls in White Plains, so he settled for $5.90 an hour working for the city's Department of Finance.
"The pay isn't great, but I took it because it's hard out there," he said. "You take what you can get."
Mr. Palmer is majoring in computer information services and said that even though his income was limited this summer, his work with the Finance Department complemented his studies.
Douglas Lin, 19, who graduated in June from White Plains High School and will be attending Harvard University in September, said he also applied to several stores but "heard nothing back."
"They didn't even seem interested," said Mr. Lin, who is working at a clerical job in White Plains City Court for $5.50 an hour.
The county continues to be one of the largest employers of young people in Westchester, although money for summer jobs was in short supply this year. Salvatore De Santis, Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, said his department offered jobs to 800 17- and 18-year-olds -- down about 100 jobs from last summer.
Competition was keen for those positions, with the county receiving several thousand applications for jobs at public beaches, pools, golf courses and parks.
Kelly Moroch, 20, a college student from Hastings-on-Hudson who is earning $8.06 an hour as a lifeguard at Sprain Ridge Park in Yonkers, said she waited five years to land that position -- working first at other county jobs, including as a cashier at parks, to get work experience and references.
At the state Department of Labor in Albany, Vincent F. DeSantis, a principal economist, confirmed that the job market remained difficult for youths, although the New York state unemployment rate for 16- to 19-year-olds dropped to 17.5 percent in the second quarter of the year, compared with 22.5 percent for the same period last year. In part, that was because fewer teen-agers were looking for work -- 70,000 in 1995 compared with 93,000 last year, he said.
But he cautioned that the jobless figures for teen-agers told only part of the story.
"What we really listen to is the word on the street," he said, "and that is that job opportunities for young people are very limited."
He added that youths living outside of cities tend to fare better in the job market, often finding work at country clubs, swimming pools, lumber yards, garden clubs and amusement parks.
But competition is keen for those positions, and Mr. De Santis urged young workers to develop a good attitude, respect for authority and "a willingness to do all sorts of jobs without thinking anything is below you."
That was the advice heeded by Jason Katz, a 17-year-old from Yonkers, who is working as a caddy at Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale.
"It's not a human job, taking orders and listening to the golfers yell, but it's O.K. for now, although I would have liked something better," he said.
At Ardsley Swimming and Tennis Club, the manager, Leo Bragg, added to the list of job qualifications for young workers. "They should be well spoken and make a good appearance, especially when dealing with the public," Mr. Bragg said, explaining that he chose only 18 from a "very large pool of applicants" to work as lifeguards, maintenance workers and tennis attendants this summer.
Administrators of summer programs are suggesting that when all else fails, young workers seeking summer employment should consider volunteering.
"Sometimes that's the only option, and it's not a bad one," Ms. Campbell in Peekskill said. She said high school students there received elective credits toward their diploma for approved volunteer work.
Mr. Lin in White Plains said that he had applied for volunteer work at Westchester County Medical Center, in addition to his other job, because he is considering a career in medicine. "Employers are impressed when you have volunteer work on your resume," he said. "It looks good."

HEADLINE: The Emerald City

BYLINE: By James Carroll; James Carroll's most recent book is "The City Below," a novel about Boston. His column on politics, religion and culture appears in The Boston Globe.

 BODY:

THE BOSTON IRISH
A Political History.
By Thomas H. O'Connor.
Illustrated. 363 pp. Boston:
Northeastern University Press. $24.95. 
"IF there had existed in the 19th century a computer able to digest all the appropriate data, it would have reported one city in the entire world where an Irish Catholic, under any circumstance, should never, ever, set foot. That city was Boston, Massachusetts." So begins Thomas H. O'Connor's book "The Boston Irish," which tells the raucous, tragic but also hopeful story of what happened when the Irish, most of them in flight from famine, dared to set foot in that city, and dared to stay.
In other places, Irish immigrants and their descendants moved rather smoothly into positions of economic, social and political power, but in Boston they were confronted by a Yankee establishment that did not want them. The stain of that rejection marked the soul of the city. Despite all appearances of patrician high-mindedness, Boston's initial hatred of the Irish remains its Original Sin. Thus, the Irish presence has been known from the start for a spirit of xenophobic defensiveness that is still evident.
But from the 19th century on, the most important and fateful conflict involving the Irish in Boston has been the group's argument with itself -- not the familiar, though still interesting, story of its combative hatred of others, whether other immigrants, blacks, Jews or the WASP upper class. Mr. O'Connor demonstrates that the familiar story is so far from the whole story that, as usually related, it is false. As he puts it, the popular image is fixed, say, on James Michael Curley sending "Yankees into fits of apoplexy by proposing to sell the Public Garden for $10 million." But it was Hugh O'Brien, the city's first Irish mayor, not the old aristocracy, who promoted the Boston Public Library and rescued Frederick Law Olmsted's plan for the "Emerald Necklace" park system, he writes.
Hugh O'Brien and James Michael Curley represent two strains of Irish political leadership in Boston -- one adept at coalition building, not only with the monied establishment but with a range of ethnic and racial groups, and the other devoted in populist fashion to the elevation of "neighborhood" interests. Mr. O'Connor contrasts bridge builders like O'Brien and his 20th-century counterparts, John B. Hynes and John F. Collins, with turf defenders like Curley and Patrick J. Kennedy and John F. (Honey Fitz) Fitzgerald. This division between "city leaders" and "ward leaders" reached a climax in the school busing crisis of the 1970's. Mr. O'Connor defines the real Boston story of those years in the words of J. Anthony Lukas: "a feud within the Irish political family."
Raymond L. Flynn, then a member of the city council, and most other leaders of the Irish neighborhoods opposed busing; but the busing was ordered by a Federal judge who was Irish-American (and a Kennedy man at that), W. Arthur Garrity, and imposed by an Irish-American mayor, Kevin H. White. Even the dispute decided last month by the United States Supreme Court about the demand of homosexuals to march in Boston's St. Patrick's Day parade (the High Court said they could be excluded) is an argument among the Irish: the gay and lesbian group that forced the issue pointedly defines itself as Irish-American.
Thomas H. O'Connor is a professor of history at Boston College and a native of South Boston and, according to Jack Beatty, Curley's biographer, "the dean of Boston historians." In this book he earns that title, embodying as he does the best aspects of the two Irish strains -- openness and loyalty. His training and erudition enable him to turn a coldly objective eye on South Boston's blatant politics of racism; "frightening" is the word he uses. But his love not only for the city but for its wards comes through as well. Beginning with the ancient travails of the Irish-English wars and concluding with the triumph of the "New Boston," "The Boston Irish" is a work of the historian-as-citizen.
Because he has mastered Boston politics' deep past, Mr. O'Connor is able to give us, in the concluding chapters, the best recounting of the contemporary scene that I have seen. It is a neglected story, often lost in the cliched perception of Boston parochialism. The truth is that while other cities have approached collapse, Boston, under the leadership of a generation of well-educated, public-spirited Irish-Americans, has reinvented itself, become energetic and open to newcomers. Even intractable problems are being faced head on: for all its costs, busing in Boston succeeded in ending government-sponsored segregation.
Mr. O'Connor makes clear the particularly important contributions of Mr. White and Mr. Flynn, who succeeded him as mayor. Each represented an opposite side of the Boston Irish tradition, but each found ways to transcend himself and enable his broad constituency to do the same. The thrust of Mr. O'Connor's story is clear: the Irish succeeded in turning hostile Boston into their own city. The question is, will they -- can they -- complete the job of turning it over to someone else?

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Settlement Reached In Big Insurance Case
Merrill Lynch, Coopers & Lybrand and a New York law firm have agreed to pay the state of Florida $100 million to settle charges involving the biggest insurance-company failure in the state's history. Florida officials said that Merrill, the nation's largest brokerage house, will pay $45 million; Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, will pay $50 million, and the law firm of Shereff, Friedman, Hoffman & Goodman, $5 million. [Page D2.]
 
Remaking Environmental Law
The drive by Republicans in Congress to change major environmental programs is expected to reach full force this week. Tonight, Republican Senators will try to pass a measure that changes how regulatory decisions are made. And a House committee is scheduled to vote tomorrow on cutting Environmental Protection Agency spending by one-third. [A1.]
 
Challenging an F.C.C. Rule
A 25-year-old Federal Communications Commission rule that limits how much television programming the networks can broadcast at night is "a mistake going back as long as 10 years," Reed E. Hundt, the F.C.C. chairman, said. The commission will decide the future of the prime-time access rule at a meeting scheduled for July 28. [D8.]
 
Detroit Papers Dig In
The six unions that went on strike Thursday and the publishers of the Detroit Newspapers appear to be digging in for a lengthy battle that could ultimately cost Detroit one of its two big daily papers. [D8.]
 
The Wrath of the Internet
Since Martin Rimm's undergraduate research paper about pornography on the information highway was published in The Georgetown Law Journal and featured in Time magazine, he has encountered scorn on the Internet. Peter H. Lewis: On the Net. [D5.]
 
First, Obscurity. Now, Success?
Bolt Beranek & Newman designed the first modem, chose the @ symbol for electronic-mail addresses and built the computer network from which the Internet evolved. Now it seems poised to cash in on the Internet's enormous growth. [D5.]
 
Saving Money on the Web
Companies ranging from package deliverers to banks are using the World Wide Web not to make money, but to save some. [D5.]
 
The World Bank as Small Lender
The World Bank is leading a drive to raise more than $200 million from international donors to provide small loans to entrepreneurs in developing countries. [A7.]
 
The Latest From Apple
Apple Computer will introduce two Macintosh models today in its consumer-oriented Performa line, offering aggressive pricing and advanced multimedia features. The company says that the new machines play to its strengths in the publishing, education, multimedia and consumer markets, and will help it regain market share this year and next. [D4.]
 
Crisis of Comic Proportions
With 59 comedies going into production this summer -- up from about 45 last year -- comedy writers have become the television industry's hot commodity. [D7.]
 
Sidestepping Orville
New spots for Orville Redenbacher popcorn products do not focus on the 88-year-old who built the company and created the snack's image. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Tech Stocks Defy Gravity and Rewrite Conventional Wisdom

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Conventional wisdom has it that the second quarter brings a slump to the producers of computers, software, semiconductors and disk drives. Not so this year.
With a few exceptions, the companies that have reported second-quarter results have met or exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates, sending already lofty prices of technology stock to new highs on an almost daily basis. 
 The exceptions, like Advanced Micro Devices and Sybase, have had product problems that say little about the group as a whole. But among the big gainers, the strong performance of issues like Motorola and Seagate Technology appears to bode well for all technology issues, as does the anticipation of the introduction of Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system on Aug. 24.
Many investors are betting that the tech stocks can continue to defy gravity through the third quarter and into the Christmas season. But some analysts caution that so powerful is Windows fever that if the introduction is even just a little slower than the buoyant forecasts, disappointment may follow for many technology companies.
The parade of strong earnings is expected to continue this week with results from Intel, Microsoft, Apple Computer, Texas Instruments, Cypress Semiconductor, LSI Logic, Integrated Device Technology, Informix Software and Sun Microsystems. Electronic Arts is expected to report lower revenue and profit, reflecting the transition to new systems in the video game market.
Making the case for bullishness, Bruce Lupatkin, research director at Hambrecht & Quist, said there has been a fundamental change in the technology industries from the old cyclicality.
"In years past, the technology market was almost self-contained," Mr. Lupatkin said. "Semiconductors went into work stations that were used to write software that was used to design more powerful semiconductors. What's happened is a dramatic proliferation of technology into consumer products, information infrastructure around the world and in corporations. All of these things came together at the same time and effectively broadened the market opportunity."
Hambrecht & Quist's analysts expect a major buildup in anticipation of a strong fourth quarter, with some weakening at the retail level during the summer as customers wait for Windows 95 and then for hardware and software that takes advantage of it.
Another factor driving up the prices of tech stocks is the major positions taken by big mutual funds, like the Fidelity Magellan Fund of the FMR Corporation. The funds now "need to be in technology," Mr. Lupatkin argued. "It's a big enough part of the economy; it's not a niche, and the market caps are large enough." The real sign that the group is topping out will be overpriced and oversubscribed initial public offerings -- something that has not happened yet, he said.
Michael Murphy, editor of The California Technology Stock Letter, is more pessimistic, saying that the tech group is at or near its peak and poised for a fall.
"This is a classic case of buy on the rumor, sell on the news, and the news is the introduction of Windows 95," he said. "I think this is going to be a successful product inevitably, but it's going to have a very slow adoption rate. If you have a slow ramp, you very quickly get price-cutting."
Previous new versions of operating systems, including Windows 3.0 and Novell's Netware 4, have taken 18 months or more to catch on. Companies are loath to switch until all compatibility issues have been resolved, and a major new operating system like Windows 95 is likely to demand more powerful processors, larger hard disks and more memory, as well as new applications, to show its best.
"It's a very expensive upgrade by the time you get done -- $1,200 to $1,500 a set," Mr. Murphy said.
Price-cutting on personal computers, he continued, would quickly ripple back through components like memory chips and disk drives, causing earnings disappointments throughout the technology group. His advice is to take profits now.
"We're down to 40 percent invested, with no PC-related stocks," Mr. Murphy said. "We're buying biotech stocks, and letting this thing play itself out."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. PROPOSING GREATER CHOICES ABOUT MEDICARE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
House Republicans have begun drafting proposals to make immense changes in Medicare, by imposing annual limits on spending in the program and by giving elderly people a choice of private health insurance plans as alternatives to the standard Federal program.
Confidential documents prepared by Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee describe numerous options that would increase costs for Medicare beneficiaries who stay in the standard program, under which the Government pays separately for each doctor's visit and each hospital admission. More than 90 percent of the 37 million Medicare beneficiaries receive care through such fee-for-service arrangements. 
 Under the Republican plan they would be allowed to remain in the standard program, but the proposals would create strong financial incentives for them to switch to health maintenance organizations; the number of Medicare recipients in H.M.O.'s is already on the rise.
"A greatly expanded choice of plan options will be made available to Medicare beneficiaries at time of initial eligibility and during subsequent annual open enrollment seasons," say the documents, which put flesh on the bones of the budget cuts already endorsed in principle by both houses of Congress. The budget plan approved by Congress last month would slow the growth of Medicare by cutting projected spending by $270 billion, or 14 percent, over seven years.
Under the main Republican proposal, the Government would make regular payments to private health plans chosen by Medicare beneficiaries. The basic Federal contribution would be the same for each person in a given market area, but it would be "adjusted for demographic and risk factors." An H.M.O. would, for example, get more money from the Government for enrolling an 86-year-old woman with cancer than for signing up a healthy, vigorous 65-year-old.
If a Medicare beneficiary chose a private health plan that charged less than the Federal payment, he or she would receive a cash rebate equal to the difference. But if a beneficiary enrolled in a private plan that charged more than the Medicare rate, "the beneficiary must pay the additional premium to the plan."
This proposal for a Government-supervised bazaar, in which health insurers compete for business, resembles the system of managed competition recommended by many health policy experts. President Clinton proposed a form of such competition in his ill-fated effort to remake the nation's health care system in 1993 and 1994.
But there is a big difference: The Republican plan applies only to Medicare beneficiaries, while Mr. Clinton wanted the Federal Government to guarantee and regulate health insurance for all Americans. He insisted on "universal coverage" and got nothing.
Under the Republican plan, the options available to Medicare beneficiaries would include health plans sponsored by employers, labor unions and trade associations. Retiring workers could stay in their employers' plans.
Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who heads the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said the documents, dated July 5, accurately reflected the "general conceptual approach" being taken by House Republicans in their effort to modernize Medicare and save its Hospital Insurance Trust Fund from bankruptcy.
But he added that the proposal would be refined as work on the legislation continued. Many Republicans have said they do not want to disclose or discuss details of their Medicare plan until they roll out a formal legislative proposal in September.
The fight over Medicare promises to be the biggest battle between the new Republican majority in Congress and the Democrats, who repeatedly accuse the Republicans of planning drastic cuts in Medicare to finance tax cuts for the wealthy.
The documents from the Ways and Means Committee show that the Republicans are considering many novel ideas. They would, for the first time, try to impose limits on the growth of Medicare, which since its creation in 1965 has been an open-ended program, purchasing health care for anyone who meets the eligibility criteria.
Under the Republican proposal, there would be "specific growth rates in Medicare outlays" for each of the next seven years. The spending targets would be set separately for Part A of Medicare, which pays for hospital care, and Part B, which pays for doctors.
"If program spending exceeds growth rates set in law," the documents say, "then outlay reductions will be triggered." Federal payments to H.M.O.'s and other private health plans "would be set in advance to meet the targets, so outlay reductions, if necessary, would be made only in the Medicare fee-for-service program."
Representative Jim McDermott of Washington, a leading Democratic spokesman on health policy, said the Republican proposal for a standard Federal payment, or voucher, would reduce the choices available to Medicare beneficiaries. "Seniors will be forced into the most restrictive H.M.O.'s," he said. "They will not have more choice because they will not have the money to buy an adequate policy. They will have to buy the cheapest policy possible."
H.M.O. patients typically pay just a few dollars for each visit to a doctor, but those in the traditional Medicare program are responsible for at least 20 percent of the fees charged for doctors' services. One of the Republican proposals would discourage Medicare beneficiaries from buying private insurance to cover that 20 percent share. The Republicans evidently believe that such Medigap coverage insulates patients from the cost of their care and encourages them to overuse doctors because they do not have to pay the patients' share of the bill, or coinsurance.
Thus, under one Republican option, "a new program would be established to encourage beneficiaries to self-insure (not purchase Medigap coverage) for Medicare coinsurance liabilities." This proposal would reduce the patients' share of doctors' bills to 15 percent if they agreed to do without Medigap insurance. But if Medicare beneficiaries chose to buy such coverage, as most now do, they and their insurers would be responsible for 25 percent of the doctors' charges.
Another proposal on the Republican list would increase the Medicare Part B deductible, now $100 a year, and raise it automatically to keep pace with medical inflation. Other proposals would require Medicare beneficiaries to pay 20 percent of the costs of home health care services, clinical laboratory services and the first 20 days of a stay in a skilled nursing home.
Yet another proposal would increase Medicare premiums for people with higher incomes. The documents do not say who would have to pay the extra premium, nor do they specify the amount. But they do say, "This additional premium would be collected annually, with payment accompanying the April 15 filing of income taxes." Under current law, Medicare beneficiaries, except for those with very low incomes, pay the same premium, $46.10 a month.
The Republicans would also give Medicare beneficiaries a one-time opportunity, at the age of 65, to set up medical savings accounts and enroll in private insurance plans covering catastrophic medical expenses. People choosing this option would permanently forgo other types of Medicare coverage and would pay most of their medical bills from their medical savings accounts.
Another Republican proposal would enable Medicare beneficiaries to share any savings achieved by the Government when they report waste, fraud or overcharges by doctors or hospitals.
But the heart of the Republican plan is the effort to create more choices for Medicare beneficiaries. Private insurance plans wishing to do business in the Medicare market would have to be certified as meeting Federal standards. Their benefits would have to be at least equivalent to those in the standard fee-for-service Medicare program, but could be delivered in different ways.
In addition, the documents say, private "health plans must agree to serve all beneficiaries in a market area on a first-come-first-served basis, up to plan capacity."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Another Proposed Pathmark and Another Debate

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
WELCOME to Pathmark II. Or is it Pathmark Too?
First came Pathmark I, the proposed supermarket in East Harlem so controversial that after years of planning, it's still on hold. Now come plans for another Pathmark megastore, this one in Springfield Gardens, Queens. And New York being New York, its fate is shaky too, even though the idea goes back six years, originated with a community organization, has the approval of the local Congressman, the Mayor, the City Planning Commission, the Borough President and half of an evenly split community board. 
 "This is ridiculous," complains Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President. "People want it and deserve to have it. On the merits there's no way it should fail."
But City Councilwoman Juanita E. Watkins, worried about traffic, congestion, security and the future of local storeowners in her Queens district, opposes the project. Council members tend to defer to their colleagues on local issues unless the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, intervenes, and so far he has stayed away from Pathmark II. So nobody is predicting what will happen when it goes before the Council today and tomorrow.
The economic argument for the store is a strong one. The city estimates that residents of the thriving middle-class, predominantly black neighborhoods of southeast Queens spend $166 million a year on food, half of it in Nassau County. The border is just a few blocks away from the proposed 17-acre site of the new store -- at the intersection of Springfield and Merrick Boulevards.
Richard Lipsky, an aggressive lobbysist for food merchants in Springfield Gardens and Laurelton, argues that those Queens neighborhoods have good stores. But others say that, as is often the case in minority neighborhoods, those stores do not provide the choice, quality or lower prices available in Nassau. "We're just hemorrhaging sales across the border," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
THOUGH still undecided about the East Harlem Pathmark, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani supports this one because it is essentially a private enterprise, Mr. Rose said. It would benefit from the same city tax break available to all commercial development outside of midtown Manhattan, but unlike the East Harlem store, it would be built without large government subsidies, and on privately owned rather than city land.
The Queens store is also unencumbered by the ethnically charged infighting that seems to have silenced, at least temporarily, the normally outspoken Mr. Giuliani. In East Harlem, the fight is between black political leaders who would share in the development of the store, and Hispanic political leaders who oppose it in favor of local shopkeepers, many of whom are Hispanic, too. That presents the Mayor with quite a problem since he has never been popular with blacks in the city and lately seems to have lost support among Hispanic New Yorkers.
In Springfield Gardens, the disagreement is between Ms. Watkins and local shop owners on one side, and most everybody else on the other, including the often contentious Queens Citizens Organization. That community group sought construction of a supermarket in southeast Queens in the first place and does not get along with Ms. Watkins. That is not the reason for her opposition, she said. "Politics be damned. I care about what is in the best interest of the community I represent, and this is not."
But the neighborhood's Congressman disagrees. "The reality is that you develop anchor tenants, like the Pathmark, around which you build," said Representative Floyd H. Flake, a champion of economic development in his community. He contends that with so many shoppers leaving the area already, building a Pathmark would not do any more damage to local stores and could actually attract more economic activity. There is no guarantee that some stores would not be pushed out. But others might well move in.
On balance, most people in the neighborhood think that the logic argues for a Pathmark, not against it. But logic does not always prevail over politics in New York.
NEWSPAPER POSTSCRIPT: Those who are not journalists must wonder why it is that those of us who are react so dramatically to a newspaper's demise. One reason, of course, is that we empathize with colleagues and realize it could have been us. But there's another reason, a more noble one, forgive the earnestness: we realize that we are in this together and that losing a newspaper means losing an enterprise whose daily practitioners do not think about bottom lines and advertising and revenue.
Serious reporters, editors and photographers -- and they are to be found in every newsroom -- are dedicated to peeling away the hypocrisy and the hype, getting at the truth, and sharing it with the public. That is why the departure of New York Newsday hurts. It means the loss of a competitor whose work made every other newspaper in the city a better newspaper. It means the loss of a partner.

HEADLINE: Budget Slashes Could Close Hospital

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
If there is a tangible symbol of Big Government, and of its ideal of providing sophisticated services to all, it might well be the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center.
The sprawling hospital is by some measures the largest in the nation and serves most of the county's poor, its trauma victims, AIDS sufferers and serious burn victims. It trains more medical residents and nurses than any other hospital in the country. It treats 500 people with leprosy. The vast majority of its patients are indigent or receive public assistance, and just 1 percent have commercial health insurance. 
 The hospital also provides thousands of jobs in one of the most economically beaten-down sections of the county, East Los Angeles.
Unfortunately, the County-U.S.C. Medical Center has another standout feature -- an annual operating deficit of more than $200 million at a time when Los Angeles County is in a serious fiscal crisis. The vast majority of the deficit is not the result of tighter finances in the county, but of budget cuts in the state capital and in Washington. Combined, the state and Federal Governments provide about three-fourths of the county's health services budget.
That is why this monument to a social and political ideal is the subject of two urgent debates: one is about the details of cutting costs and making do with less while the other, more far-reaching debate is over how many people the county government will allow to go without proper medical care, who those people will be and where people will go for what medical care they can obtain.
The county's chief administrative officer, Sally R. Reed, has proposed closing the medical center, which she has estimated would save the county almost $350 million a year, more than a quarter of the $1.2 billion budget gap it is facing in the current fiscal year. Union officials, some doctors and local politicians have called closing the center unthinkable, and a pitched battle is being fought over its future.
But whether the four-million-square-foot center is closed, or drastically scaled back, as many here expect it will be, it has become a potent symbol of the deep shift in the county government's view of itself, and of the impact that the new priorities in Congress are starting to have on the delivery of critical services.
"This represents the loss of a very noble effort on the part of the government to provide medical services for everyone," Ms. Reed said. "But we just can't do that anymore."
Douglas D. Bagley, executive director of the county's Department of Health Services and the former chief executive of the medical center, put it in plainer terms. "The question of whether we survive financially is a question of our social priorities and values," he said. "It's not a question of whether these services are needed."
Ms. Reed, like many others here, has argued that private hospitals would provide many services offered by the medical center, perhaps even more efficiently. But even officials at the private hospitals who embrace this view also make it clear that the poor would suffer.
"We're entering an age of the reality of the limits of health care," said William Parente, president of the Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center and a member of several committees from hospitals in the area studying these issues. "I fear that the result of saying we just can't spend the money is that there will be reductions in medical care for certain people. They'll be cared for, but only up to the limits of our financial capability."
Under the law, hospitals are required to provide at least initial treatment for most emergency patients. Mr. Parente and other private hospital officials have said that they would be financially capable of handling certain emergency patients, even those who are uninsured, and some Medicaid patients. But they have generally said that they would be unable to treat uninsured patients who had suffered the worst types of injuries or Medicaid patients who required expensive or long-term care.
The medical center carries a daunting burden. It is the only place where many of the patients can go for medical care, while at the same time it is at the forefront of many medical specialties, from trauma care to the treatment of troubled pregnancies.
It is a gritty and sometimes grim place. Its main waiting room, without air-conditioning, was a sea of troubled faces on a recent afternoon. In the general medical ward, there are five beds in a room, no air-conditioning and no telephones or televisions.
The medical center delivers more than 10,000 babies a year, receives more than 855,000 emergency and outpatient visits and treats 28 percent of the county's seriously injured patients.
In the intensive care ward on a recent afternoon, a 7-year-old girl who had been shot in the abdomen was sitting up for the first time in a week, surrounded by clouds of red, white and blue balloons. A few doors down, a prisoner from the county jail lay in the coma he had fallen into six weeks earlier, when he was savagely beaten.
One issue on which nearly all agree is that, though the patients of the hospital will be the most affected, they appear to have had the least influence over the hospital's fate. That is just another part of the reality of the hard-edged budget politics of the 1990's.
"Closing County-U.S.C. would be a disaster of catastrophic proportions, even more than any earthquake," said Antonio Villaraigosa, who represents East Los Angeles's in the State Assembly and has helped organize some of the many protests and marches by residents struggling to keep the medical center open.
"Unfortunately," he said, "the people of this community often don't have an avenue to support or criticize a government program, but local residents have at least tried to register their dissatisfaction."
The hospital faces two basic problems. The first is cuts in health care budgets by the Federal Government. Of the hospital's $756 million operating budget last year, the county provided just $93 million. The remainder came from the state and the Federal Government.
A total of 64 percent of the hospital's patients are on Medicaid, the Federal-state health care program for the poor. About 30 percent are indigent with no means of paying their bills. A large proportion of those patients are illegal aliens. The remainder are either Medicare patients, have commercial insurance or pay for their own care.
"The problem is not runaway expenditures," Mr. Bagley said. "The problem is not carry-over deficits from previous years. In fact, we have a surplus in most years. The problem is that 80 percent of the budget is financed from external sources, and those sources are shrinking."
The second basic problem is that private hospitals feel the big public medical centers have encroached on their business. "They should provide primary care for those who have no alternative," Mr. Parente said. "That is their responsibility, and it should stop there."
Many private hospitals in the county are operating with about 50 percent of their beds filled, on average, while 76 percent are filled at the County-U.S.C. Medical Center. Closing the medical center could thus help fill many empty beds in private hospitals.
That could potentially improve their profitability but at a cost to the county's poorest residents. "Everyone would very much like to see it survive for a long time," Ms. Reed said. "The center is a source of pride in the community. But I see this as inevitable. We cannot meet all the needs of all the needy people in the community."

The waiting area serves the center's emergency room and ambulatory-care patients. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Not a Laugh Riot: Comedy Writers in Short Supply

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.

 BODY:
Just as professional sports teams struggle to find enough quality players to fill each position during an expansion year, the number of television comedies has grown so much this year that television executives say they are worried that there will not be enough quality comedy players -- in this case, writers -- to go around.
This summer in Hollywood, 59 comedies are going into production, up from about 45 last year. The demand has been increased because of the addition of two new would-be networks -- WB and UPN -- and the growing interest among cable networks in producing original comedy programs of their own. In addition, aggressive moves to develop a base of comedy shows are being made by new production studios like Dreamworks and Brillstein-Grey Entertainment. 
 Executives at the networks and studios said that 500 to 600 writers would be required to fill the staffs of these new comedies, and that it was highly unlikely that the industry could find that many bright comedic minds.
"It's really insane," said Jamie McDermott, the senior vice president in charge of prime-time series for NBC. "All over town, bidding wars are breaking out for second- and third-level writers on successful comedies."
The battle for comedy writers has serious financial implications for a business that relies on the situation comedy for the bulk of its profits. "Are people making sensational deals? Yes," said Jeff Greenstein, a young comedy writer whose first series, "Partners," created with Jeff Strauss, will appear on the Fox network this fall. "Have prices gone up for everybody else? Yes."
Comedies are in demand because they usually attract the biggest audiences and always make the most money in syndication. Thus, the networks want prime-time schedules filled with comedies and the companies that produce shows want to make as many comedies as possible to generate more syndication revenue.
The problem of the dilution of comedy talent is made worse by the emphasis most new comedies place on writing. "The new shows are driven by smart writing," Ms. McDermott said. Her network, NBC, has set the standard for smart writing with shows like "Seinfeld," "Frasier" and "Friends."
"Friends" has become the most copied show in television. But its director, James Burrows, said: "It's silly to try to clone a show like that. The call for good writing is too demanding."
Still, the networks are trying. Mr. Strauss said he and Mr. Greenstein looked at more than 200 writers to build their seven-person staff on "Partners."
The competition for good writers is coming from everywhere, including some well-financed new production companies looking to establish themselves quickly as comedy producers.
"Both Dreamworks and Brillstein-Grey are cash-rich situations," Mr. Strauss said. Both companies have co-ownership deals with ABC. As a result, the network has backed them with cash, which they are using to sign up comedy writers at a rapid rate.
"We've been very aggressive," said Brad Grey, co-chairman of Brillstein-Grey. Among the long list of comedy writers lured to his company are former writer-producers from series like "Roseanne," "Frasier," "The Simpsons" and "Grace Under Fire." Dreamworks has grabbed important staff members from shows like "Mad About You" and "Ellen."
Mr. Grey denied that his company's recruitment blitz came down to throwing a lot of money at writers. He cited his company's quick success in getting shows on the air -- the first four comedies the company developed have made it onto network schedules -- as well as the writers' desire to "help us build this company."
Mr. Grey acknowledged that every writer lured away by Brillstein-Grey and Dreamworks created a hole on an existing show that needed to be filled. "We've brought a lot of writers into the fold who've done well elsewhere," he said. "From that perspective we've caused other people a lot of problems."
A senior executive from another production company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Grey's heavy-wallet approach was damaging the economics of the business. He cited a former producer-writer from one series whom Mr. Grey had lured away with a two-year deal worth about $5 million. That was more than double the amount the writer might have received elsewhere, the executive said.
What troubles some industry executives, including Ms. McDermott, is the raiding of young writers who may not be ready to take on their own series. "It's the most frustrating thing in the world," she said, adding that as more comedies get onto the air, more and more talent with less and less experience is getting raided.
Mr. Greenstein agreed. "People who have not had the experience of growing with a show or even being in the editing room or casting, these people are getting high-dollar deals," he said. And that, naturally, elevates the money that has to be paid to experienced talent, he said.
The escalation of prices for writers is rippling through the industry in other ways. Ms. McDermott said that with the studios having to pay higher salaries to sign writers, they now demand longer commitments from networks for their series.
"Everybody is forced to step up," she said. "Instead of 6 episodes they insist on getting an initial order for 13. We have to give them what they want because Les Moonves at CBS is going to give them 13. So we say 13. Then all the costs go up." Leslie Moonves is the new president of CBS Entertainment.
And as salaries skyrocket, so does the pressure on hit shows. "What now happens on the first year of a successful show," Mr. Greenstein said, "is first of all the staff gets depleted because everybody rushes to grab up any interesting eligible members of the writing staff. Then the studio is already on the backs of the executive producers saying, 'We need more shows, like now.' "
All television shows generate a deficit for their owners, who count on syndication money to make up those deficits and generate profits. A strong comedy can make hundreds of millions of dollars from its repeats in syndication.
But, Mr. Greenstein said: "There could be a major reckoning this fall, when 'Seinfeld' and 'Home Improvement' go into syndication. If they don't perform as well as expected, everything is going to sink."
Indeed, at some point soon the syndication market can be expected to be as saturated with comedies as the networks currently are in prime time. Mr. Greenstein said it might become very difficult for a middling hit comedy to command an acceptable price in syndication if it had to compete with 25 others.
"At some point you start asking yourself: How much comedy viewership is there to go around?," he said. "I'll tell you, we're pushing the limits."

LENGTH: 478 words

HEADLINE: A Worthy Competitor

 BODY:
After 10 valiant years, New York Newsday has closed its doors. Its relatively brief turn on the city's stage unfortunately produced $100 million in losses. Despite staff opinion that a turnaround was possible, the paper's corporate bosses at the Times Mirror Company in Los Angeles decided on Friday to shut the paper down.
This may have been a sound economic call, but it was a sad outcome nonetheless. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani lamented a further loss of the "diversity of opinion" needed in a city as diverse as this one. He noted further that competition from a variety of newspapers produces strong journalism. 
 In the paper's final edition on Sunday, its editors and writers struck notes of pride, sorrow and anger in equal measure. There was pride in the paper's record of accomplishment, sorrow for the 700 employees who will lose their jobs, anger that a living newspaper had -- prematurely in their view -- been sacrificed to the bottom line by business managers on the West Coast.
Murray Kempton, the columnist, said on Friday, "You know, I've never been folded by strangers before." He was even more annoyed when he sat down to write his last column. "It is a very bad deed, my masters, to set a tree to growing and then kill it full of life and growing still."
The Times Mirror people obviously felt that the tree could not be saved. In the beginning, they had hoped to find a profitable niche between the two tabloids, The Daily News and The New York Post, and the upmarket New York Times. That niche turned out to be small. Essentially a hybrid, New York Newsday never acquired a sufficiently compelling identity to attract enough readers and advertising. Circulation, which peaked in 1991 at just over 300,000, declined to 216,000 this year -- half that of its next largest competitor, The New York Post.
The paper also faced the same inexorable demographic trends, compounded by a durable regional recession, that have made New York City a tough go for all newspapers. In the late 1920's, New York supported 13 citywide newspapers. As recently as the early 1960's, it supported seven. It is now back to three.
Along the way, New York Newsday gave its readers a good ride. It won three Pulitzer prizes and boasted a distinguished roster of columnists, a lively editorial page, a solid sports section and aggressive local coverage.
The editor, Don Forst, said that New York Newsday had given its best shot. "This was a gutsy newspaper. You came in and tried to elbow and knee your way, literally, onto newsstands." The Times Mirror Company made an expensive bet that a new newspaper could be built in the core of urban America, instead of in the affluent suburbs where many metropolitan papers have focused their efforts. That it did not win that bet is a sad message not only for the newspaper business but for our cities as well.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Iraq Frees 2 Americans After 4 Months

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Two Americans who had been imprisoned since they crossed into Iraq four months ago were released today by President Saddam Hussein in what American officials said was an effort to persuade the United Nations to lift economic sanctions against his country.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said, however, that the United States had promised nothing in exchange for Iraq's sudden decision to release the two men, William Barloon, 39, and David Daliberti, 42. Mr. Hussein released them after Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat, appealed to Mr. Hussein in a one-hour meeting this morning to free them on humanitarian grounds. 
 Mr. Richardson, who has adopted the role of a globe-trotting troubleshooter during the last two years, had consulted closely with the Clinton Administration before making the trip to Baghdad. He said in a statement released by his office that "there were no deals made in the meeting; there was no quid pro quo or concessions."
Mr. Barloon, of New Hampton, Iowa, and Mr. Daliberti, of Jacksonville, Fla., seemed relaxed and healthy when they appeared at the Milya-Mansour Hotel today in Baghdad alongside Mr. Richardson. In early May, both men complained of chest pains and stress and were taken to a Baghdad hospital, where doctors said Mr. Barloon had some possible scarring of tissue in his heart.
In their brief public appearance today, Mr. Daliberti would only say that it was "a wonderful day."
Mr. Barloon's brother, Edward, said in a telephone interview from his home in Rosemount, Minn., "This was a very, very pleasant surprise to wake up to on a Sunday morning." He said that not only had he not known about Mr. Richardson's trip before today, but that he had never heard of Mr. Richardson.
A spokesman for Mr. Richardson said that the Congressman had left Baghdad by car today with the two men and that they would arrive in Amman, Jordan, early Monday morning, after what was expected to be a 10- to 12-hour drive through desert.
In March, an Iraqi court sentenced Mr. Barloon and Mr. Daliberti to eight years in prison for illegal entry, although Iraqi officials often accused the two men of being spies.
The two men, who worked for American aircraft maintenance companies in Kuwait, insist that they made an innocent wrong turn across the Iraq border on March 13 when they were seeking to visit a friend at a United Nations outpost in northern Kuwait, just south of the Iraq border.
United Nations officials acknowledged that their guards had mistakenly allowed the two Americans to cross the border. As soon as Mr. Barloon and Mr. Daliberti entered Iraq, they were seized by the police.
The detention of the two men aggravated the already bitter relations between the United States and Iraq, with American officials often saying it was uncivilized to jail two people for what the Administration described as having innocently strayed into another country. Iraqi officials asserted that the two Americans could not have accidentally stumbled into their country and could have entered it for just one reason: to spy.
Appearing today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Christopher said any international efforts to ease economic sanctions against Iraq were "totally unconnected with this."
Nonetheless, Mr. Christopher said, "this is a very, very important step."
Speaking about Mr. Hussein, he added that "perhaps he was trying to court some international favor," to win easing of the trade sanctions that were imposed against Iraq to punish it for invading Kuwait in August 1990.
A White House official interpreted Mr. Hussein's decision to pardon the Americans this way: "The Iraqis have tried for some time to get the sanctions lifted. They probably have concluded that as they move into the fall and a series of U.N. Security Council reviews of whether to ease the sanctions, this is an impediment they don't need around. They concluded that not only are they not going to get anything from keeping these guys in jail, but it is a liability."
Shortly after learning about the release of the two men, President Clinton called their wives, and he had 10-minute telephone conversations with each to pass on the news.
The two women said they were overjoyed to learn that their husbands would no longer have to spend their days in Abu Ghraib Prison near Baghdad, where they shared a six-by-eight-foot cell and often had just rice and water for meals.
"Obviously I am absolutely elated and can't believe this ordeal is coming to an end," Mr. Barloon's wife, Linda, who is on a business trip in Singapore, told CNN.
Stu Nagurka, a spokesman for Mr. Richardson, said the Congressman left for the Middle East Thursday night after an intermediary had urged him to get involved in the issue.
In the statement he released today, Mr. Richardson said, "I commend the Iraqi Government for taking this positive humanitarian action."
White House officials said Iraq had sent messages for months through intermediaries that it wanted something in exchange for releasing the two Americans. The Iraqis called for unfreezing Iraqi assets, easing the United Nations trade embargo and obtaining millions of dollars in food and medicine.
Iraq's Foreign Minister, Mohammed Said al-Sahaf, suggested in May that Mr. Hussein might release the two Americans if Mr. Clinton sent him a letter requesting clemency.
Administration officials said they refused to provide a quid pro quo or a Presidential letter because they did not want to give Mr. Hussein any reward for imprisoning the two men, or to lend his Government international legitimacy by dealing with it. Nonetheless, they said they had no objections to private citizens or members of Congress approaching the Iraqis to try to win the release of the two prisoners so long as they made clear that they were not envoys of the Administration.
On "Meet the Press," Mr. Christopher said, "No letter was delivered; no concessions were made." He added that Mr. Richardson "wasn't authorized to negotiate."
The state-run Iraqi News Agency sought to portray the release of the two Americans as a response to a request from Mr. Clinton. The agency said Mr. Richardson had conveyed an appeal from "President Clinton, the U.S. Congress and the American people."
Mr. Richardson, a member of the House Intelligence Committee, went to Burma in February 1994 to meet the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who was then under house arrest but who was recently freed. In December 1994, he interrupted a trip to Seoul to go to North Korea to help negotiate the release of an American soldier and the body of another after their helicopter went down over North Korea.
When Mr. Richardson visited Hanoi a month ago, North Vietnamese officials gave him 100 pages of documents about missing American soldiers -- documents that the Administration later said were important.
To back up the Administration's assertions that it made no concessions to Iraq, a senior White House official said the Administration would continue to insist that Iraq comply with all the United Nations conditions for lifting sanctions, including eliminating all its weapons of mass destruction and accounting for missing Kuwaitis and stolen Kuwaiti military equipment.
