PUB-DATE: July 17, 1995

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1441 words

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The ambitious Republican campaign to undo major environmental programs reaches full force this week on several fronts in both the House and Senate.
One of this year's most significant environmental votes is set for Monday evening, when Republicans will try to cut off debate in the Senate so they can force through a measure to change the way regulatory decisions are made. The bill is sponsored by the majority leader, Senator Bob Dole. 
 In the House, the Appropriations Committee is scheduled to vote the next day on cutting spending by the Environmental Protection Agency by one-third, severely curtailing the agency's operations and flatly prohibiting it from enforcing central parts of several existing laws, including those on air and water pollution.
These are only two of the many lines of attack in a coordinated legislative effort that sees new developments almost every day. All over the Capitol, legislators are considering changes to the principal laws that govern mining, grazing, logging, toxic wastes, water quality, endangered species and pesticides, in each case considering proposals to make the laws more favorable to industry.
"It is clear that this is a concerted effort," said Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, in an interview on Friday. "If they can't get it one place, they try it another place. This is about shutting us down, there can be no mistake."
Under the budget proposal, her agency's workforce would be cut by thousands of employees, while under the bill on regulations they would be confronted with vast new procedural requirements, putting the agency in a double bind.
Congressional Republicans, aided by many conservative Democrats, intend to limit sharply actions by the E.P.A., the Interior Department, the Energy Department and any other agency involved in environmental programs. Their strategy is four-fold:
*Rewriting the nation's basic environmental laws, a process that takes time but is gathering speed.
*Singling out particular regulations by passing narrowly focused provisions, sometimes attaching them to unrelated bills.
*Cutting the overall budgets of the environmental agencies, sometimes abolishing whole branches.
*Altering the procedures used to write regulations, putting more emphasis on cost-benefit analysis and opening new avenues for industries to appeal Federal rules in court.
Some of the proposals are breathtaking in their potential effect. For example, the Clean Water Act amendments passed by the House would drastically reduce Federal protection for wetlands. A new survey by regulatory agencies has found that in some states almost all regulated wetlands, where development is controlled for environmental reasons, would be removed from Federal jurisdiction.
The survey was conducted by the Army Corps of Engineers, the E.P.A., and the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service. They found that using the new definitions of wetlands, almost 98 percent of all wetlands in South Carolina would be removed from Federal jurisdiction. So would 90 percent of wetlands in Georgia, 94 percent in Alabama, 88 percent in North Carolina, 75 percent in Nebraska, 65 percent in South Dakota, 71 percent in Wyoming, and more than half in Florida.
But even though the Senate Environmental Committee is about to consider a wetlands provision like the one that the House has already approved, the bill's prospects are considered uncertain in the Senate. So Republicans are simultaneously trying to put a provision in the E.P.A. spending bill that prohibits it from enforcing the existing wetlands law. And they are pressing for anti-regulatory legislation requiring that property owners be compensated for declines in property values when wetlands are regulated.
The all-out attack has thrown the Clinton Administration into a pitched battle, if a defensive one. President Clinton, who in his first two years rarely threatened a veto and never employed one, now routinely says that he will veto environmental initiatives from the Congress.
In his weekly radio address on Saturday, Mr. Clinton strongly criticized the bill limiting Federal regulations. For the past week, the Administration has worked closely with Senate Democrats as they sought to highlight the problems they see in the bill.
"This Congress is willing to adopt a regulatory system that would let polluters delay and sometimes even control the rules that affect them," Mr. Clinton said.
Although the Republicans have made some concessions in the Senate bill -- for example, eliminating a provision that would have halted clean-up projects at hundreds of Superfund sites contaminated with toxic pollutants while further studies were conducted -- the core provisions of the bill are still unacceptable to the Administration, which has pledged to veto it unless there were fundamental changes. (Republicans agreed to delete the Superfund provisions partly because they planned to rewrite the law anyway, eliminating the liability of companies for past pollution.)
But before Senate Democrats can force major changes to the regulatory bill, they must survive a motion to cut off debate altogether. Democrats are confident of defeating the first such vote, scheduled for Monday, but there will be another on Tuesday night and they are not sure how long they can hold on to the necessary 41 votes to keep the debate alive.
The votes in the Senate are being watched closely as a significant political barometer, because House Republicans have demonstrated repeatedly that in alliance with a core of conservative Democrats they have the votes to approve far-reaching environmental changes.
Environmentalists and the Clinton Administration have pinned their main hopes on the Senate, where a minority can force modifications to more radical proposals by threatening to filibuster proposals after they emerge from the House.
Even a Presidential veto is of limited use when the Congress changes environmental laws by attaching riders to spending bills, like a rider to a spending bill for the current year that would suspend environmental statutes as they apply to logging on certain Federal lands. Having vetoed that bill once, Mr. Clinton has signaled that he will accept a compromise version, which is awaiting final clearance by the Senate, even though it still includes the logging provision.
The House proposal for the E.P.A. budget makes clear the power of spending bills to influence environmental policies.
The bill would cut the agency's annual budget to $4.9 billion in 1996, a reduction of $2.3 billion from this year's spending, proportionately the biggest reduction proposed for any major Federal agency.
"The agency has headed in the wrong direction, for the wrong reasons, and in a manner which can impose unnecessary costs on American industry," said the report of the Republican-dominated appropriations subcommittee that drafted the measure. "The agency needs to recognize that there are simply not enough available financial resources to 'fix' every perceived environmental problem."
The subcommittee removed money for the agency to enforce air pollution permits, to regulate toxic air pollution from oil refineries, to encourage tough state automobile inspections, to require accident prevention plans in the chemical industry, to limit pollution from cement kilns, to encourage state car-pooling plans, to gather and publish data on chemical use, to protect wetlands, to set water quality guidelines for the Great Lakes, to write new industrial water pollution regulations, to issue stormwater runoff rules, to control sewage overflows into rivers, and much more.
Some of the toughest fights involve issues that the Administration and Congress have been struggling over for more than two years: logging, grazing and mining on public lands. Votes could be cast in all three areas within the next several days.
A Senate committee is expected to move ahead on legislation on grazing that the Administration opposes because it focuses the management of 170 million acres of public land exclusively on livestock production, which environmental advocates contend damages the land if not carefully controlled. In testimony before the House last week, Mike Dombeck, director of the Bureau of Land Management, said the bill would "set back public rangeland management 50 years."
And in the House, there is likely to be one more vote on Monday on whether to give mining companies the right to buy Federal land containing valuable mineral deposits for low prices. A moratorium on these mining patents will expire unless Democrats win a vote in the House to extend it.


GRAPHIC: Congress is considering a wide range of proposals, pushed mainly by Republicans, to overhaul environmental statutes and lessen their impact on businesses and landowners. Here are some of the major laws under review:

 Regulatory Overhaul
 A broad relief bill that changes how regulations on health, safety and the environment are written, placing more emphasis on costs and opening important new avenues for challenging burdensome regulations in court. The House has already passed a similar bill. Pending in the Senate.

 Clean Water
 Proposed revision of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 would allow new waivers of anti-pollution requirements, remove most wetlands from Federal jurisdiction and allow states to continue to emphasize voluntary, not mandatory, controls on polluted runoff from farms and other sources. President Clinton has threatened to veto the version that passed the House in May. Senate action is pending.

 Endangered Species
 Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican, has introduced legislation that would try to limit Federal regulators' ability to declare endangered species' habitats off-limits to development and force the regulators to give greater consideration to human and economic costs when developing species protection plans. The House has taken no action.

 Grazing Fees
 Senator Pete V. Domenici, a New Mexico Republican, and Representative Wes Cooley, an Oregon Republican, have introduced bills that would institute a new formula for calculating grazing fees. The fees would be more modest than the increase proposed in February 1994 by the Administration, which would have gone to $4.28 per cow per month from $1.86. The White House withdrew the plan in December in the face of violent opposition and probable defeat.

 Pesticides
 On May 23, a House Agriculture subcommittee approved a bill to make it more difficult for the Environmental Protection Agency to bar certain pesticides. Both the regulatory overhaul bill being debated in the Senate and the E.P.A. budget being considered in the House would prohibit the agency from enforcing the Delaney clause which bans cancer-causing chemicals in processed food.

 Forest Management
 As part of the spending cuts for the current fiscal year that President Clinton vetoed, Congress approved provisions to require the Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management to undertake a 30-month program to promote the harvesting of salvage timber, a measure environmentalists said would lead to harm in forests. Mr. Clinton cited the provision as a reason why he vetoed the bill, but has agreed to sign a new version that also includes it. The compromise is held up by a procedural dispute in the Senate.

 Mining
 Seeking to preempt stricter proposals to update the antiquated 1872 mining law, members from Western states, with the support of industry, have proposed bills that would impose modest royalties, limit regulations and preserve the rights of miners to take ownership of their claims. A bill has been introduced in both the House and Senate.
 The Interior Department spending bill before the House would allow the sale of public lands, which had been suspended, to resume; a vote is expected this week.

 Superfund
 Republicans contemplate a major overhaul of the program that cleans up the nation's worst hazardous waste sites. They want to eliminate the provision that can hold private businesses responsible for cleaning up waste dumped before the Superfund law was enacted. No bills have yet been introduced.
 The regulatory bill being debated in the Senate, like the one that has passed the House, would have delayed hundreds of clean-up projects so that new studies could be conducted. But the Senate, in a concession to Democrats, dropped that provision from the bill. (pg. A11)

HEADLINE: World Bank Plans Small Loans to Poor

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 14

 BODY:
The World Bank is leading a drive to raise more than $200 million from international donors to provide small loans to help poor people start their own businesses in developing countries.
Donors met on June 27 and 28 at the World Bank in Washington and created a group to oversee the program, which would provide the money to local banks that specialize in loans, training and advice to help poor people achieve self-sufficiency. 
 The loans would be as small as $100 and would be repaid with modest interest in as little as a year, generating capital for other borrowers. The group estimates that the $200 million in cash and programs pledged so far could finance credit for a million prospective entrepreneurs a year.
No money is available yet, because the agreement is awaiting approval from governing boards of the donor institutions. Ismail Serageldin, the group's chairman and a vice president at the World Bank, said the group would meet again in January 1996 to allocate funds.
"The bank is the only one of the financial institutions that works on a global basis rather than a regional basis," Mr. Serageldin said in an telephone interview from Washington.
He said the program was "new to the extent that we've never done this before, but it's not an abandonment of our philosophy" of working through governments of developing countries.
The program will tap the successes that specialized local banks have experienced in making modest loans, often without collateral, to poor applicants in countries like Bangladesh, Kenya, Indonesia, the Dominican Republic and Colombia.
The most prominent of them, the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh, had assisted two million cooperative members of the bank, most of them women with families, as of last year. The bank's loans, which average $100, help poor people support themselves by livestock and poultry-raising, handicrafts, shopkeeping or trading.
The World Bank's charter requires it to channel financial assistance through governments. The bank, which has been accused of not reaching those who most need help, described its new effort to help the poor more directly as "an important complement to the current efforts" in its development aid.
In addition to the World Bank, prospective donors include the United States Agency for International Development, the United Nations Development Program and Capital Development Fund, the International Fund for Agricultural Development, the African and Asian Development Banks and the governments of Canada, France and the Netherlands.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 18, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a group created to provide loans to the poor in developing countries omitted its name, and referred incompletely to the involvement of the World Bank. The new organization is the Consultative Group to Assist the Poorest. It is nominally independent but will have its headquarters at the World Bank; the bank is its most prominent donor.

HEADLINE: New Brokerage Guidelines Are Approved

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
Brokers must take greater care to insure that securities they sell to pension funds or other institutional customers are suitable, an industry group said in guidelines disclosed today.
The National Association of Securities Dealers's guidelines would require brokerage firms to determine whether customers have the expertise and resources to make informed investment decisions. 
 The new guidelines were approved at the agency's board meeting on Friday and announced today by the executive vice president for regulation, John Pinto. The guidelines require Securities and Exchange Commission approval, which could come this year.
"Our rules require members to have a reasonable basis to believe that a recommendation is suitable for the customer to whom it is made," Mr. Pinto said. The guidelines list questions firms should answer in dealings with institutional investors.
The proposals, which generated intense industry interest, gained a higher profile after the bankruptcy filing of Orange County, Calif., in December. County officials have accused their broker, Merrill Lynch & Company, of selling them unsuitable derivatives and other interest-rate-sensitive investments. Merrill Lynch strongly denies wrongdoing.

HEADLINE: Businesses Trim Inventories in May to Slowest Growth This Year

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17

 BODY:
Stocks of unsold goods on company shelves grew at their slowest pace this year in May, the Commerce Department said today.
Economists said the more modest advance suggested that businesses -- which earlier this year began trimming output to rein in swelling stockpiles -- had begun to get a better handle on inventories. 
 "It looks like businesses are getting very close to eliminating the inventory overhang and may be preparing to step up production in the fourth quarter to meet current demand," said William Griggs, an economist with Griggs & Santow Inc.
Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted $956.21 billion, after a revised increase of 1 percent in April. That increase was previously reported as eight-tenths of 1 percent. The May advance was the smallest since a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in December 1994. The last time inventories fell was in March 1994.
Some economists worry that a combination of flagging demand, bulging inventories and production cuts could lead to a recession. Indeed, economists believe the economy showed little or no growth in the second quarter.
But recent information suggests a pickup may be imminent. On Friday, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales were up an estimated seven-tenths of 1 percent in June. The same day, the Federal Reserve said industrial production rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June, the first gain since January.
"The direction of inventory changes is critically dependent on growth in demand," said Sam Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. "If demand picks up, we'll see an inventory-accumulation cycle starting. And if demand doesn't pick up, then we should see a continued decline in inventories."
In May, inventories increased at all stages of business activity. Retail inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Manufacturers' inventories increased six-tenths of 1 percent, and wholesalers' inventories grew one-tenth of 1 percent.
Business sales rose half a percent in May, the first rise in three months. Sales fell a revised three-tenths of 1 percent in April, which was previously reported at four-tenths of 1 percent.
The inventory-to-sales ratio -- a measure of how long it would take to sell existing stocks at the current pace -- fell to 1.41 month's worth in May from a revised 1.42 month's worth in April. The April ratio previously was reported as 1.41.

HEADLINE: Officials Shift Their Tactics On Housing

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Frustrated by high costs, community opposition and an inability to find public housing sites in white neighborhoods, city and Federal officials have all but abandoned an effort to build any new public housing in New York City.
Instead, the Federal Government will allow the city to spend $230 million earmarked for new housing to rehabilitate existing units. 
 The shift, which was announced yesterday by Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, will allow the New York City Housing Authority to upgrade at least 22,624 units of public housing. And just as critically, the maneuver allows the city to keep money it might have lost otherwise because the Housing Authority has not been able to find development sites that comply with Federal rules.
"This is an example of how cooperation between HUD and city and state officials can lead to creative uses of Federal housing funds," Mr. Cisneros said.
Although officials say the agreement will improve the living conditions of an estimated 57,000 residents of public housing, it effectively halts an expansion program by the Housing Authority that sought to add 2,500 units of new housing.
The authority now has more than 150,000 families on a waiting list for public housing. Officials say the list has grown by a third since the early 1970's because of the economic downturn in the late 1980's and the increasing homeless population.
The agreement was also a setback in the Government's effort to give more low-income families the opportunity to live in mixed-income neighborhoods where schools and services tend to be better than they are in poor neighborhoods.
In recent years, Federal regulations have discouraged the development of new housing projects in low-income and predominantly minority neighborhoods. And although the city's housing needs made New York City eligible for more than $250 million in development funds, officials said the city could not meet the Federal regulations. The rules require cities to expand the areas in which new public housing is built, a response to the fact that the worst public housing developments are often in racially segregated and economically isolated neighborhoods.
Because of the high cost of real estate in New York, officials said the Housing Authority was limited almost exclusively to property the city already owned. And most of the land the city owns consists of abandoned buildings in poor, minority neighborhoods.
But even with city-owned sites in appropriate neighborhoods, the Housing Authority often found the going rough. In one case, the authority battled the residents of a neighborhood on the Upper West Side for more than two years over plans to build 35 units on the site of a beloved community garden.
The Housing Authority went forward with the project, which is now being built, only after a carefully negotiated plan to move the garden.
Despite the city's pressing need for more affordable housing, housing advocates were largely supportive yesterday of Mr. Cisneros's plan.
"You have to make judgment calls on things like this," Frank P. Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, said. "But in general, from my perspective, it seems like a pretty good tradeoff. The Federal Government's site and neighborhood standards was a policy that had no friends, and New York was finding it impossible to meet them. This way the money will be used as a preservation tool," he said.
Officials said the money would be directed at public housing developments that are owned by the city and the state. Together they represent about 12 percent of the properties managed by the Housing Authority. The rest are owned by the Federal Government. And officials say the state and city have lagged far behind federally assisted developments in maintenance and repairs.
"This agreement complements and extends the city's ongoing efforts to revitalize housing and commercial development in distressed city neighborhoods," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who joined Mr. Cisneros and other officials at City Hall for the announcement yesterday.
Ruben Franco, chairman of the Housing Authority, said that between 1983 and 1995, his agency received annual subsidies of about $284 for each unit of state-owned public housing that it manages and about $548 for each unit of city-owned housing. By contrast, HUD has contributed about $951 for each unit of federally owned public housing.
The Housing Authority is responsible for about 167,000 units of federally owned housing. It manages 13,904 state-owned units and 8,720 city-owned units.
Twenty-six state- and city-owned public housing developments in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx will benefit from the renovation funds. The Housing Authority expects to spend about $10,000 per unit on reconstruction, remodeling and repairs. The money will be spent primarily on upgrading plumbing, heating and electrical systems.
Once the work has been completed, 2,481 units will be transferred to the Federal inventory.

HEADLINE: Japan's Schools: Safe, Clean, Not Much Fun

SERIES: Main Street, Japan: In the Schools

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: OMIYA, Japan

 BODY:
It is the end of a school day, and Hiroyo Ikoma is laughing in the junior high bathroom, doing what 12-year-old girls in Japan normally do with their classmates at this time.
She's scrubbing the floors. 
 "Bathroom duty is the worst," Miss Ikoma complained lightly as she sprayed a hose in the direction of her partner's mop. "Of course, we're supposed to scrub the toilets, too, but we don't."
In Japanese schools, like this one in the verdant hills near Ise in central Japan, it is children rather than janitors who do the cleaning. From first grade through the senior year of high school, children spend 15 minutes to half an hour a day to take out the garbage and remove any graffiti that their buddies have unkindly left behind.
"Kids write graffiti in pencil," explained Miyuki Shibahara, a teacher at the junior high school in the nearby town of Nishiki, since they have to clean it themselves. "They don't have the stomach to write in pen."
As Americans dissatisfied with their own educational system look at alternatives, Japanese schools stand out in many ways. They offer discipline, orderly classes, safe corridors, rigorous training in basics like reading and mathematics, and practical lessons in physics like this one: For every action, like sticking gum under a desk, there must be an equal and less pleasant reaction, like removing it.
Several days around Omiya, a town of 5,700 set at the foot of hills covered with cedar forests, leave one with a feeling that schools here are not so much institutions of learning as of social engineering. Much of Japanese society, good and bad, seems rooted in school practices; if the Battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton, the Japanese economic miracle was won in the (student-scrubbed) classrooms of Omiya and a thousand towns like it.
No diverse country can be captured in a single microcosm, but Omiya has rhythms and anxieties that resonate beyond the rice paddies that mark the edge of town. In Tokyo, nearly 200 miles away, people talk about who will be the next Prime Minister; in Omiya, folks chat about whether fireflies are visible and whether schoolgirls will be allowed to wear skirts that rise above their kneecaps.
These days the young people of Omiya (pronounced OH-mee-yuh) are eagerly anticipating the beginning of summer vacation on July 21, for if they sometimes seem angelic during the school year, perhaps it is only because they are too busy studying to get into trouble. Japanese schools provide a crime-free and drug-free environment, but sometimes they also risk providing a fun-free environment.
In Omiya, as in many Japanese towns, loudspeakers broadcast a message each evening during the school year: "Good boys and girls, it's almost 6 o'clock. Let's be careful of cars and go home now."
 
Regimentation
Lots of Rules;
Some Rebellion
Schools are social cookie-cutters in Japan, assembly lines that press students into the same shape and constantly remind them that they are members of a larger community. Rules are ubiquitous, and the atmosphere even at public schools is a bit like that of an American military academy.
Omiya Junior High, for instance, not only stipulates the uniform but also bans wristwatches, hair ribbons, curled hair, bleached hair, perfume, scented deodorant, earrings, makeup, money, non-standard school bags or anything else that could set one student apart from another. The school even bans colorful shoes, although footwear is left at the entrance and exchanged for identical slippers that students and teachers wear inside the school building.
Yet the student whom the others describe as the coolest kid in the junior high school, Kazuhiro Fujikura, has triumphed over the homogenization process -- and that is what makes him so kakkoii, or cool. That plus the fact that, although mediocre academically, he is a good baseball player and, as 14-year-old Asaha Shimomura gushed, "he's so cute."
Mr. Fujikura bored a hole in the heel of his slippers. This creates a distinctive "thump, thump" when he walks down the hall, sending pulses soaring among his admirers.
It is striking that for all their reputation for docility, students in Japan seem as rebellious in spirit as American youths. The difference is degree: they smoke cigarettes instead of marijuana, get into fistfights instead of knife fights, and mostly just get kissed instead of pregnant.
Mr. Fujikura rebelled by showing up at school earlier this year with brown hair. The teachers made him dye his hair black again, but he is unapologetic.
"It's interesting to have a funny hair style," he said as he sat on the floor in a corridor. "I'd love to have blond hair."
Students test the rules in many other ways. Skirts are supposed to extend to at least the kneecap, but girls pull them up at the waist to titillate with an inch or two of flesh above the knee.
One boy used a fragrant mousse in his hair -- only to have a teacher drag him by the hair to a faucet and wash it out.
A problem for students is that the school uniform requires white socks, and it is difficult to be kakkoii while wearing white socks. But white socks are regarded as acceptable if they are bunched up a bit above the ankle.
So to keep socks at this height, without having them drop further, students use Sock Touch, a special glue stick marketed for just this purpose. One girl demonstrated by applying Sock Touch to her bare calf and then putting on the sock at just the kakkoii height.
Schools in Japan freely set standards for students not only in the classroom but also at home and even during summer vacation. The idea is that schools not only teach students but also train them how to fit into society -- and remind them that the school is the source of their identity, and that they can no more escape it than they can flee their other family, the one at home.
Junior high schools bar students from stopping anywhere on their way home from school, even at a store to buy a drink. On vacation, they are not allowed to visit karaoke restaurants, coffee houses or arcades.
Romances are scrutinized as well. Some of the 154 students in Omiya Junior High School have boyfriends and girlfriends, and teachers try to keep an eye on them and make sure that no one gets hurt.
"If they're really going out, then we have to talk to the parents and make sure that they don't get in trouble," said Akio Murata, the principal.
Schools begin to inculcate the values that dominate Japanese society, like the emphasis on hierarchy. Beginning in junior high school, for instance, everyone is cast as senpai, or elder, or as kohai, or junior.
"If a senpai says 'morning,' we're supposed to answer politely with 'good morning,' " explained Naomi Yoshida, an eighth grader. "If a senpai says 'bye' in a casual way, we're supposed to say 'goodbye.' "
Miss Yoshida is addressed by older students as "Yoshida" or with the diminutive "Yoshida-chan." But to younger pupils she is "Yoshida-san," just as if she were an adult.
 
Work, Work, Work
School Pressure
Means Little Play
Mr. Fujikura, the coolest student, says he does no homework and does not go to a cram school, but that is unusual. Most Japanese students work far harder than their American counterparts.
For starters, there is a half-day of school two Saturdays a month, and summer vacation lasts only six weeks. During vacations, teachers assign homework, so that students will not forget what they have learned.
Shingo Horie, a 16-year-old junior, catches a train each morning at 7 A.M. for the hourlong ride to senior high school. Omiya has no senior high, so the 7 A.M. train is jammed with the town's young people commuting to several high schools in the larger city of Matsuzaka.
Mr. Horie dozes or does homework on the train, and then plays on the basketball team after school. He gets home at 8 P.M. and then does two or three hours of homework before going to bed.
"I have hardly any time to play with friends," he said.
Why do young people work so hard?
"We want to go to good universities and get good jobs," Mr. Horie said. "Then there's also pressure from parents and teachers."
Pressure from teachers includes the requirement that students take all school books home each night. The high school has lockers -- though nearly all students leave them unlocked, for theft is unknown -- but even so, students must lug all their books home as an inducement to use them.
The pressure from parents is even greater, particularly from the "education mama." These are devoted housewives whose mission in life is to wheedle and bully their children to spend every moment studying.
Some "education mamas" have been quoted in the Japanese press as saying they had sex with their own sons, so that the boys would not need to waste time dating girls. Soap operas and a movie have been made about such mother-son relationships.
The Japanese themselves refer to the teen years as "examination hell," a time of extraordinary pressure when a few failed exams can peg a student as a prospective lathe worker instead of a corporate executive. But Japanese youths also have intact families and sometimes a close-knit community of students to provide support, and in fact the suicide rate for Japanese teen-agers is well below that for Americans.
In any case, the academic pressure perhaps pays off, for Japanese students learn a lot. At Matsuzaka High School, where some of the best Omiya students go, all pupils learn calculus, chemistry and trigonometry.
International studies have consistently shown that Japanese students perform among the best in the world in math and science. A survey of 13-year-olds in 15 countries found that in math, Japanese ranked first and the United States ranked 11th.
Japan excels in these comparisons even though Government spending on education accounts for a smaller proportion of its gross national product than in the United States. The lower spending is partly attributable to Spartan physical conditions: not only do students do all the window-cleaning and floor-waxing themselves, but students are left to shiver in the winter in unheated classrooms.
 
Shortcomings
Some Learning
Omits Thinking
While the academic side of the ledger is generally very impressive, there are some subjects that Japanese schools teach miserably. One is English, and after visits to English classes in Omiya it is easy to see how Japanese manage to study the language for six or more years without learning to speak it.
English classes are taught almost entirely in Japanese, by a teacher lecturing at a blackboard with very little class participation. English words are memorized as if they were chemistry symbols.
Takeshi Niwa, the English teacher at Omiya Junior High School, notes that the all-important college entrance exams test only the students' knowledge of written English.
"If we taught a lot of spoken English, we would be behind on the grammar, and students would fail the entrance exam," Mr. Niwa said.
Another area that seems poorly taught, perhaps because it conflicts with the Japanese desire for consensus, is World War II. The young people in Omiya seem to learn almost nothing of the war and their country's role in it.
The Rape of Nanjing, in which Japanese soldiers killed tens of thousands of Chinese civilians, was a central event in the war and remains a major sticking point in relations between Japan and China. Yet of a dozen students interviewed only a few had even heard of it.
None knew that the massacre had happened in China, and one said he thought that it had occurred in the United States.
The textbooks edited by the Government suggest why students know so little about the war. The high school textbook simply records in one sentence that "Nanjing was occupied," without specifying that more people may have died in the course of that occupation than immediately after the atomic bombing of Hiroshima.
More broadly, while American students learn to question, Japanese students learn to obey. The network of rules seems intended partly to teach the same lesson that is central to Marine boot camp: that people must obey even rules that they think are silly, that they must subsume themselves to a larger community.
Students in Omiya are taught to memorize but perhaps not to think. Class participation is rare, and the ideal educational task is an equation for which there is only one precise answer.
Perhaps as a result, Japanese students do very well in international mathematics comparisons with questions that are purely equations. But in story problems, where students have to think as well as compute, they do not do nearly so well, though still much better than Americans.
Some scholars say Japan's educational system served admirably over the last century, in building an industrial society with a labor force skilled at bolting together cars or even engineering steadily smaller radios. But these scholars worry that "trained seals," as one Japanese critic described graduates, will lack the creativity to master the information age in the coming decades.
"I serious believe that if we do not change our educational system, it will be the ruin of our country," Morihiro Hosokawa, a former Prime Minister, warned in an essay this month. He complained that the system is so regimented and so focused on cramming information into young minds that it stifles the children.
Whatever the merits of these concerns, it would be too harsh to suggest that schools around Omiya are nothing more than bleak assembly lines of memorization.
In rules and rigidity, the overall atmosphere is a bit like that of parochial schools or especially private boarding schools in America or Britain earlier in this century. The system can be brutal for those who do not fit -- bullying is a big problem in Japanese schools, though not in Omiya -- but it also creates a tight sense of family for most of the students.
"I've never seen any system that is so family-oriented, where teachers and students are together as one," said Matthew Low, an American who lives near Omiya and has taught English for two years in Japanese high schools. "You see the kids crying at junior high school graduations, and then they hold reunions. Whoever heard of a junior high school in the U.S. having reunions?"
 
Main Street, Japan
Later articles will examine other aspects of life in a small town in Japan.

It is one of the practices that produce orderly, safe and rigorous, if regimented, education; Japanese students, like these in the junior high school in Omiya, work much harder than their American counterparts. But some critics say a system that stresses memorized learning rather than thinking ill prepares the young for a changing world. (Photographs by Fumiyo Asahi for The New York Times) (pg. A6)

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1175 words

HEADLINE: New Conversion Spin: Military Contractor Really Rocks

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: WATERFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
Kevin Falvey is the archetype of cool. He spent 15 years playing keyboards for Joe Cocker. His boots are still pointy-toed and black, and he looks like a man who would curl up and die if forced to wear a tie. But his latest gig has a new twist: he gets to know Pentagon secrets.
At Sonalysts Studios, it's all in a day's work. Sonalysts (pronounced SAHN-ah-lists), a submarine technology company founded in the early 1970's to exploit the intricacies of zero-tolerance underwater acoustics, is trying to mix top secret with Top 40. 
 This is not your father's military-industrial complex. In the post-cold war economy, dramatic departures from the old ways of thinking are often the only way for a military contractor to insure survival. But it can make for a long, strange trip: Sonalysts, which is just down the road from the giant submarine construction bays of the Electric Boat shipyard, is staking its future on a bet that state-of-the-art video and sound production is essentially the same, whether for the United States Navy or for Time Warner.
Proving that point, however, means mixing together two very different cultures: ex-submariners and production artists. In the company's work force of 475 people, 150 are former submarine fleet officers, including 25 former commanders. Newer hires include graphic artists like Rena DeBortoli, known for her peasant dresses and dangling earrings, and Neil Goldberg, the former lead guitarist with the Annihilators, who is now an engineer-composer for the Sonalysts recording studio. Mr. Falvey is a vice president for music publishing and a talent scout for promising new bands.
This is a place where offices with encryption-coded door locks exist side by side with hospitality suites for visiting film producers, and where guests who must aver their status as United States citizens to enter one building can then proceed next door and listen to a blistering guitar riff.
"In my world, a problem can be you ran out of Perrier," said Mark Levinson, a Hollywood film producer who signed on with Sonalysts early this year as a vice president, and is now on the lookout for motion picture deals from his office in Los Angeles. "In their world, a problem can be that you sprung a leak at 300 feet below the surface and you all might die."
The company's first Hollywood exposure came several years ago when it helped produce sound effects for the submarine chase movie, "The Hunt for Red October." The first feature actually filmed here, "Killer," with Mr. Levinson as co-producer and starring James Woods, was completed last fall, but has yet to be released.
"They're very good at stabilizing the more hysterical aspects of show business," said Mr. Levinson, whose films include "Mystic Pizza," and "Teen Wolf." "It's just like in 'Apollo 13.' " They say, 'We're working the problem.' "
Experts who track the military industry say that trying to convert a technology from military to commercial use is tough, and that the entertainment industry is as cutthroat as they come. Still, a few have tried: a California-based company, Greystone Technology, which made flight simulators for pilot training, has shifted into software programs for virtual-reality computer games. A few other software producers are trying to get into computer animation for movies and television.
But can a company that thrived by silent running really make the leap into the world of glitz, glamour and self-promotion required by show business? Or is a dose of saltwater discipline just what the entertainment business needs?
"They know how to meet deadlines," said J. Keith Green, president and chief executive officer of Patient Education Media Inc., which is producing 75 medical videos at Sonalysts with Time Life. "You don't find that everywhere in my business."
One added spin to the Sonalysts culture clash is that the military part of the company is very much alive and well -- accounting for 75 percent of Sonalysts' $40 million in revenues last year -- with no walls between the two sides of the business. What that means is that nearly everyone must have security clearance because military work flows through even some of the most artistically minded new departments. Mr. Falvey, for example, needs a red "secret" level clearance badge because he sometimes works on soundtracks for military training films.
The company's finances are also all lumped together, a fact that gives Sonalysts' new music publishing unit the distinction of being almost certainly the only competitor in its field that is routinely audited by the Pentagon.
But employees say the growing artistic presence inside the company has also changed its military side. Ralph Guardiano, a senior executive vice president who came here after an earlier career in commercial television, said that when he arrived six years ago, the military training videos produced by Sonalysts were just about as boring as you would expect: talking heads, dull scripts, flat productions.
The first time he tried something slightly new, by "flipping" an electronic image on the screen so that it appeared to spin three-dimensionally -- an effect used all the time on television news -- the officers in charge were stunned, Mr. Guardiano said. Approval had to come down through a whole chain of command. All that has changed.
"Now, they've come to expect everything at a very high quality, with lots of flash and sizzle," he said. "Where we used to ask permission, now they're telling us that's how it needs to be."
David Hinkle, who retired from the Navy in 1973 as commander of nuclear submarine Pargo and founded Sonalysts with his wife, Muriel, shortly thereafter, said he thought the cultural strains would be much worse. He believes artists secretly want some discipline.
"They cope because, as we explain to them, it's fine and well to be an artist, but you also have to be a success at it," Mr. Hinkle said.
Mr. Hinkle has formulated a whole theory of corporate management based around what he calls the "matrix" system found in every submarine: a mix of iron-willed discipline and freedom all centered around the knowledge that every member of the crew has the power to sink the boat.
"When things go bad," he said, "you're in this little enclosed cylinder. Everybody can kill everybody else."
Apparently, not too many show business people talk, or think, like that.
"There's no doubt about it, when you go to Sonalysts, they're ex-submariners, and they walk and talk submarines," said Tony Bongiovi, owner of the Power Station, a New York recording studio that has produced the likes of Eric Clapton, Branford Marsalis and Pat Metheny. Mr. Bongiovi, whose second cousin is rocker Jon Bon Jovi, is a partner with Sonalysts in Power Station New England, the sound-recording studio scheduled to open here in late July.
Mr. Bongiovi said that a major rock band has signed to record its new album here this summer, launching the new studio. The name of the group and the dates and times of the session? Top secret, of course.

Bhavesh Patel and Jay Nilson, discuss a project. (Photographs by Carl D. Labianca for The New York Times) (pg. B5)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); 

CITY: LOS ANGELES, CA, USA (79%); 

COMPANY: SONALYSTS STUDIOS TIME WARNER SPORTS (55%); TIME WARNER BOOKMARK (55%); US NAVY (55%);

HEADLINE: Stop the Regulation Machine

BYLINE: By Orrin G. Hatch and Jon Kyl; Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, is a member of the committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton has said that the efforts in Congress to change the way Federal regulations are made "would let polluters delay and sometimes even control the rules that affect them." Such scare tactics have clouded real debate about how to whittle away the excesses of bureaucracy without sacrificing public health and safety.
In the Senate, the proposal sponsored by Bob Dole, the majority leader, would simply make sure that agencies undertake cost-benefit and risk-assessment studies so that the regulations the Government adopts are sensible -- that they save lives and protect the environment without imposing needless costs on business and the consumer. 
 Yet critics insist the bill would lead to tainted meat in grocery stores and carcinogens in drinking water. To clear the air for real debate, several myths need to be debunked.
Opponents insist that the bill would roll back rules protecting the environment and public health and safety. Unlike a bill already passed by the House, the Senate plan wouldn't overturn anything. It would require agencies to study costs and benefits of existing rules, but they would not be forced to modify or repeal any regulation. That would be voluntary.
Critics say that requiring cost-benefit analyses would prevent agencies from enacting urgently needed regulations. But the bill allows for emergency exemptions from such studies if regulations are needed quickly to prevent serious health or safety problems or immediate damage to the environment. If there was a sudden outbreak of the bacteria E. coli in hamburger from a certain manufacturer, the agency could shut down the contaminated plant through an enforcement order; new rules could be worked out and studies done once the emergency was over.
The activities of Federal agencies would not, as some have said, grind to a halt. The bill would require agencies to review their rules, but only those imposing huge costs without significant benefits are in jeopardy. (An example is the Environmental Protection Agency's hazardous waste disposal ban, which prevents one premature death for every $4.2 billion spent.) Only regulations that have a projected long-term cost to the economy of more than $100 million would need to be reviewed, and agencies would be given 11 years to do so.
The bill allows anyone challenging a Federal rule in court to ask the judge to review any improperly done cost-benefit and risk-assessment studies. Opponents say this right would clog the courts with lawsuits. But every major regulation is already challenged in court. The cost and risk studies could not be separately challenged. Affected parties could only challenge an entire rule. Nor would the bill allow judges to second-guess the conclusions of agency experts, as critics claim; it would require judges to defer to the factual and technical findings of the agencies.
Critics say the bill would require a huge new bureaucracy to review the rules. This isn't true. Many agencies, including the E.P.A., already have employees who do such studies. Any new costs incurred in the review would be small compared with the sums saved by eliminating unneeded regulations.
Those who rail against regulatory reform claim the high ground on the environment, but they really want to protect the status quo. They don't consider that the economic burden of complying with Federal rules amounted to more than $600 billion last year. They are also ignoring popular opinion. Most Americans are tired of big government and want Congress to use some common sense.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Take Fall; Trading Is Reported Quiet

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended sharply lower in quiet trading yesterday, dragged down by a growing view that the Federal Reserve will not cut short-term interest rates again this summer.
The market has been re-evaluating the prospects for a rate cut since a report on Friday showed surprising strength in retail sales for June. A separate report that day showed a gain in industrial production in June for the first time this year. Treasury prices fell on Friday. And a report yesterday on business inventories suggested that businesses might be preparing to step up production. 
 The decline yesterday was "a continuation of Friday's downward move," said Michael McGlone, a bond futures trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York. "The numbers on Friday basically knocked the whole idea of economic weakness and further Fed easings out."
A sharp rise in commodity prices, reviving fears of inflation picking up, also weighed on bonds yesterday. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds. Yesterday, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities jumped 2.5 points, to 233.98, led by sharp gains in grain prices.
"Anytime the C.R.B. index moves more than two points, that matters to me," Mr. McGlone said. "The C.R.B. rallying should heighten fears of inflation."
On July 6, the Federal Reserve said the threat of rampant inflation had receded enough for lower interest rates for the first time in nearly three years. The Fed cut its target for overnight bank loans a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.75 percent.
Yesterday, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 12/32 , to 1128/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.67 percent, from 6.60 percent on Friday. The price of the two-year note also fell, pushing its yield up to 5.74 percent, from 5.68 percent on Friday.
Still, yields on the 30-year bond are hovering near the 16-month low of 6.47 percent on June 22. Lower borrowing costs enticed the World Bank, RJR Nabisco Inc. and other companies to schedule debt sales of more than $2.5 billion for this week.
In the municipal market, bonds fell yesterday as investors shied away from bonds that mature in more than 15 years amid concern that proposals in Congress could reduce their tax benefits, traders said.
The Treasury, meanwhile, sold $13.2 billion in three-month bills and $13.2 billion in six-month bills at is regular weekly auction.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Cross-Border Taxes Complicate Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Transfer pricing -- what multinational companies charge their affiliates for goods and services moving across national borders -- is creating growing problems in world trade, a leading accounting firm says in a study published today.
"Transfer pricing is the most important international tax issue facing multinationals today," Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, said after surveying 210 companies. 
 Five of six companies surveyed have had a transfer pricing dispute with the tax authorities, Ernst & Young said, and 49 percent are now engaged in a dispute.
Ernst & Young noted that around the world governments "have become increasingly aggressive in their endeavors to maximize and protect" their revenue base by challenging transfer prices.
As a hypothetical example of transfer pricing issues, consider a company with two subsidiaries. One subsidiary makes tennis shoes in Malaysia for $1 a pair. The other sells the shoes at shopping malls in the United States for $100 a pair. By having the American subsidiary pay $75 a pair to the Malaysian subsidiary the parent company effectively takes its profits in Malaysia, which has been known to declare tax holidays to attract companies, and not the United States.
The United States taxes significant profits of overseas subsidiaries unless they are invested or paid out as dividends. Thus, tax experts say, the law encourages these companies to invest in new plants overseas rather than repatriating profits or investing in American factories.
Ernst & Young found that inquiries by tax authorities about such arrangements affect behavior. Among the 165 surveyed companies that have had transfer prices questioned, half in setting other prices took into consideration the prospect of another inquiry, compared with 17 percent among companies that have not been challenged.
The survey covered companies with headquarters in eight countries -- Australia, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands and the United States.
Transfer pricing issues have grown in tandem with world trade and budget deficits in the United States, Ernst & Young found.
A 1986 law expanded a decades-old requirement that multinationals base transfer prices on arm's-length dealings to include standards commensurate with economic benefit and industry practices, said Joy DeGrosky, an I.R.S. expert on the issue. She said a 1990 law directed the I.R.S. to ascertain that prices were not structured to reduce Government revenues unfairly.
Ernst & Young found that 93 percent of transfer pricing disputes involved management and administrative fees charged to subsidiaries. The big money, however, is in royalties and in transfers of finished goods, which were at issue in nearly half of the challenged transactions.
A key strategy to reduce such disputes is negotiated agreements between companies and tax authorities. "We will see a considerable increase in advance pricing agreements," said Richard V. L. Cooper, an economist and a report author.
But a leading international tax lawyer, Charles Bruce of Moore & Bruce in Washington, warned yesterday that advance pricing agreements carried significant risks.
One is that confidential information given to the I.R.S. may be used by the Government to negotiate a similar agreement with a competitor. "There is worry that competitors may calculate backward, from what the I.R.S. says is confidential information," Mr. Bruce said.
A second concern, he said, is that in litigation a company may be forced to disclose its advance pricing agreement to a competitor.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Rumors of Central Bank Buying Spur Dollar's Rise Against Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against the Japanese yen yesterday as speculation grew that the United States and Japan would again act in concert to weaken the yen.
Since the Federal Reserve and the Japanese central bank surprised the market on July 7 by buying dollars for yen even as the dollar was starting to rise in value, traders have been wary of further interventions. 
 Indeed, traders said yesterday that the central bank, the Bank of Japan, had probably bought dollars at rates of 88.20 yen and above in Asian trading. The Japanese bank did not comment on its actions.
"It's becoming more and more apparent that the U.S. and Japan have some sort of agreement to push the dollar over 90 yen," said Steve Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York.
The dollar was also helped by a report by Japan that its trade surplus with the United States declined in June for the first time in eight months. The surplus gives Japanese exporters a hoard of dollars they sell for yen when bringing profits home.
The dollar rose as high as 89.20 yen yesterday, its highest level since March 31. In late New York trading, it was quoted at 89.04 yen, up from 87.83 yen on Friday. It also rose to 1.3969 German marks from 1.3903 marks. The British pound fell to $1.5947 from $1.5954.
Even after yesterday's gains, the dollar is still down 11 percent against the yen so far this year. The strong yen makes Japanese exports more expensive, thwarting a revival of the economy.
The damaging effect of the strong yen showed up clearly in Japan's June trade report. Its surplus with the United States fell 11.5 percent, to $4.19 billion, compared with last June -- the biggest one-month drop since September 1993.
"The focus overnight was the decline in Japan's trade surplus," said Jeffrey Yu, senior currency dealer at Sanwa Bank in New York. "The market has used that as an impetus to buy dollars against the yen."
Also contributing to the dollar's gains yesterday was speculation about options purchases by big investors. The options would give them the right, though not the obligation, to purchase dollars and sell yen at a predetermined price. The options will rise in value if the dollar extends its gains against the yen. "There are some indications that U.S. hedge funds are buying call options for around 95 yen," Mr. Yu said.
The banks selling the options have in turn been buying dollars as a form of insurance, in case the option owners exercise their right.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aids Bolivia in Trampling Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Defying U.S. Threat, Bolivians Plant More Coca" (news article, July 11) fails to mention one critical aspect of the United States role in that country: its deep and direct involvement in human rights abuses. 
 Bolivia's rural counternarcotics forces -- created, funded and trained by the United States -- run roughshod in the Chapare, the country's primary coca-growing region, beating residents, stealing their money and goods, arbitrarily searching their homes at all hours day and night.
Bolivia's harsh antidrug law, passed under strong United States pressure, denies defendants any possibility of pretrial release and requires acquitted defendants to remain in prison until the court's decision is mandatorily reviewed by the Supreme Court, a process that can take years. Bolivians detained on drug-trafficking charges allege that agents of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration participate in abusive interrogations.
The effects of United States pressure were demonstrated in April, when the Bolivian Government, threatened by the United States with the loss of crucial economic support unless rigorous counternarcotics policies were implemented, declared a state of siege.
Although the Government ostensibly imposed the state of siege to end demonstrations by teachers' unions, it used the resulting suspension of certain constitutional rights to suppress peaceful opposition to antidrug actions demanded by the United States, arresting leaders of the coca growers' unions and sending them into internal exile.
Rather than ignoring these violations, the United States should use its influence on Bolivian counternarcotics policy to seek the elimination of laws and practices that trample fundamental rights, whatever their contribution to counternarcotics objectives.
 
JOSE MIGUEL VIVANCO
Executive Director
Human Rights Watch-Americas
New York, July 12, 1995

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus With U.S. Narrows

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 17

 BODY:
Japan's global trade surplus grew 2.1 percent in June, but the politically sensitive surplus with the United States narrowed for the first time in eight months, the Finance Ministry said today.
Economists said the increase in the overall surplus was caused largely by the yen's strength, which inflated the size of the dollar-denominated surplus. In yen terms, June's surplus declined 16.6 percent. The yen-denominated surplus has narrowed for seven consecutive months. 
 As the yen strengthens, it raises the dollar value of Japanese exports, resulting in a temporary widening of the dollar-denominated surplus, The stronger Japanese currency slows exports, eating into the surplus, by making them expensive overseas.
The Finance Ministry said the overall trade surplus rose to $11.57 billion in June from $11.34 billion in the month a year earlier. That was the second monthly increase.
Japanese exports rose 19 percent, to $40.05 billion, from $33.72 billion in June 1994. Shipments of machine tools more than doubled, while exports of computer chips increased 46.4 percent.
Imports increased 27 percent, to $28.48 billion from $22.39 billion. Imports of office equipment, mostly personal computers, contributed the most to the increase, up 79 percent.
In trade with the United States alone, Japan's June surplus shrank for the first time in eight months, contracting 11.5 percent from a year earlier, to $4.19 billion from $4.74 billion.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Koreans Buying Zenith, Last American TV Maker
The last American-owned television manufacturer, Zenith Electronics, gave up its battle to survive on its own and agreed to sell a controlling interest to LG Electronics, the South Korean manufacturer that sells products under the Goldstar name.
LG said it would pay $10 a share, or more than $350 million, to lift its Zenith stake to 57.7 percent from 3.8 percent. [Page A1.]
 
Westinghouse Shows Interest
In $5 Billion Bid for CBS
Westinghouse Electric has indicated to Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of CBS, that it is interested in buying the company for about $80 a share, or $5 billion in cash, two people with knowledge of the talks said. Although Mr. Tisch has repeatedly said CBS is not for sale, he is still believed to be willing to accept at least $80 a share. [D4.]
 
Nasdaq Index Breaks 1,000
A surge in technology stocks lifted the Nasdaq composite index 6.57 points, to 1,005.89, the first time it has closed above 1,000. Technology stocks also helped the Dow industrials rise 27.47 points, to 4,736.29. [D10.]
 
The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 6.67 percent on the growing view that the Federal Reserve will not cut short-term interest rates again this summer. [D22.]
 
The dollar surged to 89.04 yen as speculation grew that the United States and Japan would again act to strengthen the dollar. [D19.]
 
Bank Earnings Are Mixed
Chase Manhattan reported lower earnings for the second quarter, hurt by sharply weaker results in its retail business. Earnings at several other large banks, however, including Nationsbank, First Interstate and First Chicago, rose. [D2.]
 
A Bear, Stearns Resignation
John C. Sites Jr., 43, who built up Wall Street's largest mortgage-backed securities business at Bear, Stearns, resigned, saying he wanted to devote more time to his family. [D10.]
 
Offer Extended for Legent
Computer Associates, still negotiating with the Justice Department, extended its $1.74 billion offer for Legent until Thursday. [D3.]
 
Modest Rise for Inventories
Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted $956.21 billion. That is the smallest advance since a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in December 1994. Economists said many businesses had apparently begun to get their investories under better control. [D4.]
 
Executive Changes at Olde
Two top executives at Olde Discount, a Detroit-based brokerage firm under regulatory pressure, left their posts last week. [D22.]
 
Tax Issue Causing Disputes
Ernst & Young says, in a study out today, that transfer pricing -- what multinational companies charge their affiliates for goods and services moving across national borders -- is creating problems in world trade. [D5.]
 
Bad Bets on Scott Deal
Speculators have been piling into Scott Paper stock for weeks, sensing a takeover. They were right, but for many it turned out to be a losing bet. Yesterday's offer was below Scott's recent trading level. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Astronomers Cite Mobile Phones
The European Science Foundation warned that if the multibillion-dollar mobile telephone industry continued to expand without safeguards, radio astronomy would be swamped by a sea of radio interference. [C10.]

HEADLINE: Store Project In Queens Has Backing In Council

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Despite opposition from some neighborhood merchants, several members of a key City Council subcommittee yesterday said they would support plans to construct a 65,000-square-foot Pathmark supermarket in Springfield Gardens, Queens.
After hours of testimony in a packed Council chamber from residents, religious leaders, politicians and others, Council leaders said a vote on the issue would be put off until today. But the statements of support from several Council members suggested that it would be difficult for opponents to derail the plan, which has deeply divided the middle-class Queens community. 
 Neighborhood merchants have largely opposed the building of the new store, saying that the supermarket will drive them out of business, increase traffic and ruin economic development plans. But supporters of the supermarket, including many neighborhood residents, contend that a new store would provide an important shopping alternative for people who are forced to drive long distances to a large supermarket.
The City Council must vote on the plans because the area selected by Pathmark -- at the intersection of Springfield and Merrick Boulevards -- is not zoned for stores larger than 10,000 square feet.
Many members of the Council's subcommittee on Permits, Dispositions and Concessions, said they supported the project. But Juanita Watkins, a Democratic Council member who represents Springfield Gardens, has led the opposition toward the Pathmark store, saying it would be too disruptive a presence in a quiet neighborhood.
The subcommittee was scheduled to vote on the matter yesterday. But Council leaders said that a vote would likely come this morning, in part because the volume of people who showed up to testify extended the hearing well into the night. Some Council members also said Ms. Watkins was seeking to negotiate modifications in the plans for the store.
The issue of the Queens Pathmark store comes just two months after Pathmark Stores, in Woodbridge, N.J., faced bitter opposition by small merchants over its plans to build a large store in East Harlem, with the help of government financial incentives.
The plans for the East Harlem store were approved by the Manhattan Borough Board, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani still has not said whether he supports or opposes the 53,000-square-foot project. As a result, the supermarket that was planned at 125th Street and Third Avenue as an anchor in the revitalization of commerce in the blighted neighborhood remains stalled.
Pathmark officials say that the two episodes illustrate the difficulties of completing economic development projects in New York City.
"We certainly would have liked to see decisions made expeditiously," said Stanley Sorkin, vice president of public affairs for Pathmark. "People say time is money. And when you delay a decision, I think everyone loses something. The consumer, in terms of getting better shopping quality. And we are obviously disappointed that we do not have a new store under construction that would generate sales and profits for us."
Representative Floyd H. Flake, a Democrat whose Congressional district includes Springfield Gardens, said: "This project has the potential to anchor and invite further development by entities that have ignored communities like yours and mine."
He added that the project was expected to bring in 200 new jobs to the community, and that Pathmark had promised to hire 80 percent of those employees from the neighboring community.
But Monica Webster, a local resident, said she opposed the project because "it would bring increased traffic, strangers and crime to our community."
More than three-fourths of the 300 people in the Council chamber cheered the elected officials who testified in support of the project.
Still, there were efforts last night to make the plan more palatable to Ms. Watkins, who met with Pathmark officials and Councilwoman June M. Eisland, a Democrat who heads the Council's Land Use Committee, to determine what changes might be acceptable to all parties.
Among the considerations, staff members said, was a plan to scale the project down by 5,000 square feet and to reduce its hours of operation to something less than 24-hours a day. Also, there were discussions on having Pathmark create a fund to make money available to local merchants to make improvements on their stores.
Mr. Giuliani has supported the Queens Pathmark store, citing the fact that it did not include any major government subsidies. When asked about the difference between the Queens project and the Harlem proposal, Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that "they raised totally separate issues."
Mr. Giuliani has been accused by many officials of being reluctant to take sides because supporting the project could alienate the many smaller store owners, many of them Hispanic, who are against it. They further cite the Mayor's declining numbers in opinion polls among Hispanic New Yorkers.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 29, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on July 18 ("A Pathmark for Queens") stated that a Pathmark supermarket planned for East Harlem would be built on land donated by the city. In fact, the city would provide a mortgage allowing a nonprofit developer to buy the land over 25 years at a 1 percent interest rate.

HEADLINE: In House, Spending Bills Open Way to Make Policy

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18

 BODY:
House Republicans took the unusual step today of using a spending bill to make policy, approving an appropriations measure that would revoke or substantially restrict nearly 20 environmental laws that have become anathema to big business.
The action was but one skirmish in a multifront budget battle in the House of Representatives and in committee, as House Republicans worked furiously to finish their 13 appropriations bills before the scheduled August recess. 
 But whatever final legislation emerges from the House, its decisions on the series of bills that provide financing for Government agencies are likely to be mediated by the much more moderate Republican majority in the Senate.
Ample evidence of that was seen today when Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, chairman of the Budget Committee, released the budget limits for the Senate Appropriations subcommittees.
The Senate plan included the same bottom line in budget authority as the House, $489.161 billion, but differed significantly on how to spend that sum.
Mr. Hatfield would allocate $1.6 billion more for labor, health and human services and education programs than the $61 billion that the House allowed. He would give $1.6 billion more to water and energy development, a traditional haven for legislators' pet projects or pork barrel spending, than the House's figure of $18.7 billion
Mr. Hatfield also cut deeper into spending for a half-dozen departments, including Defense, $1.4 billion; Commerce, $1.3 billion, and Transportation, $200 million, than the House.
Even as the House Appropriations Committee moved to rein in some environmental laws that big business has complained about most, the Senate balked at passing regulatory changes that big business has also championed, causing the majority leader, Bob Dole, to pull the bill off the floor.
The House committee, voting along party lines, approved a $61.7 billion allocation for veterans, housing, environmental and other programs for 1996, but included language that would withhold money for enforcement of statutes like the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts until Congress had decided on reauthorizing them.
As the Appropriations Committee worked, the full House ended its debate and voted on an $11.96 billion allocation for the Interior Department. That bill, which passed 244 to 181, includes legislation that would reduce Federal financing next year by 40 percent for the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities and would halt all financing to the arts agency in two years.
That vote was followed immediately by the opening of a floor debate on the appropriations for the Treasury Department, the Postal Service and other agencies. That $23.2 billion measure is $322.7 million less than in 1995 and $1.8 billion less than the Administration had requested. There are $41 million in cuts from the Executive Office, including all money for a major advisory group, the Council of Economic Advisors, and the bill prohibits Federal employee health-insurance plans from covering abortions, except when a mother's life is at risk.
Before the House quits for the week on Friday, it is also scheduled to debate three other appropriations bills, for the Agriculture Department, for the Transportation Departments and for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments, as well as for the judiciary.
The bill on veterans, housing and environmental programs, which the committee approved today in a party-line vote, was one of the sparest appropriations bills to gain favor.
Although the National Aeronautics and Space Administration budget sailed through virtually unscathed at $13.67 billion, $705 million less than its budget request, the bill overall cut discretionary spending by $8.3 billion from the 1995 allocation.
The major cuts are from the Environmental Protection Agency, which would receive $4.88 billion, 33 percent or $2.4 billion less than its current budget, and from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which was allocated $19.1 billion, a 23 percent or $5.5 billion reduction.
"It is certainly the case that many of the agencies in this bill are unhappy," said Representative Jerry Lewis, Republican of California and chairman of the Subcommittee on the Veterans Affairs Department, Housing and Urban Development and Independent Agencies. "But the House Appropriations Committee is clearly prepared to draw a line on spending."
The bill would close four agencies, for savings of $723 million, the subcommittee's part of the National Service Program, known as Americorp; the Community Development Financial Institutions, the Chemical Safety and Hazards Investigation Board and the Council on Environmental Quality.
The bill also has 17 riders or side language about the E.P.A., which Democrats complained went beyond the Appropriations Committee's traditional powers and intruded into realms usually reserved for authorizing committees.
The bill would allocate $1.5 billion for the water programs, but it has a rider that none of the money would be available unless Congress reauthorizes the Clean Water Act.
Another rider would exempt states from having to start centralized vehicle-emissions tests.
"The effect of this bill is that people in communities across this country will suffer," the E.P.A. administrator, Carol Browner, said in a telephone interview. "My ability to make sure that the quality of air that people breath and the water that they drink is good will be in question."
