HEADLINE: In Hamptons, Lines in the Sand Ignite Tempers;
Oceanfront Residents Try to Restrict Public Access to Beaches

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.

 BODY:
From the edge of his beach towel on the sugar-soft sand of Fowler's Beach, Joseph Obermayer can see the rise of newly built ocean estates, which he scornfully derides as potato mansions inhabited by the territorial nouveau riche.
From the edge of eight-foot-high privet hedges bordering his oceanfront development on the old Henry Ford estate, Joern Brunvall can see Fowler's Beach bathers like Mr. Obermayer, gauche summer tourists who litter country roads with beer bottles and lines of unsightly cars. 
 These are the lines in the precious sand that divide wealthy oceanfront landowners from middle-class visitors in the Hamptons, where only a handful of beaches are open to the public. As the East End's potato lands have sprouted houses, each new enclave of owners has sought bans on parking along the access roads to the beaches. They have been so effective that the metal No Parking signs are as ubiquitous as service entrances to the local estates.
Of course, the right-of-way along the beach below the high-water mark has been guaranteed to the public since Colonial days by a law known as the public trust doctrine. The enduring question is: Can you get there?
"It's a question of a natural conflict between people who choose to live on the ocean and people who don't and want to use it," said William W. Esseks, a lawyer who has represented several Hamptons property owners who have won parking restrictions along beach access roads. "You should not park on the roads because they're trying to have a certain ambiance in the town: views across pastoral fields without cars and trucks."
On the South Fork of eastern Long Island, beach territory is so prized that earlier this summer in Sagaponack, a tourist came to blows with the young daughter of a corporate executive who the police said had demanded the removal from "our property" of a car parked on a public road.
Many of these fierce sand struggles are territorial fights pitting the Upper East Side, wealthy Manhattan newcomers who value the privacy of their second homes, on the beachfront, against middle-class New York City beachgoers.
Along the coast of Northeastern states, this debate is acute, as rural properties edging the Atlantic are subdivided into lots and expensive homes. "Potato mansions" is the term that critics like Mr. Obermayer use for the airy, contemporary houses that have replaced potatoes along the two-lane roads leading to the beaches.
"The reason why this is a big issue in the Northeast is because beach towns that used to be strictly tourist towns are becoming residential, and in becoming residential, the people who live there no longer want tourist space," said Jack Samuels, a professor of recreation and tourism at Montclair State University in New Jersey. "They want to have privacy. They don't see the fact that tourism is sustaining the local economy."
All of these forces have come into play on the sandy shores of places like Peter's Pond in Sagaponack and Fowler's Beach in Southampton, which has had a reputation for almost two decades as the East End's oldest gay beach, drawing bronzed sunbathers from all over Long Island and Manhattan.
Both beaches lack amenities, except the cobalt blue of the Atlantic and wind-scoured stretches of sand. There are no garbage cans, lifeguards or toilets. There are also no requirements for beach passes, and tourists are accustomed to parking along the two-lane public roads that lead to the beaches.
Residents of the Fordune development, 44 lots and homes that have been carved from the old Henry Ford estate, wanted to achieve a country look along the country road that borders their development. Last summer, the development's association moved successfully to ban the very vehicles that made Ford rich. As a result, up went a string of No Parking signs on the road by the development's entrance.
In turn, the development's Fowler Street neighbor, a farm family that has worked the land for generations, sought a parking ban on the road near their large Colonial-style house. The Village of Southampton had put up No Parking signs along that road, but the beachgoers had draped the signs with paper bags, contending that the village lacked the authority to impose those restrictions. They argued that only the Town of Southampton had that right.
When frequent beach visitors like Steven Welch and Carol Hageman realized how quickly parking spots were vanishing, they formed a group, walked beach blanket to blanket in search of donations and hired a $150-an-hour lawyer to reclaim lost spaces. Many supporters were gay men with homes in Manhattan and the Hamptons who could afford to write a check, but not the time to fight Town Hall.
"They want the beach to themselves and they don't want outsiders coming there," said John Rogers, 51, an interior designer with residences in Southampton and the Upper East Side, who has been active in the fight to reclaim parking spaces on Fowler's Beach. "The people at Fordune have multimillion-dollar homes and they don't want to go through the beach and stumble over boys and girls frolicking in the sand."
"It's their delicate sense of privilege and sense of privacy," said Mr. Welch, 38, a Southampton resident and a chef by trade.
On the other side of the road, the oceanfront residents give several reasons for concern about parked cars: safety, esthetics, litter, unsanitary beach conditions, public urination.
Margaret H. Fowler, whose in-laws have farmed the land along Fowler's Street for generations, said the crush of traffic along the road was "an accident waiting to happen." She said the parking spaces should not have been eliminated by the Fordune development.
But her neighbors there will not accept the cars. "We pay high taxes and high costs and therefore we are trying to maintain the pristine areas that we live in," said Clifford V. Brokaw 3d, 67, president of the Fordune Association and a retired investment banker with residences in Southampton and the Upper East Side.
The association's vice president, Joern Brunvall, a former Upper East Side resident who now lives year round in Southampton, said some day trippers crashed into the development's privet hedges and trampled the grass planted by the homeowners. "I don't think class is an issue at all in this," he said. "It's parking that's an issue. It seems like the people from the city are trying to overrun us here."
That is basically the same argument of Daniel Shedrick, the chief executive officer of the KMS Group Ltd. in Connecticut, who owns 64 acres of potato fields fronting Peter's Pond beach in Sagaponack. Earlier this summer, Mr. Shedrick drew his line in the gray sand of Peter's Pond with a full-page advertisement that appeared in the Southampton Press.
"Not Murder," declared the headline in bold block letters. "Just a broken nose," added the smaller print of his complaint, about beach thugs who had attacked his daughter and tourists who had tramped along his property to "dump their garbage, destroy private property and enjoy the sun." Not to mention the bacchanalian beach parties of "indescribable proportions."
In June, Mr. Shedrick sued the Southampton Town Board for $5 million in damages, asserting that his property had lost value because the board had failed to enforce parking restrictions along the beach-access road that runs past his property.
Mr. Shedrick has proposed the banning of parking on the road at all times, along with the posting of an attendant in a guard house to monitor activity and break the "criminal, Pavlovian" habits of beachgoers.
In his advertisement, Mr. Shedrick railed against "nine unidentified male teen-agers" who assaulted his daughter, Elizabeth Shedrick, a 25-year-old Fordham University graduate student.
But the Southampton police said they had investigated the incident involving Ms. Shedrick and had concluded that only two teen-age boys had been involved in the dispute. One arrest was made last week in connection with the fight, and Ms. Shedrick has also filed a harassment complaint against a 17-year-old East Hampton resident who the police said was involved in the incident.
Detective Doreen Isola of Southampton said a fight apparently erupted as a beach party broke up and people headed toward their cars along the road. As Ms. Shedrick tried to drive around a parked car, somebody made a comment.
"She told them to leave and that that was her property," the detective said. "And the argument escalated from there."

HEADLINE: Pataki Walks Fine Line on Rail Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 18

 BODY:
In his quiet efforts to resolve the Metro-North Commuter Railroad contract dispute, Gov. George E. Pataki is struggling to balance two conflicting mind-sets within his administration: those who want him to take a hard line against labor and those who believe he must work with the unions to avoid a disruptive strike.
To some of his advisers, the talks between Metro-North's 17 unions and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority give the Republican Governor a sterling opportunity to show that he can be tough with organized labor as part of his effort to hold down government costs. 
 But today, a spokesman for organized labor said that he had seen no evidence that the Governor was even involved. Indeed, Mr. Pataki has made few public comments about the negotiations, neither attacking labor nor vigorously endorsing management's positions. While negotiations were going on, Mr. Pataki spent the afternoon viewing storm damage in the Adirondacks.
Mr. Pataki's low-key role has arisen partly because some advisers have counseled that a harsh stand against the unions could result in a strike that would disrupt the region's economy and the lives of 100,000 commuters who live in the northern suburbs, which strongly supported the Governor in last year's election.
Moreover, some of Mr. Pataki's aides argue that taking an aggressive position against the unions could antagonize blue-collar workers who supported Mr. Pataki last year and undermine the Republican Party's efforts to expand its base among working-class voters in the New York City region.
Mr. Pataki does not sit at the negotiating table, but wields immense influence over the M.T.A. through his appointments to its board. He has taken a two-pronged approach to influencing the talks.
On the one hand, he has studiously avoided making inflammatory comments about the unions. He has sought to cast himself as a moderate voice interested in a settlement, not brinkmanship. He has been in daily contact with M.T.A. officials, while the State Labor Commissioner, John E. Sweeney, has been in close touch with union officials.
But in the mold of his political hero, Theodore Roosevelt, the Governor has also threatened to use what many of his aides consider the biggest stick available to influence the unions: a change in Federal labor laws that would effectively make it impossible for Metro-North's unions to strike.
To do that would require the passage of legislation by the Republican-controlled Congress. Mr. Pataki's aides think that would happen quickly if the Metro-North unions did go on strike. Congressional hearings on this legislation had been scheduled for Wednesday, and Mr. Pataki had planned to testify. But those hearings have been postponed, partly at Mr. Pataki's urging because of progress in the talks.
In an interview today, Mr. Pataki made it clear that he wants to resolve the dispute without a strike. "We're not looking for a victory for one side or the other," he said. "We're looking for a resolution that is fair and in the best interests of all of us."
But the Governor made clear that if the unions did not agree to work-rule changes that could save the M.T.A. millions of dollars, a strike might be inevitable.
"I don't intend to micro-manage or dictate to the negotiators how it should go," he said. "But I think this is an important long-term question for the state. If it cannot be resolved, the unions have a right to strike and Metro-North would have an obligation to not sign off on a pact that they cannot afford."
Mr. Pataki also emphasized that he was intent on avoiding what he considers the mistakes of his Democratic predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, in his handling of a similar labor dispute last year between the Long Island Rail Road's unions and the M.T.A.
The dispute came during the heat of last year's gubernatorial campaign, and a prolonged strike threatened to make life miserable for thousands of people in a region politically vital to Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo leaped vigorously into the talks, making repeated calls to both labor leaders and M.T.A. negotiators. He sent his own representative to the bargaining table. He canceled many public appearances to monitor the negotiations.
As a strike loomed, Mr. Cuomo took a hard line against labor, saying the M.T.A. should not "use taxpayer dollars to bribe the union." But five days later, after the strike had begun and he had been sharply criticized by labor leaders, Mr. Cuomo pressured the M.T.A. to accept a settlement that acceded to many of the unions' demands.
Mr. Pataki said that Mr. Cuomo's role in those talks was inappropriate and political and that he would avoid micro-managing the current talks so as not to undermine the authority of the M.T.A. chairman, E. Virgil Conway, who is his appointee.
"We are not going to repeat that mistake," he said of Mr. Cuomo's involvement. "We put together a very sound team that is going to look not for a short-term political gain but for the long-term best interests of the entire region."

HEADLINE: Regents Prepare for Storm on Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18

 BODY:
With an agenda of hotly contested proposals to eliminate affirmative-action policies at the University of California, the meeting of the university's governing board on Thursday will be a proving ground for a central social issue of the decade.
Gov. Pete Wilson, using the dismantling of affirmative action as a cornerstone of his Republican Presidential bid, has announced he will exercise his right for the first time in years to preside over the meeting. Jesse Jackson is coming to town on Wednesday to lead protests. And the White House has announced that President Clinton will deliver an important address on the subject on Wednesday. The 26 regents themselves appear to be sharply divided. 
 At the center of the tempest is a close Wilson ally on the board, Ward Connerly, 56, a wealthy, black Sacramento housing developer who says affirmative action has outlived its usefulness.
In January, after discussing the matter extensively with Governor Wilson, Mr. Connerly proposed that his fellow regents eliminate the use of race, sex, religion, color or national origin as a criterion for admission to the university and for hiring and contracting. Part of Mr. Connerly's proposal would ask the university administration and the faculty senate to propose supplemental criteria that would let admissions officers consider socioeconomic status.
Since he made his proposal, Mr. Connerly has been under an intense spotlight. He has received praise for his courage in taking an unpopular position, but because he is black, some blacks have denounced him as a turncoat, an Uncle Tom and worse.
An earnest, intensely expressive Mr. Connerly leaned forward repeatedly to emphasize his points when interviewed in a Sacramento restaurant on Monday.
A friend of the Governor for more than 25 years, he said his proposal was incubated in a conversation with Mr. Wilson on Thanksgiving Day. The Governor had called to extend his good wishes, but Mr. Connerly began a discussion about his discomfort with the university's affirmative-action policies.
"I told him," Mr. Connerly said, "I'm all for the outreach programs and the efforts to break up the old-boys network that prevents equal access to participate in university life. I said I thought it was wrong of the university to sign a multimillion-dollar contract with the same auditor year after year because it would be too expensive and take too much time to open it up to bidding. That's wrong.
"But, I also said I was troubled by the affirmative-action policies that impose racial preferences. They are exclusionary to some, and that's not fair.
"And what do those race-based policies say to black kids? They say, just do enough to get by. They undermine hard work and I want to oppose them."
Mr. Connerly said the Governor encouraged him to proceed with the proposal, which parallels Mr. Wilson's own initiatives in state hiring and contracting.
"So I started talking to individual regents, asking them, 'Have you thought this through?' " Mr. Connerly continued. "Only about 3 of the 26 regents agreed with me. The Governor then began talking to them. Today, because of his efforts, we have about 14 or 15 who agree with us. That should be enough to adopt the resolutions but you've got to get them there to vote and they have to find the courage to go through with it."
Asked how he reacted to blacks who denounced him as a traitor to his race, Mr. Connerly said: "When I was growing up, my friends were white, Hispanic and black. I'm one of the most cosmopolitan people you'll ever meet. Now, some of the whites who associated with me were called nigger lovers. But it didn't deter them. They felt our relationship was more important than letting bigots dictate who their friends would be. It's the same here. If I'm opposed by people with infantile views, should I give up? Certainly not."
Mr. Connerly also said that he had once been staunchly in favor of affirmative-action programs, but that now he believed that they were harmful.
"I think there were compelling reasons in 1960 to change the culture of our country," he said, "but today we're not in an institutionally racist society as we were in 1965."
The policy, he said, "devalues the black person who gets up every morning and works and excels."
Asked what might be the impact on enrollment of his resolution if adopted, Mr. Connerly said: "It's impossible to say until the supplemental criteria, socioeconomic or whatever, are determined and approved by the Board of Regents. We shouldn't make policy based on how many blacks or Hispanics get admitted. That's what got us into this trouble in the first place."
In 1968, when Mr. Wilson was a member of the state Legislature, he named Mr. Connerly a consultant for the state Housing Committee. In 1992, Governor Wilson appointed him to the California Competitiveness Committee and then to a 12-year term as a regent.
Mr. Wilson himself began his Presidential bid soon after endorsing a statewide initiative that would overturn laws taking ethnicity and sex into consideration for hiring and contracts. Aides say Governor Wilson's opposition to admissions practices granting preferences based on race and sex is one of the central positions in his Presidential campaign, and he hopes that the meeting will let him present his ideas to a national audience.
Speaking to a group of business leaders in Los Angeles today, Mr. Wilson restated his view that affirmative-action programs result in reverse discrimination and should be dismantled.
Another possible Presidential contender, Mr. Jackson, has threatened that he and his supporters will practice civil disobedience if not granted time to defend the programs. The regents have placed Mr. Jackson's name on a list of 17 public officials and guests who will be allowed to speak for more than the usual three minutes on Thursday.
The sprawling nine-campus university, which now enrolls 151,000 students, is also caught up in the events. Faculty and student-action groups have bombarded the regents with mail and petitions most of them supporting affirmative action.
Jack Peltason, president of the University of California, will address the regents asking them to preserve the affirmative-action policies. He declared in a letter to the regents last month that abandoning racial preferences would be a grave mistake.
He also persuaded the regents to postpone consideration of a change in policy until this month after the Legislature had appropriated money for the university system, fearing that if the regents acted on the issue sooner, the Legislature might seek to punish the university by cutting its budget.
The session will open on Wednesday afternoon when a group of about a dozen regents will meet with 200 students.
Governor Wilson will address the meeting on Thursday in a departure from the usual practice of allowing others to speak first. Aides said the Governor wished to set the tone of the meeting.
After the 17 officials and guests have spoken, about 30 out of 150 names will be drawn out of a hat to randomly select other speakers.
"The format will be something like a Phil Donahue show," said Terry Colvin, a spokesman for the University of California.
Governor Wilson contends that as few as 40 percent of all students are admitted to state-run universities in California strictly on the basis of their academic achievement.

Chart: "Proposals: Grappling With Affirmative Action"
Proposals before the California Board of Regents on whether to dismantle, modify or retain the university's affirmative-action programs.
DISMANTLE PROGRAM: Ward Connerly, a Sacramento businessman, proposes that as of Jan. 1, 1997, the university eliminate "race, religion, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin as criteria for admission" or for hiring or contracts. He modified his proposals last month to allow for the consideration of supplemental criteria like social or economic discrimination.
ELIMINATE GROUP PREFERENCES: David Flinn, a regent whose term ended in June, has proposed a compromise that allows consideration of race and sex on an individual basis, and not give preference in hiring or admission based on membership in a racial group. He would consider an applicant's education, family environment, economic hardship, physical disability and racial, sexual or religious discrimination.
MAINTAIN RACE-BASED PREFERENCE: The student member of the Board of Regents, Ed Gomez, a graduate student in history at the Riverside campus, will ask on behalf of the Student Association to keep current policies, and expand preparatory programs and hiring.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Off For 4th Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday after a report showed a strong gain in retail sales.
The decline was the fourth consecutive decline in prices as traders continued to assess the direction of the economy and interest rates. Recent data have shaken the market's view of a slowing economy and cast doubt on the prospects for another move by the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates. 
 A report yesterday provided further evidence of a rebound in consumer spending. The Johnson Redbook service said retail sales rose 1.1 percent in the first two weeks of July. Sales were also running 8 percent above the pace recorded a year ago, the service said. Johnson Redbook's weekly reports are watched by many traders and investors because they are considered harbingers of the Government's own monthly report on retail sales.
"The economy is not dead," said Joseph Bench, who manages $450 million of bonds at New Castle Advisers in White Plains. Now, "bond yields are more likely" to climb to 7 percent during the next four weeks, he said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32 , to 1101/32 , pushing its yield up to 6.76 percent, from 6.67 percent on Monday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
The yield on the two-year note, which mirrors expectations for changes in Fed monetary policies, rose yesterday to 5.80 percent from 5.74 percent. On July 6, when the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, the yield on the two-year note fell nearly 26 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
If traders conclude "the Fed is done easing, the two-year could move 35 basis points in a real hurry," said Cary Leahey, a money-market economist at Lehman Brothers Inc.. Two-year notes could yield at least 6.5 percent if the Fed is leaving its overnight target where it is, he said.
Recent data suggest the "economy is on the mend," said Steven Wood, director of financial markets research at Bank of America in San Francisco. "Many people would assume that implies the Fed's not going to lower rates again," he said.
The market's attention will be focused today on Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, as he appears before a House Banking subcommittee for his semiannual testimony on the state of the economy and monetary policy.
Some traders said bonds could rise after testimony concerning the rate cut.
"In the context of talking about the rate cut, you have to say bullish things," said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company. "You can't say, 'I cut rates because growth and inflation are speeding up.' "
Mr. Greenspan may also "hold up the possibility that the cut was the first of a series," said Ken Sullivan, a trader at First Chicago Capital Markets. "He's more likely to get hammered for why he didn't cut more than why he cut in the first place," he said.
Earlier yesterday, bonds recovered from an overnight decline as securities firms underwriting $1.5 billion of World Bank bonds bought back Treasury securities sold earlier as insurance against losses on the new bonds.
The World Bank, the international development agency, sold 10-year global bonds through firms led by Deutsche Morgan Grenfell and Lehman Brothers International (Europe).
Securities firms that underwrite corporate bonds often sell borrowed Treasuries, in so-called short sales, to protect against losses until the new debt is sold.

HEADLINE: Twist a Dial and Cab Fare Soars, Police Say

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
Thousands of people who rode taxis in New York City in recent months may have noticed that the drivers fiddled a lot with their CB radios. What they didn't notice, the police said yesterday, was that sometimes as the radios got louder, the fares got higher.
The police arrested Mohammad I. Ahmed, a cab driver, yesterday and said they believe that in the last six months, he has rigged the meters in at least 500 yellow cabs, including his own, to overcharge passengers. 
 Deputy Inspector Vincent Kennedy said Mr. Ahmed charged fellow cabbies $75 to $100 to install a device called a zapper, consisting of a pin and two wires. One wire was attached to a wheel and another to a CB radio -- separate from the dispatcher radio -- and the meter reading increased along with the radio volume.
"The price went right up," said Inspector Kennedy, who is in charge of the taxi enforcement unit, which was formed in April when the police took over enforcement of taxi rules from the Taxi and Limousine Commission. "There are a lot of people who are getting ripped off."
So far, Mr. Ahmed has been charged with altering three taximeters, but the police made it clear that they think he is responsible for far more cases of meter tampering and that he was clever enough to swindle riders familiar with New York as well as unwary tourists.
Mr. Ahmed, the police said, would approach cabbies waiting for fares in the early morning in front of the New York Hilton on West 51st Street and Avenue of the Americas and offer his services. He could install a "zapper" in less than 20 minutes and worked on about 10 cabs in a typical day, the police said. The rigged meters charged passengers up to twice the legal fare of 25 cents per one-fifth of a mile, the police said.
Inspector Kennedy said that Mr. Ahmed, 39, of 710 Beverly Road in Flatbush, Brooklyn, was arrested at 5:45 A.M. yesterday after he was videotaped tampering with two meters. He was charged with possession of forged instruments and was given a summons.
"We've taken a major meter tamperer off the streets," Leonard Kaplan, First Deputy Commissioner of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said.
Although city officials suspected that Mr. Ahmed was fixing the meters, they said they could not move to arrest him without the help of one of his colleagues, who could provide them with details. Then, 10 days ago, a driver approached the police and helped them set up a sting to nab Mr. Ahmed, Mr. Kaplan said. Mr. Ahmed looked stunned and did not utter a word when officers clamped handcuffs on his wrists.
Police and taxi officials could not estimate how much Mr. Ahmed's scheme had cost riders altogether.
In recent years, the economics of driving a cab has suffered along with the decline in the region's economy, making it more difficult for drivers to earn a living. Last year, the Taxi and Limousine Commission rejected the industry's call for what would have been the first fare increase since January 1990, arguing that drivers would not benefit since taxi owners share most of the profits.
"I think it's just a case of water seeking its own level," Michael Higgins, publisher of Taxi Talk newspaper, said. "Unfortunately, some guys are not making that and some guys are taking the low road into putting more money into their pockets."
For years, taxi officials have grappled with ways to make meters tamper proof or resistant. The latest measure was to install a plastic cover on the meter.
So far this year, the taxi commission has received 1,026 complaints of rigged meters, Eugene Rodriguez, an agency spokesman, said, and officials believe that many of the complaints in recent months involved cabs that Mr. Ahmed had worked on. There were 1,093 complaints lodged all of last year.
Customers who have been the victims of overcharging by a cabbie welcomed the news of an arrest.
In March, Isabel Delgado, a dental assistant, was heading home to Elmhurst, Queens, after a flight from Kennedy International airport. About four blocks from her home, the fare, which normally cost her $16, was already at $20. Ms. Delgado, who only had $20 with her, said she had to leave the cab and walk the rest of the way home, her luggage in tow.
She said the driver began to curse her in Punjabi, but Ms. Delgado understood everything he said because her husband, a cab driver, is from India.
"I was so upset," Ms. Delgado, who took the driver to court, said. Last month a judge ordered the driver to pay a $100 fine.
"I wanted to make a difference," she said. "Next time, he's going to think twice before he does something like that."
Many taxi drivers declined to discuss Mr. Ahmed's arrest yesterday, but a few conceded that meter tampering is widespread. They also said, however, that the Police Department's takeover of the taxi and limousine enforcement had spurred some drivers to disconnect their devices.
"Whoever had a fast meter fixed it properly," Balvinder Singh, sitting behind the wheel of his cab in Chinatown, said. "People are scared of the police."
Officials said that Mr. Ahmed also offered his customers a way to avoid detection before the required inspections three times a year. For an additional fee of $25 to $40, they said, he would temporarily disconnect the device to thwart taxi inspectors.
While Mr. Ahmed's specialty was the zapper connected to a radio, officials said they had in the past seen similar devices hooked up to horns or even the window crank of a cab.
Mr. Ahmed could not be reached for comment last night. A man who answered the telephone at Mr. Ahmed's residence in the evening refused to discuss the case, saying he did not know the details of the arrest.
Earlier, sitting in Mr. Ahmed's living room, his oldest daughter, Sonia Ahmed, 17, told a reporter that her father was a talented mechanic who knew how to fix everything.
Mr. Ahmed emigrated from Pakistan in 1981 and first got work in gas stations. But after seven years and one too many robberies, he began driving a cab, his daughter said.
About a year ago, Mr. Ahmed brought his own $175,000 medallion, Mr. Kaplan of the Taxi and Limousine Commission said.

HEADLINE: Orange County Financial Plan Is Devised

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., July 18

 BODY:
Orange County's financial advisers today recommended a new recovery plan designed to lift this county from bankruptcy without new taxes, but with the help of the California Legislature.
The plan calls for the county to cover some $2 billion in bankruptcy-related debts by diverting taxes -- primarily property and sales taxes -- already paid by residents. If approved by the county's Board of Supervisors, the plan would be submitted to the Legislature in mid-August. Under California law, such tax diversions require legislative action. 
 With the defeat last month of a half-cent increase in the county sales tax, Orange County has been groping for ways to repay debts incurred after a failed investment scheme last year forced this wealthy county to file for bankrtupcy. The sales tax measure took such a drubbing, and the county is so strong an anti-tax stronghold, that financial experts and local politicians have since recognized that any new recovery plan would have to be based more on tax-shifting than tax-raising.
Until now, the county's resistance to proposed solutions to its financial crisis had left its five-member Board of Supervisors facing options that seemed either unrealistic or politically unpalatable. After the board tried last week to rein in William J. Popejoy, the independent-minded banker who had served for five months as Orange County's unpaid chief executive, Mr. Popejoy resigned, calling the government "dysfunctional." On Friday the board chose Jan M. Mittermeier, director of the county's main airport, as his interim replacement.
Mr. Popejoy had reduced the county's debt by $300 million and put off $800 million in debt for another year, after the loss last December of $1.7 billion in high-risk investments.
But everything he did to achieve those results seemed to bring pain to a county that still seems reluctant to face the dimensions of its problems. He cut the operating budget by 41 percent, threatening 15,000 county government jobs, and led the failed campaign for the tax increase to 8.25 cents per dollar.
Political analysts said Mr. Popejoy might have been unable to make these cuts, or even suggest the tax increase, had the supervisors been more closely involved.
Only one of the five supervisors joined Mr. Popejoy in vigorously campaigning for the tax increase. And on June 27, 60 percent of those voting rejected it.
Ms. Mittermeier, who is 55, has been a county employee for 21 years. She rose from chief of its internal audit department to director of John Wayne Airport, and is accustomed to working under the board's close direction. She will be one of the candidates the board will consider as it seeks a permanent successor to Mr. Popejoy in the next month or two.
"We don't need any more drama," Supervisor William Steiner said when Ms. Mittermeier's appointment was announced.
As outlined today the new plan, drafted by Salomon Brothers, seems to avoid dramatic cuts or tax increases, proposing instead to shift a portion of the sales tax used to cover local transportation needs to debt repayment. It would also take property taxes that are given to special municipal districts -- water, flood and sanitary districts -- and divert them to the county's creditors.
The plan also calls for restructuring some of the county's long-term leases, a form of debt, to reduce its annual borrowing costs. Salomon Brothers estimates that this three-pronged approach would raise more than $1 billion, with the rest of the county's debts covered by budget cuts, asset sales and some recently issued short-term notes.
Bruce Bennett, the county's bankruptcy lawyer, said the proposal is based on the notion that the county must repay all its creditors in full if it is to calm noteholders and other creditors, who fear that they might be forced to accept partial payment on their claims.
Such concerns, particularly on the part of municipal bond investors, have made it difficult, if not impossible, for the county to borrow in the credit markets. The proposal is intended to signal the municipal markets that the county will honor its debts -- even if it must turn to Sacramento to do so.
With Gov. Pete Wilson, who has long opposed tax increases, running for President, there is little political will in Sacramento to aid Orange County. But the new plan is designed to provide a solution generated by the county that requires neither state funds nor additional county funds, but that could lift a cloud of uncertainty that has settled over all California municipal borrowers since the Orange County bankruptcy filing.
"If we achieve this financial package our debts will be able to be repaid in fully next year," Mr. Bennett said. "If we don't, we won't have enough money and it will be a long time before we emerge from bankruptcy."
Some lawmakers in Sacramento have expressed concern about setting a tax-shifting precedent, particularly if what is being shifted to a county government is property taxes that were to go to cities. But Chris Vareles, a Salomon banker, said that the plan tries to address that concern by shifting taxes only from special municipal districts and not from the cities themselves. Better still, Mr. Vareles said, since the plan obviates the need for tax increases, which under California law must be approved by the voters, it is "a more creative way of accessing money without having to go to a vote."
At today's meeting, members of the county's board expressed relief that no new taxes would be needed to resolve the bankruptcy.
One supervisor asked whether the plan could be adopted only in part, leaving out the proposed tax diversion but retaining the long-term debt restructuring. William J. Popejoy, the county's outgoing chief executive, expressed serious doubt: "Maybe," he said. "But only if you took this package and sold it to a foreign buyer who had never read a newspaper about Orange County."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Customer Incentives Take a Big Toll on Chrysler Profits

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 18

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation said today that net income tumbled 85.9 percent in the second quarter, as higher customer incentives slashed the profit from each vehicle.
Net fell to $135 million, or 35 cents a share -- below Wall Street's expectations -- from $956 million, or $2.61 a share, a year earlier. The results in the latest quarter included a previously announced charge of $143 million, or 36 cents a share, related to the ending of a shift at an assembly plant in Newark, Del.. 
 Even on an operating basis, Chrysler's earnings were below expectations. Chrysler's profit from operations of 71 cents a share fell below Wall Street's forecast of 93 cents, based on the mean estimate of 13 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Revenue fell 4.6 percent, to $12.5 billion from $13.1 billion.
Even as per-vehicle profit plunged to one-quarter of what it was a year ago, analysts said the worst might be over for the nation's third-largest auto maker. Chrysler has depleted inventory and absorbed the cost of introducing its restyled line of minivans, allowing it to raise prices later this year, said Nick Lobacarro, an analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company.
"I don't think the third quarter is going to be anything to write home about either, but they are setting themselves up to have a gangbuster fourth quarter," he said.
Robert Eaton, Chrysler chairman, said the results were disappointing but expected because of higher incentive and production costs.
Shares of Chrysler fell 37.5 cents, to $49.50, on the New York Stock Exchange today.
Not even sales in June, the biggest month in company history, could bolster Chrysler's earnings. The company increased incentives such as cash rebates and less expensive financing by more than any other American car maker.
Incentive costs rose to $1,035 a vehicle from $610 a year earlier. The incentives helped increase Chrysler's sales 12 percent in June from a year ago, to 236,404 vehicles.
But Chrysler earned just $303 on every sale. A year ago, Chrysler led Detroit's auto makers with a per-sale profit of $1,298.
The company's share of the North American market declined to 15.2 percent from 15.4 percent in the second quarter. In 1995's first six months, market share fell to 15.1 percent from 15.6 percent.
The auto makers are counting on a stronger economy to lift profits during the rest of the year and into 1996. The Federal Reserve's decision earlier this month to ease credit could spur more consumer spending, allowing Chrysler to cut incentives, Mr. Eaton said.
Chrysler said sales of its revamped mini-vans were strong. It said it expected its 1996 Dakota pickup trucks and Jeep Wranglers to increase earnings later this year.
Chrysler's cash balance fell to $6.9 billion in the second quarter from $7.4 billion because of capital spending on production startups. The company expects to return the balance to more than $7 billion by the fourth quarter.
The cash was the focus of efforts by the investor Kirk Kerkorian's Tracinda Corporation to buy Chrysler earlier this year. Upset that Chrysler was not doing more to increase the value of its stock, Mr. Kerkorian offered to buy the company for $55 a share, using $5.5 billion of the cash reserve to help finance the transaction.
The offer was rescinded in May after it failed to win financial backing.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Legislators Against the Arts

 BODY:
It is an astonishing day for New York when it has a better friend in Alan Simpson than in its own Congressional representatives. The Wyoming Senator is one of three Republicans who have come up with a sensible alternative to the House's slash-and-burn approach to arts funding. Yesterday the entire Republican side of the New York delegation voted to write the death warrant for the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities, approving a bill that would end all funding within two years.
It is surprising to see upstate moderates like Amo Houghton and Sherwood Boehlert joining the anti-arts swing, but it is at least understandable. Their constituencies are not nearly as dependent on the arts as is the New York metropolitan area. But for Susan Molinari, Michael Forbes, Peter King, Daniel Frisa and Rick Lazio, it is mind-boggling. These Representatives are selling their constituents down the river. 
 Do they think that the 100,000-plus jobs generated by the arts and other cultural institutions in the New York metropolitan area are held only by Manhattanites? Do they believe there are no residents of Staten Island or Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Putnam counties who are performers, painters or sculptors? These die-hard budget-cutters are not only punishing the artists. They are also hurting the thousands of people who work as production assistants, secretaries, stagehands and accountants for the theaters, television studios and galleries in the area, not to mention restaurants and other businesses that depend on the huge tourist trade attracted by New York's cultural riches.
The arts in New York will not, of course, die without Federal support. For many institutions, N.E.A. money represents only a small percentage of their budgets. But Federal support also gives them a special stamp of legitimacy that, in turn, gives private donors the confidence to support them.
To some members of Congress, jobs in the art world may seem much less vital than, say, jobs in the defense industry. But they are every bit as important to the New York economy as those of submarine workers at Electric Boat are to southeastern Connecticut. Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, would rather jump off the Groton pier than cast a vote threatening his constituents' jobs. The New Yorkers cannot even take shelter behind claims that they are fixing the budget. These are small amounts, and there are far more wasteful expenditures they are ignoring.
Federal funding for the arts is also highly important in rural areas, where artists have less access to rich veins of private philanthropy. But for New Yorkers, the arts are Electric Boat, Long Beach, Newport News. Representatives Forbes, Lazio, King, Frisa and Molinari should not be allowed to forget this come election time.
Their more enlightened colleagues in the Senate, Nancy Kassebaum, Alan Simpson and Jim Jeffords, are sponsoring a much less bloodthirsty alternative to the House bill that would cut the N.E.A. by only 5 percent a year over five years, and contains no eventual cutoff. That is still not ideal. But in these times it may be the best deal the arts can get. May the Senators restore sanity to the arts budget when their turn comes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
MERRILL LYNCH & CO. (MER,N)

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, bolstered by rallies in the stock and bond markets, said yesterday that earnings rose 12 percent in the second quarter.
Profit at Merrill, the nation's biggest securities firm, rose as interest rates fell to 16-month lows, stocks reached record highs, underwriting of corporate stocks and bonds advanced, and mergers surged. Earnings were $282.7 million, or $1.40 a share, up from $251.8 million, or $1.18 a share, in the 1994 quarter. 
 The per-share profit of $1.40 was well above the forecast of $1.19 from analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Revenue, net of interest, rose 6.3 percent, to $2.55 billion, from $2.4 billion a year ago.
Reflecting an increase in stock trading, revenue from commissions rose 11 percent in the quarter, to $765 million.
Trading revenue increased 10 percent, to $615 million, as rising profits from convertible securities, interest-rate and currency swaps, junk bonds and over-the-counter stocks offset lower revenue in municipal bonds and mortgage-backed securities.
Investment banking revenue, bolstered by fees for advising in mergers, rose 4 percent, to $335 million. Underwriting revenue was flat.
Fees from asset management rose 8 percent, to $464 million, as assets under management increased 12 percent, to $180 billion.
The firm said expenses increased 6 percent in the quarter because of increased compensation and legal fees resulting from its litigation with Orange County, Calif., over investment losses suffered by the county. Professional fees, which include lawyers' fees, rose 21 percent, to $105.5 million. (Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: We Paid a Terrible Price for Atom Bomb

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Richard Rhodes is no doubt correct in stating that the emergence of nuclear weapons 50 years ago "changed the conditions" for global war ("Echoes of the Big Bang," Op-Ed, July 15). But we can't agree with his view of the bomb's enormous value as a peacemaker, past and future. And Rhodes also ignores the terrible price we paid for embracing the bomb following the Trinity test. 
 Trinity, in fact, was a tragic event. It marked the birth of America's lasting dependency on ever more destructive nuclear weapons. Trinity also enhanced the idea of the bomb as a usable military weapon; our leaders were drawn to its power, leading directly to the destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
Mr. Rhodes attributes the absence of world war after 1945 to the credibility of United States and Soviet deterrents. On numerous occasions, however, one mad, or misperceived, act could have instigated a nuclear holocaust. For the same reason, he is too sanguine in suggesting that we have "little to fear" from an Iraqi, Iranian or North Korean bomb. We can hardly put permanent faith in the mixture of nuclear restraint and good luck that has prevailed so far.
Even if the bomb played a part in avoiding another world war, it has not prevented hundreds of regional wars, including America's own bloody involvement in Korea and Vietnam.
And Mr. Rhodes fails to emphasize the crucial fact that miscalculation might lead not just to another world war, but also to the end of the world as we know it.
Mr. Rhodes also does not explore the many ways that the bomb has severely damaged America and its people. The economic price of the arms race -- recently placed at $3.9 trillion -- and its environmental impact are well known, but other costs are just as significant.
The secrecy of the Manhattan Project, for example, did not end with Nagasaki.
It came to surround the entire nuclear realm with horrible results for millions of Americans unwittingly exposed to forms of radiation or subjected to cruel medical experiments.
That climate of secrecy would eventually pervade much of our Government -- and society as a whole.
Trinity, far from liberating us from fear, marked the beginning of our nuclear entrapment, and of enduring danger to a human future.
 
ROBERT JAY LIFTON
GREG MITCHELL
New York, July 16, 1995

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Big Monthly U.S. Trade Deficit Broadly Drives Down the Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most other leading currencies yesterday, weighed down by a report that the the United States had recorded its largest monthly trade deficit in May and by a selloff in American stocks and bonds.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the trade deficit in goods and services widened to $11.4 billion in May, slightly above that in April, but also more than $1 billion ahead of the figure expected by many economists. A big trade deficit weakens the dollar because the currency must be sold to pay for the excess of imports. 
 "The dollar sold off a little after the trade deficit was bigger than expected," said Earl Johnson, currency adviser at the Bank of Montreal-Harris Bank in Chicago.
It was further weakened by declines in American stocks and bonds. When foreign investors sell American assets, they convert the dollar proceeds into their own currencies. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 50.01 points, to 4,686.28, and the price of the 30-year Treasury bond also fell, driving up its yield to 6.76 percent.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.3899 German marks, down from 1.3969 marks on Monday. The dollar settled at 88.40 Japanese yen, down from 89.04 yen.
Even with the dollar's decline yesterday, traders did not expect it to fall much further because many of them think that the American and Japanese central banks are committed to weakening the yen. On July 7, the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve intervened in the markets on a huge scale, buying hundreds of millions of dollars for yen. Since then, the Japanese bank has bought an estimated $5 billion to $10 billion more in dollars, said David Gilmore of Foreign Exchange Analytics.
As a result, said Graham Broyd, manager of currency sales at National Westminster Bank in New York, "a lot of people are expecting a higher dollar against the yen."
While the American trade deficit weighs on the dollar, the assumption of additional dollar purchases supports it, Mr. Johnson said.
In other currency trading yesterday, the dollar was last quoted in New York at 1.1586 Swiss francs, down from 1.1692 francs, and at 4.8257 French francs, down from 4.8633. The British pound rose to $1.5962 from $1.5942. The dollar slipped to 1,611.5 Italian lire from 1,612.5. The Canadian dollar fell to 73.48 American cents, from 73.76 cents on Monday.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS: One Year to Atlanta 1996;
A Lot of Optimism But Hurdles to Leap

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Exactly one year from the opening of the centennial Summer Olympic Games, the temperature is rising into the high 90's, dormitories at the athletes' village are sinking from unexpected settling and the financial forecast remains as hazy as a humid July morning.
If Billy Payne, the chief organizer, is sweating, however, it doesn't show. He has promised the biggest and best Olympics ever, and he expects to deliver. A year out, the track is being installed at Olympic Stadium, ticket sales have exceeded expectations, 5,000 athletes have begun arriving for pre-Olympic competitions and the economic impact of the Games has been projected at $5.1 billion. 
 Although organizers insist the Games are "on time and on budget," the Atlanta committee's original surplus, forecast at $156 million, shrank to $60 million last year with a final projection due in October. Whether the Games will have their familiarly lavish look or a bargain basement feel will depend on whether organizers meet their $1.58 billion budget as they seek to sign more second-tier corporate sponsors and shore up disappointing sales of Olympic coins.
For Atlanta, there is much more at stake than the threat of a blown budget. A year and 17 days from today, will the Games, with 10,700 athletes from 197 countries and two million visitors expected, be remembered for wilting heat, sclerotic traffic and an endless parade of corporate logos? Or will they be remembered for embracing Southern hospitality, racial harmony and stirring athletic achievement?
Not everything has gone like clockwork, and some considerable hurdles remain. A planned $50 million, 21-acre Centennial Park remains a glorified dirt-bike course, and the intended sale of two million personalized bricks that will line the park's walkways has faltered at 160,000. The Olympic drug lab has yet to gain accreditation. The official mascot, Izzy, resembles a soap bubble with a thyroid condition. Last week, the temperature hit 98 degrees, considerably higher than the 75 degrees that organizers contend is the average for July.
"It's one of those situations where you exceed even your own very high expectations, and then you wait to see how folks measure it -- and you kind of hold your breath a little," Payne said in an interview last week.
The Atlanta Games will be Southern in character -- "Our friendliness will steal the show," Payne said -- and uniquely American in their financing. As the curtain goes up and Atlanta steps upon the international stage, these Games will be played against a backdrop of unprecedented corporate involvement.
The Games will be held in the backyards of Coca-Cola, CNN and Delta Airlines, and in a city deemed one of the world's four best in which to do business in 1994 by Fortune magazine. At a cost of $1.58 billion, these Games are being privately financed by the Atlanta organizing committee, meaning that the money comes from broadcast rights, corporate sponsorships, ticket sales and merchandising.
NBC wrote the largest corporate check, paying $456 million for American television rights. Twenty sponsors paid up to $40 million apiece to become Olympic "partners." If Atlanta lacks the inspiring architecture, culture, exotic presence and teeming boulevards of Barcelona, if the downtown area is where they paved paradise and put up a parking lot, at least these Games will have something that no previous Olympics could claim -- an official game show, an official anti-theft device and an official country and western album.
Since the wide world of commerce will be as prominently featured as the wide world of sports, the Games may seem more like an international Super Bowl. Corporate sponsors, along with Olympic v.i.p.'s and members of the news media will have many of the best seats and stay in the most convenient hotels, while thousands of spectators will have to commute from places like Birmingham, Ala., and Chattanooga, Tenn.
The corporate footprint will be on everything from drug testing to security to building the Olympic stadium to providing ambience to deciding the start time of the men's marathon. A 92-foot Swatch watch will adorn a local building, McDonald's will place six restaurants in the athletes' village, an eight-acre Coca-Cola Olympic City will feature interactive games, and Daimler-Benz, the German automaker, has pledged to restore the crumbled house where Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," was born.
Some $500 million worth of building projects, funded in large part with corporate money, will be available for local use after the Games. Centennial Park will enliven a blighted area of downtown. The 85,000-seat Olympic Stadium -- the first to have luxury suites -- will be downsized into the home of baseball's Atlanta Braves, while the track will be reinstalled at Clark Atlanta University. A new aquatic center and eight new dormitories will go to Georgia Tech, a basketball arena to Morehouse College and a football stadium to Morris Brown University.
 
Dissenting Notes From Sponsor Tune
 Not everyone, though, is smitten with the idea of strictly privately financed Games, which lack the safety net of a public bailout. The concept was developed at the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, after the 1976 Montreal Games went into public debt of $1 billion. Unlike Los Angeles, which used existing facilities and accumulated a surplus of $220 million, Atlanta has had to construct 10 new competition venues and refurbish several others.
Dick Pound, a Montreal attorney who is the International Olympic Committee's liaison to the Atlanta Games, suggested last year that the Games may no longer be awarded to a city without a Government committed to rescue any financial shortfall. Last week, Pound said he still believed that no organizing committee should pay for the construction of stadiums and infrastructure.
"Revenues should pay for the party, not the banquet hall," Pound said.
Organizers also have been criticized as elitist for giving special ticket considerations to politicians. Some have said that the reliance on corporations to provide atmosphere is confirmation that Atlanta's downtown is sterile and in danger of becoming indistinguishable from other cookie-cutter Sun Belt cities. Others believe it is excessive to build a $170 million Olympic Stadium for 17 days' use, then carve it in half for the Braves while bulldozing their current home, Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.
Anita Beaty, co-chairwoman of the Olympic Conscience Coalition, said that despite a $75 million project to build 1,000 new housing units near Olympic venues and a $42 million Federal grant to renovate the Techwood-Clark Howell housing project near the Olympic village, Olympic construction would displace 5,000 housing units for the poor. She also said that she feared that homeless people would be incarcerated during the Games to prevent their appearance on the streets.
"The Olympics have become a commercial circus, using athletes and athletic events to make incredible profits at a cost of great human suffering," said Beaty, who is also president of the National Coalition of the Homeless.
 
Traffic and the Heat Could Mean Trouble
The most critical unresolved issue for organizers is traffic. The plan is essentially to turn Atlanta's downtown into a pedestrian mall, with cars intercepted at park-and-ride lots and spectators ferried to events on the local rail system and in 2,000 buses. The city is notorious for gridlock, and the recent Super Bowl was a traffic nightmare.
If Atlanta the city won't be the star of these Olympics, perhaps the Games themselves will. Eleven million tickets -- more than the Los Angeles and Barcelona Games combined -- went on sale in May. Athletes, staying for the first time in fully air-conditioned dorms, will participate before the largest Olympic crowds ever; the Georgia Dome, for example, will hold 30,000 spectators for basketball and gymnastics.
Still, Atlanta's claim of being the best Olympics ever will be diminished if searing heat debilitates any runners in the men's marathon, which will start at 6:30 P.M. next Aug. 4, a time when the average temperature is 80 degrees with 65 percent humidity. Several runners have said the heat will turn the race into a "death march."
Also, Michael Johnson of Dallas, the world's top-ranked sprinter at 200 and 400 meters and potentially the most dominant American athlete at the Atlanta Olympics, said he will not run both events at the Olympics as long as their preliminary rounds overlap.
"Whichever one I decide not to run is going to be a joke," Johnson said last month at the national track and field championships.
 
Vision of Showcase For Racial Harmony
 On display at these Games will be Atlanta's emotional history of the Civil War and the civil rights movement. Remnants of the Confederacy are still visible in the Georgia state flag; golf was hurt from consideration as an Olympic sport because of exclusionist policies at the Masters course in Augusta; volleyball was moved out of Cobb County after the county passed an anti-gay resolution, and Somali athletes looking for a training site were rebuffed by Barrow County over the treatment of American soldiers in that East African nation.
But Atlanta also served as the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s civil rights pulpit. It is home to a large black middle class and six historically black universities. Minority-group members make up more than one-third of the organizing committee's employees and minority-owned businesses have been the recipients of one-third of the committee's contracts.
"I would maintain that in terms of black and white working together in friendship and cooperation and achieving significant success, we're the best example of that in the world," Payne said.
Andrew Young, the former Mayor and Ambassador to the United Nations, said the American South may free itself of an image of racial intolerance and backwardness during the Olympics, just as South Africa's apartheid-fermented reputation "got out of jail" last month when it was host to rugby's world championship.
"These will be the affirmative action Olympics," Young said. "Atlanta can become the center for the export of Southern idealism."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gasoline Prices Fall as Traders See Lower Stocks as Adequate

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices fell yesterday as traders bet that American refiners would be able to meet demand this summer while running on leaner inventories.
On other commodity markets, copper prices fell while corn rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index gained 0.11 point, to 234.11. 
 Gasoline stockpiles fell to a seven-month low of 207.6 million barrels two weeks ago and have been running 3 to 5 percent below levels of a year ago all year, according to American Petroleum Institute data.
After the market closed yesterday, the institute said gasoline stockpiles rose by 560,000 barrels last week, or less than 1 percent, surprising analysts who had expected a decline.
While such low inventories would normally keep prices high, traders said the oil industry was adjusting to a new, lower level of inventory that keeps costs down.
"Everyone is living hand to mouth," said Tom Knight, manager of East Coast refined products trading at the Fina Oil and Chemical Company in River Edge, N.J.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, unleaded gasoline for August delivery fell 0.4 cent, to 53.58 cents a gallon, the lowest price since March 14. August crude oil gained 15 cents, to $17.35 a barrel.
Copper prices gave up early gains to settle lower amid concern the pace of inventory declines is slowing.
Copper stockpiles held in London Metal Exchange warehouses fell by just 350 metric tons since Friday, to 141,100 tons. While that is the lowest inventory level since September, 1990, the drop was less sharp than the two previous weekly declines.
As a result, many analysts are beginning to think a weakened United States economy has begun to slow demand for copper from industrial users like automobile makers.
Corn prices rose for the third consecutive day, reaching a 17-month high, as traders sought indications of how much rain would fall in the Midwest this week.

HEADLINE: Fujitsu Gets A Tax Break

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., July 18

 BODY:
The Multnomah County Commission said here today that it had approved a $23 million tax reduction for a $1 billion computer chip expansion project by Fujitsu Microelectronics Inc., a unit of Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan. 
 Under the agreement, the company's tax assessment on the property near here will be capped at $100 million for 15 years. In return, Fujitsu signed an agreement to provide education, housing, transportation subsidies and training for the county's unemployed. The expansion will add 445 jobs to Fujitsu's plant.

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
Two Calypso Monarchs in the Park

BYLINE: By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Super Blue summed up the mission of Trinidadian calypso at Central Park Summerstage on Sunday afternoon. "We are informing, educating and entertaining at the same time," he announced. Calypso watchers have long worried that the party chants of modern soca (or soul-calypso) are driving out calypso's long tradition of sophisticated wordplay and social commentary. Sunday's concert brought something from both sides: Super Blue's jubilant, participatory soca hits and Black Stalin's buoyant message calypsos.
Super Blue, born Austin Lyons, has won Trinidad's Road March competition seven times since 1980 and has held the Soca Monarch title since it was introduced in 1993. The winning road march is the song played most often by the mobile sound systems in the carnival parade; it's the people's choice for party music. 
 Super Blue's voice has a cheerful growl that can sound like classic soul music or Jamaican dancehall toasting. He's a master of the propulsive groove, the sing-along chorus and the exhortation to join the party. He alludes, now and then, to Trinidadian culture and history, but his songs are made to get people moving.
After doodling with North American pop songs, Super Blue settled into his soca hits and turned the audience into a dancing, shouting mass. Many had brought something to wave during songs like "Flag Party" and "Signal for Lara," a tribute to the Trinidadian cricket player Brian Lara, with its chorus, "Raise your bat and party!" For a finale, Super Blue strutted into the audience, dancing from the stage to the bleachers.
The gray-bearded Black Stalin (born Leroy Calliste), who was named Calypso Monarch in 1979, 1985, 1987, 1991 and 1995, merges calypso traditionalism with touches of Rastafarianism and hopes for pan-Caribbean unity. With more conversational, behind-the-beat vocals and more lilting, less aggressive music than Super Blue used, he was openly didactic; "We Can Make It," from 1988, exhorted Trinidadians to stand firm during an economic crisis; "Burn Dem," from 1987, told St. Peter what to do with certain world leaders.
There were lighter songs, too, including "Tribute to Sundar Popo," this year's calypso winner, in which Black Stalin asked a songwriter to deliver a song he had requested long ago. Black Stalin sang it during his short set, as an encore, and again with Super Blue and a cameo guest calypsonian, Gabby.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Superblue, the soul-calypso singer, at Central Park Summerstage. (Jack Vartoogian)

HEADLINE: High-Speed Ferry Service To Begin Across the Sound

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: SOUTHOLD, L.I., July 18

 BODY:
The Foxwoods Casino on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation near New London, Conn., thinks it has a sure bet: promoting the launching of the first high-speed ferry service across Long Island Sound. The Long Island Rail Road also wants a piece of the action.
The new service, operated by Cross Sound Ferry Services Inc., is scheduled to begin on Wednesday morning, when a twin-hulled catamaran, Sea Ski 1, designed to carry 350 passengers, will make its maiden run to Orient Point, L.I., from New London. 
 No reservations are required for the ferry, and boarding will be first come, first served. The cost of a same-day round trip is $20. Passengers on the first three daily ferries from Orient Point will be able to take advantage of free coach service to the casino and a $25 food and gambling bonus provided by Foxwoods. The bonus includes $10 in food credits and $15 in gaming vouchers.
While the 12 daily crossings may please gamblers, as well as others planning to catch an Amtrak train in New London for Boston, officials on Long Island, including Thomas Wickham, the Supervisor of the Town of Southold, are not happy.
"Southold has become a funnel for all those on Long Island who seem to have an insatiable appetite for gambling," Mr. Wickham said. "They all take the one and only winding two-lane road to Orient Point and leave their cars parked all over the place."
"We don't want to close the operation down," he said. "We just want a site plan for parking so we can get out of our driveways and the fire trucks can get out of the firehouse."
Attorneys for the town of Southold went to court today seeking to block the new service. They argued that Cross Sound Ferry had failed to discuss the traffic problem with town officials and file a plan to improve the terminal's parking lot to accommodate the expected increase in traffic.
Justice Patrick Henry of State Supreme Court in Central Islip ruled that Southold and the ferry operator should work together to measure the impact of traffic and resolve their parking dispute.
Using the combined L.I.R.R. and express ferry service, it should take less time for Long Islanders to get to the Connecticut casino than it now does to get to Atlantic City, said Stanley Mickus, a spokesman for Cross Sound Ferry, whose headquarters are in New London.
Cruising at 30 knots, Sea Jet I is the fastest ocean-going passenger vessel ever built in the United States, he said, and should cut travel time for the 16-mile trip across the Sound to 30 minutes. The larger, more conventional ferries, operated on the same route by Cross Sound Ferry, take an hour and a half to transport cars and trucks as well as passengers.
Even the Long Island Rail Road has joined in promoting the new high-speed service. The commuter line will be offering a $25 package for a round trip from Penn Station to Foxwoods.
The gamblers special will leave Penn Station at 7:39 A.M. five mornings a week and return at 12:26 A.M. The package includes a 10-minute bus ride between the L.I.R.R. station at Greenport, L.I., and the Orient Point ferry terminal, and a half-hour bus ride from the New London ferry terminal to Foxwoods, in Ledyard, 15 miles northeast of New London.
The train will also pick up passengers at stops in Mineola, Hicksville, Farmingdale and Ronkonkoma.
High-speed ferry service across the Sound has been a dream of the tourist and business community ever since plans to build a third bridge across across the Sound died in the 1970's.
Most recently, the Suffolk County Legislature supported a proposal for a new ferry terminal and high-speed service to Connecticut from Shoreham, L.I., the site of the Long Island Lighting Company's decommissioned nuclear power plant.
Opponents, including Shoreham residents, along with Lilco's hesitancy to sign a lease, buried the idea.
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, said he welcomed the new ferry service as a way to boost the Island's economy.
"But I think I'll stick to the slower ferry," he said. "It's been my experience with casino gambling that the longer the trip takes to get there, the better it is for me."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Orange County Plan Uses Taxes for Debts
Orange County's financial advisers recommended a plan to lift the California county from bankruptcy without new taxes.
The plan calls for the diversion of taxes already paid by county residents, primarily property and sales taxes, to cover some $2 billion in backruptcy-related debts. If approved by the county's Board of Supervisors, the plan would be submitted to the State Legislature next month. [Page A10.]
 
I.B.M. Surpasses Forecasts With Strong Rise in Earnings
I.B.M.'s second-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $1.72 billion, or $2.97 a share, surpassing the highest forecasts made by Wall Street analysts. Revenues rose 14.2 percent to $17.5 billion, as the computer maker showed improved results in virtually every part of its business. [D4.]
 
Chrysler's Income Drops 86%
Chrysler's earnings tumbled 86 percent in the second quarter, to $135 million, or 35 cents a share, below Wall Street's expectations as higher customer incentives slashed the profit from each vehicle. [D15.]
 
The I.R.S. Casts a Wider Net
The Internal Revenue Service is planning tough compliance audits starting this fall to find out how accurately groups of individual taxpayers fill out their forms. [A1.]
 
Intel's Profit Falls Short
Intel reported a 37.3 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, but its results still fell a few pennies short of Wall Street's expectations. [D4.]
 
Microsoft's On-Line Move
Taking a step closer to a showdown with the Justice Department, Microsoft said that not only did it plan to include access to its on-line service in the Windows 95 operating system next month, but that the service would be fully linked to the Internet. [D4.]
 
Report on Barings Collapse
In a report to Parliament, Britain's central bank attributed the collapse of Barings in part to errors by managers who failed to spot large-scale unauthorized trading by Nicholas Leeson, the head trader in Singapore. [D2.]
 
14.4% Gain at Philip Morris
Philip Morris said second-quarter earnings jumped 14.4 percent, to $1.41 billion, or $1.67 a share, powered by explosive growth in the company's overseas tobacco revenues. [D7.]
 
Perelman Lawsuit Settled
A settlement was reached in a lawsuit brought against Ronald O. Perelman's company by a former top executive, who contended he was wrongly dismissed. [D4.]
 
$2.2 Billion Italian TV Deal
Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian media magnate-turned-politician, has agreed to sell more than half his television business to banks and private investors, including Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia, for about $2.2 billion. The deal would allow him to maintain management control of his television interests -- more than 40 percent of the Italian airwaves. [D7.]
 
More Times Mirror Cutbacks
The Los Angeles Times plans to eliminate 450 jobs this year, as part of the aggressive cost-cutting by its parent, Times Mirror. [A15.]
 
New Ads From Volkswagen
New ads for Volkswagen start tomorrow and are the first from its new agency, Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot in Boston. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Newspaper to Cut 450 Positions

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Times announced today that it planned to cut 450 full-time positions by the end of this year, and employees in the editorial department said they were told that these cuts would include up to 160 out of 1,300 news-gathering positions.
Breaking with the newspaper's recent practice of using attrition and buyouts to cut its staff and save operating costs, the reductions announced today would include an undetermined number of outright layoffs, said Laura Morgan, director of communications for the newspaper. 
 In a memorandum to the staff, the publisher, Richard D. Schlossberg 3d said, "Although we will use attrition and other voluntary methods we will have involuntary terminations in some departments."
In the past five years, as the paper's staff was cut to 5,800 employees from 6,500, many reductions were made through buyouts. This time, Mr. Schlossberg said, there will be no companywide buyout offer, although the methods of reduction will vary by department. The publisher said retirement packages would be based on years of service and would be up to one year's salary and health benefits.
He said the cuts were necessary because of the continuing weakness of the Southern California economy and fast-rising newsprint costs.
Reporters said they were told that cutbacks in the news operation could affect all parts of the newspaper, in the home office, suburban bureaus, in Washington and abroad.
Speculation about cutbacks was accelerated with the closing this week of New York Newsday, which is also owned by the Times Mirror Company.
